fields.headline: Liverpool keep it level-headed
fields.standfirst:
Houllier's talk of a goal glut comes to nil-nil as the emphasis goes on defence
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: In a Catalan cauldron brimming with red and blue Liverpool drew Barcelona's sting last night to preserve their hopes of winning a first European trophy since 1984.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield  at the Nou Camp
fields.body:
In a Catalan cauldron brimming with red and blue Liverpool drew Barcelona's sting last night to preserve their hopes of winning a first European trophy since 1984.

Having earlier predicted their visit might spark a 5-5 goal glut, the Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier has clearly been mixing mind games with defensive drills. Instead, faced by a five-man midfield in front of an inspirational rearguard, Barcelona huffed, puffed and foundered in angry frustration.

"I'm not going to apologise for becoming only the third team to come here and stop Barcelona from scoring," said Houllier. "If I'd gone out and attacked and lost by three goals you would be calling me naive. What's the point in being naive? That would be a betrayal to our supporters.

"You have to look at the size of the pitch and the quality of the opposition and you see how English teams have fared here. We were looking for an away goal but we have done very well defensively. You have to praise the team. You don't achieve performances like this at the Nou Camp by luck and we were not allowed to attack more."

Only when home irritation translated into sloppiness late on - the substitute Robbie Fowler's looping header from Steven Gerrard's cross had Jose Manuel Reina scurrying nervously - did the visitors threaten to prise a priceless goal. Yet at the final whistle it was mission accomplished and the strains of You'll Never Walk Alone drifted across the emptying arena.

While Liverpool have been gorging themselves on three fronts recently, with the FA Cup and their pursuit of a top- three finish still whetting appetites, Barcelona - a city of sumptuous seafood - have been left with the scraps of a season of damp squids. Their humiliating elimination from the first phase of the Champions League prompted Louis van Gaal's ignominious departure. An inability to challenge Real Madrid at the top of La Liga has grated ever since.

From the dregs of Van Gaal's reign Lorenzo Serra Ferrer has at least whipped up this Uefa Cup pursuit. Nevertheless, with the mouth-watering array of attacking talent at his disposal, under-achievement hangs heavy in the air even if apathy has yet to creep on to the terraces. Last night's game, potentially the biggest of Barca's season, was played to a deafening din of drums and firecrackers from the stands.

For the victors a final in Dortmund awaited, probably against Alaves who were busy building up a 5-1 first-leg lead against Kaiserslautern.

Not that the patient short-passing routines of the early stages had pulses racing until Rivaldo emerged to skim a shot off Sami Hyypia for a corner before evading his marker to nod Luis Enrique into the area; but the Catalan sliced his shot horribly wide.

With Emile Heskey playing as a withdrawn left-sided midfielder, only Michael Owen's tireless running provided an outlet to disrupt Barca's monopoly on possession. Yet, with white shirts banked behind the ball, the procession of home attacks was repelled to hoots of derision.

Pep Guardiola's 24th-minute free-kick was nodded behind by Markus Babbel with Patrick Kluivert poised at the far post and Jamie Carragher dived to block Luis Enrique's second-half goal-bound shot after Sergi's cross had been inadvertently touched on by Hyypia.

Much to the chagrin of the home side, Rivaldo, still twisting and turning to create his own space, then flicked a volley wide of Sander Westerveld's near post. When the Brazilian's lay-off with four minutes to go was smashed goalwards by Xavi only for Westerveld to save smartly, the Catalans appeared as likely to find a finishing touch as Gaudi might on his Sagrada Familia.

After 17 years without a European trophy some of the old Scouse swagger is showing its head again and Liverpool's defensive defiance warmed their supporters' cockles.

"We can score three if we need to at home," added Houllier. "Perhaps the balance of the game was wrong and we should have had more of a sense of adventure and audacity, but we've scored 96 goals this season, the most in England, and they haven't included 95 own-goals. It will be different at Anfield."

Liverpool (4-5-1): Westerveld; Babbel, Hyypia, Henchoz, Carragher; Murphy (Smicer, 60min), Gerrard, Hamann, Berger (McAllister, 83), Heskey; Owen (Fowler, 73).

Barcelona (4-2-3-1): Reina; Gabri, Puyol, De Boer, Sergi; Guardiola, Cocu; Luis Enrique (Xavi, 72), Rivaldo, Overmars (Zenden, 72); Kluivert.

Referee : H Krug (Germany).

fields.headline: Couto tests positive
fields.trailText: Lazio's Portuguese international Fernando Couto has tested positive for a banned substance, widely reported it as the anabolic steroid nandrolone.
fields.body:
Lazio's Portuguese international Fernando Couto yesterday admitted he had tested positive for an undisclosed banned substance but said he was confident he would be cleared of wrongdoing.

The central defender failed a post-match drug test after the Rome club's 4-1 win at Fiorentina on January 28. A corroborative second sample is being tested and the results will be announced later this month. The nature of the banned substance has not been revealed but the Italian and Portuguese media have widely reported it as the anabolic steroid nandrolone.

"I'm confident that I'll be cleared," Couto said yesterday. "If I'm picked to play on Satur day I'll do so and I'll give 100%."

If the second test confirms the first, Couto faces a ban of at least a year. Two players from the Serie A side Perugia and one from second division Pescara were handed 16-month suspensions for similar offences earlier this season.

Lazio have issued a statement in which they denied club staff had administered any banned substances and said that the club insisted on regular dope and haemocrit-level tests for players. The latter indicate the presence of stamina-boosting drugs such as erythropoietin.

Couto has been capped 75 times for his country, a national record he shares with the goalkeeper Vitor Baia.

webTitle: Hoddle holds his breath on Campbell

fields.headline: Hoddle holds his breath on Campbell
fields.trailText: Tottenham could be boosted by the return to action of seven first-team players for Saturday's showdown at Old Trafford, but Sol Campbell remains a worry.
fields.body:
Tottenham's quest to reach the FA Cup final for the first time in a decade with victory against Arsenal on Sunday could be boosted by the return of seven first-team players who missed last Saturday's 2-0 defeat at Highbury.

Tim Sherwood, Stephen Carr and Oyvind Leonhardsen, all long-term absentees, have been training all week while Sergei Rebrov has recovered from a hamstring strain. Glenn Hoddle is also hopeful that Ledley King, Steven Clemence and Sol Campbell will be fit for Old Trafford.

"Obviously they're very short on match practice," said Hoddle yesterday, "so it's a question of whether they start, with a view to taking them off, or the other way round. But I think, whatever happens, there'll be a gamble on two or three of the players. It's a very difficult decision and it'll be a very late decision; I'll wait for some of these players even up to Saturday night."

For Campbell he may wait even later. "Sol is of vast importance," Hoddle said, "especially with the way the Arsenal team are, all pace and power. The presence that Sol gives us, and his quality of play, would be a major bonus for us. He's improving but whether the game's going to come too quickly for the ankle to recover, I don't know. He's going to be touch and go."

For Spurs, though, defeat is out of the question. "It would take the whole team playing well to beat them," said Carr, "but it makes you nervous even thinking about losing. Basically, our season's over if we don't win, it's as simple as that."

The Arsenal manager, Arsène Wenger, has given up hope of Dennis Bergkamp being fit. The Dutchman missed Saturday's win after damaging an achilles tendon and was not fit for Wednesday night's Champions League victory over Valencia.

Wenger said: "The scans on his foot do not look too bad but he still has pain and he won't be playing on Sunday. I fear he could also be short for our league game at Manchester City on Wednesday."

Arsenal still have three strikers to choose from but, with Nwankwo Kanu again out of form against Valencia, it looks likely that they will start with the French international pairing of Thierry Henry and Sylvain Wiltord. "If there are any changes, they will only be a few touches," Wenger said.

The Cameroon midfielder Lauren, left out last night, could be recalled with the match-winner Ray Parlour moving to the right flank, but Ashley Cole is likely to keep the left-back spot ahead of the Brazilian Silvinho.

Uefa has withdrawn a yellow card shown to Valencia's Roberto Ayala during Wednesday's Champions League defeat by Arsenal. The booking has been transferred to his team-mate Jocelyn Angloma, and Ayala will now be able to play in the second leg.

Two former directors of Nottingham Forest Football Club face a legal bill in excess of £2m after losing their high court battle to outlaw a £6m cash injection deal for the First Division side.

Irving Scholar, the former Tottenham chairman, and Julian Markham had claimed that the deal, which issued £6m of shares to the international equity fund manager Nigel Doughty, devalued their 25% shareholding in the club and was an "improper" device to give Doughty control of the whole business.

fields.headline: Stereo MC's still connect
fields.standfirst:
Stereo MC's
Manchester University
*****
fields.trailText:
Stereo MC's
Manchester University
*****
fields.body:
When a band has been away for nine years they cannot expect to waltz back into the premier league as though nothing has happened. Fortunately, no one has mentioned this to the Stereo MC's. They ambled on stage as that group who did the song from the mobile phones ad, the 52nd best band ever (according to Q magazine) and keepers of a flame most people thought went out when Noel Gallagher was still working for British Gas. By the time they ambled off, they were heroes.

Pasty singer Rob Birch exuded a dilapidated charisma, doing a remarkable job of not being upstaged by the irrepressible Cath Coffey and the rest of the female front line. Nick Hallam stayed behind his keyboards, as faceless and hunched as a techno boffin, while drummer Owen If and percussionist Kwaku Dzidzornu laid down the sort of pummelling rhythmical bedrock many drum machine-laden dance acts can only dream about.

The band sounded exactly the same as it always did. The MC's are masters of melodious swagger, producing finely chiselled, diamond-hard anthems that are effortlessly streetwise and yet curiously melancholy. Put simply, for all the seamless blending of hip-hop, funk, soul and rock'n'roll, and the goosebump-inducing vocal harmonies, this is just a fantastic pop group with fantastic pop songs.

The newer tracks from the Deep Down and Dirty album were slightly anonymous, but that was perhaps inevitable, given the spine-tingling familiarity of the oldies. When the sound engineer applied the Connected vocal effect to Birch's voice during his introduction to that song, a tremor of anticipation shuddered through the auditorium. As the group blasted into the opening groove, the crowd went wild, energised by the sort of emotional escapism that ageing ex-Hacienda veterans remember with a tear.

The performance was so infused with energy, the overall sound so sharp and contemporary, that it was impossible to accuse the band of coasting on nostalgia. They are clearly champing at the bit, and ready, one hopes, to stick around and be brilliant for a long while to come. Anyone looking for the greatest band in the world can stop right here - the Stereo MC's have moved from number 52 to number one overnight.

 Stereo MC's are at Fabric, London EC1 (020-7336 8898), tonight.

webTitle: Dove flies in as rate is cut

fields.headline: Dove flies in as rate is cut
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Business leaders welcomed the appointment of another inflation dove to the Bank of England's rate-setting committee yesterday as Threadneedle Street cut borrowing costs for the second time in three months.
fields.body:
Business leaders welcomed the appointment of another inflation dove to the Bank of England's rate-setting committee yesterday as Threadneedle Street cut borrowing costs for the second time in three months.

The Bank said it eased rates by 0.25 percentage points to 5.5%, their lowest since January last year, because of the risks to growth from foot and mouth disease and the global slowdown.

Official figures yesterday showed that the manufacturing sector is already teetering on the brink of recession because of the collapse in world demand for hi-tech goods.

Kate Barker, chief economist at the Confederation of British Industry, is to join the Bank's nine-member monetary policy committee, taking the place of DeAnne Julius, the MPC's leading inflation dove, the Treasury announced.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, said he was delighted that Ms Barker had agreed to be one of the four "external" members of the MPC appointed by the government. "Kate is a first class economist and I am delighted that her talents have been recognised in this way," said the CBI director general, Digby Jones. "She has many years experience in business which I am sure she will use to great effect."

City analysts said the arrival of Ms Barker confirmed hopes that borrowing rates could be as low as 5% by the end of the year.

"While people's views can change, we would suspect she will be very sympathetic to the conditions in industry and not just manufacturing," said Ciaran Barr, chief UK economist at Deutsche Bank.

News of Ms Barker's appointment came as the office for national statistics announced that industrial output shrank by 0.3% in February. The main reason was a steep decline in energy extraction and supply - which the ONS blamed on poor weather in the North Sea - but manufacturing failed to rebound after January's steep fall, rising just 0.1% over the month.

Analysts said the hi-tech manufacturing boom appears to be over. Demand for mobile phones, internet connections and digital set-top boxes kept the manufacturing sector afloat for much of the last year, while old economy sectors such as textiles and metals were declining.

So-called new economy firms have begun cutting output in response to the global fall in demand for hi-tech goods. Over the last three months demand for network components and mobile phones has fallen by almost 9%.

Industry is already in recession on the wider measure, which includes the energy sector, and many analysts expect manufacturing to follow.

"Given the general downbeat survey evidence of late, it seems more likely that output will weaken further," said Daniel Kaye, UK economist at Capital Economics. "Technical recession in manufacturing over the first half of the year now looks likely."

The ONS said it had cut its estimate of the trend rate of growth in manufacturing from 1.5 to 0.5% this year. Statisticians said industrial production in February was largely unaffected by the onset of foot and mouth, although they expected the impact to be more serious when the March data is published.

The epidemic has already caused food prices to increase, according to the British Retail Consortium. Prices rose by 0.7% in March, the highest month on month rise for nearly two years.

fields.headline: Ensemble Modern/Herreweghe
fields.standfirst:
Barbican, London
****
fields.trailText:
Barbican, London
****
fields.body:
Almost exactly 300 years of musical history separate Heinrich Schutz from Igor Stravinsky. Yet the German kapellmeister who strove to transcend the austerity of 16th-century Protestant church music, and the cosmopolitan cultural magpie who unswervingly absorbed what he needed from the past and made it his own, proved to be perfect partners in this programme. Conducted by Philippe Herreweghe, it brought together the choir he founded 30 years ago - the Collegium Vocale Gent - and the finest of current modern-music groups, the Ensemble Modern.

The Ensemble were surplus to requirements in the Schutz: the Musikalische Exequien (1636), his elaborate, achingly expressive funerary triptych, needs only a group of continuo instruments to support its closely woven textures. Herreweghe's minimalist conducting - the barest indications of pulse, the occasional shrugging emphasis, but often just eagle-eyed encouragement - was still capable of shaping such music with consummate skill. Every phrase was unselfconsciously moulded and, with each voice allowed to retain its own personal timbre, there was no suggestion of bland uniformity. The polyphonic intricacies were brought thrillingly alive, whether in the massive opening concerto, which sets the words of the German funeral mass as a sequence of calls and responses between a group of soloists and the main choir or the extraordinary final chorus, in which the Nunc Dimittis is combined with extracts from the Book of Revelation.

In many ways Stravinsky's Mass, from the 1940s, is more austere than anything in the Schutz. There's not a wasted note: the text is delivered in an almost matter-of-fact way, and the quintets of woodwind and brass instruments supply punctuation rather than decoration. Though lines were submerged on occasion - women were used for the soprano parts where Stravinsky suggested boys, sacrificing pungency in the lower registers - Herreweghe's account was a model of directness.

The insistent delivery of the Gloria harked back to the Russian primitivism of Les Noces, while the Agnus Dei had a matter-of-fact simplicity. Before it, the Ensemble wind gave a wonderfully unbuttoned performance of Stravinsky's Octet, treating it as real chamber music. The players listened carefully to each other, minting fresh ideas as they went along, for the perfect extrovert contrast to the intensely serious works on either side.

fields.headline: LSO/Boulez
fields.body:
Engage Pierre Boulez to conduct and Cecilia Bartoli as soloist, and you are 99% of the way to ensuring that a gala concert lives up to its name. Last night's, given in aid of the London Symphony Orchestra's education centre and a children's hospice service, certainly fulfilled its billing.

The presence of the Duke of York brought the evening's first cherishable moment - Boulez conducting God Save the Queen. It was a truncated version, delivered with as near to perfunctory efficiency as courtesy would allow. Then straight into Berlioz's Overture to Beatrice and Benedict, which began almost as strait-laced as the national anthem. The opening theme's thrust and parry were distinctly subdued, and the long, lazy theme of the slow section was unusually solemn, yet lit up with unexpected tints and half-tones. Only when the music picked up speed again did it begin to glitter as it should.

Bartoli was there for Berlioz too. She has just added Les Nuits d'Eté to her repertory; no doubt as she sings it more the sense of line and wholeness in each song will grow. But already her performance contains some very special things, not least her total absorption into every phrase of the Gautier poems the cycle sets. Her range of inflection and vocal colour was vast: honeyed effusions for the opening Villanelle, tone thinned down to nearly a whisper for Le Spectre de la Rose. Never have these songs seemed so operatic, never so close to the world of Berlioz's masterpiece The Trojans. After it an encore was essential, and that was Berlioz too, the song Zaide, in which Bartoli revealed another talent, decorating her seductive performance with some dashing castanets.

Boulez then tackled a work that has long been one of his party pieces - Ravel's complete ballet Daphnis et Chlöe. With an orchestra as dazzlingly accomplished as the LSO it must be a delight to conduct, for every fleck of colour in this iridescent score can be realised. The immaculate ensemble and virtuosic elan of the playing were often breathtaking. But Boulez now is far, far more than just a supreme technician on the podium: he brings a work like Daphnis fully to dramatic life. Using an elasticity of pulse to shape the episodic score into utterly coherent paragraphs, he imbues the music for the two lovers with languorous sensuality and the moments of high tension with a palpable sense of menace. It's hard to imagine the work better conducted, or played.

 A version of this review appeared in later editions of yesterday's paper.

webTitle: Davies urges investors to get real

fields.headline: Davies urges investors to get real
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Savers' expectations of double-digit investment returns are unrealistic in today's low-inflation, low-interest economy, financial services authority chairman Sir Howard Davies said yesterday.
fields.body:
Savers' expectations of double-digit investment returns are unrealistic in today's low-inflation, low-interest economy, financial services authority chairman Sir Howard Davies said yesterday.

With bank and building society savings rates due to fall further following yesterday's quarter-point base rate cut, the FSA is concerned that investors seeking a better deal might be lured into risky products promising high returns.

Sir Howard suggested that many people made unrealistic assumptions about the returns to be gained from their investments.

Headline inflation was expected to remain at around the government's target rate of 2.5% for the foreseeable future, so consumers must "adjust their expectations".

"Savers need to understand that low inflation means lower nominal returns."

Sir Howard said it was important that consumers were not misled into thinking they could obtain high returns from low-risk investments. He singled out for criticism the new breed of individual savings accounts that invite small investors to put money into hedge funds, traditionally the preserve of the very rich.

Two of the regulator's biggest headaches, mortgage endowments and the guaranteed annuity rates which landed Equitable Life in trouble, stemmed from the failure to adjust to lower inflation, he said.

Low inflation protected the value of savings even though headline rates of return on investments were falling, Sir Howard said.

In the late 1970s savers were receiving 15% on National Savings accounts. But that return had to be set against inflation which was running at 18% in 1980.Today, a return of 4.5% left investors better off in real terms.

fields.headline: Schwab spreads tech pain
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Guardian Unlimited Money
More net news
fields.trailText: Investor anxieties have forced Britain's biggest online stockbroker, Charles Schwab, to cut up to 180 jobs, writes Rupert Jones.
fields.body:
Investor anxieties have forced Britain's biggest online stockbroker, Charles Schwab, to cut up to 180 jobs, 20% of its UK workforce.

The company has seen average daily share trades fall to 5,000 from 8,000-10,000 a year ago. It has been hit particularly hard by the slump in hi-tech stocks which has scared off many dot.com investors.

The announcement yesterday came two weeks after the company's main US operation announced 3,400 job cuts, 11-13% of its staff.

Russ Shaw, senior vice-president of Charles Schwab Europe, said it had to respond to market conditions and "fundamental changes in the trading behaviour of British private investors".

With more than 30 brokers now offering online share dealing in Britain, he anticipated a shake-out in the sector. "I don't think there is going to be room for everybody, especially during this down period."

Between 160 and 180 jobs will be lost, spread across the company's headquarters in Birmingham and offices in London and Milton Keynes. It hoped to achieve the reductions through voluntary redundancies.

The company said share trades were down 30% on what it hoped they would be.

Just over a year ago Charles Schwab expanded rapidly to cope with a surge in share dealing, which at its height saw the number of trades hit 14,000 a day as small investors flocked to buy and sell hi-tech stocks. After criticism that it was struggling to meet demand, it opened the customer service centre in Milton Keynes.

webTitle: £120m in loans offered as tourism lifeline

fields.headline: £120m in loans offered as tourism lifeline
fields.standfirst:
A drop in tourist bookings of up to 80% in Cumbria and 10% across UK has prompted the government to offer £120m in loans

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: A drop in tourist bookings of up to 80% in Cumbria and 10% across the UK has prompted the government to offer a £120m lifeline in loans
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, John Vidal and Michael White
fields.body:
The government will today announce £120m of guaranteed loans to the hard pressed tourist industry. Ministers confirmed yesterday that bookings are down 10% across the country and up to 80% in the worst hit areas of Cumbria and Devon.

The loans package is designed to tide the industry over its growing cash crisis, but is unlikely to be seen as enough by the many small rural tourist businesses on the edge of collapse.

The English regional tourist boards estimate they are losing £200m a week in revenue, and the figure could be four times greater over Easter, which often represents as much as 10% of the industry's annual takings.

The loans will be announced by the culture secretary, Chris Smith, alongside £6m in subsidies to increase marketing by the English Tourism Council and the British Tourism Authority.

Mr Smith warned the cabinet yesterday that the danger of "significantly reduced" bookings for the summer was now serious. The package has been worked up in urgent talks between the Department of Culture, Downing Street and the Treasury. The money is on top of existing rate relief and VAT holidays.

The Conservatives are likely to claim that the package follows their own call for interest free loans of up to £10,000. The tourist industry will claim the assistance is dwarfed by the huge compensation payments being prepared for farmers.

But as President Bush told the Scottish first minister, Henry McLeish, in Washington that he "empathised with the UK" - and the European parliament snubbed Britain by voting overwhelmingly to call for a review of the non-vaccination policy - there were clear signs that government was becoming deeply frustrated at local councils in unaffected parts of the country.

Mr Blair has already met council leaders to urge them to take a common sense approach to footpath closures but large areas still have blanket bans.

The government found an unexpected ally in Sir Sean Connery, who was in Washington. "You will find our majestic countryside open," he said. Agriculture minister Nick Brown, who told cabinet members that he would be spending much of the Easter holidays at his ministry's headquarters, advised caution however, saying that the epidemic might be levelling off but no risks could be taken.

"This is a very serious outbreak which is likely to have a long tail," he told MPs as some pressed for faster cull-and-bury policies and others urged relaxation of restrictions on the movement of animals in unaffected areas.

The problem facing vets was multiplied by the fact that for every reported case of foot and mouth confirmed, there were two that turned out to be false alarms, Mr Brown said.

Compensation payments to farmers were now approaching £600 million, Downing Street said.

About 1,600 soldiers are working on foot and mouth in 14 areas of the country.

fields.headline: Why computers waste your time
fields.standfirst: Judi James remembers a time before email
fields.trailText: Judi James remembers a time before email
fields.body:
Does your PC give you relief or grief? It could cut a swathe through all those time-consuming admin chores and freeing your brain up for high-level thinking and decision-making. Of course, the relationship may have broken down a little.

PC rage is discovering increased popularity in the modern workplace. Swearing at your PC has always been good sport on the odd occasion, but now outbursts have started to get more frequent and more personal.

The problem possibly began when we discovered - not what the pc can do, but what it can't. Customer care is based on two principles: finding out what the customer wants and giving it to them, and constantly exceeding expectations.

The love affair with IT lasted only as long as it took us to learn exactly how to use it. Before that point we thought any inadequacies were down to our own stupidity.

We believed that the PC was capable of anything and everything, from supplying a recipe for the perfect tarte tartin to giving us a step-by-step guide for world domination.

Discovering it has its limits was sobering and a low moment in the customer care relationship. They dawdle. They crash. They deny access. They can be extremely non consumer-friendly.

They are great for shopping, having a read, learning and researching. But they can make lousy time managers. Someone, somewhere, will one day compile a honest-to-goodness time log to discover whether they save or lose you time at work overall.

Listening to a colleague new to email the other day, I was able to see the time-wastage aspect at source. This is a woman who would normally send three letters a week, and who would get her PA to write them.

If she needed to contact someone urgently she would pick up the phone and have an immediate exchange of views. Now she is a slave to email. She is delighted to be able to send messages anywhere, any time.

What she has failed to realise is that most of these are sent and received in the evening, from her home. Meaning that her work/life balance has turned very steeply in favour of the work option. Some go out as late as midnight. Some poor sod will find them on their screen first thing the next morning and then feel obliged to respond. One truly sad soul even wrote back at four minutes past midnight, on a saturday night.

The secret is to review your PC work and ask the question "why?" a lot, as in "why do I do this electronically?" Does it save me time or create time? How much quicker and/or convenient is it for me to do it this way? Did I choose the electronic way or did I do it because of external nerd-pressure?

Is it really easier for you to access your computer diary than a paper one? Would a letter or phone call be more appropriate than that email? How long have you spent weeping over that crashed computer and how long would it have taken had you used an alternative?

PCs are great but their use needs to be seen as limited. There are things we can do that we could not without them and there are jobs that are easier using an alternative medium. If in doubt, always ask yourself the classic time-management question: Is this the best use of my time, right now?

fields.headline: Exorcising Jeffrey Archer
fields.standfirst:
Defending Jeffrey . . . ?
West Yorkshire Playhouse, Leeds
****
fields.trailText:
Defending Jeffrey . . . ?
West Yorkshire Playhouse, Leeds
****
fields.body:
The subconscious of Edward Petherbridge is a strange place to be. It is like an actor's weird attic, full of half-remembered speeches, discarded costumes, stacks of mildewed anecdotes and a few mothballed resolutions to give the whole charade up one day and perhaps become a painter. It can be mildly diverting watching a seasoned pro pottering about among his own mental bric-a-brac, if the project is a tad self-indulgent.

But Petherbridge's attic contains a sinister secret that enlivens this self-penned one-man show no end, however detrimental it may have been to his career. Stashed away, under a heap of still-fresh hostile notices, is the fact that, until February this year, Petherbridge played Jeffrey Archer's defence counsel in Archer's ill-fated courtroom drama, The Accused.

You can only marvel that Petherbridge has rustled up this explanation, exculpation and exorcism in such a short space of time. But then, as he makes the least expected of entrances, dangling from the end of a flying wire, Petherbridge is clearly not an actor who relishes hanging around. What emerges is something like his own post-traumatic stress production: a truly bizarre cross-fertilisation of bumbling after-dinner anecdotes with a spell-binding demonstration in stage mechanics - as if Ned Sherrin had gone into therapy with Robert Lepage. Rarely has an audience seemed so polarised between rapt enthusiasm and utter bewilderment.

I too felt a bit of both. There's a section where Petherbridge apostrophises inconclusively on modern painting, then indulges in a spot of sub-Rolf Harris splatter painting. After this strange exercise in watching paint dry, he re-emerges dressed as Pierrot and, in a pool of ravishing blue light, gives a heart-meltingly beautiful account of the prison soliloquy from Richard II, mixed with some oblique, Oedipal stuff about never being able to communicate properly with his father. You can only marvel at the tenacity of the man's self-examination. Genius or madness? fields.bodyText: The subconscious of Edward Petherbridge is a strange place to be. It is like an actor's weird attic, full of half-remembered speeches, discarded costumes, stacks of mildewed anecdotes and a few mothballed resolutions to give the whole charade up one day and perhaps become a painter. It can be mildly diverting watching a seasoned pro pottering about among his own mental bric-a-brac, if the project is a tad self-indulgent. But Petherbridge's attic contains a sinister secret that enlivens this self-penned one-man show no end, however detrimental it may have been to his career. Stashed away, under a heap of still-fresh hostile notices, is the fact that, until February this year, Petherbridge played Jeffrey Archer's defence counsel in Archer's ill-fated courtroom drama, The Accused. webTitle: Brand new Britain has old look

fields.headline: Brand new Britain has old look
fields.standfirst: Image makers' preference for Shakespeare and the Spice Girls embarrasses some exporters in era of globalisation
fields.trailText: Image makers' preference for Shakespeare and the Spice Girls embarrasses some exporters in era of globalisation
fields.body:
As the fleeting fad for Cool Britannia subsides, Britain's global corporations and export businesses are locked in a struggle over how the nation and its brands ought to be portrayed around the world in the long term.

At a seminar hosted yesterday by the Walpole Committee - a club of about 50 UK businesses, all with an emphasis on nostalgia - it was argued that Britain should be promoting itself as the home of "excellence and quality, prestige and exclusivity".

Meanwhile, corporate incarnations of the once proud state-run monopolies have been slowly shedding their national colours. British Gas, British Steel, British Aerospace, British Petroleum and British Telecom are all brands that have faded as the privatised industrial behemoths have demerged or repositioned themselves as global players.

In the wake of such changes Walpole and its members have taken a lead in branding Britain's business identity abroad, often portraying the UK as a heritage park devoted to the nostalgia industry.

Nostalgia trip

Walpole chief executive Julia Carrick admits a certain image of Britain's past has been excessively fostered by some of her members, but insists this is changing. "The balance between nostalgia and modernity is something that we are addressing with our members," she says. "We are trying to persuade them to capture a happy medium and redress an imbalance towards nostalgia that has existed in the past."

However, a list of Walpole's members -packed with traditionally orientated firms such as Aga Rayburn, Harpers & Queen and the Savoy Group - paints a different picture. Conspicuous by their absence are Britain's hi-tech businesses such as ARM, Autonomy and Psion; and modern designers such as Paul Smith, Conran and Dyson.

Roger Mitchell, deputy chairman of Holland & Holland, a London gunsmith established in 1835, is candid about his firm's interest in Walpole.

"We became members because we saw an opportunity in certain promotional events," he says as the dapper delegates mingle during a coffee break.

Walpole's last event was an award ceremony in New York at which the Duchess of York presented medals of excellence - embossed with the head of the 18th century prime minister and minister for commerce Sir Robert Walpole - to a number of its members.

"I think it is a brilliant idea," says Martin Skan, chairman of Chewton Glen Hotel and another Walpole member. "I'm very proud of being British. But our promotion efforts are so feeble. Walpole is a way to beat the drum."

Others are appalled that the image of British business is being left in the hands of such nostalgic interests. Charles Powell, chairman of advertising agency BMP DDB and former publicity adviser to the Labour party, says all UK-based firms should be involved in the process of promoting Britain.

"Wherever they are in the world, people will always want to know where a company is from," he says. "So, any company that trades abroad is affected by Britain's image - and they ought to do something about it."

One BMP research experiment asked businesses worldwide to categorise an anonymous fictional company, having only been told its was a pen manufacturer, either from Germany, America or Britain.

The results showed that the fictional British firm was perceived as old fashioned, trustworthy and boring; its German rival was hardworking, trustworthy and innovative, while the US company was modern, innovative and creative.

'Dim memory'

"What people abroad don't pick up on is that a fifth of all post-war technological inventions were made in Britain. They see us as the Spice Girls and Shakespeare, with only a few having a dim memory that we used to be a quite innovative nation."

Some image consultants argue that it is more than just the pressures of globalisation that have prompted many larger British corporations to abandon their national colours.

Chris Ludlow, a director at consultancy firm Henrion, Ludlow & Schmidt, says: "BT may have dampened down their 'British' tag in order to be an international company, but its competitors, like Deutsche Telekom, manage perfectly well on a global stage - we know it is German, but we tend to think that might be quite a good thing technically.

"British brands, on the other hand, can look singularly parochial - a bit pricy, a bit fusty, a bit little less single-minded than a German organisation."

Others have suggested the privatised industry heavyweights have been conducting a concerted purging of everything associated with their public sector past - including names and branding.

Jonathan Griffin, who runs a new government taskforce charged with raising the profile of British businesses, says he is already resigned to many more firms airbrushing out their national roots as they revise their corporate images for the global marketplace.

"We have seen a lot already," he says. "And we can fully expect that many more companies will want to mention their country of origin less and less over the coming few years."

He points out that, where Britain was once dubbed the workshop of the world, for many multinationals this is now an historical aside with little relevance to present global emphases.

"Britain is not the place to be manufacturing mass market products any more - you only have to look at the history of the car industry to see that," Mr Griffin says.

"These days, you can manufacture in the Far East and import here. Your product may have a British brand on it, but it is still manufactured in the Far East. This is not the fault of Walpole and its members; it's just the nature of the British manufacturing base and the nature of the global markets."

Charging a premium

Perhaps surprisingly, a spokeswoman for British Airways - one of the few large international companies belonging to Walpole - argues that those firms branding themselves as British are able to charge customers a premium for "flying the flag".

"Our Britishness is recognised internationally and is core to our business - it adds that feeling of historical prestige, of authoritativeness and reassurance, which can be important in some overseas markets," she says.

"A lot of people are prepared to pay that little bit extra to travel on BA because it gives them that feeling of reassurance travelling home."

Others have suggested that the "buy British" mentality - first promoted under Harold Wilson - is insulting to modern consumers who tend to purchase what they feel to be value for money.

Complacency on this point can be costly, as the recent troubles at Marks and Spencer - that most British of retailers -starkly illustrate.

fields.headline: £1m for Royal & Sun chief
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Top executives at the Royal & Sun Alliance insurance group failed to earn their bonuses in 2000 for the third year, but chief executive Bob Mendelsohn still managed to earn more than £1m, writes Jill Treanor .
fields.body:
Top executives at the Royal & Sun Alliance insurance group failed to earn their bonuses in 2000 for the third year, but chief executive Bob Mendelsohn still managed to earn more than £1m, writes Jill Treanor .

A multimillionaire American, Mr Mendelsohn failed to achieve the performance criteria of the options plan installed at the time of his appointment - which de pends on the relative performance of the company's shares during the period.

Mr Mendelsohn received basic pay of £632,000 and a £413,000 payment - of which £383,000 was described as "expatriate" benefits to cover his relocation from the US. That took his cash pay to £1.04m, up from £976,000 in 1999.

He took the helm after the merger between Sun Al liance and Royal Insurance in 1996. A turbulent share price has meant executives have not been paid cash bonuses since 1997, with the exception of Mr Mendelsohn who two years ago received pay of more than £2m. The company said this was to buy him out of a US performance deal.

US managers are to benefit from a new stock option scheme.

fields.headline: Peter Singer's top 10 books
fields.trailText: Controversial philosopher and professor of bioethics Peter Singer has been working in the field of 'practical ethics' for 30 years - "which means that when I began there was no such field". He was a passionate founder of the modern animal rights movement and has written on animal rights, abortion, euthanasia and the ethical implications of the global rift between rich and poor.
fields.body:
Controversial philosopher and professor of bioethics Peter Singer has been working in the field of 'practical ethics' for 30 years - "which means that when I began there was no such field". He was a passionate founder of the modern animal rights movement and has written on animal rights, abortion, euthanasia and the ethical implications of the global rift between rich and poor.

His most recent book is Writings on an Ethical Life, a collection of his most provocative writings.
Buy Writings on Ethical Life at Amazon.co.uk

1. The Descent of Man by Charles Darwin
Together with Darwin's The Origin of Species - and a better read - this book ushered in the modern understanding of what we are, and our relationship to other animals.

2. Pride and Prejudice by Jane Austen
If this is not the best novel ever written, I don't know what surpasses it for fine observation of manners, character and passions, all told with the most delightfully delicate sense of humour.

3. The Methods of Ethics by Henry Sidgwick
After 100 years, this remains the most careful, thorough and accurate study of ethics I know.

4. On Liberty by John Stuart Mill
Mill's defence of individual liberty and freedom of expression is a model of political argument, and a pleasure to read.

5. Reasons and Persons by Derek Parfit
Parfit's penetrating thought and spare prose make this one of the most exciting, if challenging, works by a contemporary philosopher.

6. The Selfish Gene by Richard Dawkins
A highly readable theory about how we came to be as we are. Dawkins is always stimulating and full of ideas, even if he needs to be read in a questioning frame of mind.

7. Silent Spring by Rachel Carson
Probably the most important book on the environment ever written, and once you read it, it is easy to see why.

8. In the Shadow of Man by Jane Goodall
The classic study of our closest relative, the chimpanzee.

9. Humanity by Jonathan Glover
A philosopher's look at the moral history of the 20th century, full of remarkable information and wise reflections.

10. Final Exit by Derek Humphrey
Unlike all the other books on this list, this is one that I hope you'll never want to read. But if the day comes when you need to be in control of how your life ends, and you can't find a doctor who will help, this is the book to get.

fields.headline: Nice dancing, shame about the choreography
fields.standfirst:
Houston Ballet
Sadler's Wells, London
**
fields.trailText:
Houston Ballet
Sadler's Wells, London
**
fields.body:
It has been 18 years since Houston Ballet last visited Britain and its dancers are obviously unknown here - which is one reason that the company's programme of mostly new one-act ballets is a good follow-up to the ballerina-oriented Cleopatra with which its season opened. On Wednesday most of the company took a turn centre stage and, during the course of the evening, demonstrated the entertaining mix of styles and personalities within Houston's ranks.

Mauricio Canete, for instance (who plays the wimpy Ptolemy in Cleopatra), turned out to have a fast and fizzy technique, with brisk feet and a surprising scale for such a small dancer. Mireille Hassenboehler danced with an admirably grown-up self-possession and elegance. There was also a brief appearance from the company's star principal, Carlos Acosta (well-known to London through his appearances with the Royal Ballet), who performed ballet's equivalent of a rodeo in the pas de deux from Petipa's Diana and Acteon.

Acosta, who has been with Houston since 1993, is a superb dance athlete - the dazzle with which he embellishes his enormous jumps is almost blinding. He also manages to combine classical grace with a spontaneous, ever so slightly louche charm. "Feral" has become Acosta's personal cliche - used a few times too many in his critical accolades - but he is without question a prince who's walked a little on the wild side.

He danced on Wednesday with Lauren Anderson, who also has a big stage personality and an exuberant attack. Unlike Acosta, though, her energy lacks classical finish. A technique that was turned to feisty and exotic purpose in Cleopatra looked naive and a little ragged in the refined sophistication of Petipa.

Diana and Acteon was a late addition to the programme and would have struck an oddly archaic note had the three new works looked more convincingly modern. It's a depressing feature of contemporary ballet-making that so few choreographers possess an idea that's original, let alone up to date (and if they do, they are rarely able to please their audience). Each of Houston's new ballets was actually a reworking of genres that have been playing on the international stage for years.

Trey McIntyre's Second Before the Ground was by far the best of the bunch, featuring some arrestingly inventive movement. But its material was made soft and sickly by falling into the groove of "romantic cute" - its performers forced to play the kind of whimsical courtship games that so often make ballet dancers look like prepubescent virgins rather than grown-up men and women.

Natalie Weir's In a Whisper (which was danced to a lugubrious playing of the Adagio from Schubert's String Quintet in C major) was a textbook study in ballet angst - its central male dancer locked in a sullen metaphysical grump and resisting any amount of pleading from his anguished friends. And finally came Stanton Welch's Bruiser, a perkily upbeat juggling of sports motifs - mostly coy boxing moves and muscular jogging. This is a ballet desperately seeking the funky common touch, only 30 years after Twyla Tharp found it first.

 Further performances of Cleopatra tonight and tomorrow. Box office: 020-7863 8000.

webTitle: Theatre review: Mill on the Floss

fields.headline: Mill on the Floss
fields.standfirst:
New Ambassadors, London
****
fields.trailText:
New Ambassadors, London
****
fields.body:
It begins with the ducking of a witch and ends with a flood; in between you will be swept away by Shared Experience's adaptation of George Eliot's novel. First produced by the company in 1994, Helen Edmundson's version of the story has taken a long time to reach the West End but it undoubtedly deserves its berth. It is devastatingly good.

The great trick of the adaptation is that it never settles for the bare bones of narrative: it always gives you the emotional tenor of the story and always expresses the themes. Adapting from page to stage is almost always perceived as a second-rate art, but here it is elevated to something that is both true to the original novel and transcends it. But to talk about its being faithful is irrelevant - it is also completely of itself. When I first saw this production some years ago I had never read the novel but, as a result, I rushed out and bought it. Now I know the book intimately, but the stage version is as thrilling as ever.

The vision is so complete that it is impossible to say where Edmundson's contribution ends and that of directors Nancy Meckler and Polly Teale begins. At its heart are the three Maggies, played by three actresses: First Maggie is the impetuous, wayward child, maybe her very soul; Second Maggie is the young woman who tries to suppress her nature so she can bow to the wishes of her domineering brother Tom; Third Maggie is the mature woman caught between the two as she struggles to reconcile her love for her cousin's beloved, Stephen Guest, with her need to do the right thing. Some of the best moments come when the struggle between the Maggies is most obvious. There is a lovely scene when Third Maggie is confronted by the knowledge of her love for Stephen while First Maggie creeps slyly around the edge of the piano, leading her on into dangerous waters.

This is a dazzlingly acted production, where the boundaries between text and physicality become blurred as feelings are evoked with a swing on a rope or a sudden frozen image. In the rising floodwaters you don't just see but experience every mixed emotion of a woman trapped and doomed by the expectations of a society suspicious of an intelligent woman who thinks and feels too much for her own good.

 Until May 5. Box office: 020-7369 1761.

webTitle: Frank Keating on the boredom of the domestic season

fields.headline: Will the fat ladies please shut up
fields.trailText: Where is any competitive edge to the season's finale? We may as well drift off now and be home early: we know the credits just about off by heart. Domestic seasons are becoming excruciating bores.
fields.body:
Can't you just feel this sporting nation on the edge of its proverbial armchairs as it lives every remaining kick of the tumultuous north v south Second Division championship ding-dong between Millwall and Rotherham: 77 points apiece as the two clubs gird themselves for one final voluptuous dive for the tape.

And, er, that's about it. Well, is there much else remotely to get worked up about? Football's other league titles have been done and dusted - and drowned in drawn-out cliche - for long months now. Where is any competitive edge to the season's finale? We may as well drift off now and be home early: we know the credits just about off by heart. The yawn has been wide and prolonged, the outcome totally predictable.

Manchester United have been strolling to another inevitable Premiership title since even before the clocks went back last October. Since when they have hardly been given a single decent workout, scarcely been stretched to anything resembling match tautness - and, by golly, it didn't half show when they went through the motions against Liverpool last weekend before fannying around against Bayern Munich on Tuesday.

It is sometimes said of overtrained prizefighters that they have "left all their form in the gym". Conversely with Man United - so pallid and meek has been most of their opposition, week in and week out, that they have long been able to treat every match as little more than a gymnasium visit. Which is all they have needed to collect points by the bucketload. But "match hard"? United have scarcely had a hard match in years. So when one presents itself, they cannot respond. The resulting lethargy possibly cost them the European Cup last year, and probably ditto this.

In the First Division, the Harrods fashion-platers Fulham have also been the obvious runaway champions since leaves were on the trees. So, too, in Scotland, where Celtic have for yonks been such a Sauchiehall Street ahead that even the most rabidly partisan Ranger should, in his right mind, have logically given up bothering. It is the same syndrome almost all over - one rich strutter and the poor masses scrabbling for the crumbs. Domestic seasons are becoming excruciating bores.

At rugby union, a long winter, perhaps, but the shortest of short odds since well before Christmas that Leicester would be champions, with the rest nowhere. In the Tigers' case, they even suffered last week from the Old Trafford malaise, sending down virtually a second XV and being beaten by Gloucester - although in Leicester's case it must be 100-1 on that they, at least, will pull themselves together in time to take on the same opponents come their Heineken Cup semi-final.

In Wales - oh, drowsy meaninglessness - Swansea and Cardiff still reach neck and neck for the championship. But what's new and vibrant in that? It's even more yawnworthy dull in Scotland, where Melrose have long given up the ghost of catching Hawick. Old Bill might declaim, "I can tell ye, they'll be dancing in the ol' streets o' Hawick tonight" - but I doubt they will. The season has long been a foregone conclusion.

Well, at least summer's a'coming in... So what? Domestic competitiveness? Fat chance. Sane bookmakers are even baulking at accepting reasonable bets that Surrey will win their third County Championship on the trot - or rather at a canter with their eyes half-closed. You've as much chance of getting a worthwhile bet on Man United not winning next season's Premiership.

Do you detect a cyclical syndrome? Yes, cyclical all right - and cynical, too.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Barcelona 0 - 0 Liverpool
fields.standfirst: Refresh this page for the latest action
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Barcelona: Reina, Gabri, de Boer, Puyol, Sergi, Luis Enrique, Guardiola, Cocu, Overmars, Rivaldo, Kluivert. Subs: Dutruel, De la Pena, Alfonso, Xavi, Petit, Dani, Zenden.

Liverpool: Westerveld, Babbel, Henchoz, Hyypia, Carragher, Gerrard, Murphy, Hamann, Berger, Owen, Heskey. Subs: Arphexad, Ziege, Smicer, Fowler, Barmby, McAllister, Vignal.

Referee: H Krug (Germany)

1 The toughest test yet for Liverpool this season as Barca kick-off what should be a cracking tie. Goals are to be expected.
3 Not too much to get excited about in the early minutes; Liverpool look happy just to get the feel of the humungous Barcelona pitch.
7 Rivaldo peels away on the Barca left after Murphy gives the ball away; Henchoz dives in and distracts Rivaldo enough to hold things up.
9 Heskey tries to get away on the Liverpool left; Cocu stops him in his tracks.
10 First real opening for Barca when Overmars gets away to the by-line and cuts the ball to Rivaldo on the edge of the area, but the Brazilian can't control it.
11 At last, things pick up; Barca win a corner, Hamann clears, Overmars pops it back in and Rivaldo knocks it down for Luis Enrique to shoot wide.
14 Guardiola tries to release Luis Enrique on the right, unsuccessfully. Barca still with the initiative, firmly camped in the Liverpool half. Liverpool look happy to soak up the early pressure (if that's the right word) and wait to hit on the break.
18 Guardiola sprays the ball out for Sergi to send Overmars away on the left; Overmars gets past Babbel and pulls it back for Liverpool to clear. Barca keep up the pressure with Overmars on the 18-yard line; Hyypia scrambles a clearance. Guardiola the root of many of Barca's moves.
22 Brief glimpse of an opening when Liverpool burgle possession from a sloppy pass and Barca are caught short at the back, but Berger over-hits his pass to Heskey and it is easy for Reina.
24 Barca free-kick to the left of the area; curled into the far post, Babbel heads behind for a corner. Comes to nothing
26 Sloppy passing again hands possession to Liverpool; signs of a few openings for the visitors, which is what they seem to have been waiting for.
29 First corner to Liverpool after Heskey releases Berger on the left and his cross is put behind for safety. Barca clear.
32 Rivaldo in a great position on the edge of the Liverpool area - until Henchoz puts in a great tackle to clear.
37 Rivaldo chests it down 20 yards out, spurns the left-foot shot when Henchoz closes in and instead turns to fire wide with his right.
39 Liverpool free-kick on the edge of the area; deflected for a corner - Reina claims one yard out.
41 Kluivert and Rivaldo not clicking up front for Barca. Kluivert fluffs a lay-off to Rivaldo in the area, when only a couple of minutes ago Rivaldo spurned a one-two with the Dutchman only to blow a shot across the face of goal.
45 One minute extra to play. Cocu tries a shot from distance - no go.

Half-time - very quiet in the opening period, very boring for the keepers - so much for the goals! Liverpool need to break out of their half and start to create things rather than sit back so deep and wait for something to go wrong for Barca. Come in, Steven Gerrard, are you out there? Nevertheless, a solid performance at the back by Gerard Houllier's men and that has to be good news for Liverpool.

46 We can only hope that things improve this half. Expect Barca to step up the pace. Cocu with an early cross for Rivaldo in the area, but is beyond the Brazilian.
47 Babbel tries to find Owen up front - too long. Already a more attacking feel to the game, if only because the crowd have found their voices.
53 Concerted pressure after Kluivert knocks the ball into Rivaldo. He loses possession, but Barca stick at it until a crucial interception by Heskey inside the area breaks things down and Henchoz clears.
55 Crucial block by Carragher to deny Luis Enrique - corner. Guardiola deep to Cocu, who crosses for Kluivert to fire wide under pressure from Henchoz.
58 Barca free-kick 35 yards out; Rivaldo has a crack - into the wall.
60 Substitution Smicer on for Murphy.
60 Heskey battles his way to the by-line but can't get his cross to Owen. Barca break to win a corner; Gerrard does well to pin Barca back to the touchline from the rebound...
62... Liverpool then give away a free-kick 35 yards out but it is spooned into the crowd.
64 Barca corner; Guardiola takes but Heskey clears.
67 Liverpool free-kick a good 35 yards out; Hamann aims for Hyypia but wastes it.
68 Corner to Barca after good work by Overmars near the left corner flag; comes to nothing.
69 Cocu shoots from 25 yards - wide.
71 Liverpool back four rock solid as Barca sweep in after Rivaldo finds Overmars on the right for a cross.
72 Substitutions Xavi and Zenden on for Luis Enrique and Overmars.
73 Substitution Fowler on for Owen, who has been sacrificed for the good of the team by being left alone up front.
74 Smicer in the right, holds it up, knocks it in to Gerrard, who pops it in first touch to Fowler in space in the area - too long.
76 Dodgy moment as Kluivert charges in on the left of the area, crosses for Rivaldo but Westerveld blocks and then holds off Rivaldo before Liverpool can clear. On another night, Westerveld could have conceded a penalty.
83 Substitution McAllister on for Berger. Lots of movement by Barca around the Liverpool area, but the final touches have not come and the back four have shut things down superbly.
86 Rivaldo knocks the ball back to Xavi but his shot is easy for Westerveld. Booking Fowler, after he reacts to an elbow in the head by Guardiola.
88 Corner to Barca; Guardiola takes it short and Liverpool clear. Booking Zenden after Cocu sells him short.
90 Barca corner in the first minute of stoppage time; Hyypia clears. Gerrard with a late shot wide after Liverpool break down the left. Barca sweep upfield from the goalkick and Rivaldo gets it in the net - offside. Full-time. Barcelona 0 - 0 Liverpool An awful game but great result for Liverpool - roll on Thursday week.

fields.headline: Sophie won't set watchdogs on papers
fields.trailText:
Thursday 6pm: The Countess of Wessex is not expected to lodge an official complaint over the "Sophie tapes" debacle, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
Apr 5: Sophie's partner may quit
Apr 5: Sophie faces new row over business role
Apr 4: 'No special favours for Sophie', says PCC
Apr 2: The Countess and the tabloid sting
Apr 2: Sheikh rattles and rolls out star victims
fields.body:
The Countess of Wessex is not expected to lodge an official complaint to press watchdogs against the Mail on Sunday or News of the World over the "Sophie tapes" debacle.

Sources say she has been advised not to go any further because the situation was so "muddied" by her own interview with the News of the World last Sunday.

"It would also mean an investigation into the whole affair, which she will not welcome," said one source.

But today the consensus of opinion was that the countess, who is a PR consultant, will suffer more damaging revelations this weekend because of mistakes made by Buckingham Palace aides, say sources close to the affair.

They say News of the World editor Rebekah Wade has been "backed into a corner" and now has no option but to publish the contents of the tape recordings obtained by an undercover reporter.

"She has got to recover some ground and the only way she can do it is to publish the tapes," said one source on the paper.

"We looked really lame. We got a good headline out of the interview, but we just looked like puppets," said an insider.

Newspaper executives were said to be horrified by the reaction of rival papers on Monday.

But the pressure is also mounting on Buckingham Palace communications secretary Simon Walker.

He is being blamed for failing to limit the damage.

"The advice that Buckingham Palace gave was spectacularly badly judged and there is only one place in the palace that could have come from.

"I think his standing might be judged in a different light."

"Issuing denials about a story that looks to be true is like waving a red rag to a bull," said one source close to the royals.

Mr Walker has already been blamed in newspaper reports for opening a rift between the Palace and the PCC.

Palace claims that it had clinched a deal with the News of the World on the advice of the PCC were categorically denied yesterday by PCC chairman Lord Wakeham in a letter to the Daily Telegraph.

Others say the mishandling of the affair will delight Prince Charles's aide Mark Bolland who has been keeping his distance.

"He has a working relationship with the press. He knows how the papers operate.If Sophie had gone to him for advice she may not have been in the position she is now in," said one source familiar with the royals.

webTitle: Inside story: Dalton Conley, academic superstar

fields.headline: A life less ordinary
fields.standfirst: He grew up a lone white kid among the black gangs of New York's Lower East Side. Now those difficult years inspire his acclaimed studies of race and class.  Lauren Sandler on the rise of Dalton Conley, academic superstar
fields.trailText: He grew up a lone white kid among the black gangs of New York's Lower East Side. Now those difficult years inspire his acclaimed studies of race and class. Lauren Sandler on the rise of Dalton Conley, academic superstar.
fields.body:
It could be the pitch for a socially minded reality TV show. Take a white kid and raise him in the gang-ruled black and Latino projects of New York City's Lower East Side. Not a tough kid, but a socially awkward one. Give him educated middle-class parents - a father of Mayflower stock and a Jewish mother - but poor, living on food stamps. Send him to a good school across town in Greenwich Village to provoke a heady contrast in his daily life, and see what he learns about race and class.

Such is the strange-but-true life story of Dalton Conley, as his new memoir, Honky, will tell you. And as all good made-for-TV stories offer a dramatic epilogue, so does his story: he went on to become one of the hottest stars of the academy, studying - what else? - the sociology of race and class. Now, at 31, he has been poached from his position at Yale, seduced by New York University's promise of tenure and his own social research centre.

He has penned a scholarly study of the connection between race and wealth called Being Black, Living in the Red, which argues that the foundation for class inequity between races is based on assets, not household income itself. For this he received accolades within both the academic and popular press.

Conley has become a superstar by making connections between the field and the personal, or as the mission for his Centre for Advanced Social Science reads: linking academy to policy to community. And now, in Honky, he has mined his own life as a social science experiment.

For all his academic success, Conley is hardly just another tweedy resident of the ivory tower. In his writing, as well as his classroom, Conley has a self-deprecating sense of humour and a hip set of cultural references. Case in point: he begins Honky with the epigraph: "Your mother is so white she went to her own wedding naked". His ease with humour, language, and the human world is what elevates him to the level of public intellectual. That skill, combined with what he admits is a "Machiavellian" focus on his career, is what makes Conley such a star. He can turn his award-winning Columbia dissertation into a praised book, write scholarly articles, convene symposia. But he can also synthesise the ideas behind his work in an honest and readable coming-of-age tale "about literary truths, not scientific ones," he writes.

Conley's story goes like this. His father and mother were living the 60s bohemian life on New York's Lower East Side. He was a painter, she was a writer. They were from families of some privilege and when space opened in Masyryk Towers, one of the projects that lay the foundation of the city's skyline, it seemed like a safe place to raise kids. This was long before crack, before news magazines ran cover stories on gangs, before the progressive housing experiments of the 60s and 70s had given way to the familiar American urban catastrophe of the 80s and 90s. Still, "the steel door to our apartment was my security blanket," Conley writes.

In Conley's view, "learning class is like learning a language". That education began when he was the only white kid enrolled in the local public school, where he quickly discovered skin privilege. At school, all the kids suffered corporal punishment , except for Conley. And privilege spared him another rod - that of New York's inequitable school system. Using a friend's address cross-town, Conley's parents sneaked him into a progressive school in Greenwich Village, where he felt as though he lived in another country.

He lived as a chameleon, transforming his language and attitude on the cross-town bus as he shuttled from one world to another. The resultant awkwardness he thinks kept him away from the magnetic trap of gang life at Masyryk Towers (his best friend, a black boy named Jerome, was shot when a bullet ricocheted off one of those towering blocks). But it's easier not to play when nobody wants you on their team - and when other experiences - summers away at a lakefront cottage, afternoons in oak-panelled libraries, expectations of a college graduation - suggest that the game is played entirely differently elsewhere.

This awareness hardly placed Conley solidly in the protected middle class, but instead in the cracks between comfort and poverty. "If the exception proves the rule," Conley writes, "I'm that exception."

Certainly, after the Greenwich Village primary school, the exceptional rise gathered pace. He went on to one of New York's best high schools. Success in the sciences led to undergraduate work at Berkeley in California, then graduate work at Columbia, where his interest turned to the science of humankind.

"I wanted to write about homelessness," he says. But slowly, his own experience came to the fore. "I was always interested in the disempowered, in the economically disadvantaged, but I didn't realise the autobiographical connections until later." That unique perspective, as well his academic prowess, led to a teaching position at Yale, before his new gig as NYU's social science wunderkind.

It's a little hard to differentiate Conley from his students when he enters the lecture hall in NYU's grand main building. The social ineptitude seems years away as he strides in with easy charisma, confident in a huge puffy Spiewak ski parka in hip-hop-hooray silver. Standing before his class in a marble hall he begins doing for his students what he has done in his career - making the meaning of big ideas accessible by linking theory with the reality of personal experience.

To illustrate this lecture about the sociology of the medical profession he shows a scene from the cerebral sci-fi movie, Gattaca. It's impossible not to make the connection between Conley's life and what appears onscreen - the story of an awkward kid whose life, like Conley's, was a form of social experiment. "My real resumé was in my [body] cells," says Ethan Hawke's protagonist. "Now we have discrimination down to a science."

Sitting behind his cluttered desk in a tiny office packed with social texts, Conley says what he's done doesn't differ greatly from what all academics do. "I think that on an unconscious level all academics are trying to figure out their own experience through the method of science, where it's more comfortable, where you can rely on other sources for authority."

Conley's experience also motivates the work of his centre, which coordinates academic outreach to kids from his old neighbourhood. But he says it may be time to leave the race-class dynamic debate behind: "In some ways I feel like I have nothing to say on race any more. What else do I have to say after I've told my own story?"

fields.bodyText: It could be the pitch for a socially minded reality TV show. Take a white kid and raise him in the gang-ruled black and Latino projects of New York City's Lower East Side. Send him to a good school across town in Greenwich Village to provoke a heady contrast in his daily life, and see what he learns about race and class. Such is the strange-but-true life story of Dalton Conley, as his new memoir, Honky, will tell you. And as all good made-for-TV stories offer a dramatic epilogue, so does his story: he went on to become one of the hottest stars of the academy, studying - what else? - the sociology of race and class. Now, at 31, he has been poached from his position at Yale, seduced by New York University's promise of tenure and his own social research centre. He has penned a scholarly study of the connection between race and wealth called Being Black, Living in the Red, which argues that the foundation for class inequity between races is based on assets, not household income itself. For this he received accolades within both the academic and popular press. Conley has become a superstar by making connections between the field and the personal, or as the mission for his Centre for Advanced Social Science reads: linking academy to policy to community. And now, in Honky, he has mined his own life as a social science experiment. For all his academic success, Conley is hardly just another tweedy resident of the ivory tower. In his writing, as well as his classroom, Conley has a self-deprecating sense of humour and a hip set of cultural references. Case in point: he begins Honky with the epigraph: "Your mother is so white she went to her own wedding naked". His ease with humour, language, and the human world is what elevates him to the level of public intellectual. fields.headline: Universities suffering from 'bidding fatigue'
fields.trailText:
Universities today complained they were being forced to waste time and money bidding for funds from the government.
Special
report: Research funding
fields.body:
Universities suffering from "bidding fatigue" today complained they were forced to waste time and money jumping through hoops to win funds from a series of government initiatives.

The latest minister to hold out the hope of funds was Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers, who invited bids for a £40m fund to help transform British scientists' bright ideas and discoveries into commercial successes.

UK universities and laboratories now have until July to bid for money to help them develop new products, improve business-university relations and make research more commercially viable.

Universities UK (UUK) President, Professor Sir Howard Newby, although welcoming the fund, did not like the strategy. He said: "Our concerns are that there are still a large number of small scale funds for which we have to invest time and money to bid for. The chance of success in bidding remains small as the demand well exceeds the available funds."

He said that if the money was put together into a lump sum instead of parcelled out in bids, it would give universities more flexibility. "Obviously we would expect to account for our expenditure and undergo evaluation, but it would take away lottery odds. I expect researchers will still bid for Byer's funds, but looking ahead the whole system needs to be tidied up."

The government has now set aside £15m to improve product development - paid out under its University Challenge Fund to provide researchers with access to "seed" funding for products in the early stages of development. In addition, £15m to build up links between businesses and universities has been allocated under the Science Enterprise Challenge, which will establish new centres and expand the twelve existing science enterprise centres set up at universities, including Bristol, Cambridge and Glasgow.

There is also £10m to support the commercial exploitation of research at public sector laboratories under the Public Sector Research Exploitation Fund.

A spokesman for the Higher Education Funding Council for England said he understood the researchers' dilemma. "We're aware that the process of bidding for research funding puts an added strain on institutions. For that reason, with future rounds, money will mostly be merged under the Higher Education Innovation Fund to provide a more formulaic procedure where institutions are just allocated the money.

"A balance needs to be struck. On the one hand, some institutions will find allocated funds are not representative of their level of research, on the other, already strained institutions have to find time to put bidding proposals together if they want more money."

Guidelines for the Science Enterprise Challenge, University Challenge and Public Sector Research Exploitation Fund are available on the DTI's website.
