webTitle: Teachers' boycott of pupil goes to court

fields.headline: Teachers' boycott of pupil goes to court
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The mother of a 16-year-old pupil refused lessons by some of his teachers because of his alleged behaviour yesterday took their union to the high court.
fields.body:
The mother of a 16-year-old pupil refused lessons by some of his teachers because of his alleged behaviour yesterday took their union to the high court.

The boy, known as student P to the court, was expelled last June by the headteacher at the school in Bromley, south London.

Teachers claimed he had threatened them, assaulted pupils, and was unteachable; all of which he denies.

The governors reinstated the boy in the autumn, against the recommendation of the headteacher. At this point teachers in the second largest teaching union, the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, were balloted for industrial action, and voted not to teach him.

The boy is being taught in isolation at the school by two supply teachers who are not members of the NASUWT.

His mother, who has brought the action, complained that he was not receiving a proper education as he prepared to take his GCSEs this spring. She is asking the high court to declare the industrial action illegal.

Nigel Giffin, counsel for the mother, told Mr Justice Morison that it was not a question of whether the boy did or did not commit any act.

"Whatever the claimant may or may not have done," he said, "it's not for the teachers to usurp the role which parliament has given to the head and governing body, or an independent appeal tribunal."

He argued that industrial action was illegal because it was not related to teachers' terms and conditions of employment.

The NASUWT is adamant that its action constitutes a valid trade dispute, and that there has been no diminution in the service its members provide - as the boy has the benefit of one-to-one teaching.

Mr Justice Morison said he regretted that a matter of this kind had to be resolved in a court of law, and that it had been impossible for the parties to reach agreement among themselves.

Judgment is expected tomorrow, in what will be a landmark ruling for the education service.

Speaking later outside court, a spokesman for the family said the boy was a good, mild mannered student who was keen to complete his education. Due to take eight GCSEs this spring, he was in danger of getting grade Es rather than the Bs and Cs he was expecting.

"It is imperative that he resumes his normal education as soon as possible," the spokesman said, adding that it was difficult for the boy to "express himself".

He said: "Are we saying schools are run by unions and not headteachers and governors? Perhaps in the case of [this] school this may be the case."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the NASUWT, said a principle was at stake.

"The union is defending the right of teachers to refuse to teach pupils who are seriously disruptive and/or violent," he said.

"A crucial principle is at stake. Can teachers be forced by their employers to risk physical assault and outright abuse in the course of their duties?

"NASUWT declares loud and clear that a union has the right to take lawfully balloted industrial action to prevent its members from such danger.

"NASUWT is also defending, by implication, the right of other pupils to receive their education, and to do so free from threats and violence from other children."

webTitle: School at centre of rare TB outbreak

fields.headline: School at centre of rare TB outbreak
fields.standfirst:
Thousands of pupils may have to be screened after health officials say particularly virulent strain of disease is likely to spread rapidly

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Thousands of pupils may have to be screened after health officials say particularly virulent strain of disease is likely to spread rapidly.
fields.body:
A major outbreak of tuberculosis - which may turn out to be one of the biggest in the UK since the disease was brought under control in the 1980s - has been identified at a secondary school in Leicester.

Last night public health officials said 24 cases of TB have been confirmed, 20 of them children at Crown Hills community college and one a teacher. About 700 children, aged 11 to 14, have been screened and of those a further 60 look likely to have been infected with the disease.

"This is a major outbreak," said Gerry Bryant, specialist registrar in public health with Leicestershire health authority. "I'm not aware of a published outbreak of this size in a school. We believe it might be part of a larger community outbreak. It is very difficult to tell at this stage."

Dr Philip Monk, consultant on communicable disease control at the health authority, blamed the outbreak on a particularly virulent strain of the disease that is spreading rapidly.

Thousands of children may potentially have to be screened if it is thought the disease had spread. "We may be looking at six primary schools that feed into Crown Hills community college. That would be 2,000-2,500 pupils as a starting point. Then there are around 3,000 pupils from secondary schools," Dr Monk said.

It is highly unusual to get a significant number of cases in a school because generally, children tend to be infected not by each other but by very close contact with adults, usually members of their family.

There will certainly be more cases to come. Every child and teacher in the school will now be screened. Not every person who develops TB is infectious, but some of the Crown Hills children have proved to be so, and so the disease may well have spread within their families. All those infected have been given the standard course of antibiotic TB treatment, and the 60 who had strongly positive skin-prick tests, indicating likely infection, have been given a shorter course to keep the disease at bay.

The outbreak began when one child in year nine developed TB last August. Ninety-three per cent of the children at the school are of Asian origin and it is possible the child became infected on a visit to India, where TB is endemic. The second case, in October, involving a child in the same class, was discovered when the first child's close contacts were screened. When a third child in the class developed TB last month, it was decided to mount a major screening exercise.

For Gary Coleby, headteacher of the school in inner-city Leicester, the news of the rising numbers is a blow. Its Ofsted report before Christmas said it was one of the best urban schools in the country. And for three years running it has been one of the government's top 200 improving schools. Mr Coleby is trying hard to reassure everyone that it is business as usual.

"The original three children diagnosed have all been treated and are all back at school," he said. "The parents are concerned but they are being kept very closely informed about what is going on and they are involved in the process so they know what is happening. We do have a lot of parental support here and it is now paying dividends.

New strains

"The most important message is that there is no panic and the school is operating absolutely as normal, although with some disruption because of the screening."

Sixty years ago, this outbreak would have been a disaster and a tragedy, because TB was a regular killer, but the BCG vaccination, together with better drug treatment, surveillance and meticulous follow-up of all the contacts of anyone with the infection have made deaths unnecessary.

But nobody takes tuberculosis lightly. The number of cases in the country is rising among people who are born abroad or whose parents were. TB is killing millions in south-east Asia, Africa and eastern Europe - and is frequently the direct cause of death of those whose immune systems have been damaged by HIV.

But what alarms public health officials most is the onward march of new strains of TB which are resistant to the antibiotic drugs most used to treat the disease. Unless the disease can be brought under control elsewhere in the world, increasing numbers of multi drug-resistant TB (MDRTB) cases will arrive in the UK. They are hard - and expensive - to treat. The Crown Hills college outbreak is not MDRTB, but it has arrived from abroad and all the vigilance of the public health officials has not been able to prevent it.

The finger was immediately pointed at the absence of the BCG vaccination programme in schools. Many parents have voiced anxieties at the temporary halt to vaccinations two years ago which was caused by a shortage of vaccine.

Less than two weeks ago, on World TB Day, the government announced that the BCG vaccination programme for schoolchildren would be restarting. In London, which has more TB cases than anywhere else, vaccinations for 13-year-olds have already started again. There is a cohort of children who have been missed, some of whom may be about to leave school and, potentially, travel to countries where TB is endemic. Those, the government has said, will receive a catch-up vaccination in the summer. Government policy is that children born in TB endemic areas, or whose parents or grandparents were born there, should be vaccinated at birth. Those who come to live in the UK should be vaccinated on arrival.

The vast majority of Crown Hills' 1,200 pupils have been protected from TB, but unfortunately the BCG is only 60 to 70% effective and the strain that has hit the school appears to be particularly virulent.

Ironically, what has happened in Leicester underlines the limited usefulness of the schools vaccination programme, which is coming under review in a few years' time and which there may be moves to end.

"There has been discussion in the medical press about how much benefit is achieved by the schools programme," said John Watson, a consultant epidemiologist at the Public Health Laboratory Service. "You have to vaccinate an awful lot of children to prevent a single case of TB. It is not comparable to the childhood vaccination programmes against measles, for instance."

What is TB and how is it spread?

What kind of disease is tuberculosis?

Contagious, caused by a bacteria that attacks the lungs, although it can also target the lymph nodes, bones and occasionally the brain.

How common is it?

It used to be very common in the UK. Known as consumption in Victorian times, it claimed the lives of many poets and writers, notably Keats. There were 50,000 cases a year in the 1940s, which dropped to 5,000 in the late 80s, rising to just below 7,000 now. This is nothing compared to Africa, eastern Europe and south-east Asia. TB makes 8m people a year sick worldwide and kills 2m.

How is it spread?

Through the air, when sufferers cough, spit or sneeze. The sick used to be shut away in sanatoria to recover, or more often die, but current wisdom is that people do not catch it without prolonged close contact. Children, the elderly and the frail or immuno-compromised are at greatest risk. Before pasteurisation, TB could be contracted from milk from cows infected with bovine TB.

Does everybody who comes into contact with TB bacteria get the disease?

No. One third of all people are estimated to carry the bacteria, but only one out of 10 of them will develop TB.

What are the symptoms?

Fever and night sweats, coughing, losing weight and blood in the sputum are some of the main ones. Symptoms usually take months to appear.

Is it treatable?

Yes, thanks to antibiotics. Patients are given a six-month course of four drugs. It is vital to stick to the course, even when the symptoms disappear, or the bacteria lingering dormant in the body will mutate to become resistant to the drugs.

Is that a big problem?

The spread of multi drug-resistant TB (known as MDRTB) is extremely worrying. There are particularly serious problems in the former Soviet Union. The World Health Organisation says MDRTB threatens global control of the disease.

TB makes 8m people a year sick worldwide and kills 2m. How is it spread? Through the air, when sufferers cough, spit or sneeze. The sick used to be shut away in sanatoria to recover, or more often die, but current wisdom is that people do not catch it without prolonged close contact. Children, the elderly and the frail or immuno-compromised are at greatest risk. Before pasteurisation, TB could be contracted from milk from cows infected with bovine TB. Does everybody who comes into contact with TB bacteria get the disease? No. One third of all people are estimated to carry the bacteria, but only one out of 10 of them will develop TB. What are the symptoms? Fever and night sweats, coughing, losing weight and blood in the sputum are some of the main ones. Symptoms usually take months to appear. Is it treatable? Yes, thanks to antibiotics. Patients are given a six-month course of four drugs. It is vital to stick to the course, even when the symptoms disappear, or the bacteria lingering dormant in the body will mutate to become resistant to the drugs. Is that a big problem? The spread of multi drug-resistant TB (known as MDRTB) is extremely worrying. There are particularly serious problems in the former Soviet Union. The World Health Organisation says MDRTB threatens global control of the disease. webTitle: Regime of bullying exposed at abbey school

fields.headline: Regime of bullying exposed at abbey school
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: A regime of bullying and intimidation at Westminster Abbey choir school has been exposed in a confidential report to the school by the local authority.
fields.body:
A regime of bullying and intimidation at Westminster Abbey choir school has been exposed in a confidential report to the school by the local authority.

The 31 page report, a copy of which has been seen by the Guardian, details complaints by parents of pupils and former pupils at the school and undermines attempts by the abbey to claim the school has been the subject of criticisms only by an unrepresentative minority.

It paints a picture of pupils living under a fierce disciplinary regime in which toys were limited, comics and music centres banned and contact with home severely restricted.

The school's headmaster, Roger Overend, was forced out in February after a draft copy of the report, which has since been amended, was shown to the dean of the abbey, Wesley Carr, who is also the school's chairman of governors.

The famous 37 pupil choir school is the only school in the country providing education exclusively for choristers.

But it has recently been racked by controversies beginning with the dean's decision to sack the former organist, Martin Neary, in 1998. It has suffered a recruitment crisis with only four boys attending auditions for up to 12 places.

The report, by Westminster city council's social services department, follows a detailed inspection last autumn, which included 11 visits by a three person team over eight days.

The report warns that significant concerns were raised about the welfare of the children and that a further visit will take place before the end of the summer term.

The school has refused to publish the report, though it has circulated copies to parents.

While acknowledging that most parents were happy with the administration, it said: "A significant number of parents, choristers and staff have raised concerns about the conduct of the headmaster. These concerns included intimidation through shouting, threats, the tape recording of a conversation with a chorister, humiliation through name calling, gestures and actions, inequality in the treatment and use of disciplinary measures applied to individual choristers."

It said these were not isolated incidents and added: "Concerns relating to choristers are roughly proportional to the length of time they have been at the school and have been raised at earlier times with the headmaster and dean."

When the Guardian first published details of parental concerns about the school and Mr Overend's behaviour in December, the abbey claimed the critics were unrepresentative.

It added that social services had been conducting a regular inspection and had not as far as the governors were aware found any case of bullying.

The dean's support for the headmaster was withdrawn two months later when he was called to a meeting and asked to resign.

According to those present at a parents' meeting last week held to discuss the report, Mr Overend, who is the stepfather of two boys at the school, claimed he had effectively been sacked and placed the blame on parents whom he named.

A comment by the school at the end of the report said Mr Overend left for personal reasons and that his resignation was accepted with regret.

The report claimed that Mr Overend had been given too much responsibility over decision making and had been subject to excessive stress. It conceded that educational standards were high.

fields.headline: Kirch dismisses F1 threat
fields.trailText:
4pm: Kirch and EM.TV have dismissed Formula One carmakers' threat to form a breakaway championship. By Dan Milmo.
Mar 1: EM.TV pledges to keep F1 on free-to-air TV
fields.body:
The German media companies at the heart of the Formula One dispute have dismissed the carmakers' threat to form a breakaway championship.

Sources close to Kirch Group and EM.TV, who control the sport's commercial arm, claimed the drastic warning was mere "muscle flexing".

It has also emerged that the companies are willing to offer the irate carmakers a 25% stake in Formula One's commercial operation.

"The teams are flexing their muscles. They want certain things to be made clear about pay-TV, and we are very relaxed about it. There will be a solution to this," said one source.

The big carmakers in Formula One, including Ferrari, McLaren and Williams, have threatened to set up a new championship if Kirch and EM.TV put the popular races on pay-TV.

Formula One teams demand as wide a TV audience as possible in order to plug their products and their backers.

The source said the sport will be kept on free-to-air TV because it will not get enough exposure on premium channels, and the £1.7bn invested in the rights would be wasted.

"Why should we invest that much money in it? Formula One needs audiences, and in Germany alone it is not big enough to make it a successful pay-TV event," said the source.

The source added that the carmakers are contracted to the present championship format until the end of 2007, and setting up a rival event will be a costly and time-consuming task.

"They will not be able to build up a series that quickly, and it will cost so much money. They are just making their points in a very sharp way," said the source.

However, the combined power of Formula One backers Jaguar, Fiat and Ford are unlikely to back down unless they get some form of control in SLEC, the sport's commercial arm.

Kirch and EM.TV now appear to have reached a compromise with their 25% stake offer.

It is well-known the companies were infuriated about the lack of consultation over the SLEC deal, which was brokered by UK tycoon Bernie Ecclestone.

fields.headline: Easter online
fields.standfirst: Don't waste Holy Week trying to sort out Easter eggs for the nephews and nieces: get it over with from your desk or your living room
fields.trailText: Don't waste Holy Week trying to sort out Easter eggs for the nephews and nieces: get it over with from your desk or your living room
fields.body:
There is a massive selection of Easter gifts for kids at Whittard of Chelsea including the non-chocolate variety: the cute daisy bunny and mug set (£20), blue bowl with speckled eggs (£4.75) or the colourful 'paws off my eggs' coaster (£3.50).

Make Easter fun with Whittard's Easter egg hunt kit which includes colourful plastic shells to hide eggs and treats in the garden, bunny markers to give clues, as well as a special prize bunny keyring and various mini eggs (£10). Standard delivery is £2.95 (within five days) and £5.95 (for next day delivery if ordered by 12). They also deliver worldwide and delivery is free for orders over £50.

Woolworths have Easter treats for all ages. Easter bunny ears (£1.99), Easter loot bags (£1.49) and fluffy bunny toys (£9.99). Gain respect from your offspring or siblings with Digimon mini eggs (£1.99).

For grown-up Easter treats how about the Charbonnel et Walker plain chocolate Easter egg (£20) from Whittard of Chelsea. They also have many non-edible gifts such as decorated egg shaped candles (£3.50) and an Easter-themed teapot ('purple eggs in space'- £15.00). For some truly indulgent delectables, how about the Belgian egg (£17.95) with miniature creamy ganache and praline eggs (310g egg with 10 miniature eggs) from ChocExpress or for dark chocolate lovers, the cocoa chic egg filled with hand made dark chocs (£19.95). The Italian traditional orange and almond Easter cake (£22.95) makes for an original gift. ChocExpress offer free three day delivery, nationwide.

Bargains abound at Asda at home where you will find a wide selection of kids' favourites with multibuy discounts. Choose from Cadbury's, Mars, Nestle or Terry's favourites and pick three eggs for £6, with a free delivery on your first Easter order. All subsequent orders of less than £99 incur £3.50 but there is no minimum spend per order.
For your beloved (or their 'beloved' parents) you might need something more reassuringly expensive, such as a selection of Neuhaus finest dark, milk and white chocolate pralines presented in an exclusive Easter ballotin (£27.50) from House of Chocolate.

A good value, sophisticated alternative is the 350g Crown Royale luxury hand made egg, hand wrapped in foil and silk flowers, a snip at £10.00. The site offers UK delivery at £3.95, and reasonable European and worldwide services. The in-laws can't fail to be pleased with a classy Mint Collection Egg delivered by Sainsbury's for £8.99 plus delivery.

If you can't stand the thought of another egg, Groovy chocolate can supply chocolate Easter cards with a choice of edible images from their gallery or your own photos (220g for £9.95). Standard first class delivery within the UK is included and worldwide delivery is available.

Thornton's Easter range is predictably upmarket but with the odd silly soft toy thrown in for the kids. Speciality eggs on offer include 250g dark mint eggs spun with honeycomb pieces (£7 plus postage) and 420g toffee eggs at £6. Children may prefer the milk chocolate rabbit at £2.99. They impressively stock a diabetic egg at £5.50 (all UK deliveries £3.95).
For those on a gluten free, organic, vegan or sugar free diet, Freshfood stock Green and Black's fairly traded chocolate eggs - a bargain at £2.74.

fields.headline: Chronicle of the Dover tragedy
fields.standfirst:
Paul Kelso describes the sad events that led to 58 illegal Chinese immigrants perishing in a container lorry on June 18 last year

Special report: refugees
fields.trailText: Paul Kelso describes the sad events that led to 58 illegal Chinese immigrants perishing in a container lorry on June 18 last year.
fields.body:
The third weekend of June was the hottest of last year. In the UK and across northern Europe temperatures climbed into the high 30s, and in Rotterdam, Holland, the sun beat down on football fans attending Euro 2000.

The great harbour city was still reeling from the party that followed a Dutch victory on Friday evening, and come Sunday June 18 the fine weather was a convenient excuse for more chilled beer. For 60 Chinese illegal immigrants however, huddled in the back of a sealed container lorry in a warehouse in the city's docks, the heat was to prove devastating.

Ke Su Di, 20, was among them. A delivery boy from Fujian, he had left his family home just 11 days previously. His parents had paid a Snakehead smuggling gang £4,000, the first instalment of a £20,000 fee - equivalent to 10 years wages - to get him to the UK.

When he left his head was full of dreams of prosperity, both for himself and his parents. Now, dressed in three layers of clothing to avoid carrying luggage, he squatted in the container and waited for the last leg of the journey to get under way. He can have had no idea that he would be one of only two to leave the lorry alive.

The group had gathered around 2.30 that afternoon, travelling from safehouses to the warehouse in Waalhaven, a section of Rotterdam's harbour. Inside was a white 1995 Mercedes truck hooked up to an 18 metre container, its refrigeration unit long broken.

As well as the 60 Chinese, half a dozen other men were present including a lorry driver and petty criminal called Perry Wacker, who helped the Chinese board the lorry. Had Ke or the others looked up as they climbed into the darkness they might have seen a pink teddy bear, incongruously hanging from the rafters. It would have been the last thing most of them saw clearly, save for the bodies of their colleagues.

Once all 60 were aboard, four containers of water were passed up, and a stack of tomato boxes were loaded by Wacker and others into a specially built frame at the rear of the container.

Using sign language, Wacker pointed out a small vent on the left hand side of the trailer which was to be their only source of light and air. When this was open, he indicated, they should talk only quietly. When it was closed, as it would be at some point, they should remain silent. Then the doors closed.

Shortly before 3pm Wacker climbed into the cab and set out for Zeebrugge. He arrived at the ferry terminal around 6pm, 90 minutes before the ferry was due to depart. At 7pm he was waved forwards to board the European Pathway, a P&O freight-only ferry bound for Dover. The time had come for total secrecy.

Wacker untied the rope with which the air vent had been held open, forced the small door closed, and went in search of his dinner. With this act he sealed his cargo's fate. Inside Ke Su Di saw Wacker's hand reach up, then blackness.

Inside the container the 56 men and four women baked. They discarded layers of clothes until many were bare chested, finished the water then desperately sucked at the tomatoes for moisture.

The stagnant air inside the lorry was slowly turning to carbon dioxide; every breath poisoned the atmosphere. Some inside began to pound the side of the lorry and shout, more interested now in survival than secrecy.

"People began to panic because the window was shut and there was no air," Ke Su Di told Maidstone crown court.

"Some people removed tomatoes and wanted to kick open the doors. There was a lot of shouting and screaming but noone came to help." By the time the European Pathway docked at Dover at 11.30pm everyone but Ke Su Di and Ke Shi Guang, 22, was dead.

The first thing the search team noticed as they swung open the rear doors of the container was the heat. Sensing something wasn't right, a senior officer looked over the tomatoes and shouted into the container, "Hello, hello".

He heard a small noise, then silence. "lllegals, I think they might be in trouble," he called to his colleagues. Two dock workers were summoned and they were the first into the container. One of them, Barry Betts, saw what he thought was a pile of palettes. In fact, it was "a sea of bodies".

As his eyes adjusted to the darkness, he heard moaning and watched as Di and Guang struggled to free themselves from under the weight of the dead. Outside, Wacker stood expressionless, stroking a customs sniffer dog.

 You can read a full version of this article in tomorrow's Guardian.

webTitle: A short history of interactive TV

fields.headline: A short history of interactive TV
fields.standfirst:
Fron Winky Dink to Sky Sports
More net news
fields.trailText: Fron Winky Dink to Sky Sports
fields.body:
1953: A children's television programme called Winky Dink and You, begins the move towards interactive TV. Kids in the US buy a special transparent sheet to place over the screen and, using ordinary crayons, help the show's characters draw things like pathways or tools. The series is discontinued because children begin drawing directly on the TV screen. See www.toonarific. com/w/WinkyDink.html

1959: First use of telephone call-ins during NBC's Today Show.

1964: At&T demonstrates the first video telephone at the New York World's Fair.

1970: BBC technicians use the vertical blanking interval - the space between television frames - to send messages between transmitter sites around the UK. This technology was later developed into teletext. The technicians remain anonymous.

1972: BBC announces Ceefax. ITV announces Oracle.

1974: Ceefax launches.

December 1977: The world's first commercial interactive TV service opens in Ohio. Qube offers 30 channels divided between broadcast TV, pay-per-view and interactive programming. Despite its popularity, it is not a commercial success.

1979: Prestel is launched in the UK. Although designed to be used on TV sets using a special adaptor (with a modem), many users access the service via home computers. First commercially available technology to link the TV with the telephone. See www.prestel.co.uk

November 1988: The BBC broadcasts What's your Story?, a children's TV programme presented by Sylvester McCoy. The show asks viewers to phone in with suggestions of what happens next. The best ideas are then used.

1993: Oracle changes its name to Teletext and uses the Fastext buttons for its quiz, Bamboozle. The buttons enable users to navigate pages more quickly.

1994: Channel Four programme Gamesmaster takes messages from an internet chat room and puts them on to TV via Teletext subtitles. There are delays in the messages appearing on screen so although popular, it only runs for one season. Videotron pilots interactive TV in the south-east. The analogue system allows viewers to choose content and make sports bets. Kellogg's Frosties broadcast an interactive ad.

April 1996: BT runs an interactive TV trial in Ipswich and Colchester. Interactive ads for Walkers Crisps allow viewers to play a quiz, watch the 10 greatest goals or play a spot-the-bag game.

June 1996: Television Par Satellite becomes the first broadcaster to launch digital interactive services fully. Rival Canal+ follows suit.

October 1998: Sky Digital launches its 140-channel service via satellite. The handset gives access to TV guides on screen, though customers wait a year before the interactive shopping service Open is available.

March 1999: NTL launches a trial interactive TV service.

July 1999: Cable & Wireless signs 10,000 subscribers. The interactive services allow access to a range of websites. C&W is now part of NTL. Two-Way TV launches its games and quiz service.

August 1999: Interactive football makes its debut on Sky Digital. Viewers of the Arsenal v Manchester United game can view highlights during the game, access statistics and select different camera angles.

September 2000: ONdigital launches ONnet, a system that it says allows full internet access via a set-top box.Sky's first interactive ad, for Domino's Pizza.

Autumn 2000: Telewest's Active Digital shopping platform finally goes live after being launched nearly a year before. Services to be rolled out in 2001 include video on demand. NTL rolls out its internet TV service.

March 2001: The Advertising Standards Authority rules that an ONdigital ad "misleadingly exaggerated" its claim that its interactive TV service offered "full internet access".

April 2001: Newham Council in east London announces plans to issue set top boxes to council tenants to report faults.

webTitle: Councils make headway in care trusts row

fields.headline: Councils make headway in care trusts row
fields.trailText: Local authorities are claiming a victory in their bid to stop the NHS taking over community services, following government concessions on care trust proposals.
fields.body:
Local authorities are claiming a victory in their bid to stop the NHS taking over community services, following government concessions on care trust proposals.

The Local Government Association (LGA) says amendments to the health and social care bill, allowing councils to nominate local trust board members, are "very positive". The move should assure local authorities a voice in the way adult care services are delivered in the future.

"Local authorities are democratically accountable organisations. We can't allow these services to be dictated by the NHS," said an LGA spokesperson. "We are very pleased."

Health minister John Hutton confirmed the changes in a meeting with the LGA on Tuesday, after a coalition of local government organisations and charities threatened to campaign for care trusts to be removed from the bill.

Councils have voiced concerns that care trusts - NHS bodies that will provide health and social care services for adults - will herald a health service takeover of social services, rather than a partnership.

Under the new proposals, councils will be able to nominate members to serve on care trusts' governing boards. Health and social services will decide locally the number of local authority places for each care trust.

The LGA said it had been reassured that the nominees would not just be a token minority on a health care trust board. During the bill's second reading in the Lords, health minister Lord Hunt said: "We want to see governance arrangements for care trusts include a minimum number of local authority members which reflect the wishes of local partners within a flexible national framework."

But the LGA said the lines of accountability for local authority services delegated to any care trusts had still to be resolved.

The bill had been due to go to report stage in the House of Lords today but has now been postponed until after Easter.

fields.headline: Carlton tries to poach Gavin
fields.trailText:
10.45am: BBC Worldwide boss Rupert Gavin is being eyed up by Carlton Communications for its vacant head of content job, writes Jason Deans.

Click here for latest BBC news
fields.body:
BBC Worldwide boss Rupert Gavin is being eyed up by Carlton Communications for its vacant head of content job.

It is believed he is top of the "love list" of candidates the company has drawn up as a possible new head of content.

The job was created last year as part of the streamlining that led to the dramatic departure of Lord Alli.

Insiders at the ITV giant have confirmed they are poised to approach the former BT executive who is believed to have clashed with BBC director general Greg Dyke.

Carlton Communications refused to comment on the reports that emerged at MipTV in Cannes this week.

A BBC Worldwide spokeswoman said: "There have been no talks between Rupert Gavin and Carlton."

It is said Mr Gavin's relationship with Mr Dyke has become strained over deciding the future strategy for BBC Worldwide.

Mr Dyke is said to want a greater say in how Worldwide operates, while under previous director general Sir John Birt Mr Gavin was used to more autonomy.

The director general is thought to believe the public service part of the BBC should have more say in how its programming rights are exploited commercially, rather than simply handing the rights over to Worldwide and letting it get on with it.

Mr Dyke is also understood to want to cut Worldwide's overheads to increase its profitability.

The future direction of the BBC's commercial arm is being thrashed out as part of a review that was due to have been completed earlier this year.

One cost-cutting option said to be under consideration is to scrap Worldwide's global marketing brand development division, which is headed by Jeff Taylor.

GMBD was set up in 1998 to introduce a more multimedia, marketing led approach to exploiting BBC brands around the globe.

The division can point to successes such as Teletubbies and Tweenies.

But critics argue that outside children's programmes there are relatively few properties that have the potential to become Teletubbies-style cross-media and merchandising blockbusters.

They believe the multimedia marketing operation should be scaled back to concentrate on children's properties.

In other areas, it is thought Worldwide may revert to its old system of organising its activities into TV distribution, publishing and merchandising licensing.

The review is expected to be completed by May.

In the longer term, Mr Dyke is also thought to be considering turning Worldwide into more of a licensing operation, farming activity such as making toys and publishing books based on BBC programmes to third parties.

This is another point of difference with Mr Gavin, who has favoured expanding Worldwide's activities, into making Tweenies toys for instance.

webTitle: Bergkamp ruled out of FA Cup semi-final

fields.headline: Bergkamp ruled out of FA Cup semi-final
fields.trailText: Dennis Bergkamp has been ruled out of Sunday's FA Cup semi-final with Tottenham at Old Trafford.
fields.body:
Dennis Bergkamp has been ruled out of Sunday's FA Cup semi-final with Tottenham at Old Trafford.

Bergkamp missed last Saturday's 2-0 Premiership win over Spurs after damaging an achilles tendon and was not fit for last night's Champions League clash with Valencia.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger said: "The scans on his foot do not look too bad but he still has pain and he won't be playing on Sunday. I fear he could also be short for our league game at Manchester City on Wednesday."

Wenger is likely to start with Thierry Henry and Sylvain Wiltord against Tottenham. Cameroon midfielder Lauren, left out last night, could also be recalled with match-winner Ray Parlour moving to the right.

However, Wenger was keeping his cards close to his chest, saying: "If there are any changes they will only be a few touches."

Meanwhile, Henry has warned Spurs that Arsenal have no plans to concentrate solely on Europe - and are determined to win Sunday's match.

He said: "The Champions League is out of the way now and this semi-final is going to be a special game. Our confidence is high and we will be just as determined on Sunday as we were against Valencia.

"Tottenham might hope we are more focused on Europe, but this is just as big a game for us," he added.

Henry, who scored in his last two matches for Arsenal, has urged his team-mates to turn their current good run of form into trophies.

"I am scoring goals again and I feel I have regained my fitness," he said. "A month ago my legs felt heavy and I couldn't make the runs I wanted to make, but now I feel sharp again and I think I look sharp on the pitch. But people will not remember that - they remember teams that win things."

"I want to win something for Arsenal," he added. "I came here to win trophies, I haven't done that yet so the semi-final of the FA Cup represents a great opportunity for me and the team."

Henry is under no illusions, however, about the size of the task still facing Arsenal in their challenge for a Champions League semi-final place.

Although Valencia have lost three times at home to Barcelona, Real Madrid and, most recently, Espanyol this year they are still unbeaten in 16 consecutive Champions League ties in the Mestalla Stadium.

"It is not finished yet because they have scored an away goal which makes it very tough for us. But equally it will be tough for them as well," said Henry.

"We know we will have to defend well but if we can do that we are capable of doing something on the counter-attack."

webTitle: Preventing the selection of victims from behind bars

fields.headline: Preventing the selection of victims from behind bars
fields.standfirst: An award-winning project is using prison officer skills to identify offenders who pose a risk to children - even while they're still in jail
fields.trailText: Feature: An award-winning project is using prison officer skills to identify offenders who pose a risk to children - even while they're still in jail. Martin McNamara reports.
fields.body:
The father of a convicted sex offender was bringing the prisoner's child into jail for a family visit. Only the minor was not the prisoner's son but a child brought in simply for the prisoner to molest during visits.

This real-life case highlights an ongoing problem in the treatment of sex offenders; many prisoners are using their time inside to "groom" future victims. Now a project, jointly organised by the child protection charity, the NSPCC, and Wandsworth prison, has been hailed as a way forward in stopping sex offenders using their time in prison to plan future crimes.

"There have been a relatively small number of children abused while visiting prisoners," said Stephen Landy, NSPCC manager of the project at Wandsworth prison. "But prisons are not the most child-friendly environments, and it is important that the children who are there are who they are supposed to be and are safe."

The only minors allowed into prison to visit "schedule one" prisoners - that is those convicted of a crime against a child - are the prisoners' own children. But how are prison staff supposed to know if children brought in as visitors are who they claim to be?

At Wandsworth, the project has set up a system of checks so a visiting child is identified correctly. The children are also digitally photographed, so that, on future visits, prison officers can check it is the same child. "But we try to do all this in a way that will not upset the child," said Mr Landy.

Sex offenders find ways to continue their trade behind bars, from building relationships with single mothers through lonely hearts adverts in magazines, to linking up with other jailed sex offenders to form paedophile rings. This is information prison officers could pick up in their day-to-day work with the prisoners, but would be hard in many cases for child protection social workers in the community to pick up on.

Traditionally prison officers have not had much part to play in the risk assessment of prisoners. Mr Landy believes this is a waste of a valuable resource. The project has introduced a post of designated child protection officer inside the prison walls - a rarity in British prisons. The post has been filled by a prison officer.

"I don't think you should underestimate the potential worth of prison officers in child protection," said Mr Landy. "One of the really exciting things about this project has been tapping into the enthusiasm and creativity that prison officers have been able to put into this work."

A recent example of the project's work was the case of a father who was convicted of assaulting two of his children. While still in prison, the man had begun putting pressure on his third child. "Part of our job is helping prison officers identify the subtle stuff," said Mr Landy. "It's the kind of 'daddy will buy you a bike if you are good' coercion that prison officers sometimes miss."

Prison officer Paul Wright, principal officer of the project in Wandsworth, said stereotypical images of prison officers have meant they are rarely consulted on the assessment of offenders. "We've got so much knowledge and that's been overlooked," he said.

When the scheme started nearly two years ago, some in social services were, said Mr Wright, "sceptical of our involvement. Now they realise prison officers have a part to play in child protection."

There are more than 200 men convicted of sex offences against children in Wandsworth prison. "When you've got that number of sex offenders in one place, there is an awful lot of information sloshing around," said Mr Landy.

Part of the job of the project is helping prison officers pick up and recognise that information and, just as importantly, pass it on to the relevant child protection agencies.

"Our main achievement is that we have encouraged prison officers to communicate with social services departments," said Mr Landy. "Prison officers have become part of the child protection system."

Earlier this month, the project won the Lord Woolf award from the Butler Trust, which recognises creative work undertaken in the prison service.

Mr Landy praised the governor of Wandsworth for recognising the potential of the project but is campaigning for the same practices to get taken up in institutions around the country. "Prison governors are required to protect children," he said. "Unfortunately, how it's done across the prison system is very piecemeal. There are other prison establishments where it just isn't happening."

webTitle: Belgium government mounts legal challenge to M&S

fields.headline: Belgium joins battle against M&S closures
fields.standfirst:
M&S face legal challenge from Belgium government over closures

Guardian Unlimited Shopping
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer's troubles in mainland Europe deepened last night after it emerged that the Belgian government is, like the French, considering legal action over its store closure programme.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer's troubles in mainland Europe deepened last night after it emerged that the Belgian government is, like the French, considering legal action over its store closure programme.

The fact that M&S chairman Luc Vandevelde is a Belgian counts for little with the country's employment minister, Laurette Onkelinx, who has al ready asked officials to check whether the retailer has broken employment laws.

Under Belgian law, employers are supposed to give good notice of closure plans to trade unions and work councils in advance of taking a decision. Workers at Belgium's four M&S stores learned that they were to lose their jobs only through the press.

The firm's store in Brussels on the busy Rue Neuve, a pop ular drop-in point for homesick expats, has only recently been refurbished, and employees were shocked to learn at such short notice that it was to be shut.

Its ready supply of chicken tikka sandwiches and new world wines had won it a following among the locals but that affection has now given way to anger.

On Tuesday, workers at the M&S store in Liège staged a half-day strike to protest at the closures and trade unionists say that if the government does not take legal action against M&S, they will.

"Marks & Spencer is only closing its [continental] outlets to swell its shareholders' dividends," said Claude Roufosse, a union official. "Our lawyers are studying the file and if a national lawsuit isn't brought then we'll launch an action."

M&S's sudden announcement last Thursday of its plans to close its mainland European operations with the loss of 3,350 jobs was met with incredulity and outrage across the region.

French prime minister Lionel Jospin said the manner in which the closure was announced was "unacceptable", and suggested the retailer might have broken French employment law, which is very similar to Belgian legislation.

fields.headline: The virtual MIT
fields.trailText: All of the university's lecture notes, reading lists and assignments will be available for free online within the next two years.
fields.body:
One of the world's leading universities is to place its course materials free on the internet.

The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has announced a $100m plan to provide most of the content for all its courses for free on the internet for the next 10 years. From lecture notes to reading lists, assignments to syllabuses, people will have access to 500 of MITs 2,000 course materials within two years.

There are only two virtual universities in the world - Athabasca in Canada and another in Finland. However, e-learning has been adopted widely by business schools as the preferred medium for distance learning.

The UK's e-University project last week appointed a holding company to oversee their project to mount online courses from British universities to students worldwide. The initiative is expected to cost £200m.

The MIT project, called OpenCourseWare, is rather different, providing source material rather than interactive courses. But MIT President Charles Vest called it a bold move that would change the way the web is used in higher education. "We see it as source material that will support education worldwide, including innovations in the process of teaching and learning itself."

Subjects across the MIT curriculum spectrum, including architecture and planning, arts, engineering, humanities, social sciences and management, will feature on the site.

The University of California, Los Angeles, has plans for a similar site, but on a more ambitious scale. Professor Steven Lerman, chairman of the MIT faculty, said that both projects stemmed from concern over the growing "privatisation of knowledge." He noted that many universities, including MIT, see the internet as a means of delivering revenue-generating distance education. "We need to take advantage of the tremendous power of the internet to build on the tradition at MIT and in American higher education of open dissemination of educational materials and innovations in teaching."

However some academics at MIT are critical of what they see as a half-hearted step towards distance education. John Williams, an associate professor of engineering systems, said people would compare the web pages with "richer distance education products" offered by other universities and companies.

"I view it unfortunately as being disembodied content missing the richness of the lecturer, the instructor and the students - all of which make up an MIT course - and not just the raw content," he said.

However, most feel it will offer great advantages to academics worldwide, especially for developing countries trying to develop their higher education systems. For the individual, the materials will be useful for self-study or as additional information for assignments at other institutions.

John Williams, an associate professor of engineering systems, said people would compare the web pages with "richer distance education products" offered by other universities and companies. "I view it unfortunately as being disembodied content missing the richness of the lecturer, the instructor and the students - all of which make up an MIT course - and not just the raw content," he said. However, most feel it will offer great advantages to academics worldwide, especially for developing countries trying to develop their higher education systems. For the individual, the materials will be useful for self-study or as additional information for assignments at other institutions.

fields.headline: Yahoo! to launch MusicNet rival
fields.trailText:
4.45pm: Yahoo! has grabbed a lifeline by teaming up with Vivendi Universal and Sony to offer music over the web. By Dan Milmo.
Apr 2: Music giants join forces to rival Napster
fields.body:
Ailing Internet giant Yahoo! has grabbed a lifeline by teaming up with Vivendi Universal and Sony to offer music over the web.

Yahoo! has been reeling from a dire profit warning and a series of management resignations, but today's deal has provided some much-needed relief.

The company's shares rose 25% in early trading in New York after it confirmed that it would distribute the Duet music service co-owned by Vivendi Universal and Sony.

Duet will be a direct rival to the MusicNet venture launched by AOL Time Warner, EMI, Bertelsmann and Real Networks earlier this week.

Vivendi and Sony provide nearly 40% of the world's music sales, and Yahoo!'s massive customer base will give the companies access to millions of music fans worldwide.

Today's deal means that the world's five largest music companies have signed up to services designed to counter rogue internet sites such as Napster and Gnutella.

The deal also marks Vivendi's first major US distribution deal.

Related story

webTitle: Councils 'spend too much on asylum seekers'

fields.headline: Councils 'spend too much on asylum seekers'
fields.trailText: Councils across the country could be spending too much on housing asylum seekers, a report from the government's local authority spending watchdog claims. Simon Parker reports.
fields.body:
Councils across the country could be spending too much on housing asylum seekers, a report from the government's local authority spending watchdog claims.

Ministers currently set a maximum payment for every asylum seeker who is housed by a local council. The audit commission says this system means that authorities in areas with cheap accommodation can afford to pay above market rates, and have no incentive to cut their costs.

Councils in more expensive areas such as London, meanwhile, are left out of pocket because they are forced to pay out more than they claim back from ministers. In 1999-2000, authorities had to find more than £30m from their own budgets.

The government recently upped the amount it pays to some authorities in London and the south-east to house asylum seeker families, but the commission is calling on ministers to go further by linking compensation levels to local rents.

This is likely to hike up compensation levels in the south-east, where asylum seekers are concentrated, while lowering them in the rest of the country.

Commission controller Andrew Foster said: "Some councils, mostly in London, have not always been properly reimbursed for the costs of supporting the growing number of asylum seekers. Recent announcements that London boroughs will be able to claim more are very welcome.

"We have also discovered that some councils have not been as economical as they could have been in supporting asylum seekers, and we question whether some areas have been able to claim too much."

Accommodation costs account for about two-thirds of the costs of supporting asylum seekers, many of whom are placed in temporary private sector accommodation because of a lack of council housing.

At present, most authorities can claim up to £140 a week for adult asylum seekers, and £240 for families. The amount available for families was last month raised to £350 for the London boroughs, Slough and Oxfordshire.

Since last April, much of the responsibility for dealing with new asylum seekers has passed to the Home Office's national asylum support service, but councils are still shouldering a share of the burden in a wide range of cases.

Sir Robin Wales, chairman of the Association of London Government, said: "London boroughs continue to support 64,060 single adults, families and unnaccompanied asylum seeking children who arrived before these new arrangements were introduced to accommodate asylum seekers."

The audit commission's findings are based on an examination of the work of 12 councils in England and Wales.

fields.headline: New Media Markets
fields.standfirst: Publication date: April 5
fields.trailText: April 5: Orange is setting up a wireless games publisher in a concerted attack on the market.
fields.body:
Orange is setting up a wireless games publisher in a concerted attack on the market.

The government's decision to include UniChem in pilot schemes trailing the electronic transmission of NHS prescriptions has reawakened fears over the security of online medical information.

Ogilvy Interactive has lost Michael Phillips, its head of viral marketing. He has left to launch his own marketing and technology consultancy.

The government is to set up a taskforce to lead the fight against the growing problem of child porn on the internet.

Internet sales houses may face a challenge for future business as AOL pushes ahead with plans to sell advertising opportunities outside its network.

fields.headline: 'Hoof and mouth' blights tourism
fields.standfirst: But the reason Americans aren't planning holidays in the UK could also be due to the US stock market collapse, says Jane Martinson
fields.trailText: But the reason Americans aren't planning holidays in the UK could also be due to the US stock market collapse, says Jane Martinson in New York.
fields.body:
Some people pay more attention to the cartoons in the New Yorker than the magazine's fine writing. Which is a pity for the UK government and tourist authority.

In this week's edition is a drawing of an obviously sceptical pair of Americans, sitting in a travel agency. Pointing to an enticing poster for a European holiday, a desperate looking agent says: "It's as beautiful as the poster, except, of course, no more cows."

The downturn in the number of Americans wanting to visit the UK because of the foot and mouth outbreak is no laughing matter for Britain's tourism industry. Americans are by far the most numerous and high spending of visitors to the UK. Last year, four million of them managed to contribute £2.5bn to the national purse.

Government and business officials have blamed the media, of course, for whipping up hysteria about the disease and causing bookings to slow. Artistically gruesome pictures of slaughtered cattle did cover the front pages of the New York Times, USA Today and other leading newspapers just as Americans were busy planning this summer's trips across the Atlantic after all.

Ann Litt, the head of Undiscovered Britain, a specialist agency in Philadelphia, says that a lot of the coverage has sensationalised the problem. One client phoned from the airport to say it felt like the black plague and he was worried about getting off at the other end. "I told him humans can't even get it and it was ok," she says.

There have been a rash of scare stories about crisis Britain. These have ranged from daily news reports to long winded musings about the symbolic nature of cud chewers, and how the disease is really a symptom of a canker in the colonial corpse. In spite of this, however, the impact on business so far has been limited. Very few Americans have actually cancelled their trips to the UK although bookings are down on last year's record number.

Only one man has blamed the disease for cancelling a deluxe $15,000 (£10,400) trip with Ms Litt's agency. His holiday involved residence at the best hotels in London and Edinburgh and a chauffeured car but no walks in the country.

However, he became irate at the thought of Stonehenge being closed by the time of his planned arrival in the UK - September - so he cancelled. "He said he had read an article in the weekend travel section of USA Today and accused me of sending him someplace unsafe," said Ms Litt.

Her other customers - she sends several hundreds Americans all over the UK every year - have all been satisfied once she has explained how much of Britain is still open. "Britain has so much to offer," she says, and her customers seem to listen.

When all else fails, Ms Litt, an American, invokes the special relationship. "I think Britain really needs the support of American travellers, and we should be there for our friends," she says.

The British tourist authority in New York has also stepped up its efforts to entice tourists by upgrading its website over the past two weeks. Travelbritain.org has a special update on "hoof and mouth".

Indeed, Robert Titley at the authority believes that using the American term for the disease would have prevented so many callers asking whether they eat meat or drink milk in the UK. "People think of feet as affecting humans," he says.

While all this furore over a livestock disease has upset the tourism industry, the real cause for the slowdown in bookings this year is likely to be far less graphic.

Most travel agents in the New York area said that clients were cancelling trips because of the collapse of the US stock market. Last week's plunging stock prices wiped billions of dollars from the net worth of many Americans. "A lot of people feel nervous about spending $10,000 on a holiday just now," says Ms Litt.

Including the joys of Cumbria and Stonehenge is unlikely to ease such uncertainty.

fields.headline: Diary of a hypochondriac
fields.trailText: Something is going on in my throat, and I don't like it. I noticed the obstruction, to the right of the Adam's apple, a few weeks ago while re-reading John Diamond's book, C: Because Cowards Get Cancer Too, after he died.
fields.body:
Friday: Something is going on in my throat, and I don't like it. I noticed the obstruction, to the right of the Adam's apple, a few weeks ago while re-reading John Diamond's book, C: Because Cowards Get Cancer Too, after he died.

Saturday: The psychosomatic explanation is too obvious and yet, in my mind's eye, I see a sentence from the obituary: "Norman first noticed his cancer in March 2001," it reads, "but, irony of ironies, mistakenly believed it was a psychosomatic reaction to the death from throat cancer of his friend John Diamond. It was this unwonted reticence about seeking medical advice, his doctor, Sarah Jarvis, suspects, that cost him his life."

Sunday: Sorely troubled night gives way to fractious morning. "You're not worrying about your throat again, surely," says Rebecca as she scrapes the seeds from her melon. "Don't tell me that's why you keep pushing that chopstick down your throat?" "Not at all," I tell her. "That's because I've mislaid half a Peking duck, and thought it might be in my throat."

She is rising from the table now. "And a bowl of hoi sin sauce," I continue, and am poised to mention the pancakes when the butter dish hits the floor and I head robotically for dustpan and brush.

Monday: One amazing thing about the human mind is that, when it comes to aping real symptoms of real illness, there is little it cannot do. My first serious health scare came at the age of 20 when, after being reminded that I was born with systolic murmur (a hole in the heart), I concluded that the organ was failing and needed replacement. I spent the next 12 months in torment, too petrified to see a doctor despite constant pain in the chest and left shoulder and numbness in the left arm. All classic cardiac symptoms, of course, like the oedema on my left ankle. Only when I began breakfasting on neat whisky did I go to my then GP Sonia Robinson at the Jackson's Lane surgery in Highgate. She listened to my heart, had me run up and down some stairs, declared me in perfect health and asked if I might consider talking to a therapist.

Within an hour the pain and numbness had vanished. A week later, the ankle swelling had gone too. I never did see that therapist.

Tuesday: The obstruction continues to come and go. It comes when I remember it, and goes when I forget. I am blissfully unaware of it, then I recall the blockage and am terrorised by the sensation of malignant cells pulsating away.

Wednesday: For the first time in months on my own account (I have been in touch regarding a boy of my acquaintance) I call the Grove clinic to learn that the first appointment is not until tomorrow at 5.30pm, and with an unfamiliar name. "This Dr Thompson," I ask the receptionist, "Where did he do his training? How long has he ... Hello??"

Thursday: I am inspecting the pictures of Mr Tony Blair's visit to the Grove when I am called to room 23. It is years since I saw a new doctor and I am keen not to alarm him when he asks after the problem.

"Oh, just a spot of throat cancer," I say. Dr Thompson, a friendly chap of much my own age and half the weight, seems startled. Why would I assume something so drastic, he inquires, instead of a sore throat or virus? It is my turn to look baffled.

He then examines the lymph nodes, none of which are enlarged, and looks down my throat, in which he sees nothing unusual. "The thing about this," he begins, "is that it's probably psychosomatic." I interrupt: "And what if it isn't?" He asks if I've ever considered that I might tend towards hypochondria. The theory has occurred, I reply. He asks me to return in 10 days if I'm still worried. As I head for the car, I swallow carefully and it's still there. Like General MacArthur and Mohammed Ali, it seems, I shall return.

fields.headline: Sarah Boseley
fields.standfirst: On whether we should be recording consultations with doctors, and the pros and cons of taking HRT
fields.trailText: On whether we should be recording consultations with doctors, and the pros and cons of taking HRT.
fields.body:
Can you imagine it? You arrive at the hospital, torn between dread and hope, to discuss with the consultant whether he or she thinks your Down's syndrome baby is suitable for heart surgery. There will have been examinations and tests and finally you are there, sitting across the table with your stomach churning waiting for the verdict. Then somebody - perhaps a nurse, perhaps the consultant - puts a tape recorder on the table and turns it on.

This is the recommendation of the inquiry into the treatment of Down's syndrome children at the Royal Brompton hospital in London. The inquiry found that doctors who declined to operate to mend the holes in the hearts of Down's children had not meant to discriminate against them, but that in failing to go the extra mile and pursue all the options for them, that was effectively what they did.

The parents have been outraged. So hurt and appalled are they that tape recording consultants - to get the evidence if there is bias or a bad judgment - must feel like a good idea. If only they had secreted a machine in a jacket pocket, there would have been no argument. Perhaps they could have got the guilty party sacked. That's how you feel when things have gone wrong. Some of the parents whose babies were sent for heart surgery at the Bristol Royal Infirmary and did not survive, at a time when some doctors were aware that the hospital's success rates were unacceptably low, may feel the same.

But what does that tape-recorder on the table do to the conversation between consultant and parent? It puts a barrier of suspicion between them. That tape says that the patient does not trust the doctor. It may also come to say that the doctor does not trust the patient. It's a step further towards the sort of litigation culture that prevails in the US. The doctor is not going to have a full and frank conversation with the parent - he or she is going to say what they know they can defend in court.

The sort of "key consultations" the inquiry report has in mind are emotional affairs and they need to be. Parent and doctor both usually care passionately about the fate of the child. That needs to be let out. There has to be trust and there has to be an exchange of feelings. How will that happen with the tape going round and round and somebody occasionally checking to make sure the red recording light is still on?

Tape recorders are the tools of the police interview. They are not suitable for the consulting room. But the fact that an inquiry can think they might be is a devastating indictment of the state we are in. Huge improvements in communication need to be made and trust in doctors needs to be rebuilt. More openness is needed, less paternalism and encouragement to parents and patients who want a second opinion. Tape recorders will make many doctors shut up like clams. They are not the answer.

To HRT or not to HRT. The question becomes increasingly difficult. A recent study has shown that women who take hormone replacement therapy in the shape of oestrogen for 10 years have an increased risk of ovarian cancer. In fact, their death rate from it was twice that of women who had not taken oestrogen.

But the numbers are still small. The Cancer Prevention Study in the US recruited 1.2m women, of whom 944 had died within a decade from ovarian cancer. But it's a particularly nasty cancer because survival chances are not good.

This isn't the only risk now recognised in taking HRT. Taking oestrogen alone, without progestin, increases the risk of endometrial cancer - cancer of the lining of the womb. It can also lead to bloodclots and gallstones. Last year it was also found that taking combinations of hormones for several years increases the risk of breast cancer.

But there are health advantages to taking HRT. Not only does it relieve the menopausal symptoms of hot flushes and sleep disturbances, but oestrogen can help prevent the bone-thinning of osteoporosis. Several studies have found that it also reduces deaths from heart disease.

So what should women of a certain age do? It's a tough one. The official line is that they should weigh up the risks and benefits of their own case, but there will always be an element of uncertainty. It's not a good situation for the anxiety-prone.

The latest study from the US may increase women's alarm, but at least it is good to know that the effects of HRT are still being studied. Huge numbers of women are now taking it, but as with any long-term medication, they are effectively taking part in an experiment. It may be as well to remember that.

Huge numbers of women are now taking it, but as with any long-term medication, they are effectively taking part in an experiment. It may be as well to remember that.

fields.headline: Marathon man
fields.trailText: They always say if you start dreaming in a foreign language you can call yourself truly fluent. Well, I woke up running the other morning, my legs cycling under the duvet, my arms flashing around, powering me to my imaginary finish line.
fields.body:
They always say if you start dreaming in a foreign language you can call yourself truly fluent. Well, I woke up running the other morning, my legs cycling under the duvet, my arms flashing around, powering me to my imaginary finish line. Running lying down, like an overturned beetle.

Maybe it's a good sign. Less than 17 days to go to the marathon and I've become a professional. And in a crazy way it got me thinking - if I win the marathon I will pocket £40,000. Break the world record as well and I'd get around £91,000. It's not a bad incentive to give up journalism and train for the rest of my life. And I'm not without some natural talent. I have memories of sprinting the 100 metres at school in less than 15 seconds.

My fantasy is cut short. I remember a conversation I had a few weeks ago with Bud Baldaro, an English teacher at a Midlands school who doubles up as one of Britain's best running consultants. He put my achievement into perspective.

He told me the men's winner of last year's London Marathon, Antonio Pinto, crossed the line in a time of 2:06:36. Pinto ran 26.2 miles - about 42,150 metres - in just over 126 minutes. Effectively he ran the 100 metres in 18 seconds, 421 and a half times - back to back, no stopping, no rest.

I shall not despair. Instead I'm concentrating on the big day and what it will bring. I open a helpful marathon fact pack to learn strange things. Apparently there will be 68 ambulances on standby during the race, plus 500 stretchers. For reasons discussed last week 88lbs of petroleum jelly will be available on the course (recap: nipples, rubbing). There will also be 710,000 bottles of water and 120,000 packs of a branded isotonic drink.

But most interesting is that a 26.2-mile line will be marked on the road using 300 litres of paint. It will take me past 76 pubs and when I cross the finishing line I will stagger into a happy nest of 34,000 sandwiches - some of them cheese - made for the runners. What a dream.

webTitle: Jon Bryant on trying to get treatment for his back pain

fields.headline: Watch your back
fields.standfirst: Jon Bryant has just resorted to spinal surgery after three years of trying every treatment he could find for back pain. But why, he asks, did his GP, physio and many alternative specialists not compare notes?
fields.trailText: Jon Bryant has just resorted to spinal surgery after three years of trying every treatment he could find for back pain. But why, he asks, did his GP, physio and many alternative specialists not compare notes?
fields.body:
I am slowly recovering from a lumbar laminectomy - the partial removal of a disc from the lower spine. The surgeon visited me every day, while I was in hospital, to look at my impressive sacral scar. He hoped he had carried out an operation to cure me. It was, for me, the last resort after three years of back problems; but for the man who was in the room next door, it had been 15 years of excruciating pain.

Perhaps I have wimped out too early. No one seems to think back surgery is a good idea except the surgeons themselves.

My problem was that none of the people I saw about my back ever spoke to each other. It was not that there was a communication wall between private and public healthcare or a thick beanstalk between conventional and alternative medicine. There was simply no dialogue, and so each new referral felt like going back to the beginning.

It all started nearly three years ago, when I was on holiday in Portugal and woke up with slight back ache. It is not unusual to have back pain from soft hotel beds, so I carried on lifting the cases, driving and dancing. However, that slight lumbar tension worsened when I returned home, so I went to see a physiotherapist.

She did the usual manoeuvring of limbs, knees to chest and lots of massage. The back felt more relaxed, but the tightness and spasms had returned by the next morning. I saw her about 10 times until someone recommended another physiotherapist. I never saw the first one again. She must presume I am better.

Like hairdressers who ask, rather dismissively, who cut your hair last, the new physio was not impressed with her predecessor's exercises. Now it was twisting knees while in the crucifix position and more violent clicks of my hips. After several unsuccessful sessions I returned to my GP who then sent me away for an x-ray. It was confirmed that I had early-onset osteoarthritis of the spine. Put simply, this means that the cartilages of the joint and bone begin to wear away - along with any hopes I have of improving .

The prescribed tablets made no difference. The pain in my back grew more severe and my legs ached, so I went to see a homeopath. He diagnosed compression of the lower spine and gave me comfrey tea as well as drops of alchemilla after every meal. I woke up the next day with no pain at all. Alternative medicine was the answer. I toasted myself with a glass of comfrey tea, but the pain returned the following afternoon.

I went to see the homeopath again. He clicked my neck and gave me some glucosamine, more drops and some very expensive Chinese tablets. The pain and muscular spasms were worse than ever. I never saw him again, except on the television. I don't know if he thinks he cured me.

Next on the consultation trail was a specialist in cranial osteopathy. While treating me, she said she could see a white dog dancing at my feet. Then a masseuse came to the house. She covered me in extract of St John's wort. I had to take all my clothes off which rather shocked my wife.

The following week, now finding it difficult to move, I returned to more conventional medicine with a visit to a renowned lumbar specialist. He diagnosed ankylosing spondylitis, a severe arthritis of the spine, but he suggested I had a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan at a private clinic. He declined my offer of speaking to the physio or the osteo or the homeopath.

The scan revealed that I had a large centrally-prolapsed disc between vertebrae L4 and 5. He was pleased with the diagnosis and said that a couple of sessions at a good physiotherapist should do it. If not, I might have to consider keyhole surgery. I went to his recommended physio, but my legs, by this stage, were almost constantly numb, with tingling sensations in my feet and no feeling in my toes. The sessions consisted of a quick look at my back and 25 minutes of her attempts to salvage a broken relationship on a mobile phone which rang incessantly to the tune of Love Story. I told her I was going on holiday. I do not know if she put a tick by my name.

My GP was also on holiday. The locum doctor was very concerned and could not understand how the osteoarthritis stated on my record card could lead to leg numbness. Did I feel pins and needles in my saddle? I wasn't sure. If I did, I was to call the emergency department immediately. This is the first sign of loss of bladder and bowel control. That night, at about 3am, I felt pins and needles everywhere, in my saddle, my withers, my stirrups and in my cruppers. My wife drove me to another specialist.

At last. He understood about the prolapsed disc. He looked at the MRI scan and told me I would get better, but it would take time. I saw him twice a week for a month or so and then every fortnight for two years. I was more flexible and not in constant pain, but as soon as I began to feel better, I felt worse again.

He was very much against me having an operation, having treated many failures from surgery. When the pain was acute, he advised me to put a cold compress on my back. The previous physio had suggested a hot flannel: the one before that had recommended alternating hot and cold.

In addition, I was having acupuncture once a week for pain management, shiatsu in my lunch breaks, visits to solar ray therapists, reflexologists, spiritual healers and retching on the twice-daily tincture of St John's wort, horsetail, black cohosh, licorice, skullcap and valerian concocted by my herbalist sister.

With this amalgam of remedies, physiotherapy, osteopathy, hot, cold, better, worse, light and darkness, I finally decided to see my first neurosurgeon. Surgeons are doctors of comparatively few words, whose hands shake less when they give you bad news. "You must have an operation," he said. "This prolapse is too severe to resolve in any other way."

I continued with my complementary treatments for several months and saw another surgeon for a second opinion. He looked at the same scans all the others had seen, but claimed my spine was a disaster waiting to happen. He said that I needed an implanted nylon rod, fixed into the base of the spine as well as a discectomy (removal of the offending disc). I just wanted two people to agree, any two people, so decided to see one last neurosurgeon.

The last one agreed with the first one and so I found myself lying in room 26, staring at the cylinders and tubing surrounding my hospital bed. Most of my get well soon cards had infirm animals on them: a frog sucking a large thermometer, a crocodile with a bandage over one eye and rabbit with only one ear.

Illness needs fluffy tails, without the fur: the sick are a grim bunch. Grimmer than that are those who do not get well soon, but who hang around, wincing and snapping at their well-meaning loved-ones.

Where or when did it all go wrong? I really tried everything, NHS and private, alternative and conventional, I even put toothpaste on my back one night and prayed before I went to bed, only to wake up to another day with minted sheets.

My employers have been very supportive and sympathetic, but for the past few years I have been recruited into a new job, one I share with thousands of others: I have had a career in being unwell and it takes up all my time.

I have to ask whether my situation would have been so bad had the main audience of my affliction communicated with each other. They could have held a conference about me at Earl's Court, maybe, with posters of my MRI scans on the wall and flyers detailing the treatments already received.

My GP knows nothing about my operation and must imagine that, when I did not return to see her after the brief consultation in 1999, that I've recovered.

Christopher Columbus went to his death in 1506, believing that he had discovered Asia. She probably wonders why I never returned for a repeat prescription.
