fields.headline: The Hollywood diet
fields.standfirst: We have an unhealthy relationship with food: 40% of British women are on a diet, despite evidence that calorie-counting may well make you fatter in the long term. So is a mag devoted entirely to celebrities and their wacky eating regimes really a good idea?
fields.trailText: We have an unhealthy relationship with food: 40% of British women are on a diet, despite evidence that calorie-counting may well make you fatter in the long term. So is a mag devoted entirely to celebrities and their wacky eating regimes really a good idea?
fields.body:
Celebrity Bodies is 92 pages long, with around 500 words a page. The average number of calories burned whilst reading is one every minute. Reading Celebrity Bodies from cover-to-cover will probably burn up around 18.5 calories, maximum. Indeed the only pounds you're certain to lose through reading this latest publication from the Emap stable are those in the cover price of £1.65.

The magazine's launch, last week, caused uproar. Tessa Jowell, the minister for women dubbed it "grim". From tabloids to broadsheets, everyone was up in arms at the unpalatable concept of an entire magazine devoted to the wacky fitness regimes of the stars. How could any publishing company be so downright irresponsible as to launch a magazine eulogising almost skeletally-thin idols such as Victoria Beckham?

Alison Hall, co-editor, denied that the magazine would encourage unhealthy behaviour. "People want nice bodies and I don't think that it is immoral for us to cater for that," she said. But then yesterday it all got worse: pictures of Geri Halliwell, cover girl on the first edition of Celebrity Bodies, looking frighteningly gaunt on the front page of the Mirror. Proof positive that the diets celebrated in Celebrity Bodies are not a good thing.

Actually, in the flesh, Celebrity Bodies is a bit of a relief. It's a more refreshing read than Zest, or any of the other health and beauty glossies pedalling their wares with the sort of clear-skinned smugness reserved for the over-tofu-ed. A spokeswoman for the British Nutritional Foundation (BNF) remarks on its tongue-in-cheekness. "I think it's good that they've been upfront," she says. And she's right. Celebrity Bodies is tremendously funny.

Seemingly written by a bunch of slightly pudgy wannabes, who maybe eat a Müllerlite yoghurt from time to time, and once flailed around on the living room floor and called it yoga, they'll stick in the odd wry comment - instructing Jennifer Aniston to "push the boat out, girl" when it's claimed that she'll even sometimes allow herself to eat pretzels, in moderation.

But it's true that the mag does give detailed guidance on the gamut of mad celeb diets, from the high-protein, low-carbohydrate "zone" diet favoured by the likes of Jennifer Aniston and Minnie Driver, to the "blood-type"diet followed by actress Martine McCutcheon.

The zone diet involves stuff like sausages and fruit juice for breakfast (no toast, natch), warm chicken salad for lunch and a poached salmon fillet and mixed salad for supper. All pretty yummy-sounding, but in minute quantities, of course. The blood-type diet involves eating only foods which are compatible with your blood type. (Type Os, for example, should steer clear of cabbage. You have been warned.)

Then there's the living food for health diet - a lot of detoxing and salad - and of course the diet which seems to have reduced Geri to matchstick proportions: apparently a macrobiotic diet designed by "yoga guru Kisen", whoever she or he is. It's your run-of-the-mill no-meat, no-dairy, no-caffeine, no-alcohol diet. Brilliant fun. Breakfast might be 100g of porridge, followed by a hearty lunch of pumpkin soup (300ml) and then a tofu stir-fry for dinner. Recipes all included, but if this is all Geri eats, it's hard to see why she's been spotted at meetings of Overeaters Anonymous.

"People know this isn't the way to lose weight," says our spokeswoman for the BNF. "They're unsustainable, you either end up giving up or putting the weight back on."

But is it really true that people know "this isn't the way to lose weight"? There's evidence that dieting doesn't work - that it only leads to a life of dieting, with your weight going up, down, up down - but do young women actually realise this? That simply restricting your calories can mess with your head and appetite for good? In fact, that dieting will probably make you fat?

The statistics suggest an emphatic not: right now around 40% of British women are trying to diet. It's a fair guess that most of them have a pretty unhealthy relationship with food and aren't going to stop dieting when they've squeezed into their Christmas party dresses. And the unpleasant truth is that obsessive dieting of this kind may well damage both their health and their happiness.

Countless studies show that repeated dieting makes you more likely to get heart disease, gallstones, diabetes, anaemia, cancer, and osteoporosis. It can give you lank hair, sallow skin and dull eyes, make you depressed and, crucially, perilously fat.

Last year a study published by the American Psychological Association showed that drastic weight-loss efforts (dieting, exercise, appetite suppressants, laxatives, and vomiting) in teenage girls make them more likely to become obese later in life. Those who don't try to lose weight tend to find it easier keeping off the weight. And recently the American-based National Institutes of Health found that almost 98% of all dieters not only regain the lost weight, but put on more.

In 1995, Oxford University researchers discovered that dieting could actually disturb your brain chemistry. The result is a loss of control over eating that could underlie both yo-yo dieting and clinical eating disorders such as bulimia nervosa.

The team found that dieting lowered the blood concentration of an amino acid, tryptophan, the main ingredient for making the brain messenger serotonin. Basically, the message is clear: diets can be dangerous.

And will images in the media - pictures of the super-thin such as Victoria Beckham - and details of their diets actually influence anyone? "I would say there's an association between media images and eating disorders," says the BNF spokeswoman. "But it is something which has come through all sorts of problems - low self esteem, abuse ..."

Steve Bloomfield from the Eating Disorders Association (EDA) is less tolerant: "Research shows that dieting doesn't work. And yet the media is trying to sell another publication focusing on dieting methods. The EDA would question whether aspiring to other people's bodies is appropriate".

Of course it is vastly inappropriate. But Celebrity Bodies does at least has the boldness to be honest, and indeed witty, about it, rather than hiding behind the pretence of health and wellbeing and vitality.

It's the last page of the magazine which says it best, poking a finger in the skinny ribs of the stars. The "What diet are you on then?" page includes the "Pleeeease take a photo of me diet" (for the half-dressed lovelies outside the film premieres) and the "Damn she's thinner than me diet" (for the cast of Ally McBeal).

And the whole mag does show how farcical our dieting, slim-fasting, non-stop sit-upping culture is, so much more effectively than any government campaign or sad-eyed Marie Claire article about anorexia. It acknowledges that we all want to be thin. But also that we all like pies.

 A debate at the Institute of Psychiatry tonight will discuss eating disorders and the media. Call 020-7848 0183 for details

"But it is something which has come through all sorts of problems - low self esteem, abuse ..." Steve Bloomfield from the Eating Disorders Association (EDA) is less tolerant: "Research shows that dieting doesn't work. And yet the media is trying to sell another publication focusing on dieting methods. The EDA would question whether aspiring to other people's bodies is appropriate". Of course it is vastly inappropriate. But Celebrity Bodies does at least has the boldness to be honest, and indeed witty, about it, rather than hiding behind the pretence of health and wellbeing and vitality. It's the last page of the magazine which says it best, poking a finger in the skinny ribs of the stars. The "What diet are you on then?" page includes the "Pleeeease take a photo of me diet" (for the half-dressed lovelies outside the film premieres) and the "Damn she's thinner than me diet" (for the cast of Ally McBeal). And the whole mag does show how farcical our dieting, slim-fasting, non-stop sit-upping culture is, so much more effectively than any government campaign or sad-eyed Marie Claire article about anorexia. It acknowledges that we all want to be thin. But also that we all like pies.  A debate at the Institute of Psychiatry tonight will discuss eating disorders and the media. fields.headline: Housing Today round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: April 5
fields.trailText: April 5: Council tenants in Southend have rejected a proposal to switch their homes to a housing association.
fields.body:
Another Merseyside housing association is under fire from the Housing Corporation over concerns about its governance. The regulator has slammed Liverpool Housing Trust within a month of attacking neighbouring Liver Housing Association for proposed £1.7m redundancy package for top directors.

Birmingham council has sold off its repairs and maintenance service in a £375m deal to two private companies. The move follows a dispute with the audit commission over £21.3m worth of losses run up by the in house team.

Council tenants in Southend have rejected a proposal to switch their homes to a housing association by only 82 votes. The result comes amid allegations of unfair tactics by Unison, which was against the transfer.

The definition of key workers should be widened if London's housing crisis is to be tackled, a new report has claimed. It points out that restricting the term to teachers, nurses and policemen ignores low and middle income earners who don't qualify for social housing and can't afford to rent or buy in the private sector.

The Tories have pledged to extend the right to buy to housing association tenants. Shadow environment secretary Archie Norman also promised more tax cuts for urban regeneration and tougher measures on anti-social tenants.

fields.headline: A textbook route to tension
fields.standfirst: A controversial new history textbook approved by the Japanese government applies a fresh coat of whitewash to some of the country's darker moments, reports Jonathan Watts
fields.trailText: A controversial new history textbook approved by the Japanese government applies a fresh coat of whitewash to some of the country's darker moments, reports Jonathan Watts
fields.body:
The collision between military aircraft from China and the United States is not the only issue creating tension in the Far East, where relations between Japan and its neighbours are being strained by a fierce row over differing historical interpretations of the second world war.

This perennially contentious issue returned to stoke up the diplomatic temperature on Wednesday when the Japanese education ministry approved a controversial new history textbook that Seoul, Beijing and Pyongyang claim glosses over atrocities by the imperial army in the first half of the twentieth century.

Drawn up by the Japanese Society for History Textbook Reform - a group headed by right-wing academics and politicians - the new book makes no mention of the Japanese army's use of "comfort women", the euphemism for the hundreds of thousands who were forced into prostitution in government-run frontline brothels.

It also plays down the severity of the Nanking Massacre, stating that there are reasons to doubt the Tokyo War Tribunal's judgement that the Japanese army killed a large number of Chinese civilians after occupying the city in 1937.

Although the education ministry's screening panel insisted on more than 100 changes to tone down the original text, China and South Korea say the final 337-page version continues to justify Japan's aggression from 1910 to 1945.

As soon as the book was approved, the South Korean government summoned the Japanese envoy to Seoul to express its "deep concerns" and to warn that introduction of the text in schools would threaten bilateral relations.

China's Xinhua news agency criticised the teaching material for "distorting historical facts and glorifying wars of aggression". Anti-Japanese fury in Beijing would not have been eased by the fact that the US reconnaissance plane that was forced to land in Hainan flew from Okinawa.

Former comfort women who joined a protest outside the Japanese embassy in Seoul issued a statement accusing Japan of hiding from the truth.

"It is an unforgivable sin to turn one's face away from past atrocities while many of the victims are still suffering from the abuse they endured."

The textbook dispute comes amid growing fears that as the region becomes more polarized, Japan is moving once again to sanitise its wartime history.

The picture was different around the 50th anniversary of the end of the war, when the Japanese government took a number of unprecedented steps to close the perception gap between itself and its neighbours over that period of history.

In 1993, it acknowledged of the existence of "comfort women" for the first time. Two years later, the then prime minister Tomiichi Murayama apologised for Japan's actions in the war. During this brief period of penitence, a Japanese court ruled in favour of comfort women seeking compensation from the government, a handful of brave cinemas showed a Chinese film on the Nanking massacre and school textbooks started to mention the sex slave issue and other uncomfortable subjects.

The climate of reconciliation was helped by the existence of leaders who took an active role in improving the stability of northeast Asia. Citing a desire to resolve the problems of the 20th century within the 20th century, former Japanese prime minister Keizo Obuchi signed a friendship pact with South Korea in 1998 and agreed to establish a joint panel of scholars to find a common interpretation of the past.

South Korean president Kim Dae-jung helped matters by refraining from using wartime history as a stick to beat Japan. Backed by US president Bill Clinton, he instead put his efforts into the "sunshine policy" of rapproachement with Pyongyang, culminating in last year's historic summit with the North's leader Kim Dae-jung.

The mood of hope for regional stability, which peaked at that time, is now rapidly evaporating. Clinton has been replaced by George Bush, who has cast a cloud over the sunshine policy and now seems determined to rattle China's cage. And instead of Obuchi, Japan's leader - at least for a few more weeks - is Yoshiro Mori, who has shown little inclination or talent for diplomacy.

In the process, the historical perception gap between Japan and its neighbours has once again started to widen. Since the start of this year, a senior Japanese politician evoked the ire of Seoul and Beijing by claiming that Japan's occupation of its neighbours was justified.

Tokyo courts have thrown out claims by South Korea and Chinese plaintiffs seeking compensation for wartime atrocities and the rightwing group that has produced the latest textbook will soon release a film justifying the war for spurring Asian independence from Western colonial nations.

That the ghost of the second world war has come back to haunt the Far East at a time when frosty relations between the US and China hint at a new Cold War suggests that the region could be in for a new period of polarization and instability.

webTitle: MSPs warned against sending saucy emails

fields.headline: MSPs warned against sending saucy emails
fields.trailText: Members of the Scottish parliament have been issued with a three page warning on the perils of email abuse following an incident where a Tory MSP sent colleagues a saucy message over the internet.
fields.body:
Members of the Scottish parliament have been issued with a three page warning on the perils of email abuse following an incident where a Tory MSP sent colleagues a saucy message over the internet.

Ben Wallace, the Conservative member for North East Scotland, hit the headlines when he sent friends a Christmas card entitled Jingle Boobs showing five women in stockings unwrapping presents.

Now the Scottish executive has issued its members and their staff with a "best practice" guidance instructing them to avoid "rumour, innuendo or inappropriate personal remarks."

And it also warns: "Don't send heated words in haste - store them as a draft and reconsider when you're calmer."

A spokesman for the Scottish parliament denied the guidelines were a response to Mr Wallace's controversial card. He said: "These are common sense ideas we are advising staff to adopt. They are not binding rules but advice to members on how best to use a new technology."

Unlike the Westminster parliament, all MSPs are provided with a personal laptop for remote access of political business and an automatic email address.

A report yesterday from the House of Commons public administration committee revealed that only 380 of parliament's 659 MPs have their own email addresses. It also recommended training to show MPs how to set up websites and monitor them.

The report states: "The new technologies have major potential for parliament. It is important they are explored to the full.

"This requires a long term strategy for e-access to parliament to be as easy, attractive and well used as possible."

fields.headline: Jean Anderson
fields.standfirst: Popular character actress who brought to life a vast gallery of roles on stage, screen and television
fields.trailText: Jean Anderson, the popular character actress who brought to life a vast gallery of roles on stage, screen and television, has died.
fields.body:
Tipsy aunts, querulous matrons, fearsome matriarchs, plucky parents, condescending aristocrats, taciturn chaperones, tight-lipped nannies, crusty aunts, gossipy grandmas, suspicious wives, elderly gamblers, theatrical dames, snooty dowagers, nosy spinsters and rural snobs - Jean Anderson, who has died aged 93, had a way of giving to each a singular presence, vitality, dignity and truth.

Yet, as a character actress of her quality, she had had far fewer opportunities than a star or leading performer to establish herself in our imagination, especially in the kind of depth which the musically trained Anderson liked to plumb. In the late 1920s, it was hard for a serious-minded young actress who was not arrestingly pretty to get a training in the classics, which was the only way to get on without backstage influence.

Born in Eastbourne of a Scottish family, she grew up in Guildford. After training at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art, her first professional role was on a 50-week tour of Many Waters, alongside a fellow RADA student, Robert Morley. After a stint in rep at Cambridge, where the director was Peter Powell, whom she later married, she landed the part of the mother in an Irish revival by the Gate Theatre Company, Dublin, of Eugene O'Neill's Ah, Wilderness! which visited the West End in 1936. When the company returned to Dublin, Anderson joined it for three years as leading lady.

In the 1940s, Anderson found herself working at London's Players Theatre Club, then in King Street, Covent Garden, now under Charing Cross Station, where so many other theatrical luminaries (notably Peter Ustinov) first got their footing in the theatre. Anderson enjoyed the atmosphere, camaraderie and hard work of the so-called Late Joys and had a gift for the kind of satirical, nostalgic material which continues to be sung in tribute to the Victorian music hall. She became so popular that during the absence of Leonard Sachs, the legendary founder and co-director with Peter Godfrey of the Players, she proved a most stirring substitute.

Whether in the West End or provinces, or with the newly subsidised National Theatre or Royal Shakespeare Company, she made her mark, however briefly, in plays by Rattigan or Fry, Chekhov or Ibsen, Ben Travers or EM Forster, Somerset Maugham or William Douglas Home, Jean-Jacques Bernard or Frank Wedekind - and in particular as Mme Rosamunde in Les Liaisons Dangereuses for the RSC, in which she went to Broadway (1986).

Was there a likelier Charley's Aunt (for the same company) or a haughtier dowager in Travers' Corkers End (at Guildford) or a funnier Dame Maud Gosport (looming but listing squiffily) in Rattigan's send-up of actor-managers, Harlequinade? They were typical examples of her familiar character work.

Anderson's quiet authority, vocal poise and invisible technique saw her safely through countless parts on stage, screen and television. In the 1950s and 1960s she juggled with all three mediums simultaneously, lending her dependably distinctive gallery of cousins, aunts, mothers, nurses, policewomen, social workers, teachers and officials to the big screen in A Town Like Alice, Heart of a Child, Lucky Jim, The Barretts of Wimpole Street, Spare the Rod, The Inspector, Half a Sixpence, Country Dance and The Lady Van ishes, as well as to the theatre and television.

It was the small screen, however, which seemed to bring out the best in her art; perhaps because it had more scope for the kind of kindly if sometimes curt characterisation to which Anderson brought such a compelling restraint. My favourites are still the stoic Mum in The Railway Children, the awful matriarch in The Brothers, the series about a road haulage company, and the eccentric old gambler in Trainer.

In its elegance, observation, timing and emotional insight, another gem was Molly Cowper, the ageing English social snob in Julian Mitchell's Survival of the Fittest. Herself as old as the 80-year-old character, Anderson brought out all the private suffering, loneliness, intransigence and maternal possessiveness of an old lady who refused to acknowledge reality.

Among scores of other "types" which she turned into individuals for the small screen were Jocelyn Holbrook in Tenko, the series about the experiences of European women interned by Japanese militia, Mrs Fortescue in Keeping Up Appearances, Mrs Spencer Ewell in House of Elliot, Dr Goldrup in GBH, Lady Anne in Do Not Disturb, the Dowager in Circles of Deceit, Belle in Campion, Great Aunt Anne in Evelyn Waugh's Scoop, Jo March in Little Women, and Frau Buddenbrook in Buddenbrooks. Her final television role came last year in Samuel Beckett's Endgame, back at the Gate Theatre, Dublin.

Her marriage to Peter Powell ended in divorce. They had one daughter, Aude Powell, a theatre agent.

 Mary Jean Heriot Anderson, actress, born December 12 1907; died April 1 2001.

fields.headline: Dixons admits digital TV is 'confusing'
fields.trailText:
2.45pm: The high-street retailer has admitted digital TV is too complex for consumers, reports Ashley Davies.
Mar 29: Eyre says digital is a pipedream
Mar 27: Broadcasters tackle digital apathy
fields.body:
Digital TV is still far too confusing for consumers, bosses at Dixons have admitted.

As the government presses ahead with plans to phase in the switching off of the existing analogue TV network, executives at the high-street retail store have sounded the alarm bells.

"We are moving into an era of absolute confusion because digital TV is so complex. We need to find a simple solution to consumer demands," said Danny Churchill, director of technical development at Dixons.

And the Consumers Association said greater awareness of digital TV was needed and the labelling of digital TV sets did not go far enough.

CA Research & Testing Centre officer Roy Booker said viewers simply did not know the distinctions between digital and analogue TV.

Consumer confusion is one of the biggest enemies of the government's blueprint for broadcasting in Britain.

If insufficient quantities of consumers buy digital TV, the government cannot switch off a single analogue TV transmitter.

Technological journalist and broadcaster Barry Fox slammed the government's handling of the analogue switch-off as "a shambles".

At a Voice of the Listener and Viewer conference today he called for a digital TV tsar to "shake up this bunch of incompetents".

He said: "There is a mish-mash of shared responsibility with no chain of command to get this show on the road.

"People need to be persuaded to switch over."

The conference applauded electronic programme guides, the TiVo personal video recorder service, wider programme choice, better Teletext services, internet and email access.

But areas needing improvement included the poor compatibility with video recorders, the complication of Video Plus and confusing instruction manuals.

fields.body:
365 Corporation has axed Business365.co.uk, the branded website dedicated to marketing the company's business services over the internet.

Mobile services group Zed is using a viral email campaign featuring a mock porn movie to support its recent UK launch.

Clickmango is understood to have approached Boots to sell its branded products.

fields.headline: Final fanfare for the Commons man - and woman
fields.trailText: We long-serving parliamentary hands have our favourite acts. Some are retiring from the boards this year - Ted Heath, Paddy Ashdown, Michael Heseltine, John Major and Mo Mowlam among them. Others keep going, playing to smaller and smaller crowds in smaller and smellier venues.
fields.body:
We long-serving parliamentary hands have our favourite acts. Some are retiring from the boards this year - Ted Heath, Paddy Ashdown, Michael Heseltine, John Major and Mo Mowlam among them. Others keep going, playing to smaller and smaller crowds in smaller and smellier venues.

But it does our old hearts good to see them make a last return to the West End, performing once again the acts we loved them for in the past. Imagine going to the London Palladium and catching Morecambe and Wise in the Short Fat Hairy Legs routine; later there might be Marie Lloyd singing Oh Mr Porter, and - how pungently evocative! - George Formby with his ukulele, performing When I'm Cleaning Windows.

That's how I felt yesterday watching prime minister's question time. It was like wallowing in a deep hot bath of nostalgia.

First we heard from Dennis Skinner. He is not retiring but that's all right; for years he has been part of the furniture of the House, as ancient a tradition as the Churchill statue in the lobby or the cry of "Who goes home?" Like the ravens in the Tower or the apes of Gibraltar, Mr Skinner's departure could signal the end of parliament as we know it.

Yesterday he stood up in the familiar aggressive pose that brought hope and encouragement to us all in the dark days of the class war: legs apart, shoulder pointed at the enemy (other Labour backbenchers), a haranguing arm waved towards the Tories. All it needed was a for a pigeon to sit on his head.

He wanted Railtrack renationalised - "we could buy it back for a song", he said to huge hilarity from the fans. "And also bear in mind, when we've won our glorious victory, will you ask the army to take overall control of the Tory party?"

A partisan jest, but Tories also love the patter. It wafts them back to their childhood, when their parents took them to the dress circle in the Strangers' gallery to see that grand old comedian, Dennis "And Another Thing!" Skinner, before tea at a Lyons' Corner House.

They chortled uproariously, none louder than William Hague. But we knew they were not laughing at the joke so much as cherishing their memories.

Next on the bill was Ian Paisley. Normally he contents himself with a brief rage against the IRA. Yesterday he addressed foot and mouth disease. He rose, frailer now though as vast as ever, in the grey suit some of us remember from his great performances in 1968.

It was perfect. If it is Teresa's last question ever, it could not be more fitting.

fields.headline: MacLaurin swipes Emap Elan account
fields.trailText: 10.45am: MacLaurin will handle PR for 22 consumer magazines, including Elle and Heat, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
MacLaurin Communications has scooped the account for the Emap Elan network, giving it PR responsibility for magazines such as Elle and J17.

MacLaurin takes the account in a deal estimated to be worth more than £10,000 a month.

The account, to be headed by former Daily Mail and Express journalist Ian Monk, will give MacLaurin responsibility for 22 consumer titles.

MacLaurin, which has already worked with Emap on the launches of Red and Heat, has been retained for three years to handle all title-specific public and media relations for Emap.

"It makes sense to have a single voice for the corporate image of the Emap Elan network," said Barry McIlheney, chief executive of Emap Elan.

webTitle: MTV offers legal alternative to Napster

fields.headline: MTV offers legal alternative to Napster
fields.trailText: Online music company MTVi has signed a deal with the top five record labels to sell digital singles and albums over the internet, a move that will give users a legal way to download digital music in the wake of the Napster lawsuit.
fields.body:
Online music company MTVi has signed a deal with the top five record labels to sell digital singles and albums over the internet, a move that will give users a legal way to download digital music in the wake of the Napster lawsuit.

MTVi says that users will be able to pay to download 10,000 songs from the MTV and VH1 sites by the end of this month.

The labels - BMG Entertainment, EMI Group, Sony Music Entertainment, Universal Music Group and Warner Music Group - have been trying to find a way to sell music online rather than having services like Napster and Gnutella simply give it away. The popular online song-swap service, Napster, has been shut down by litigation from the same record companies over copyright disputes.

It remains to be seen if users will warm to the idea of paying for music online rather than swapping tracks for free. MTVi will charge between about $1 (60p) and $3 for each song downloaded and $10 to $18 for an entire album.

MTVi's download service will be available through its online radio stations, Radio MTV and VHIatWorkRadio, and the company says that 100% of the music heard on these sites should be available for download by next year.

The MTVi deal is the first to involve all five major record labels, although earlier this week RealNetworks struck a deal with BMG, EMI and Warner for fee-based music downloads.

webTitle: 14 years for Dover tragedy lorry driver

fields.headline: 14 years for Dover tragedy lorry driver
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees
fields.trailText: Dutch lorry driver Perry Wacker was today sentenced to 14 years in jail for the manslaughter of 58 Chinese immigrants found dead in his lorry at Dover after he closed the only air vent and they suffocated to death.
fields.body:
Dutch lorry driver Perry Wacker was today sentenced to 14 years in jail for the manslaughter of 58 Chinese immigrants found dead in his lorry at Dover after he closed the only air vent and they suffocated to death.

Mr Justice Alan Moses, sitting at Maidstone crown court, also sentenced Wacker's fellow defendant Ying Guo, of South Woodford, Essex, to six years for conspiring to smuggle illegal immigrants into the UK in June last year.

The 60 Chinese would-be illegal immigrants - there were just two survivors - endured several weeks of arduous travel before making their fateful attempt to enter Britain.

They were escorted in small groups from China by snakehead minders after agreeing to pay a criminal gang £20,000 each to smuggle them into this country.

The journey of the 56 men and four women started in China's capital city Beijing, from where they flew by plane to the Yugoslav capital of Belgrade.

They travelled legally on Chinese passports after obtaining permits to leave the People's Republic.

During the journey the immigrants' minders forced them to wear black trousers and grey T-shirts, and were issued with a code number, so they would not be picked up by rival gangs.

When they arrived in Belgrade they were taken to safe houses and given stolen Asian passports, mainly Korean.

From there, still in small escorted groups, they were taken by car over the border and into Hungary.

They were transported through Austria and into France hidden in the backs of vans, then boarded a train in France to get to the Netherlands, where they were handed over to the European side of the network, in Rotterdam.

The two survivors of the journey, Su Di Ke, 20, and Ke Shi Guang, 22, met at Fujian airport on June 7 and were flown to Beijing.

Mr Ke told the jury at the trial that he left the Chinese capital with 15 other immigrants and two snakehead minders.

After being smuggled across Europe his group was taken to a safe house in Rotterdam. Other immigrants were already there, awaiting their chance to get into Britain.

The court heard that on June 18 the Dutch gang took the 60 immigrants in two delivery vans - 27 in one vehicle and 33 in the other - to a warehouse in the Waalhaven area of Rotterdam.

They Dutch gang members loaded them into the front of the lorry container, then used three pieces of wood to make a partition before stacking boxes of tomatoes between them and the lorry doors, to conceal their presence.

When they left Rotterdam the air-vent on the side of the trailer was tied open with a piece of string, and the Chinese were given four buckets of water to last the journey.

Mr Ke said: "Once the water was inside it was finished quickly. I did not have time to get any."

Wacker drove the lorry to Zeebrugge, leaving at 3pm and arriving just after 6pm.

Before reaching the Belgian port he stopped at a motorway service station, bought four cans of soft drink and closed the air-vent to avoid his human cargo being spotted at immigration checks.

After paying cash for a ticket for the crossing, Wacker queued to get on to a P&O Stena Line ferry.

The immigrants were trapped inside the airtight container on one of the hottest days of last summer until the lorry was searched at Dover at 11.43pm.

After parking the lorry on the ferry Wacker went upstairs, where he tucked into a meal and watched two films.

Mr Ke said his fellow passengers were calm until the air started running out.

"They started panicking after about two to three hours because the vent was shut and there was no air. Some people removed tomatoes and tried to kick open the doors. There was also a lot of shouting and screaming, but nobody came to help."

Mr Guang burst into tears while recalling the crossing in court. After being asked if he had banged on the side of the container he replied: "Yes, but no help came anyway".

The two survivors were the last loaded into the container and lay with their heads on the floor by the wooden partitions as the air ran out.

They were pulled out barely conscious by dock workers who searched the lorry at Dover.

webTitle: How an image change can revitalise your charity

fields.headline: How an image change can revitalise your charity
fields.standfirst: Makeovers should not be rushed into, says Nicola Hill, but can give staff a new sense of purpose
fields.trailText: Makeovers should not be rushed into, says Nicola Hill, but can give staff a new sense of purpose.
fields.body:
"We always thought we had a dead duck of a name," admits David Millar, chief executive of the charity, which until the end of March, was called Understanding Industry.

The charity was set up 23 years ago to offer students an insight into the world of work. It receives high-level business support from blue chip companies and is well respected in schools.

However, research among stakeholders suggested that people liked the work of the charity but thought its image was dull and uninspiring. Roger Taylor, a brand strategist who conducted the rebranding of the charity said: "We discovered that there are people who have enjoyed a seminar but couldn't remember the name of the organisation which provided it."

Other problems were the word "understanding", which was deemed patronising, and students' image of industry, which was associated with "chimney stacks and pollution".

One teacher in the research said: "It simply has to be more upbeat, glamorous and fun."

But Mr Millar didn't want a cosmetic change. "It is more than fiddling around with pantone colours, we wanted to convey a more high-tech, entrepreneurial image of industry." The charity is also using more innovative methods to reach a wider audience. Later this year it will be launching an interactive computer game, which involves students launching and managing a virtual music band. "We wanted to show that we were more dynamic," added Mr Millar.

Mr Taylor explains that the charity then set about defining its position in the market place. "Our next step was to define the target audiences, as the first stage towards getting the positioning and the communications right for each of them."

The charity defined its raison d'etre as "opening the eyes of students to the world of business". It then developed this definition into a mission statement by identifying its role for each of its target audience.

Examples:

For students: it should be an inspiring source of knowledge, direction and life skills at a crucial stage in their lives

For corporate sponsors: it should champion the interests of the business world to the younger generation

For the government: it demonstrates their support for business and enterprise

Establishing brand values was the next task on the 'to do' list. From the research, the charity concluded it needed to be:
 Young
 Forward-looking
 Dynamic
 Empowering
 Fun
 Innovative
 Creative
 Modern
 Colourful

Mr Taylor said: "Defining these provides guidelines for anyone creating communications about the organisation. At the same time, and equally important, it tells staff how they should behave, how they should deliver the brand."

The baton was then handed over to the creative team to incorporate the findings of the research and the ideas on positioning into a new name, logo and slogan.

The team came up with 50 suggestions for names but only 10 of them were available. Mr Taylor warned: "It is vital to check that domain names are available as well as charity names."

The team narrowed the selection down to businessdynamics. Mr Taylor explains: "The word 'business' communicates immediately the organisation's area of operation - and it covers all kinds of companies. 'Dynamics' has two important meanings - what makes something work and the sense of energy, we thought this was a good combination.The slogan, 'bringing business to life for students' was added to encapsulate what the charity does."

The logo, which is a stylised "b" and "d", was designed to look like two faces talking to each other as well as a computer connector.

Mr Taylor said: "When you are designing a logo, you have to design it with the internet in mind, which means it must be capable of animation." The charity's website illustrates this capacity.

And finally the charity went back to the stakeholders for their verdict. "We all held our breath in case the students would reject it and we would have to start all over again," explained Mr Taylor.

Fortunately, they liked it and Understanding Industry was consigned to the graveyard and businessdynamics was born.

Mr Millar concluded: "Don't change your name for the sake of it and don't do it lightly and seek professional guidance."

Mr Taylor added: "Rebranding should revitalise a charity and give staff a new sense of purpose as well as giving it a competitive edge."

fields.headline: Livingstone goes it alone
fields.trailText: Analysis: London mayor Ken Livingstone's decision to pull out of the Association of London Government this week provided outward proof of what was already becoming clear - the relationship between the mayor and the boroughs has deteriorated dramatically in the past year.
fields.body:
London mayor Ken Livingstone's decision to pull out of the Association of London Government (ALG) this week provided outward proof of what was already becoming clear - the relationship between the mayor and the boroughs has deteriorated dramatically in the past year.

Those present at a recent meeting concerning the Greater London Authority's (GLA) budget, which the boroughs opposed, say a furious Mr Livingstone accused council leaders of being "Millbank stooges" and peddling "Tory lies".

But this week's events have more than a symbolic significance. They could be the start of a power struggle between the mayor and the boroughs that will change the shape of London local government.

It is no secret that Mr Livingstone has an expansionist agenda for his authority. In the past, he has said the GLA should have some control of the NHS in London, and he has been lobbying ministers for more power over the capital's share of the £800m neighbourhood renewal fund.

In fairness to Mr Livingstone, his desire for more power is shared by some of the politicians on the London assembly. Even Bob Neill, the leader of the Tory group, wants more responsibility to be passed down from central government.

This desire for more power is a product of the fact that the government gave the GLA such a limited portfolio of powers in the first place. Police, fire, economic development and transport give the mayor a far more limited range of responsibilities than he enjoyed as leader of the Greater London Council (GLC).

There are rumours circulating in Westminster that the mayor wants the ability to distribute some of the boroughs' funding streams, presently administered by central government. Mr Livingstone's office strongly denies the claims, but sources close to the mayor say he might one day call for a reduction in the number of boroughs and a change in their responsibilities.

Tony Travers of the London School of Economics and the foremost expert on London's new politics said: "Livingstone's been to New York and seen that Rudy Giuliani is emperor of the city, and he's seen that for a mayor to be genuinely effective in London, he needs more power than the mayor currently has I'm not at all sure this latest move isn't the opening shot in some sort of struggle."

ALG chief executive Martin Pilgrim argues that the mayor should not attempt to take more power from local government: "We think the GLA act strikes the right balance. We see no reason to change the distribution of power."

Conflict between tiers of government in London is nothing new, but the mayor's decision to enter the ALG last year was a bid to avoid repeating historical mistakes. Mr Livingstone appears to believe his decision to join was flawed. In his letter of withdrawal from the association, he points out that the GLA sits uneasily in a borough organisation. The mayor is really a regional, rather than a local, leader. His strategic, uber-borough role, he argues, was blurred by his membership of a council association.

More importantly, the mayor points out that it had become contradictory for him to be a member of an organisation that was lobbying against his policies. This became most obvious in the row over the mayor's budget. The boroughs complained the mayor's proposed increase was too high and worked with the London assembly to reduce the increase to a manageable, but still hefty, 22%.

This suggests that the relationship between the mayor and the ALG might have been flawed in the first place, but Mr Pilgrim insists the two sides were right to give it a go: "It was worth trying. It's no secret, though, that there were some who, from the outset, believed we should be a boroughs-only club." In the rosy glow that followed Mr Livingstone's election, it would have seemed churlish for the two sides not to work closely together.

The ALG has become used to holding an exalted position in London politics. In the years between the abolition of the GLC and the inception of the GLA, association leaders such as Lord Harris have effectively become the capital's democratically elected figureheads.

Whether he gets extra powers or not, Mr Livingstone is making it clear the boroughs are to become junior partners in the new London.

Even Bob Neill, the leader of the Tory group, wants more responsibility to be passed down from central government. This desire for more power is a product of the fact that the government gave the GLA such a limited portfolio of powers in the first place. Police, fire, economic development and transport give the mayor a far more limited range of responsibilities than he enjoyed as leader of the Greater London Council (GLC). There are rumours circulating in Westminster that the mayor wants the ability to distribute some of the boroughs' funding streams, presently administered by central government. Mr Livingstone's office strongly denies the claims, but sources close to the mayor say he might one day call for a reduction in the number of boroughs and a change in their responsibilities. Tony Travers of the London School of Economics and the foremost expert on London's new politics said: "Livingstone's been to New York and seen that Rudy Giuliani is emperor of the city, and he's seen that for a mayor to be genuinely effective in London, he needs more power than the mayor currently has I'm not at all sure this latest move isn't the opening shot in some sort of struggle." ALG chief executive Martin Pilgrim argues that the mayor should not attempt to take more power from local government: "We think the GLA act strikes the right balance. We see no reason to change the distribution of power." Conflict between tiers of government in London is nothing new, but the mayor's decision to enter the ALG last year was a bid to avoid repeating historical mistakes. Mr Livingstone appears to believe his decision to join was flawed. In his letter of withdrawal from the association, he points out that the GLA sits uneasily in a borough organisation. The mayor is really a regional, rather than a local, leader. His strategic, uber-borough role, he argues, was blurred by his membership of a council association. More importantly, the mayor points out that it had become contradictory for him to be a member of an organisation that was lobbying against his policies. This became most obvious in the row over the mayor's budget. The boroughs complained the mayor's proposed increase was too high and worked with the London assembly to reduce the increase to a manageable, but still hefty, 22%. This suggests that the relationship between the mayor and the ALG might have been flawed in the first place, but Mr Pilgrim insists the two sides were right to give it a go: "It was worth trying. It's no secret, though, that there were some who, from the outset, believed we should be a boroughs-only club." In the rosy glow that followed Mr Livingstone's election, it would have seemed churlish for the two sides not to work closely together. The ALG has become used to holding an exalted position in London politics. In the years between the abolition of the GLC and the inception of the GLA, association leaders such as Lord Harris have effectively become the capital's democratically elected figureheads. Whether he gets extra powers or not, Mr Livingstone is making it clear the boroughs are to become junior partners in the new London.

fields.headline: ITV scores with soccer
fields.trailText: ITV's live coverage of Arsenal and Leeds United's Champions League quarter final clashes dominated the peaktime ratings battle with BBC1 last night, with nearly 8m viewers tuning in.
fields.body:
ITV's live coverage of Arsenal and Leeds United's Champions League quarter final clashes dominated the peaktime ratings battle with BBC1 last night, with nearly 8m viewers tuning in.

The Big Match: Champions League Live, which featured Arsenal's 2-1 victory over Valencia in southern ITV regions and Leeds 3-0 demolition of Deportivo in the north, was on between 7.30pm and 9.45pm last night.

ITV's coverage drew 7.7m and a 35% share over that period, peaking at 8.8m from 9.15-9.30pm in the closing stages of the game, according to unofficial overnights.

The Big Match was beaten by BBC1 opposition Animal Hospital between 7.30pm and 8pm, but drew ahead of the rest of the channel's line-up.

Animal Hospital had 7.4m and a 37% share. It was followed on BBC1 by This Is Your Life, which managed just 6.4m.

Between 9pm and 10pm BBC1 played the latest documentary from award-winning film-maker Chris Terrill.

Through the Eyes of the Old followed the daily lives of a number of over-60s.

But it proved no match for ITV's football, with just 4.4m and a 19% share.

webTitle: Israelis fire on Palestinian peace delegation

fields.headline: Israelis fire on Palestinian peace delegation
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli troops this morning fired on a Palestinian delegation returning from peace talks aimed at ending the crisis
fields.body:
Israeli troops this morning fired on a Palestinian delegation returning from peace talks aimed at ending the crisis

The shooting took place at about 2am local time (midnight GMT) at the Erez crossing between Israel and the Gaza Strip.

Three Palestinian bodyguards were wounded. Israel claimed the Palestinians opened fire, and Israeli soldiers shot back.

A Palestinian security chief, Mohammed Dahlan, called the shooting an Israeli assassination attempt.

His car, a silver Mercedes, was hit by seven bullets.

Mr Dahlan and other senior officials were returning to Gaza after a meeting with the Israelis at the home of the US ambassador to Israel, Martin Indyk.

The peace talks are the highest level meeting to take place between the two sides since Ariel Sharon became prime minister two months ago.

The Palestinian delegation said the talks were "difficult" and no agreement was reached.

Raanan Gissin, a spokesman for Mr Sharon, said the talks "may be a dead end, but I don't know. We'll have to see."

The Palestinians demanded that Israel remove its restrictions on their movements, withdraw its tanks and stop the targeted killing of Palestinian activists.

Mr Sharon has said he will not resume formal peace negotiations until the violence stops, but both sides have warned that the worsening violence over the past week is threatening to further destabilise the region.

In the initial meeting, yesterday, Israel's foreign minister, Shimon Peres, met senior Palestinian leaders in Athens.

The two sides disagreed over how to stop the unrest and who was to blame. Israel argues that the Palestinian leadership has orchestrated the violence to wrest political concessions from Israel.

The Palestinians counter that Israel is perpetuating its occupation of the West Bank and Gaza by force and is trying to impose its terms on the Palestinians.

webTitle: Eton boy and mother in suicide pact

fields.headline: Eton boy and mother in suicide pact
fields.trailText: A doctor's wife and his Eton scholar son have killed themselves in a suicide pact, police said today.
fields.body:
A doctor's wife and his Eton scholar son have killed themselves in a suicide pact, police said today.

Keshan Gunawardena, 13, and his 45-year-old mother were found dead last night by their father on his return to their home in Ascot, Berkshire, Thames Valley police said.

The pair are understood to have died from a massive drugs overdose. Detectives are not seeking anyone else in connection with the deaths.

An ambulance service spokesman said that the boy and his mother were already dead when paramedics arrived at the house after Kulafri Gunawardena called 999.

Paying tribute to the talented pupil, Provost Dr Eric Anderson, of Eton college, said: "We're very sad to hear of the death of Keshan Gunawardena and his mother.

"Keshan won a scholarship to Eton and came to the college as a King's Scholar last September. He had bright future ahead of him. The college's deepest sympathies go out to Mr Gunawardena."

Baffled neighbours of the "quiet" family in the leafy cul-de-sac, Prides Crossing, were shocked by the news.

Mr Gunawardena had recently given his wife an X-reg Mercedes as a present, which was today parked on the drive of their five-bedroom £500,000 home.

Today, Mr Gunawardena was not at home but was being comforted by family and friends. A Thames Valley police spokesman said that the father was "devastated".

Kyoko McDermid, who lives opposite their redbrick house, said that she was baffled because Mrs Dinesha Gunawardena had not seemed depressed.

She added: "He had just given her a brand new car. They were a friendly but quiet family. His wife used to work as an accountant for British Airways before falling sick.

"Mr Gunawardena loves his garden - he's always working there evenings and weekends."

The family had lived there since the estate was built about 10 years ago, said a neighbour. Another neighbour, Mr Harold Tew, said: "She suffered from MS. I think she also suffered from depression."

fields.headline: Jobson joins Express exodus
fields.trailText:
1.15pm update: Robert Jobson, the number three on the Daily Express, is set to quit the ailing paper, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
Apr 5: Express and Star to merge news teams
Apr 4: Express loses core newsmen
Mar 29: Express faces exodus from City desk
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
Robert Jobson, the number three on the Daily Express, is set to quit the ailing paper.

He has volunteered for redundancy, joining the growing queue of senior executives who have decided they no longer want to work under Richard Desmond.

Mr Jobson, who is assistant editor on the paper, has been with the Express in various guises for eight years.

His decision will come as a blow to the title, which is haemorrhaging senior staff on a daily basis.

Yesterday, the three most senior news executives quit the paper.

Mr Jobson joined the Express from the Sun as diplomatic editor but went on to become royal correspondent.

Under Rosie Boycott his brief was extended to ultimately include showbusiness, media, diplomatic and royal stories.

He had ambitions to edit the paper and was considered a possible candidate following Mr Desmond's takover of the paper last February.

Media correspondent Sarah Shannon is also expected to depart, leaving the showbusiness and media departments at half their strength.

One source said: "Soon there will be no men standing. Journalistic integrity here is under immense pressure and many have decided that they are better off going even if the jobs market is flooded."

Rumours also abound that Daily Star news editor Keiron Saunders will become the group news boss, with responsiblity for the Daily Express, Sunday Express and the Daily Star.

But this has been categorically denied.

"It was something started off mischieviously by someone in the Star as a deliberate rumour to see how far it would get," said a source.

webTitle: Alexander Sokurov's new film about Lenin: Taurus

fields.headline: The last days of Lenin
fields.standfirst: A decade after the fall of the Soviet Union a new film is at last telling the truth about its founder's death. By Amelia Gentleman
fields.trailText: A decade after the fall of the Soviet Union a new film is at last telling the truth about its founder's death. By Amelia Gentleman.
fields.body:
Within years of the 1917 Russian revolution, a godlike image of the new state's ruler was born. In exuberant biographies he was depicted as impervious to human pain and weakness. "Lenin cannot be killed! So long as the proletariat lives - Lenin lives!" one of his hagiographers declared.

So it came as something of a blow to learn on January 21 1924 that Lenin had in fact died. The mundane details of the prolonged illness that left him paralysed and barely able to speak were glossed over in the official reworkings of his life. Instead devoted party artists and sculptors laboured for decades to brand a triumphant, healthy image of the revolutionary leader on the minds of the masses.

Now that the Soviet imagery of Lenin has been toppled, the last agonised months of his life have been reclaimed for public consumption. This is the subject of Alexander Sokurov's new film, Taurus, recently shown to a small Moscow audience in preparation for its Cannes debut. For the first time in Russian cinema the reverence demanded by the creators of Lenin's personality cult has been abandoned. In place of adoring respect, there is harsh realism - only not the socialist variety. The 53-year-old Lenin is shown as a broken figure, crazed, rambling and unable to recognise even the distinctively sinister figure of Josef Stalin.

At the start of the film, the invalid is shown naked, half-wrapped in a sheet. We see him carried into his bath and tended to by his dreadful, downtrodden, hag-like old wife, who later retires to a back room to scrub his greying underwear by hand. We even witness his toenails being clipped as he lies writhing in his sickbed.

If Sokurov had made this film 15 years ago it would have joined six more of his earlier works, locked forever in a censor's cupboard. He would probably have been arrested, he says, before it progressed beyond the screenplay. But Moscow's cultural climate has changed so comprehensively that such an irreverent work prompted not even a stirring of outrage. Critical commentary has focused exclusively on the film's cinematographic qualities; its political content has been shrugged off as irrelevant.

This is not merely revisionism, a logical, predictable antithesis to the dozens of admiring biopics created by the hero directors of Soviet cinema. The screenplay does not aim to demonise Lenin: Taurus is a strangely neutral portrayal of an unpleasant, ailing old man, focusing on his human failings and his personal disappointments. Sokurov does not want the film to be seen as a corrective postscript to the canon of official works. "This is not a political documentary, I wasn't trying to make a political point. This is a film about a person like us," he says.

Taurus is the second film in Sokurov's planned quartet about the 20th century's most powerful rulers. The first, Moloch, was a human portrayal of Hitler at home with Eva Braun in his last weeks in power. In both works, Sokurov focuses on the intense dissatisfaction experienced by the leaders as they reflect on what they have achieved. "These are people whose lives have not worked. These were deeply unhappy human experiences - from childhood to the last days of their lives. Both attempted to change the world by violently interfering with people's lives. Neither achieved his ends," he says. "I feel very sorry for them."

The echoing empty halls of the Gorky estate form the sad backdrop to the last days of Lenin's life. Behind every door a soldier hovers, observing him. The invalid has been told the telephone no longer works; newspapers are confiscated. In a moment of semi-lucidity Lenin is horrified by the grandeur surrounding him. Suddenly struck by the Italian baroque statues and the grand piano of the former inhabitants, he demands to know how much it all cost and begins to berate his wife for her inappropriate extravagance.

"But it's all expropriated," she explains. Her husband, his brain rotten with disease, no longer understands this much-loved concept. "Stolen. It's all stolen," she translates, sending him into one of the mad rages that - according to recently declassified documents - were a characteristic of his illness.

A hazy, out-of-focus effect was created for the film, achieved with specially designed plastic and glass filters. Sokurov says it was to give the film an oil-painting feel, inspired by the paintings of Velazquez and Rembrandt. The effect is more as though the surroundings are being observed through the cataract-scarred eyes of an old man.

Despite the director's desire to inspire pity and not censure, it's hard to feel too sorry for the dying Lenin. His powerful thirst for violence imbues the entire film. When he wakes up in the morning he asks his wife to read to him about different forms of punishment, about how the flesh falls from the human form after a certain amount of beating; when they sit together picnicking in a field, she reads to him in a comforting voice about death and torture.

The merciless portrayal of illness makes this a painful film to watch: Lenin never stops groaning and muttering to himself, dragging his useless body around, collapsing as he tries to stand up, crawling on the ground. Only his beautifully observed death offers the audience a moment of respite: the final five minutes of the film are silent as Lenin sits in his wheelchair in the garden listening to the noise of cows and birds and thunder, waiting to die.

fields.headline: Chinese demand formal apology
fields.standfirst:
Special report: China

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: China today welcomed American expressions of regret for a Chinese pilot missing after a US spy plane collided with a Chinese fighter jet on Sunday, but repeated its demand for a full apology for the incident.
fields.body:
China today welcomed American expressions of regret for a Chinese pilot missing after a US spy plane collided with a Chinese fighter jet on Sunday, but repeated its demand for a full apology for the incident.

Hardening its attitude, China said the US plane's 24 crew members had broken the law and were being questioned.

Beijing's demand boded ill for a quick resolution to the crisis. Washington has ruled out an apology, saying the crew of the EP-3E surveillance plane did nothing wrong. The secretary of state, Colin Powell, said yesterday that he regretted the loss of the missing Chinese pilot, who is feared dead, but said it was time to move on.

"The regret expressed by the US side is a step in the right direction to solving this question," said foreign ministry spokesman Sun Yuxi, in China's first response to Mr Powell's remarks.

"As for the next step in handling this issue, the key is for the US side to take a cooperative attitude, admit its mistakes, take responsibility for that and apologise," Mr Sun said. He gave no sign that the plane's crew members would be released soon, despite warnings from the US president, George Bush, that China risks undermining relations by continuing to hold them.

Mr Sun said the crew members were being held while the collision was being investigated, adding: "They have caused this air collision incident and they also entered illegally into China's airspace. It is fully natural for competent authorities in China to question them about this incident."

US diplomats have been granted just one meeting with the crew and are pressing for another.

Mr Sun said the crew were safe and well and that China would consider another visit "if the US side takes a cooperative approach."

The crew have been held on Hainan island in the South China sea since making an emergency landing at a Chinese military base there after the collision on Sunday. Six US officials were waiting on Hainan in hopes of meeting them. In Beijing, police detained several Chinese protesters outside the walled US embassy compound today - an indication that the government does not want public anger over the incident to spill into the streets.

fields.bodyText: China today welcomed American expressions of regret for a Chinese pilot missing after a US spy plane collided with a Chinese fighter jet on Sunday, but repeated its demand for a full apology for the incident. Hardening its attitude, China said the US plane's 24 crew members had broken the law and were being questioned. Beijing's demand boded ill for a quick resolution to the crisis. Washington has ruled out an apology, saying the crew of the EP-3E surveillance plane did nothing wrong. The secretary of state, Colin Powell, said yesterday that he regretted the loss of the missing Chinese pilot, who is feared dead, but said it was time to move on. "The regret expressed by the US side is a step in the right direction to solving this question," said foreign ministry spokesman Sun Yuxi, in China's first response to Mr Powell's remarks. "As for the next step in handling this issue, the key is for the US side to take a cooperative attitude, admit its mistakes, take responsibility for that and apologise," Mr Sun said. He gave no sign that the plane's crew members would be released soon, despite warnings from the US president, George Bush, that China risks undermining relations by continuing to hold them. Mr Sun said the crew members were being held while the collision was being investigated, adding: "They have caused this air collision incident and they also entered illegally into China's airspace. It is fully natural for competent authorities in China to question them about this incident." US diplomats have been granted just one meeting with the crew and are pressing for another. Mr Sun said the crew were safe and well and that China would consider another visit "if the US side takes a cooperative approach." The crew have been held on Hainan island in the South China sea since making an emergency landing at a Chinese military base there after the collision on Sunday. Six US officials were waiting on Hainan in hopes of meeting them. In Beijing, police detained several Chinese protesters outside the walled US embassy compound today - an indication that the government does not want public anger over the incident to spill into the streets. fields.headline: Star and Express set to merge news teams
fields.trailText:
11.30am: News operations at the Daily Star and the Daily Express are set to merge, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
Apr 4: Express loses core newsmen

Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
News operations at the Daily Star and the Daily Express are set to merge.

Staff at the Star will be moved from the second floor of Ludgate House to join the Express team on the third floor from Monday.

And insiders say it will effectively mean joint news, sports and showbusiness operations.

Already there are signs of a joint editorial approach with reporters from the Express finding their articles reworked for the Star and vice versa.

"We don't know what exactly is going to happen yet, they have yet to reveal their plans," said one journalist.

"But we know the Star are coming up to this floor," the reporter added.

The increasingly cosy relationship betweem the two titles comes as more and more Express staff queue up for redundancy.

Speculation is mounting today that political editor Peter Oborne is poised to quit.

fields.headline: Levi's suffers setback in Tesco battle
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Tesco can continue to sell cut-price jeans until a final decision is reached in the UK courts, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Levi Strauss's battle to stop Tesco selling its jeans at knock-down prices suffered a setback today when a European court judge left the matter to the national courts.

The jeans giant took Tesco to court in an attempt to stop it importing cheaper Levi's from outside the European Union to sell at cut prices.

Levi's claimed the practice was against EU law.

The decision marks a half-way stage in a four-year fight between Britain's biggest supermarket chain and the US jeans manufacturer.

Today's ruling from a judge at the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg leaves the matter unresolved and the case will return to the British courts in the summer.

But it represents a victory for Tesco, which can carry on selling the jeans until a final decision is reached.

Levi's claims Tesco is debasing its brand by selling the jeans as a commodity.

But Tesco says it is just giving consumers what they want.

webTitle: Help with deciding charity chiefs' pay packets

fields.headline: Help with deciding charity chiefs' pay packets
fields.trailText: "Charity chief executives are paid too much."
fields.body:
"Charity chief executives are paid too much."

Supporters of charities often voice this criticism when they see jobs advertised in the Guardian. However some charities find it hard to recruit suitable senior level staff because of the salaries they offer.

The drug and alcohol charity Turning Point has just tempted Victor Adebowale away from his high profile job at Centrepoint. But Societytheguardian.com learned from an inside source that the charity had to increase its salary offer by £20,000 to attract suitable candidates, including managers in the statutory sector who tend to be paid more.

Large charities are multi-million pound enterprises which need experienced managers but last year Marie Curie Cancer Care, a charity with £68m budget came in for criticism for offering its chief executive £100,000. The successful candidate Tom Hughes Hallett, still took a pay cut from his job as chairman of Fleming Private Asset Management.

To tackle this difficult balancing act, the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO) is today launching a guide to designing a remuneration package for voluntary organisations. The result of two years' consultation, the guide gives advice on areas such as establishing a pay review process, the use of additional benefits and bonuses.

The NCVO believes the guide's recommendations will enable voluntary organisations of all sizes to help protect public confidence in charities. However, Jennie Saunders, consultant at Charity Recruitment said: "While we fully endorse the issue of transparency and accountability, we would be worried about any simplification which may result in adhering strictly to a set of statistics."

Ms Saunders added: "The non-profit sector is becoming very diverse and subtle, with a great number of variables to take into account."

Charity Recruitment's own salary survey shows that chief executive's pay ranges from £24,871 to more than £88,777. The main variable is the size of a charity's income, with those managing an annual revenue of over £25m earning a median salary of £82,000.

Author of the guide, Tesse Akpeki, said: "Trustee boards have a responsibility to set chief executive officer remuneration at a competitive level, high enough to attract and retain good quality staff. They must achieve this in a volatile climate in which all sectors are already trying to respond to a need for greater accountability and transparency in senior executive remuneration."

fields.headline: Chancellor has to delay homes aid to poorest
fields.standfirst:
Measures to tackle inner city deprivation postponed until after general election

Special report: Labour party
Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown has been forced to postpone a £100m measure to tackle inner city deprivation until after the expected June 7 general election because of a delay in compiling statistics.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown has been forced to postpone a £100m measure to tackle inner city deprivation until after the expected June 7 general election because of a delay in compiling statistics.

The chancellor had hoped to give a pre-election boost to Labour's heartlands by scrapping stamp duty on all property sales in the poorest areas. But the measure cannot be introduced until a map of poverty hotspots throughout the UK has been completed.

The delay emerged after the Northern Ireland assembly announced that it would not complete its map - a deprivation indicator - until mid June. All other regions have completed their maps.

The delay will come as a blow to the chancellor, who first announced the lifting of stamp duties in deprived areas in last November's pre-budget report.

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, later claimed that it would help to bring about an "urban renaissance" in these areas.

Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, last night seized on the delay. "Gordon Brown has spent the past four years in creasing taxes, like stamp duty," he said. "Now we learn that he is not even able to deliver a tiny relief from his own stealth tax, when he promised he would do so," Mr Portillo added

The Treasury last night played down the delay, saying that the chancellor had always said that the measure would be introduced only when the finance bill received royal assent.

The delay is expected to hold up property sales in deprived areas as buyers wait to benefit from the tax cut.

Stamp duty is paid on property deals worth more than £60,000. Buyers have to pay 1% of the value of their property on sales over £60,000 and under £250,000.

This rises to 3% on properties over £250,000 and under £500,000. On properties worth more than £500,000 buyers pay 4%.

Michael Osborne, the director of the East London estate agents Hamilton Fox, said: "Buyers for £250,000 plus properties will definitely be waiting until they hear the news on stamp duty. They would be crazy not to."

webTitle: Major breaks silence to attack Blair

fields.headline: Major breaks silence to attack Blair
fields.trailText: The former prime minister John Major has broken a self-imposed silence to launch a stinging rebuke on the government and Tony Blair in particular.
fields.body:
The former prime minister John Major has broken a self-imposed silence to launch a stinging rebuke on the government and Tony Blair in particular.

The famously mild-mannered ex-Tory leader has launched a long and detailed attack on the record of the current government as it goes into the pre-election campaign.

Writing in the rightwing weekly magazine, The Spectator, Mr Major lambasts the prime minister's claims of probity, saying Mr Blair would face "ridicule" if he repeated his 1997 plea of asking the public to "trust me".

Mr Major adds: "I, for one, no longer believe a single word that comes from the government unless it has independent corroboration."

Mr Major, who has served as a backbencher for the Conservatives since his humiliating electoral defeat four years ago, is standing down as MP for Huntingdon at the next election.

Since stepping down as Tory leader on May 4 1997 Mr Major has had a lucrative career on the international lecture circuit and made official trips to more than 12 countries.

In his piece, Mr Major recasts a famous Labour soundbite to attack a perceived Achilles heel of the government, saying: "Labour has continued to be tough on facts, and the cause of facts."

He adds: "It is a tale of bent facts and worse ethics," and criticises "how little they have achieved with such a large majority."

And in a phrase of characteristic Major prose, he claims: "Labour's behaviour has the stench of 18th century Billingsgate about it: it can be smellier than smelly."

The 1,000 word piece is also published in today's Daily Telegraph and is clearly designed to keep up pressure on the government as it heads through an unplanned month of pre-election parliamentary time.
