webTitle: Cannibalism is symptom of Moldova's decline

fields.headline: Cannibalism is symptom of Moldova's decline
fields.standfirst: Kate Connolly visits Europe's poorest country in the run-up to this weekend's elections
fields.trailText: Kate Connolly visits Europe's poorest country in the run-up to this weekend's elections.
fields.body:
It is a struggle to get information about Moldova. Planning a trip to the capital Chisinau this week, I had to explain several times over to friends just where exactly it lies.

The telephone operator went so far as to suggest that it didn't even exist: "Would that come under the Maldive islands, then?" "No, it's snugly placed between Romania to the west and Ukraine to the east." "Are you sure it's really a country, as I have nothing on it here." Attempts to find weather reports on the internet were fruitless. "See Romania", I was told.

Precisely because most fail to recognise Moldova, many Moldovans are now applying for Russian citizenship, in the hope of securing jobs elsewhere in Europe. Possess a Moldovan passport and you are likely to end up at the bottom of the bureaucrat's pile.

Moldovan officials were deeply upset by an Economist article last year that called Europe's poorest country a "nowhere land". They might find, however, that this week Moldova has finally been put on the map - though not in the way they desired.

Earlier this week it was revealed that two men were arrested after police caught them selling meat without a licence at a makeshift stall outside a butcher's shop in Chisinau.

A customer who had bought some of the meat, on sale at $2 (£1.40) a kilo, had become suspicious as it tasted like nothing he had ever eaten before.

Tests soon proved that it was actually human flesh. An investigation has now been launched into a cancer clinic in the city, after the meat-sellers revealed to police that they had acquired the body parts, which included breasts, legs and arms, from the state-run institution. Poorly paid hospital workers are alleged to have sold the parts on.

While the men face fines for selling meat without a licence, the clinic is in line for being penalised for not disposing of the parts in the correct manner - astonishingly feeble punishments.

Those who devised the legal system could not have imagined needing to establish guidelines against cannibalism.

The human flesh scandal is just the latest indication of how desperate this country of 4.5m has become. Monthly wages are between $20 and $30 (£14-20), and many state workers have not been paid for months.

Fire brigades have been forced to close down due to lack of money, leaving the government to issue orders for schools to install fire extinguishers instead. The country has been bled of 600,000, mainly young, people since independence from the Soviet Union a decade ago.

The haemorrhaging is still going on. It is hard not to find somebody who has been abroad in search of work, or who has a family member who has done so: fathers go to work in olive farms in Greece, mothers go and work as nannies in central and western Europe, and young girls who answer adverts for cleaning jobs abroad often end up in prostitution or even sex-slavery rings, in Romania, Kosovo and other Balkan countries.

The latest ways of trying to escape from poverty include selling kidneys and other body parts, or offering oneself as a human incubator. Childless Italian couples in particular are commissioning Moldovan women to bear offspring for them.

The Guardian's Italian correspondent reported last year how Lelia, who earned just $10 (£7) a month as a nurse, snapped up the offer to get $6,000 (£4,000) from one couple. It was a far better option than prostitution, she thought, as she saw how the country's economy had collapsed, life expectancy had drastically reduced and hospitals had run out of anaesthetic. In short, giving birth earned her more than she would have got in two lifetimes of nursing.

During 10 years of independence, while living standards in other EU would-be lands such as the Czech Republic, Poland and Hungary have soared, in Moldova they have sunk drastically. The Russian financial crisis of 1998 caused the traditional markets for the agricultural country to collapse, and a series of droughts hit farmers badly. A severe cold snatch at the end of last year not only left hundreds of thousands of homes without heat and electricity for months, it also ruined crops.

The situation became so bad that Moldova's last prime minister, Dumitru Braghis, commented that he felt more like a fire chief than a prime minister. ''It's as if there are fires everywhere - put one out and another starts up,'' he said.

The culmination of disastrous events coupled with widespread corruption was Mr Braghis' downfall in February, when the communists returned to power, for the first time in an ex-Soviet state.

The 70% of seats now occupied by the communist party have paved the way for its leader, Vladimir Voronin, to become president. Presidential elections are this weekend, and no one is in any doubt that Mr Voronin, a former baker, will succeed.

The outgoing president, Petru Lucinschi, a former communist turned centrist, has described as farcical his five years at the top. How many presidents would resort to such negative comments on leaving office?

''The time when I was working was a complete farce,'' he said, explaining that political bickering made it impossible to achieve much. He added that he hoped the little progress that had been made would prevent a ''return to the past''.

As his country under the communists turns towards Russia and further away from the EU, his optimism seems a little out of place.

The Moldovan response to all this is to roll out an old joke: "what happens when things hit rock bottom?" Answer: "Start digging".

The question is, where to?

An investigation has now been launched into a cancer clinic in the city, after the meat-sellers revealed to police that they had acquired the body parts, which included breasts, legs and arms, from the state-run institution. Poorly paid hospital workers are alleged to have sold the parts on. While the men face fines for selling meat without a licence, the clinic is in line for being penalised for not disposing of the parts in the correct manner - astonishingly feeble punishments. Those who devised the legal system could not have imagined needing to establish guidelines against cannibalism. The human flesh scandal is just the latest indication of how desperate this country of 4.5m has become. Monthly wages are between $20 and $30 (£14-20), and many state workers have not been paid for months. Fire brigades have been forced to close down due to lack of money, leaving the government to issue orders for schools to install fire extinguishers instead. The country has been bled of 600,000, mainly young, people since independence from the Soviet Union a decade ago. The haemorrhaging is still going on. It is hard not to find somebody who has been abroad in search of work, or who has a family member who has done so: fathers go to work in olive farms in Greece, mothers go and work as nannies in central and western Europe, and young girls who answer adverts for cleaning jobs abroad often end up in prostitution or even sex-slavery rings, in Romania, Kosovo and other Balkan countries. The latest ways of trying to escape from poverty include selling kidneys and other body parts, or offering oneself as a human incubator. Childless Italian couples in particular are commissioning Moldovan women to bear offspring for them. The Guardian's Italian correspondent reported last year how Lelia, who earned just $10 (£7) a month as a nurse, snapped up the offer to get $6,000 (£4,000) from one couple. It was a far better option than prostitution, she thought, as she saw how the country's economy had collapsed, life expectancy had drastically reduced and hospitals had run out of anaesthetic. In short, giving birth earned her more than she would have got in two lifetimes of nursing. During 10 years of independence, while living standards in other EU would-be lands such as the Czech Republic, Poland and Hungary have soared, in Moldova they have sunk drastically. The Russian financial crisis of 1998 caused the traditional markets for the agricultural country to collapse, and a series of droughts hit farmers badly. A severe cold snatch at the end of last year not only left hundreds of thousands of homes without heat and electricity for months, it also ruined crops. The situation became so bad that Moldova's last prime minister, Dumitru Braghis, commented that he felt more like a fire chief than a prime minister. ''It's as if there are fires everywhere - put one out and another starts up,'' he said. The culmination of disastrous events coupled with widespread corruption was Mr Braghis' downfall in February, when the communists returned to power, for the first time in an ex-Soviet state. The 70% of seats now occupied by the communist party have paved the way for its leader, Vladimir Voronin, to become president. Presidential elections are this weekend, and no one is in any doubt that Mr Voronin, a former baker, will succeed. The outgoing president, Petru Lucinschi, a former communist turned centrist, has described as farcical his five years at the top. How many presidents would resort to such negative comments on leaving office? ''The time when I was working was a complete farce,'' he said, explaining that political bickering made it impossible to achieve much. He added that he hoped the little progress that had been made would prevent a ''return to the past''. As his country under the communists turns towards Russia and further away from the EU, his optimism seems a little out of place. The Moldovan response to all this is to roll out an old joke: "what happens when things hit rock bottom?" Answer: "Start digging". The question is, where to? Guardian Unlimited's first ever TV advertising campaign for online launches tonight.

fields.body:
Guardian Unlimited's first ever TV advertising campaign for online launches tonight.

The commercial involves an animated newspaper that unfolds into a cityscape.

It is the first campaign for the online operation since BMP DDB was appointed to the £6m Guardian account last December.

The 60-second film was created by BMP DDB and introduces the new slogan, "Guardian.co.uk. More breadth. More depth".

The commercial breaks during Channel 4 News and will run for five weeks supported by poster, radio and online adverts and a viral marketing campaign.

"Most people imagine Guardian Unlimited as a newspaper online. This advertising is simply stating that it's much bigger than that," said Marc Sands, marketing director of Guardian Newspapers.

To get the first glance of the TV and online adverts go to our new service showcasing adland's latest work, MediaGuardian.co.uk's Creative Lounge

fields.headline: Return to the red planet
fields.standfirst:
New Mars probes are on the drawing board. Duncan Steel looks at one on the launch pad
Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: New Mars probes are on the drawing board. Duncan Steel looks at one on the launch pad.
fields.body:
All being well, the next mission to Mars will blast off this weekend. Among its prime objectives is to search for flowing water, the absolute requirement of life on Earth, so far as we know.

Success would rekindle hopes of finding life on Mars, even if only microbial. As this is 2001, there was only one name in the running for this new Nasa spaceprobe: Odyssey.

The orbiting satellite carries a range of instruments. One package will monitor the radiation environment, vital information for planning future manned missions. On Earth we are largely shielded from the dangerous flux of high-speed elementary particles made up of the solar wind and cosmic rays. Our magnetic field deflects many of these, producing the Van Allen belts thousands of miles above our heads. But Mars has a far thinner atmosphere, and a weaker magnetic field. Is it a safe planet even to visit, then, let alone colonise?

A gamma-ray spectrometer and a camera equipped with optical and infrared sensors will map its chemical composition. The camera will render fine resolution of fluvial patterns, indicating whether or not they are fresh. It will also allow the distribution of sub-surface ice, similar to permafrost, to be mapped. Such ice has been found using Earth-based radars, and we know that the Martian polar caps are partly made of frozen water, the rest being solid carbon dioxide, or "dry ice".

The possibility of liquid water on Mars was raised last summer when images from the Global Surveyor probe showed evidence of water seeping from the banks of valleys and canyons, especially in the lowest-lying regions of the planet. At such depressed altitudes the atmospheric pressure is greatest, and temperature highest, perhaps resulting in ice melting for a while when Mars is closest to the Sun.

Without huge fanfare, at the end of January Global Surveyor officially completed its mission, which began in September 1997, but data collection continues. In contrast, Nasa's Pathfinder lander which also arrived in 1997 carrying the little rover Sojourner was followed by millions of people over the internet. Not much bigger than a shoebox, checking progress of the tiny six-wheeled buggy set records for hit rates for the site, demonstrating the public popularity of Mars.

The last pair of Mars missions sent by Nasa were anything but successful. The Climate Orbiter probe was lost in September 1999 when it plunged into the Martian atmosphere, owing to a misunderstanding between project teams regarding the rocket burn required to insert it into orbit. One group had used imperial units, the other metric.

Three months later the Polar Lander probe was also a failure, contact being lost as it approached touchdown close to the south pole of Mars.

Critics argue that the history of Martian exploration has been littered with such failures. During the 1960s and 70s a dozen Soviet satellites were either lost completely, or returned very limited data. In 1988 radio contact with two further missions was lost during their cruise towards Mars. Another Russian satellite, including experiments contributed by various European nations, suffered a launch malfunction in 1996.

Japan launched its Nozomi probe to Mars in 1998, but a propulsion problem has delayed its arrival until late in 2003. The Americans may have suffered similar setbacks, but their successes have radically altered our view of the Red Planet.

The Mariner satellites 4, 6 and 7 all sent back pictures of Mars in 1960s flybys. In 1971 Mariner 9 was inserted into orbit around the planet, producing a bounty of information. That was followed in 1976 by the two Viking probes, each consisting of an orbiter module and a lander.

There followed a 17 year gap before Nasa again targeted Mars, with the Mars Orbiter probe. Contact was lost as it neared its destination in August 1993. The new mission due for launch soon - full name 2001 Mars Odyssey Orbiter - is carrying much the same suite of instruments as did Mars Orbiter, with a few improvements due to technological advances.

One lesson leant from the twin disasters in 1999 is that we can try to do too much, too quickly, with too little. There are launch windows to Mars every 26 months, set by the orbital clockwork, and Nasa had intended to send a pair of spacecraft at every opportunity for the next dozen years. The agency now has a long-term phased programme in which the missions alternate between landers and orbiters.

In June 2003 a pair of rover vehicles is to be sent, larger and better equipped that the lonely Sojourner, and also possessing far greater mobility. In 2005 it will be another mapper, the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, carrying a camera capable of detecting features as small as a basketball on the surface far below.

Then in 2007 the first of a new class of lander is planned, called Scout. Because rovers, whether using wheels or legs, can only cover limited terrain around their landing sites, eventually Nasa plans missions employing aerobots (balloon-borne instrument packages circumnavigating the planet with the ambient wind), or some form of aeroplane. Because of the tenuous Martian atmosphere these would need vast propellers, and thick wings to generate enough lift.

Nasa does not have a monopoly however. In 2003 the European Space Agency will launch its Mars Express mission, with the British Beagle 2 lander on board. To some extent this project depends on the imminent successful launch of Odyssey, because a functioning data relay satellite at Mars is needed to collect signals from the lander and then transmit the data back to Earth.

Although the nominal launch date for Odyssey is this Saturday, April 7, there is a window of some weeks. Storms over Cape Canaveral this weekend would not be disastrous, just a hiccup. With the cruise to Mars taking about 200 days, arrival is in late October. A retarding thruster burn during approach will slow Odyssey into a 25-hour orbit. Then aerobraking - flying the satellite through the Martian upper atmosphere to dump momentum - will drop it into a low orbit, taking two hours to loop the planet.

That should be completed by January. Data collection can then begin in earnest, and perhaps we will discover whether there is indeed liquid water on Mars. Remember, experience on Earth indicates that where there's water, there's life.

 Duncan Steel is a space researcher at the University of Salford. His latest book, Target Earth, was published recently by Time Life.

webTitle: Casting news: Christopher Walken is a voice-over villain for Disney

fields.headline: Christopher Walken is a voice-over villain for Disney
fields.standfirst: Plus: The Depardieus play father and son on screen; indie thriller could be screen gem; Robert Carlyle makes hay in western spoof
fields.trailText: Plus: The Depardieus play father and son on screen; indie thriller could be screen gem; Robert Carlyle makes hay in western spoof
fields.body:
 Christopher Walken is to tailor his malevolent movie presence in a comic direction when he takes the role of the human lead in Disney's animatronic kids adventure The Country Bears. Directed by Peter Hastings, the film follows the fortunes of a runaway cub (voiced by Haley Joel Osment) who hooks up with a jamboree-playing band of bears. Walken will play a Scrooge-like banker who wants to break up the party. "Christopher as a heavy is a natural," Hastings told Mr. Showbiz. "But what he really brings to the project is a great sense of humour."

&149; Gerard Depardieu and Guillaume Depardieu are to duplicate their father-son relationship in Honour Thy Father, a French family drama to be helmed by experienced TV director Jacob Berger. The pair previously acted together in All the Mornings of the World.

 Bruce Greenwood (currently starring as JFK in 13 Days) and Linda Fiorentino, of Last Seduction fame, have both signed on to star in the indie production Spoils, which begins shooting on July 10 in locations around Europe and Canada. Written and directed by Nick Meyer, the film, which is set in the aftermath of the second world war, documents the true story of the theft of the German crown jewels.

 Robert Carlyle has signed on for a leading role in the comedy Das Cowboy, a behind-the-scenes satire about a rogues gallery of actors attempting to make a movie western.

fields.headline: House prices keep rising
fields.standfirst:
Britain's largest mortgage providers agree house prices are increases but agree to differ on how much

More about house prices
Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Two of Britain's biggest mortgage providers agree that house prices are still rising, but they disagree markedly about the pace of growth.
fields.body:
Two of Britain's biggest mortgage providers agree that house prices are still rising, but they disagree markedly about the pace of growth.

The Halifax, Britain's largest lender, said yesterday that the price of an average property rose by 0.4% in March to £87,453.

Twenty-hour hours earlier, Nationwide put the figure at 1.4%.

Thelatest figure from Halifax, which follows February's 1.5% rise, means the annual rate is 4.1%, up sharply on January's figure of 0.9% but well down on the 13.5% recorded a year ago.

A Halifax spokesman said the mortgage price war, which has seen several lenders cut their borrowing costs in recent weeks, had provided a boost to the property sector, with important indicators of housing market activity confirming that demand had improved.

Inland revenue figures show a modest pick-up in property sales in the past few months following a slowdown in the second half of 2000.

"The prospects for the housing market remain good," a Halifax spokesman said. "The continuing sound economic ackground, highlighted by the recent fall in unemployment to below 1m, the likelihood of further rate reductions in the coming months and affordability levels that are not stretched should all support demand during the remainder of 2001."

Nationwide said on Tuesday that the typical price tag rose to £85,077 last month, leaving the annual rate of price growth at 7.2%.

It warned that the recent stock market turbulence and the foot and mouth crisis could have an impact on the property markets in London and the countryside.

fields.headline: No room for complacency - Brown
fields.standfirst:
• Government warns against complacency
• NFU warns crisis could escalate tenfold in north
• Daily increase slows for first time
• More vets arrive from US
• Man questioned over shooting

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText:
• Government warns against complacency
• NFU warns crisis could escalate tenfold in north
• Daily increase slows for first time
• More vets arrive from US
• Man questioned over shooting

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.body:
The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, today said that efforts to contain foot and mouth would not be relaxed "one iota", after officials indicated that measures to wipe out the disease had started to take effect.

"There is no room for complacency," he told the Commons. Speaking of the measures being taken to combat the epidemic, he said: "On the basis of scientific advice, it is beginning to bear down on the disease. Nevertheless this is a very serious outbreak and it is likely to have a long tail."

Commenting on reports yesterday from the government's chief scientific adviser, Professor David King, that the crisis would be on the wane by June, Mr Brown said: "We will be better placed to predict the future development of the disease in a week's time."

The number of cases passed 1,000 yesterday but for the first time the daily total of cases decreased. The latest official total of outbreaks stands at 1,028.

Mr Brown said the government was considering opening more disinfectant points to halt the spread of foot and mouth.

However, National Farmers' Union leaders in the north warned that the epidemic could spread much further because of "bureaucratic nonsense".

Malcolm Corbett, chairman of the Northumberland NFU, said: "While they are fiddling in Cumbria this problem is going to get 10 times worse in Northumberland."

Meanwhile, more vets were arriving in Britain from the US to help keep the slaughter policy on track and the number of soldiers involved in combating the disease is set to almost double in the next two weeks from 1,500 to 2,900, government sources said.

The Conservative leader, William Hague, said ministers should be thinking long term instead of being "obsessed with the daily numbers game".

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, was today meeting tourism bosses to discuss recovery plans as the English Tourist Board launched a campaign to revitalise the industry over the Easter break. The actor Sean Connery was expected to tell Americans later today that Britain was safe to visit.

But Mr Hague said in a speech at Uttoxeter race course that the government should introduce a permanent cut in business rates for all firms in rural areas. The opposition leader also proposed the creation of a gene bank for rare breeds threatened with decimation by the crisis.

Information urging farmers to delay letting cows back out to pasture after a winter inside was being sent out today in a bid to halt the spread.

If animals on farms where the disease is found were culled within 24 hours, and animals on neighbouring farms within 48 hours, the number of daily outbreaks would be reduced to a trickle by June, graphs released yesterday show.

The new figures make the use of vaccines less likely and mean the disease could be on the wane when, as widely expected, the prime minister, Tony Blair, calls a general election on June 7.

 A man was been arrested yesterday in connection with the shooting of a slaughterman during the mass cull of livestock in Cumbria. The 37-year-old man was arrested after an incident at Great Orton, near Carlisle. He is being questioned at Carlisle police station, Cumbria police said.

The victim, a 27-year-old man from Hastings, East Sussex, is fighting for his life after suffering serious head injuries in the incident at 4pm yesterday.

Both men were involved in the killing of livestock at the mass burial site on the former airfield when the incident occurred.

The 37-year-old man was arrested after an incident at Great Orton, near Carlisle. He is being questioned at Carlisle police station, Cumbria police said. The victim, a 27-year-old man from Hastings, East Sussex, is fighting for his life after suffering serious head injuries in the incident at 4pm yesterday. Both men were involved in the killing of livestock at the mass burial site on the former airfield when the incident occurred. Former Bristol council chief executive Lucy de Groot is one of those people who's doomed to be tipped for every big local government job going. fields.headline: South Africa's past catches up with it
fields.standfirst: How do you go about the awesome task of rewriting a nation's history, asks Chris McGreal
fields.trailText: It was little more than 20 years ago that a group of men in suits waving a bucket stormed on to the stage of the University of South Africa's lecture hall, pinned down Floors van Jaarsveld, and tarred and feathered him. Van Jaarsveld's crime was to question the myth of Afrikanerdom's holiest day - the Day of Covenant. The historian asked how Afrikaners could claim that divine intervention enabled 471 Boers to defeat 15,000 Zulus at the Battle of Blood River when the whites had been slaughtered at a previous encounter between the two. Did God switch sides, he wondered?
fields.body:
It was little more than 20 years ago that a group of men in suits waving a bucket stormed on to the stage of the University of South Africa's lecture hall, pinned down Floors van Jaarsveld, and tarred and feathered him. Van Jaarsveld's crime was to question the myth of Afrikanerdom's holiest day - the Day of Covenant. The historian asked how Afrikaners could claim that divine intervention enabled 471 Boers to defeat 15,000 Zulus at the Battle of Blood River when the whites had been slaughtered at a previous encounter between the two. Did God switch sides, he wondered?

It was too much for Eugene Terre'Blanche and his neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement (AWB). Almost no one in South Africa had heard of Terre'Blanche until he led the charge to punish Van Jaarsveld's heresy. After that, the AWB's ranks swelled, while the historian was shunned. White South Africa was far from ready to question the myths about God, race and land that provided the deluded basis for apartheid.

Two decades later, the Day of the Covenant holiday has been consigned to a very tall scrap heap of discarded fictions once taken as history. But South Africa is grappling to decide what to replace them with. "The standard thing here is to unlearn what you've learnt in school," says Bill Nasson, head of history at the University of Cape Town. "You have this old history, which is that South Africa starts in 1652 with the arrival of Jan van Riebeeck. That's gone. The problem is what you replace that with. You could replace it with the liberation struggle that begins in 1653, but that simply replaces one form of nationalist history with another.

"South Africa has a very complex history. It's the only country in Africa that had slaves imported from other parts of Africa, and when some of those slaves were freed they took slaves themselves. The problem is to address this kind of thing without vilifying one group and making martyrs of another. Nothing is straightforward in our history."

The first stage of officially reassessing South Africa's history has focused on schools, which are still waiting for the government to decide what will be taught, let alone rewrite the text books and print them. The education ministry appointed a committee of prominent historians, anthropologists and archaeologists - including Nasson - to mull over how best to address South Africa's complex past. There was common agreement that history is discredited and therefore in crisis.

"It is a considerable irony that we are having to address a 'crisis in history' when the pressing importance of history continues to be demonstrated daily in South Africa," the report said. "For we live in a society in which contemporary issues are continually understood and judged within the powerful context of a past which has bequeathed a violent legacy of conquest, colonialism and apartheid."

The school system is still heavily reliant on the old history books. Revised textbooks are available for those schools that can afford them. Some, such as the pioneering National Education Crisis Committee Peoples' History book, are widely praised. Others are simply the old version of events with a picture of Nelson Mandela on the cover.

The easy bit was deciding to dump the version of history peppered with white heroes with Dutch surnames. For decades children of all races learned that the Afrikaner was the real victim of South Africa's strife. As it was told, the peaceful Boers who settled in the Cape were oppressed by the British in the early 19th century, and so forced to make the Great Trek north. They were attacked and betrayed by the great African chiefs, including the king of the Zulus, and so had to fight for their survival.

And when they had finally established their own countries with the Boer republics, the British made war to get their hands on Johannesburg's gold mines. Tens of thousands of Boer women and children were murdered in the infamous British concentration camps. And when it was over, the Afrikaner was a British subject and a second-class citizen.

Only in 1948, with the election of the National party government, was the Afrikaner liberated. All of this went to justify the imposition of apartheid. It was not a form of oppression, its authors argued, but a survival strategy for a people persecuted on all sides.

In this version of history there was no room for the fate of the Khoikhoi, slaughtered after Van Riebeeck's arrival, or the tens of thousands of black people who also died in the British concentration camps. There was no mention of stolen land or forced removals or the execution of African men for wanting the right to govern. Neither was there recognition of the iron-age settlements in what is now Johannesburg, because that conflicted with the version of history that says the Afrikaners did not steal the land because it was empty.

Much of Afrikaner historical orthodoxy emanated from Stellenbosch University. Today the history department is led by Albert Grundlingh, the first person to hold the post who is not a former student at Stellenbosch. "History in this country is a congealed set of misunderstandings," he says. "The problem today is that after 1994 [and South Africa's first all-race election], history sort of vanished. I would like to suggest that history has served its purpose so far as the liberation movement was concerned. They don't need it to justify being in power.

"That was not the case of the Afrikaners, who used history even after they won power in 1948. It was used to justify everything they did.

"I don't think we want to substitute one set of heroes for another - black for white. But we have to begin somewhere, and I'd like to think that there is a hidden history of black and white cooperation. You can ask yourself how it is possible to maintain a system like apartheid over 300 years without cooperation. That is a good basis for exploration."

Thabo Bashe knows only too well the shortcomings of the old version of history. Once a political prisoner, he is now deputy headmaster of Zola secondary school in Khayelitsha, a sprawling black township outside Cape Town. "We wanted to know more about the struggle against apartheid. At school nothing would be said about that. As students we wanted to learn about Mandela and how the land was taken from black farmers. I went to a meeting addressed by Steve Biko, and that was the first time we heard about our own history."

Yet 11 years after Mandela was released from prison, and seven years after he was elected president, Zola secondary school still relies on apartheid-era history books. Some pupils use a 1987 text, History In Action, written specifically for black schools. It has 30 pages on the Great Trek. There are just three on black South African history.

Bashe despairs. "If you go to class, most teachers are still using the same books and asking the same questions of learners and marking them in the same way," he says. "The sad thing is, the learners don't seem to notice. It takes a long time to get the idea of white superiority out of the system, even among black learners."

Bashe says that in many ways it would be easier to leave history out of the curriculum. "But we have to teach history because these learners must be able to understand why we have Khayelitsha and why there are only black people here and why there are no coloured [mixed-race] or white people. They will understand this is a wrong thing, and that is why this must never happen again. So if the government says we are going to oppress the white people who did this to us, they need to understand why that is wrong."

Many whites have reinterpreted history to suit themselves, though on the whole they prefer to avoid the subject. "In Afrikaner circles there has been a flight from history because of apartheid," says Dr Grundlingh. "But there are others who are discovering another false history. Among some coloured people there's the deliberate invention of a Khoikhoi heritage as a way of saying we were here before the black people. It's one-upping the Africans. It's a joke because I don't think any of them have Khoikhoi blood. This is how myths are made."

fields.headline: Chancellor has to delay homes aid to poorest
fields.standfirst:
Measures to tackle inner city deprivation postponed until after general election

Special report: Labour party
Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown has been forced to postpone a £100m measure to tackle inner city deprivation until after the expected June 7 general election because of a delay in compiling statistics.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown has been forced to postpone a £100m measure to tackle inner city deprivation until after the expected June 7 general election because of a delay in compiling statistics.

The chancellor had hoped to give a pre-election boost to Labour's heartlands by scrapping stamp duty on all property sales in the poorest areas. But the measure cannot be introduced until a map of poverty hotspots throughout the UK has been completed.

The delay emerged after the Northern Ireland assembly announced that it would not complete its map - a deprivation indicator - until mid June. All other regions have completed their maps.

The delay will come as a blow to the chancellor, who first announced the lifting of stamp duties in deprived areas in last November's pre-budget report.

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, later claimed that it would help to bring about an "urban renaissance" in these areas.

Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, last night seized on the delay. "Gordon Brown has spent the past four years in creasing taxes, like stamp duty," he said. "Now we learn that he is not even able to deliver a tiny relief from his own stealth tax, when he promised he would do so," Mr Portillo added

The Treasury last night played down the delay, saying that the chancellor had always said that the measure would be introduced only when the finance bill received royal assent.

The delay is expected to hold up property sales in deprived areas as buyers wait to benefit from the tax cut.

Stamp duty is paid on property deals worth more than £60,000. Buyers have to pay 1% of the value of their property on sales over £60,000 and under £250,000.

This rises to 3% on properties over £250,000 and under £500,000. On properties worth more than £500,000 buyers pay 4%.

Michael Osborne, the director of the East London estate agents Hamilton Fox, said: "Buyers for £250,000 plus properties will definitely be waiting until they hear the news on stamp duty. They would be crazy not to."

fields.headline: Timeline: from surveillance to stalemate
fields.standfirst:
How the US-China spy plane standoff developed

Special report: China

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: How the US-China spy plane standoff developed
fields.body:
(All times, except where stated, are GMT)

Sunday April 1

9.15am local time: Chinese fighters intercept an American surveillance plane above the South China sea. The US aircraft is damaged and forced to make an emergency landing. As the plane descends, its crew is believed to be destroying intelligence equipment.

Hainan island, China, 9.33am local time: The US aircraft lands without permission on Chinese territory. Here, the 24-member crew makes its last radio contact with the US navy. They say soldiers are boarding the plane.

Camp David, USA, minutes later: President George Bush is told about the collision by his national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice. In Washington, a White House spokesman says the United States expects both the aircraft and crew to be returned safely.

Beijing, late afternoon: After a long silence the Chinese foreign ministry issues a statement blaming the US aircraft for the collision. According to Beijing, its jets were conducting normal flight operations six miles south of Hainan island when the spy plane suddenly veered towards them. China says one of its jets crashed and its pilot is still missing. The US ambassador to China meets the Chinese deputy foreign minister in an attempt to resolve the situation.

US navy command, Hawaii, shortly before midnight: The Pacific command chief, admiral Dennis Blair, says the US spy plane was in international airspace when it was intercepted by the Chinese jets. He says it was 70 miles off the coast of Hainan and, on the ground, enjoys a "sovereign immunity" that prevents other countries from boarding the plane or seizing its contents. The admiral blames the collision on "unprofessional" Chinese tactics. "It's not a normal practice to play bumper cars in the air," he says.

Monday April 2

Hainan island, early morning: Three US diplomats arrive in the island's capital to visit the spy plane's crew. They are refused permission. The US ambassador in Beijing says China has no legal right to hold the 24 servicemen and women.

The South China sea, later that morning: A US official reveals that three warships passing through the waters off Hainan island will now "loiter" in the area while the aircraft is grounded. "I wouldn't say it's a show of force," he says. "Their presence is a constant signal of US interest."

Washington, afternoon: President Bush meets his security advisers and calls on China to grant access to the crew "promptly".

Beijing, evening: China announces it will grant access to the crew late on Tuesday.

The South China sea, later that evening: The three US warships pull out of the region to continue their original missions.

Tuesday April 3

Beijing, morning: The Chinese president, Jiang Zemin, says the US must bear full responsibility for the collision. A Chinese news agency reports that Mr Jiang claims to have "sufficient evidence" that the US was to blame. Foreign ministry officials announce that they have the right to inspect the US plane.

Afternoon: China asks for an apology from the US for the collision. A foreign ministry spokesman says Beijing also demands an explanation of US air surveillance near the Chinese coast.

Hainan island, early evening: US diplomats are granted access to the crew. They say the want to ascertain the servicemen and women's heath and then secure their release. A defence attache, Neal Sealock, says the crew are all "doing fine" and have faith in America.

Washington, evening: President Bush warns that the incident threatens to damage US-Chinese relations. "This accident has the potential of undermining our hopes for a fruitful and productive relationship between our two countries," he says in a televised appearance at the White House.

On condition of anonymity, a US official says he has seen satellite images that show Chinese authorities examining the spy plane. He describes technicians "taking a wrench to it, fooling around with it, examining it, tinkering with it".

Wednesday April 4

Hainan island, morning: US diplomats press for a second meeting with the spy plane's crew. They receive no answer.

Beijing, morning: Mr Jiang demands an apology from the US before embarking on a trip to South America.

On a flight to Washington, morning: The US secretary of state, Colin Powell, insists that there is nothing to apologise for.

London, morning: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, says China is not "realistic" to expect an apology and presses for the two countries to resolve the dispute.

Beijing, afternoon: The Chinese foreign minister, Tang Jiaxuan, comes out of a meeting with the US ambassador and accuses America of "arrogance".

Washington, afternoon: A White House spokesman says that Mr Bush does not want the situation to become an "international incident". The president's preferred solution is for the Chinese to release the US crew without an apology from Washington.

Washington, evening: Mr Powell expresses regret for the death of the Chinese pilot involved in the collision but does not apologise or accept responsibility. He tells reporters: "We need to move and we need to bring this to a resolution."

fields.bodyText: (All times, except where stated, are GMT) Sunday April 1 9.15am local time: Chinese fighters intercept an American surveillance plane above the South China sea. The US aircraft is damaged and forced to make an emergency landing. As the plane descends, its crew is believed to be destroying intelligence equipment. Hainan island, China, 9.33am local time: The US aircraft lands without permission on Chinese territory. Here, the 24-member crew makes its last radio contact with the US navy. They say soldiers are boarding the plane. Camp David, USA, minutes later: President George Bush is told about the collision by his national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice. In Washington, a White House spokesman says the United States expects both the aircraft and crew to be returned safely. Beijing, late afternoon: After a long silence the Chinese foreign ministry issues a statement blaming the US aircraft for the collision. According to Beijing, its jets were conducting normal flight operations six miles south of Hainan island when the spy plane suddenly veered towards them. China says one of its jets crashed and its pilot is still missing. The US ambassador to China meets the Chinese deputy foreign minister in an attempt to resolve the situation. US navy command, Hawaii, shortly before midnight: The Pacific command chief, admiral Dennis Blair, says the US spy plane was in international airspace when it was intercepted by the Chinese jets. He says it was 70 miles off the coast of Hainan and, on the ground, enjoys a "sovereign immunity" that prevents other countries from boarding the plane or seizing its contents. The admiral blames the collision on "unprofessional" Chinese tactics. "It's not a normal practice to play bumper cars in the air," he says. Monday April 2 Hainan island, early morning: Three US diplomats arrive in the island's capital to visit the spy plane's crew. They are refused permission. The US ambassador in Beijing says China has no legal right to hold the 24 servicemen and women. The South China sea, later that morning: A US official reveals that three warships passing through the waters off Hainan island will now "loiter" in the area while the aircraft is grounded. "I wouldn't say it's a show of force," he says. "Their presence is a constant signal of US interest." Washington, afternoon: President Bush meets his security advisers and calls on China to grant access to the crew "promptly". Beijing, evening: China announces it will grant access to the crew late on Tuesday. The South China sea, later that evening: The three US warships pull out of the region to continue their original missions. Tuesday April 3 Beijing, morning: The Chinese president, Jiang Zemin, says the US must bear full responsibility for the collision. A Chinese news agency reports that Mr Jiang claims to have "sufficient evidence" that the US was to blame. Foreign ministry officials announce that they have the right to inspect the US plane. Afternoon: China asks for an apology from the US for the collision. A foreign ministry spokesman says Beijing also demands an explanation of US air surveillance near the Chinese coast. Hainan island, early evening: US diplomats are granted access to the crew. They say the want to ascertain the servicemen and women's heath and then secure their release. A defence attache, Neal Sealock, says the crew are all "doing fine" and have faith in America. Washington, evening: President Bush warns that the incident threatens to damage US-Chinese relations. "This accident has the potential of undermining our hopes for a fruitful and productive relationship between our two countries," he says in a televised appearance at the White House. On condition of anonymity, a US official says he has seen satellite images that show Chinese authorities examining the spy plane. He describes technicians "taking a wrench to it, fooling around with it, examining it, tinkering with it". Wednesday April 4 Hainan island, morning: US diplomats press for a second meeting with the spy plane's crew. They receive no answer. Beijing, morning: Mr Jiang demands an apology from the US before embarking on a trip to South America. On a flight to Washington, morning: The US secretary of state, Colin Powell, insists that there is nothing to apologise for. London, morning: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, says China is not "realistic" to expect an apology and presses for the two countries to resolve the dispute. Beijing, afternoon: The Chinese foreign minister, Tang Jiaxuan, comes out of a meeting with the US ambassador and accuses America of "arrogance". Washington, afternoon: A White House spokesman says that Mr Bush does not want the situation to become an "international incident". The president's preferred solution is for the Chinese to release the US crew without an apology from Washington. Washington, evening: Mr Powell expresses regret for the death of the Chinese pilot involved in the collision but does not apologise or accept responsibility. He tells reporters: "We need to move and we need to bring this to a resolution." fields.headline: We unhappy few Tories
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair will be Prime Minister next Christmas because he understands what the British public want


Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The public doesn't expect a great deal out of its politicians on the caring front. Often a sympathetic face is enough.
fields.body:
The public doesn't expect a great deal out of its politicians on the caring front. Often a sympathetic face is enough. Tony Blair understands this, which is why he will still be prime minister next Christmas. William Hague does not, which is why he invariably hits the bum note. Tone is what it is all about. Pun intended.

Our Tone's heart has gone out to the countryside and he's delayed the elections by a month just to show how much he cares. It won't much impress the farmers, to whom a month's delay seems rather paltry, but it should go down well with the largely urban British public.

And that's what matters. There are votes in showing a little charity. In a poll last week two thirds of those interviewed felt that Tony Blair should delay the elections. But the only justification for doing such a thing is for form's sake. There is no big democratic issue here and there aren't even many farmers who would claim there is.

By and large, modern politicians do not find it necessary to kiss sheep while canvassing and farmers trapped behind little squashed piles of disinfected straw could use postal votes. No, to most people it has simply seemed wrong to have some gung ho election campaign going on, while a section of our population was suffering so publicly.

It was a feeling that gained strength - and a certain edge - from the impression given over the past four years that the Labour party actively dislikes farmers and their ilk.

Farmers are the few not the many: that is, the ones Tony Blair said he didn't want to govern for. Worse, they are more representative of traditional Britain than cool Britannia. They look and sound as if they may be part of the "forces of conservatism". Didn't Tony once turn on such people and say, "You're history"? If not, it was certainly something very like it.

God forbid that one should be in the wrong socioeconomic category in New Labour's Britain. Neil Kinnock struck a chord when he warned people not to grow old or sick under a Conservative government. Now, under Labour, people must worry about growing unfashionable as well.

First you have your way of life held up for ridicule at a Labour party conference. Then you cough your last breath on a trolley in some dirty hospital corridor. Gee, like they say, "Life's a bitch and then you die."

There have, in any case, been specific attacks on country people: John Prescott describing the faces of Countryside Alliance protesters as "contorted"; Alastair Campbell smearing every farmer in Britain as a crook.

If farmers trusted this government we could have had this election in May, because they would have swallowed the line that this would in no way suggest that farmers were a low priority, but would support tourism. And everyone else would have swallowed it too. But, of course, farmers don't trust the government - they fear it.

We are not a nation of bullies. We don't like to see our neighbours being kicked when they are down and seeing the powers that be turning on a group - any group - makes the rest of us very uncomfortable.

"But what about the miners?" is the left's refrain. "Who cared about them?" What are these people talking about? The constant reiteration that nobody who didn't vote for Michael Foot cared about the miners is extremely offensive. I am sure most Tory voters like me felt for the miners in the 1980s.

I didn't like to see men lose their jobs, to see a whole way of life go down the plughole, to know that many would never work again. Who are all these mythical people who didn't care about the miners?

If there was contempt among us it was reserved for poor old Arthur Scargill, who doesn't seem to be exactly at the heart of the Labour establishment these days, as would surely befit one of Bloody Margaret's martyrs, especially since he was right all along about how many mines were to close.

Nastiness entered the Tory party near the end of the decade; the era that inspired the creation of Tory Boy and Alan B'Stard. One of the reasons the Conservative party is 15 points behind in the polls is because people think the party still has a nasty streak.

It is hardly something the Labour party should emulate. But then it doesn't need to. It has a very nasty streak all of its own. Those who wear their hearts on their sleeves when they talk about the poor miners losing their jobs a generation ago are the same people who seem to revel in the suffering of farmers or hauliers now.

webTitle: Tories rage over rushed elections bill

fields.headline: Tories rage over rushed elections bill
fields.standfirst:
Full coverage of Election 2001
Election 2001: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Emergency legislation postponing local elections until June 7 because of the foot-and-mouth outbreak came under assault from Tory MPs last night despite government efforts to push the bill through the Commons in a day.
fields.body:
Emergency legislation postponing local elections until June 7 because of the foot-and-mouth outbreak came under assault from Tory MPs last night despite government efforts to push the bill through the Commons in a day.

Tories claimed the severe restrictions on debate were "outrageous and absurd", tyrannical and an "insult to the parliamentary process".

But the home secretary, Jack Straw, said it was essential to move quickly to provide certainty for everyone involved in the elections. A Tory motion to stop the government's guillotine motion was defeated by 320 votes to 185. The guillotine measure had only been introduced because the Opposition frontbench was incapable of preventing its own backbenchers, Mr Straw said.

The Conservative leader William Hague said he would not co-operate with the bill, arguing the local elections should be held back until the foot and mouth crisis had been fully cleared. Conservatives added it was wrong to delay local elections in Northern Ireland since there was only one outbreak of foot and mouth throughout the province. It is the first time local elections have been delayed since the second world war.

The bill also allows 50% compensation to cover the extra cost for councils of delaying the elections. It is due to be discussed by the Lords today and on Monday and could become law early next week.

MPs were also being asked to speed through the elections (publications) bill which is designed to save political parties having to pulp tens of thousands of election leaflets. It was introduced after the parties realised they were all go ing to be in breach of revised regulations on the printing of election material such as posters. New regulations require parties to state on their literature whether they have been funded by third parties, such as unions.

The Conservative bakcbencher, Eric Forth, claimed the government was "breaking new parliamentary ground by having the gall and the arrogance to say the law of the land should be made with one hour's consideration".

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, accused the government of laziness for setting an 11pm deadline for consideration of the bills last night. She said: "Members opposite want to go home rather than to stay here and ensure that the legislation being considered ... is in good order."

For the Liberal Democrats, Andrew Stunnell said the guillotine motion was "completely out of place" and unnecessary. "The government should first of all agree to lift the guillotine and withdraw the motion and let the debate take its course: they would be pleasantly surprised," he said.

Tory home affairs spokesman, Nick Hawkins, said the "panic" guillotine measure would lead to the "most significant part of parliamentary scrutiny being squeezed" into no more than an hour. He accused the government of Orwellian behaviour, "using words in the way that suits them, changing the rules as they go along".

For the government, the junior Northern Ireland minister, George Howarth, said postponing the local elections was not a step "taken lightly" but was taken in the national interest as a matter of urgency.

"We need to make sure there is clarity for candidates and councils. We are doing precisely what the Conservatives requested us."

fields.headline: English eccentric
fields.standfirst: She was the queen of punk, and for 30 years she created the most exciting and outrageous designs in British fashion. Now, just days from her 60th birthday, Vivienne Westwood has no intention of fading away quietly.  Jess Cartner-Morley meets the legend
fields.trailText: She was the queen of punk, and for 30 years she created the most exciting and outrageous designs in British fashion. Now, just days from her 60th birthday, Vivienne Westwood has no intention of fading away quietly. Jess Cartner-Morley meets the legend.
fields.body:
Vivienne Westwood has dressed everyone from the Sex Pistols to supermodels. It is 60 years on Sunday since she was born, near the village of Tintwistle in Derbyshire; 30 years since she opened her legendary Kings Road shop. Once the Queen of Punk, Westwood has become the tabloids' favourite English eccentric, a dotty aunt figure patronised by taxi drivers and kissed in the street by strangers.

Westwood still holds a respectable evening slot on the Paris fashion week calendar; she is still sole owner of her company and of her name, no mean feat in a cut-throat industry full of white-toothed alligators hungry to strip the flesh off starry-eyed designers' ideas. Her stature is deserved: she is a great innovator, a unique talent who combines an insatiable appetite for culture and historical references with an unclouded modern eye and a rigorous approach to the craft of making clothes. As the art director of punk and the creator of the Pirates and Mini Crini collections, Westwood is responsible for some of fashion's most memorable images. Currently, moreover, she is enjoying a revival of interest among the edgier, artier ranks of the fashion world, with stylists and the hipper It Girls fighting over vintage Westwood pieces.

She is, however, in an absolutely foul mood. She doesn't want revivals, she doesn't want to be a national treasure. She wants to be taken seriously as a contemporary fashion designer. Her ex-husband, Malcolm McLaren, knew how to inflict maximum pain when he said last year that her designs "seemed to make more sense back in the 80s". Today she is fuming over the meagre press coverage of her most recent collection. In her surprisingly dowdy Battersea office, dressed in a tartan skirt with pink tights and sweater. With a diamante spider glittering at her throat, she fiddles with her cuffs and chainsmokes Gitanes, her pursed mouth emphasising the flatness of her Derbyshire vowels. Her hair is scooped into the picture-perfect pin curls of a Disney cartoon princess and tinted the colour of peach yoghurt. She is attempting to put a brave face on the disappointment - "I don't really care about the press. I used to be upset by it, but now it doesn't upset me" - but the bravado is not entirely convincing. "It's just annoying when you do what in my opinion is the best show of the whole season and there are no pictures of it, and in a few years someone else will copy it and everyone will think it's new."

Would it be fair to say she feels bitter? "Not at all. I'm very happy at the moment." She bristles visibly. "The world is a paradise," she snaps.

Westwood has never been the cosy figure some would now like to cast her as. Born Vivienne Swire, she married Derek Westwood at 21, and had a son, Ben. But three years later, she left her home and her career as a primary school teacher, and discovered Malcolm McLaren and fashion. Her 15-year relationship with McLaren was a great creative partnership, and produced a son, Joe. Now grown up, Joe Corre (the name came from McLaren's grandmother after McLaren refused to put his name on his son's birth certificate) is co-owner and co-designer of the Agent Provocateur lingerie label with his wife, Serena Rees. Their three-year-old daughter, Cora, took a star turn on Westwood's catwalk last month. Since 1992, Westwood has been married to her third husband, Andreas Kronthaler.

But these days, says Westwood, it is becoming difficult to shock anyone. "When I first started out I was walking around in S&M clothes, and no one else was. But these days those things are so mainstream that I'm not sure where you get that edge of rebellion from."

She attracts publicity without trying: in 1992 she twirled for the photographers outside Buckingham Palace after collecting her OBE, forgetting she wasn't wearing knickers; in 1999 she found herself in the headlines when it was discovered that Lambeth Council and the Heritage Lottery Fund had given £17,530 to restore iron railings and cracks in the brickwork of her Clapham house, once the home of Captain Cook's mother. Her views on fashion and sex are always provocative: she pronounces today, for instance, that "it is wonderful to be an object. You learn your power that way. I don't think feminists realise that."

But she doesn't want to talk about fashion. She wants to talk about reading, "the most concentrated form of experience you can have". A committed auto-didact, Westwood has long been a voracious reader: even as a punk, she remembers, "I'd be designing and in the back of my mind would be, I'll just get this done and then I can read my book."

Her favourite authors are Aldous Huxley and Bertrand Russell; she has most recently bought the book IBM and The Holocaust: "Because I think that's very important to read. The lengths that businesses will go to to make money - that sums up the 20th century, doesn't it. They would not have been able to round up all those Jewish people if IBM hadn't supplied all the information."

For years, Westwood has favoured Paris for staging catwalk shows. "I've hardly ever shown in London. There was a short time, when there was Rifat [Ozbek] and John Galliano showing here, that it felt like there was quite a high standard. But not now. Whereas there are people working in Paris who I consider to have some sort of professionalism," she pronounces haughtily, lighting yet another Gitane.

She likes Paris, although an unnamed friend thinks it has "gone downhill". Why? "Because of Marxism. People who consider themselves intellectuals but don't have time to really explore ideas ... Everything comes from Marx, this idea that everyone is supposed to be equal. I'm not harking upon [sic] to any age of privilege, I'm only remarking that in those ages of privilege, you also had a hierarchy of values, and nowadays there's no intrinsic value. This idea that the proletariat is born better than the rest of the world, that anyone can do anything, just because they want to, that it's all subjective."

Is that not a somewhat different viewpoint from Marxism? "Everything comes from Marx. Marxism has got completely melded with democracy."

It's hard to figure out what she's trying to say and how we got here from discussing Paris. Perhaps she is referring to the recent French municipal elections, and Paris' new socialist mayor? "What elections. I didn't know about any elections," she huffs. She is really cross now, whether because France had the temerity to hold elections without informing her personally, or because she suspects me of making up world events, I don't know. Does she read the newspapers? "Of course I read the newspapers". And so we go on.

She is not easy to talk to today. A few days later she sends me a fax to clarify her opinions on "the Marxism issue". Her point is that "when there are no judges there is no art, because we're left with the idea that everything is equal and nothing has intrinsic value."

She is in the habit of sending such notes after interviews: detesting interruptions, she is keen to make sure you fully ingest her views. She is naturally a declaimer rather than a debater, shooting out peculiar, brittle shards of dinner-party cleverness, loudly but without eye contact: "I don't believe there's such a thing as progress" and even "There haven't been any ideas in the 20th century."

She seems unwilling to entertain the concept that there might be interesting ideas of which she is unaware. She rarely visits the theatre, for instance, simply because "there's not much going on there".

On the subject of her fellow designers she attempts regal disdain - "It's not of any great interest to me what anyone else is doing" - but cannot resist adding cattily "although it would be, if I thought they were doing anything good."

The trouble with fashion is that: "There's no professionalism any more. It's all about art school, and designers aren't taught anything technical. They're not taught how to manipulate fabrics. I can make manufactured garments hang like couture, because I understand fabric. If you don't have technique you can't express yourself; you can do whatever drawing you like but it's not going to work, so you can only put together things you've already seen. Art school ruins people. After three or five years there these people think they can make clothes, and they can't. They're very frustrated."

A weary sigh. "Actually, they're not frustrated. Some of them think they're wonderful" she spits, sounding rather frustrated herself.

She attracts publicity without trying: in 1992 she twirled for the photographers outside Buckingham Palace after collecting her OBE, forgetting she wasn't wearing knickers; in 1999 she found herself in the headlines when it was discovered that Lambeth Council and the Heritage Lottery Fund had given £17,530 to restore iron railings and cracks in the brickwork of her Clapham house, once the home of Captain Cook's mother. Her views on fashion and sex are always provocative: she pronounces today, for instance, that "it is wonderful to be an object. You learn your power that way. I don't think feminists realise that." But she doesn't want to talk about fashion. She wants to talk about reading, "the most concentrated form of experience you can have". A committed auto-didact, Westwood has long been a voracious reader: even as a punk, she remembers, "I'd be designing and in the back of my mind would be, I'll just get this done and then I can read my book." Her favourite authors are Aldous Huxley and Bertrand Russell; she has most recently bought the book IBM and The Holocaust: "Because I think that's very important to read. The lengths that businesses will go to to make money - that sums up the 20th century, doesn't it. They would not have been able to round up all those Jewish people if IBM hadn't supplied all the information." For years, Westwood has favoured Paris for staging catwalk shows. "I've hardly ever shown in London. There was a short time, when there was Rifat [Ozbek] and John Galliano showing here, that it felt like there was quite a high standard. But not now. Whereas there are people working in Paris who I consider to have some sort of professionalism," she pronounces haughtily, lighting yet another Gitane. She likes Paris, although an unnamed friend thinks it has "gone downhill". Why? "Because of Marxism. People who consider themselves intellectuals but don't have time to really explore ideas ... Everything comes from Marx, this idea that everyone is supposed to be equal. I'm not harking upon [sic] to any age of privilege, I'm only remarking that in those ages of privilege, you also had a hierarchy of values, and nowadays there's no intrinsic value. This idea that the proletariat is born better than the rest of the world, that anyone can do anything, just because they want to, that it's all subjective." Is that not a somewhat different viewpoint from Marxism? "Everything comes from Marx. Marxism has got completely melded with democracy." It's hard to figure out what she's trying to say and how we got here from discussing Paris. Perhaps she is referring to the recent French municipal elections, and Paris' new socialist mayor? "What elections. I didn't know about any elections," she huffs. She is really cross now, whether because France had the temerity to hold elections without informing her personally, or because she suspects me of making up world events, I don't know. Does she read the newspapers? "Of course I read the newspapers". And so we go on. She is not easy to talk to today. A few days later she sends me a fax to clarify her opinions on "the Marxism issue". Her point is that "when there are no judges there is no art, because we're left with the idea that everything is equal and nothing has intrinsic value." She is in the habit of sending such notes after interviews: detesting interruptions, she is keen to make sure you fully ingest her views. She is naturally a declaimer rather than a debater, shooting out peculiar, brittle shards of dinner-party cleverness, loudly but without eye contact: "I don't believe there's such a thing as progress" and even "There haven't been any ideas in the 20th century." She seems unwilling to entertain the concept that there might be interesting ideas of which she is unaware. She rarely visits the theatre, for instance, simply because "there's not much going on there". On the subject of her fellow designers she attempts regal disdain - "It's not of any great interest to me what anyone else is doing" - but cannot resist adding cattily "although it would be, if I thought they were doing anything good." The trouble with fashion is that: "There's no professionalism any more. It's all about art school, and designers aren't taught anything technical. They're not taught how to manipulate fabrics. I can make manufactured garments hang like couture, because I understand fabric. If you don't have technique you can't express yourself; you can do whatever drawing you like but it's not going to work, so you can only put together things you've already seen. Art school ruins people. After three or five years there these people think they can make clothes, and they can't. They're very frustrated." A weary sigh. "Actually, they're not frustrated. Some of them think they're wonderful" she spits, sounding rather frustrated herself.

fields.headline: Thursday's rumours
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours got the 66/1shot Art Prince in the Grand National office sweepstake
fields.trailText: Alex Ferguson has £60m to spend this summer - and he wants to splash it on Ruud Van Nistelrooy, Rivaldo, Pavel Nedved and Lilian Thuram, reports the Sun. The Mail reckons that United have already begun negotiations with main target Van Nistelrooy, and "will move swiftly" to complete a £10m deal by the end of the season. But United and Van Nistelrooy have both issued statements this morning saying there is no truth in the rumours that new talks have started.
fields.body:
Alex Ferguson has £60m to spend this summer - and he wants to splash it on Ruud Van Nistelrooy, Rivaldo, Pavel Nedved and Lilian Thuram, reports the Sun. The Mail reckons that United have already begun negotiations with main target Van Nistelrooy, and "will move swiftly" to complete a £10m deal by the end of the season. But United and Van Nistelrooy have both issued statements this morning saying there is no truth in the rumours that new talks have started.

Newcastle are planning a move for Nottingham Forest's £4m-rated midfielder David Prutton, reports the Mail. Forest manager David Platt concedes: "We are losing money and have to do something about it."

Ambitious Watford want Gianluca Vialli to be their new manager, reports the Sun. The paper insists the club will make an approach this summer.

Christian Ziege has told Paul Ince he fancies a move back to Middlesbrough, reports the Daily Star. But a deal seems unlikely with Boro chairman Steve Gibson still seething about Ziege's move to Liverpool last summer. "We haven't closed the option of taking the matter outside football," he said. "Liverpool and Ziege know exactly what went on and we wish to expose that through the correct channels so the matter can be concluded to the satisfaction of the Premier League rulebook."

Southampton striker Marian Pahars will not be joining Newcastle in a £7m deal, according to Saints chairman Rupert Lowe. "We need to keep our squad together," he said. "Southampton have got to win games in the new stadium and you are not going to do that without your best players - we are not looking to sell."

Nicolas Anelka could be on the move again - this time to Italy. Onefootball reports that Anelka's brothers, Claude and Dider - who also act as his agents - have been given permission by PSG to meet with Internazionale to discuss a £20m deal. Juventus are also said to be interested.

webTitle: Foot and mouth in the media

fields.headline: Day 45: foot and mouth in the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
Day 45: The first positive stories begin to appear as the papers declare the worst of the crisis is over.
Special report: foot and mouth in the media
fields.body:
The Daily Telegraph
The first good news stories begin to emerge with the prediction that the daily tally of cases could be down to single figures by the time of the general election in June. The paper also carries a two-page report on the crisis, including a noticeboard that allows readers affected by foot and mouth to post their views.

The Guardian
The Guardian also puts the first positive news about the crisis on its front page, under the headline "Blair upbeat after being told worst of foot and mouth is over". Further coverage, including news that the vaccination option has now been abandoned, appears on page eight.

Daily Mail
No mention of foot and mouth until page 20, where the Mail bucks the general trend with the negative story that the number of cases has broken the 1,000 barrier. The opposite page carries an analysis of Britain's worsening image abroad beneath the understated headline "Plague island".

Daily Express
The Express also leads on the news the tide is turning. There are two pages of coverage and the paper's leader urges the government to reopen the countryside - but only if the disease can be contained.

Daily Star
The Star finds a small slot on page two amid its coverage of Robbie and Geri in which to cover foot and mouth. Under the headline "Farm battle end in sight", the paper claims we are now over the worst.

fields.headline: Further trouble blights Spider-Man shoot
fields.trailText: Work on the much-hyped film of the cartoon strip has been hit by a costume theft and a serious injury to a stuntman
fields.body:
Columbia's trouble plagued production of Spider-Man ran into fresh crises this week, when a theft and a major injury occurred within the same 24-hour period. The incidents come hot on the heels of last month's fatal injury to a welder employed to help construct the film's sets. The man died instantly when a metal cage was dropped from a crane onto his head.

The latest accident hit stuntman Zack Hudson, who was serving as the stunt double for the film's star Tobey Maguire (who plays Spider-Man). According to eyewitnesses quoted in the Hollywood Reporter, the accident occurred when a complex scene went awry as Hudson (doubling as Spider-Man) attempted to crash through one brick wall and bounce off another. Hudson is currently confined to the UCLA medical centre with a fractured leg and is out of action for the rest of the film. It is not known whether his absence will push production behind schedule.

Only hours before the incident, production staff had discovered the theft of four identical Spider-Man costumes (worn by both Hudson and Maguire) from the soundstage at Sony Studios in Culver City. The Culver City Police Department are investigating the crime, while Columbia are offering a reward of $25,000 (£17,392) for information leading to the "prompt and safe return" of the distinctive red and black costumes. One would say that this was a job for Spider-Man were it not for the fact that his stunt double and superhero outfit are now both out of commission. In the meantime, anyone with information should ring the theft hotline in California on 310 244 1044.

webTitle: In brief: Ashley Judd wins damages over fabricated interview

fields.headline: Ashley Judd wins damages over fabricated interview
fields.standfirst: Plus: X-Men take on deadly virus in sequel; Julia Roberts and Benjamin Bratt to wed
fields.trailText: Plus: X-Men take on deadly virus in sequel; Julia Roberts and Benjamin Bratt to wed
fields.body:
 Ashley Judd has accepted undisclosed "substantial" damages from the British magazine, Now, after it admitted to publishing an article based on an interview with the Double Jeopardy star which had never taken place. The article by Gill Pringle appeared in September 1999 but Judd's solicitor told ananova: "Ms Pringle had no such interview and indeed has never met Ms Judd. In addition, a number of statements in the article were false... and have the capacity to damage Ms Judd's reputation and career." The 31-year-old star sued the magazine, alleging malicious falsehood and false attribution. Tim Parish, a solicitor representing Now's publishers, IPC Media, told reporters: "I apologise without reservation for the publication of this article, and for the damage and upset which it will have caused to Ms Judd." Now has agreed to publish an apology to Ms Judd and pay damages and costs.

 Details of the plot for the proposed sequel to X-Men have emerged this afternoon, with reports that the mutant superheroes will be battling against a deadly virus in the follow-up to the sci-fi spectacular. The original film's screenwriter David Hayter is said to have been assigned to the project which is currently under consideration by 20th Century Fox, according to the Coming Attractions website.

 Julia Roberts and Benjamin Bratt are apparently set to marry this summer, according to reports in the American press. The Oscar-winning actress and her actor boyfriend who met in 1997 are trying to keep the exact date a secret to avoid a media frenzy. However, the Pretty Woman star's marital history has been somewhat ill-starred. In 1992 she pulled out of her wedding to Keifer Sutherland just days before the event and her 1995 marriage to Lyle Lovett lasted only 21 months.
