fields.headline: The current state of legislation
fields.trailText: When the Queen delivered her speech to the House of Lords last December spelling out the government's plans for the next parliamentary session, very few MPs expected more than a smattering of the 15 bills to complete the trek through both chambers and gain royal assent before a general election.
fields.byline: By Matthew Tempest, Patrick Butler and Matt Weaver
fields.body:
When the Queen delivered her speech to the House of Lords last December spelling out the government's plans for the next parliamentary session, very few MPs expected more than a smattering of the 15 bills to complete the trek through both chambers and gain royal assent before a general election.

The prime minister's decision to put back a general election to June 7 means that instead of dissolving parliament for a May 3 election, MPs and peers are now faced with more space than they bargained for in their legislative programme.

However, with parliament breaking up next week for a two-week Easter recess, there will be little more than a fortnight's extra time to push through bills before May 14 - the latest date that parliament can be dissolved for a June 7 general election.

First, the home secretary, Jack Straw, must get through emergency legislation to delay the local elections in England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

With cross-party support, that could be done in two days - however, Conservatives are now calling for the local elections to be postponed indefinitely, and could thereby hold up legislation in the Lords if they wished.

But because the leader of the house, Margaret Beckett, decides each Thursday the business for the following week, which bills the government will press ahead with remains to be seen.

Thus the options facing the prime minister, and his advisers, on which bills to push, are almost as delicately poised as the decision to delay the election itself.

This is the current state of play of the five pieces of legislation directly affecting the public sector:

Adoption and children
The biggest change in adoption laws for 25 years, the bill will enable more children in care to be adopted, speed up the adoption process and give more support to parents. It will create an independent review mechanism for would-be adopters who are turned down by social services, and a national adoption register to enable children to be matched more quickly with potential parents.

What stage is it at?
Introduced to the Commons on March 15 in the wake of the public furore over the "internet twins" case (although regulations to outlaw adoption over the internet are contained in the separate Intercountry adoption act), it received its second reading on March 26.

What happens next?
Never expected to complete its passage before the election, now likely to return next session, assuming Labour is returned to government.

Useful sites

Adoption and children bill
Big issue: intercountry adoption

Health and social care bill
This bill allows the government to take forward its NHS plan, published in July 2000, which aims to "modernise" the health service and make the NHS more "patient-centred".

Includes a range of measures relating to primary care, long-term care of the elderly, local government scrutiny of the NHS, patient advocacy, patient confidentiality, nurse prescribing, the creation of care trusts, employment issues and drugs dispensing.

What stage is it at?
Introduced to the Commons on December 20 2000, the bill reached the Lords on February 15. The Conservatives and Liberal Democrats threatened to derail the bill unless concessions were made on key areas such as the abolition of community health councils and the provision of powers to enable the health secretary to disclose confidential patient information to cancer researchers. Reaches report stage this week.

What happens next?
The May 3 election date gave the bill a very tight timetable. However, the extra parliamentary time means the government can pull out all the stops to ensure it becomes law before the election. Reports suggest the Tories believe they will be unable to stop the bill.

Useful sites
Big issue: health and social care bill

Health and social care bill

Tobacco advertising and promotion
The bill bans advertising and promotion - including sponsorship - of tobacco products in fulfillment of the government's manifesto commitment to ban tobacco advertising and as a key part of its strategy to cut deaths from lung cancer.

What stage is it at?
Introduced to the Commons on December 14 2000, it received its second reading in the Lords on March 28. Moves next into committee stage, for which no date has yet been set.

What happens next?
The bill was set to run out of time while a May 3 election was in the offing; with extra time now available, anti-tobacco campaigners believe ministers' manifesto commitment to the bill will concentrate their minds on pushing it through. But it is still touch and go.

Useful sites
Tobacco advertising and promotion bill
Action on Smoking and Health
Big issue: cancer

Homes bill
The bill is divided into two parts: house buying and homelessness. The first focuses on making house buying easier - those selling houses, or their agents, will be required to put together a seller's pack, before putting their property on the market. The change is designed to speed up the house buying process, make it more transparent and reduce the risk of gazumping.

The second part of bill gives more rights and protection to homeless people. Councils have a new duty to prevent homelessness. The bill also goes a long way to fulfilling a manifesto commitment to restore the right to permanent accommodation for homeless people.

What stage is the bill at?
The bill was introduced on December 12 2000 . It received its second reading in the Lords on 28 March 28. No date has yet been set for the committee stage.

What happens next?
The Conservatives have reservations about the house buying section but they have so far voted for the legislation. It is expected to go through by the end of April, but because it has bipartisan support it has been put to the end of the queue behind more contentious bills.

Useful sites
Big issue: homelessness
Shelter
Homes bill

Children's commissioner for Wales bill
Creates a children's "tsar" for Wales to review and monitor arrangements for complaints, whistleblowing and advocacy on behalf of children in range of bodies, including schools and NHS hospitals, in a bid to prevent abuse scandals.

A commissioner was one of the main recommendations of the Waterhouse tribunal into abuse in children's home in north Wales.

What stage is it at?
Introduced to the Commons on December 11 2000. Currently before Lords committee. What happens next?
Relatively uncontentious, but may not be regarded as a priority in Westminster (although it will be in Cardiff).

Councils have a new duty to prevent homelessness. The bill also goes a long way to fulfilling a manifesto commitment to restore the right to permanent accommodation for homeless people. What stage is the bill at? The bill was introduced on December 12 2000 . It received its second reading in the Lords on 28 March 28. No date has yet been set for the committee stage. What happens next? The Conservatives have reservations about the house buying section but they have so far voted for the legislation. It is expected to go through by the end of April, but because it has bipartisan support it has been put to the end of the queue behind more contentious bills. A commissioner was one of the main recommendations of the Waterhouse tribunal into abuse in children's home in north Wales. What stage is it at? Introduced to the Commons on December 11 2000. Currently before Lords committee. What happens next? Relatively uncontentious, but may not be regarded as a priority in Westminster (although it will be in Cardiff).

fields.headline: Chancellor has to delay homes aid to poorest
fields.standfirst:
Measures to tackle inner city deprivation postponed until after general election

Special report: Labour party
Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown has been forced to postpone a £100m measure to tackle inner city deprivation until after the expected June 7 general election because of a delay in compiling statistics.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown has been forced to postpone a £100m measure to tackle inner city deprivation until after the expected June 7 general election because of a delay in compiling statistics.

The chancellor had hoped to give a pre-election boost to Labour's heartlands by scrapping stamp duty on all property sales in the poorest areas. But the measure cannot be introduced until a map of poverty hotspots throughout the UK has been completed.

The delay emerged after the Northern Ireland assembly announced that it would not complete its map - a deprivation indicator - until mid June. All other regions have completed their maps.

The delay will come as a blow to the chancellor, who first announced the lifting of stamp duties in deprived areas in last November's pre-budget report.

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, later claimed that it would help to bring about an "urban renaissance" in these areas.

Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, last night seized on the delay. "Gordon Brown has spent the past four years in creasing taxes, like stamp duty," he said. "Now we learn that he is not even able to deliver a tiny relief from his own stealth tax, when he promised he would do so," Mr Portillo added

The Treasury last night played down the delay, saying that the chancellor had always said that the measure would be introduced only when the finance bill received royal assent.

The delay is expected to hold up property sales in deprived areas as buyers wait to benefit from the tax cut.

Stamp duty is paid on property deals worth more than £60,000. Buyers have to pay 1% of the value of their property on sales over £60,000 and under £250,000.

This rises to 3% on properties over £250,000 and under £500,000. On properties worth more than £500,000 buyers pay 4%.

Michael Osborne, the director of the East London estate agents Hamilton Fox, said: "Buyers for £250,000 plus properties will definitely be waiting until they hear the news on stamp duty. They would be crazy not to."

fields.headline: Sophie's partner may quit
fields.trailText:
9.30am:/ The Countess of Wessex's partner may quit her PR business amid fears that the Sunday papers are poised to print yet more damaging revelations about the royal family.
Apr 5: Sophie faces new row over business role
Apr 4: 'No special favours for Sophie', says PCC
Apr 2: The Countess and the tabloid sting
Apr 2: Sheikh rattles and rolls out star victims
fields.body:
The Countess of Wessex's partner may quit her PR business amid fears the Sunday papers are poised to print yet more damaging revelations about the royal family.

According to reports today, Murray Harkin has told Sophie Wessex he will resign from the firm if he thought his continued presence would damage the company, the countess or the monarchy.

Sunday newspapers are expected to reveal the "dynamite" content of the secret recordings of conversations between Mr Harkin and undercover reporter Mazher Mahmood at the weekend.

It is the second batch of recordings obtained by the News of the World but it is not yet clear whether the paper or a rival publication will be the first to publish the tapes.

The News of the World found itself at the centre of controversy on Sunday after it succumbed to pressure from Buckingham Palace and decided not to reveal the damaging remarks made by Sophie Wessex to Mahmood, who had posed as a sheikh pretending to negotiate a new PR account.

Mr Harkin, 36, and the countess, 36, set up the company, R-JH Public Relations, in 1997.

He met the News of the World undercover reporter on two occasions before he introduced her to the countess.

Publicly it is business as usual for Mr Harkin. He told the Sun today: "There is a lot of froth in the media but nothing's distracted us from business."

But according to the Times he has already discussed resigning with friends.

He was the original target of the News of the World sting following an approach from a former employee of R-JH.

webTitle: School at centre of rare TB outbreak

fields.headline: School at centre of rare TB outbreak
fields.standfirst: Thousands of pupils may have to be screened after health officials say particularly virulent strain of disease is likely to spread rapidly
fields.trailText: Thousands of pupils may have to be screened after health officials say particularly virulent strain of disease is likely to spread rapidly.
fields.body:
A major outbreak of tuberculosis - which may turn out to be one of the biggest in the UK since the disease was brought under control in the 1980s - has been identified at a secondary school in Leicester.

Last night public health officials said 24 cases of TB have been confirmed, 20 of them children at Crown Hills community college and one a teacher. About 700 children, aged 11 to 14, have been screened and of those a further 60 look likely to have been infected with the disease.

"This is a major outbreak," said Gerry Bryant, specialist registrar in public health with Leicestershire health authority. "I'm not aware of a published outbreak of this size in a school. We believe it might be part of a larger community outbreak. It is very difficult to tell at this stage."

Dr Philip Monk, consultant on communicable disease control at the health authority, blamed the outbreak on a particularly virulent strain of the disease that is spreading rapidly.

Thousands of children may potentially have to be screened if it is thought the disease had spread. "We may be looking at six primary schools that feed into Crown Hills community college. That would be 2,000-2,500 pupils as a starting point. Then there are around 3,000 pupils from secondary schools," Dr Monk said.

It is highly unusual to get a significant number of cases in a school because generally, children tend to be infected not by each other but by very close contact with adults, usually members of their family.

There will certainly be more cases to come. Every child and teacher in the school will now be screened. Not every person who develops TB is infectious, but some of the Crown Hills children have proved to be so, and so the disease may well have spread within their families. All those infected have been given the standard course of antibiotic TB treatment, and the 60 who had strongly positive skin-prick tests, indicating likely infection, have been given a shorter course to keep the disease at bay.

The outbreak began when one child in year nine developed TB last August. Ninety-three per cent of the children at the school are of Asian origin and it is possible the child became infected on a visit to India, where TB is endemic. The second case, in October, involving a child in the same class, was discovered when the first child's close contacts were screened. When a third child in the class developed TB last month, it was decided to mount a major screening exercise.

For Gary Coleby, headteacher of the school in inner-city Leicester, the news of the rising numbers is a blow. Its Ofsted report before Christmas said it was one of the best urban schools in the country. And for three years running it has been one of the government's top 200 improving schools. Mr Coleby is trying hard to reassure everyone that it is business as usual.

"The original three children diagnosed have all been treated and are all back at school," he said. "The parents are concerned but they are being kept very closely informed about what is going on and they are involved in the process so they know what is happening. We do have a lot of parental support here and it is now paying dividends.

New strains

"The most important message is that there is no panic and the school is operating absolutely as normal, although with some disruption because of the screening."

Sixty years ago, this outbreak would have been a disaster and a tragedy, because TB was a regular killer, but the BCG vaccination, together with better drug treatment, surveillance and meticulous follow-up of all the contacts of anyone with the infection have made deaths unnecessary.

But nobody takes tuberculosis lightly. The number of cases in the country is rising among people who are born abroad or whose parents were. TB is killing millions in south-east Asia, Africa and eastern Europe - and is frequently the direct cause of death of those whose immune systems have been damaged by HIV.

But what alarms public health officials most is the onward march of new strains of TB which are resistant to the antibiotic drugs most used to treat the disease. Unless the disease can be brought under control elsewhere in the world, increasing numbers of multi drug-resistant TB (MDRTB) cases will arrive in the UK. They are hard - and expensive - to treat. The Crown Hills college outbreak is not MDRTB, but it has arrived from abroad and all the vigilance of the public health officials has not been able to prevent it.

The finger was immediately pointed at the absence of the BCG vaccination programme in schools. Many parents have voiced anxieties at the temporary halt to vaccinations two years ago which was caused by a shortage of vaccine.

Less than two weeks ago, on World TB Day, the government announced that the BCG vaccination programme for schoolchildren would be restarting. In London, which has more TB cases than anywhere else, vaccinations for 13-year-olds have already started again. There is a cohort of children who have been missed, some of whom may be about to leave school and, potentially, travel to countries where TB is endemic. Those, the government has said, will receive a catch-up vaccination in the summer. Government policy is that children born in TB endemic areas, or whose parents or grandparents were born there, should be vaccinated at birth. Those who come to live in the UK should be vaccinated on arrival.

The vast majority of Crown Hills' 1,200 pupils have been protected from TB, but unfortunately the BCG is only 60 to 70% effective and the strain that has hit the school appears to be particularly virulent.

Ironically, what has happened in Leicester underlines the limited usefulness of the schools vaccination programme, which is coming under review in a few years' time and which there may be moves to end.

"There has been discussion in the medical press about how much benefit is achieved by the schools programme," said John Watson, a consultant epidemiologist at the Public Health Laboratory Service. "You have to vaccinate an awful lot of children to prevent a single case of TB. It is not comparable to the childhood vaccination programmes against measles, for instance."

What is TB and how is it spread?

What kind of disease is tuberculosis?

Contagious, caused by a bacteria that attacks the lungs, although it can also target the lymph nodes, bones and occasionally the brain.

How common is it?

It used to be very common in the UK. Known as consumption in Victorian times, it claimed the lives of many poets and writers, notably Keats. There were 50,000 cases a year in the 1940s, which dropped to 5,000 in the late 80s, rising to just below 7,000 now. This is nothing compared to Africa, eastern Europe and south-east Asia. TB makes 8m people a year sick worldwide and kills 2m.

How is it spread?

Through the air, when sufferers cough, spit or sneeze. The sick used to be shut away in sanatoria to recover, or more often die, but current wisdom is that people do not catch it without prolonged close contact. Children, the elderly and the frail or immuno-compromised are at greatest risk. Before pasteurisation, TB could be contracted from milk from cows infected with bovine TB.

Does everybody who comes into contact with TB bacteria get the disease?

No. One third of all people are estimated to carry the bacteria, but only one out of 10 of them will develop TB.

What are the symptoms?

Fever and night sweats, coughing, losing weight and blood in the sputum are some of the main ones. Symptoms usually take months to appear.

Is it treatable?

Yes, thanks to antibiotics. Patients are given a six-month course of four drugs. It is vital to stick to the course, even when the symptoms disappear, or the bacteria lingering dormant in the body will mutate to become resistant to the drugs.

Is that a big problem?

The spread of multi drug-resistant TB (known as MDRTB) is extremely worrying. There are particularly serious problems in the former Soviet Union. The World Health Organisation says MDRTB threatens global control of the disease.

webTitle: Turning Point sees Centrepoint chief move on

fields.headline: Turning Point sees Centrepoint chief move on
fields.trailText: One of the UK charity sector's highest profile chief executives, Victor Adebowale, has announced his departure from homelessness charity Centrepoint. He will become chief executive of Turning Point, the drug and alcohol charity. Nicola Hill reports.
fields.body:
One of the UK charity sector's highest profile chief executives, Victor Adebowale, has announced his departure from homelessness charity Centrepoint. He will become chief executive of Turning Point, the drug and alcohol charity with an annual income of £24m, in September.

The move will come as a shock to homelessness charities. Turning Point is less well known than Centrepoint where Mr Adebowale has enjoyed a high profile. This reached a peak in the wake of the death of Princess Diana, who was an active patron of the charity.

While at Centrepoint Mr Adebowale, one of the few black chief executives in the voluntary sector, was awarded a CBE and regularly advised ministers on several initiatives including the New Deal. He was also believed to be in the running for the post of homelessness tsar - a job that went to Shelter's Louise Casey.

Mr Adebowale recently introduced a new management structure to Centrepoint. He will take over from Ted Unsworth of Turning Point who has been chief executive since 1998.

Turning Point initially hoped to recruit someone for £65,000 but two members of the charity's board insisted it find at least a further £20,000 to attract the right calibre of applicant.

Chairman of the board, Lionel Joyce, former chief executive of Newcastle city health NHS trust told SocietyGuardian.co.uk: "This salary level [£65,000] was a complete nonsense, in the NHS we would pay somebody £75,000 to run a £20m trust in Northumberland. This post is based in London with a national remit."

The salary for the chief executive post was eventually advertised at £85,000. Mr Joyce said: "No one on the shortlist would have applied if we had advertised the post at a lower salary. Some were already earning £80,000."

Mr Joyce claims the voluntary sector is in a dilemma. The statutory sector has been raising salaries remorselessly and even pays its non-executive directors: "Effectively both sectors are recruiting from the same market place and the voluntary sector is in danger of falling behind, whereas it should be setting the agenda."

The National Council for Voluntary Organisations has launched a guide to setting chief executive's salaries. Chairwoman of the remuneration guide working party, Lady Tumin said: "By adopting a systematic and fair approach to remuneration we can be sure that CEOs in the voluntary sector receive fair remuneration packages."

 Additional reporting by Matt Weaver

webTitle: Free tea in Devon - all MPs welcome

fields.headline: Free tea in Devon - all MPs welcome
fields.trailText: A backbench Labour MP last night organised a patriotic response to government appeals to help the stricken tourist trade by taking an Easter holiday in Britain when he offered a free cream tea or a pint to any of his 658 colleagues willing to visit Exeter.
fields.body:
A backbench Labour MP last night organised a patriotic response to government appeals to help the stricken tourist trade by taking an Easter holiday in Britain when he offered a free cream tea or a pint to any of his 658 colleagues willing to visit Exeter.

By nightfall Ben Bradshaw, the city's MP, had 15 positive replies, ranging from Sir Michael Spicer on the Tory right to Tam Dalyell, the veteran member of Labour's awkward squad whose own ancestral home, The Binns at Linlithgow, is itself a tourist attraction (entry 75p).

Mr Bradshaw's initiative, designed to cash in on "unexpected free time" arising from the cancelled Easter election, coincided with a loftier appeal from Janet Anderson, the minister for tourism, who made an emergency trip to busk for trade in the TV studios of New York last week.

Asked on BBC Online if she expected Tony Blair and fellow grandees to say "we're not going to Tuscany (this Easter), we're off to the Lake District", Ms Anderson replied: "Yes, I think you probably can."

Downing Street was predictably wary of such an appeal. Mr Blair's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, whose holiday time is usually divided between France and Burnley FC, brushed aside patriotic pressure. "Ministers are grown ups and they can make their own decisions," he said. "The government is absolutely committed to the promotion of British tourism."

Mr Blair, who will probably be at Chequers, never planned to take an Easter holiday anyway. But senior colleagues, who had expected to spend the next three weeks campaigning for a May 3 poll, were quick to spot an opening. The Foreign Office said Robin Cook (currently working in Belgrade) and all his ministers will be in Britain for Easter.

At the Home Office Jack Straw's staff said "he only holidays at his desk" before admitting he may spend some time at his Cotswold retreat. Chris Smith, the culture secretary and ardent hill walker, is certain to do "much holidaying in Britain", one aide said.

Mr Bradshaw - who also expects the health minister, John Denham, in Exeter, - says in his letter to MPs that he will "buy you a cream tea or a pint of our excellent locally brewed ale or cider".

fields.headline: Dennis buys motoring title Evo
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Dennis Publishing has acquired Evo in a bid to strengthen its hold over the automotive sector, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Dennis Publishing has acquired Evo magazine from Evo Publications in a bid to strengthen its hold over the lucrative automotive magazine sector.

Dennis believes Evo, aimed at hardcore car enthusiasts, will complement its existing car magazine Auto Express.

"We are absolutely delighted to have Evo as a stablemate to Auto Express. It is a superb magazine run by a terrific team," said Dennis's managing director Alistair Ramsey.

Evo, which launched in 1998, has built up a circulation of 40,000.

Evo is the fifth magazine Dennis has bought this year.

Evo's editorial team will remain at their Wellingborough base, while advertising sales staff will move to Dennis's London headquarters.

fields.headline: Ministers defend Whitehall empires
fields.standfirst:
Dismembering of big departments will serve only to strengthen Treasury's power, Blair warned

Special report: House of Commons
fields.trailText: Ministers are resisting plans to break up some of Whitehall's biggest departments to improve the efficiency of "joined up" government if Labour wins the general election. It will serve only to enhance Gordon Brown's power, they are warning.
fields.body:
Ministers are resisting plans to break up some of Whitehall's biggest departments to improve the efficiency of "joined up" government if Labour wins the general election. It will serve only to enhance Gordon Brown's power, they are warning.

Neither Jack Straw, home secretary, nor David Blunkett, who is widely expected to move from the Department of Education and Employment to succeed him, is keen to see his likely new territory dismembered - "Balkanised" as one cabinet minister put it - in advance.

But John Prescott, who is ready to leave the huge Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions - which Mr Straw could take over - will be reluctant to move unless he can take regional policy and local government with him to a new post, probably in the Cabinet Office. Nothing has yet been decided. But Tony Blair would need a rough idea of changes he wants to make, in advance of Labour's expected second election victory on June 7, in order to fit relatively round ministerial pegs into round departmental holes.

If time can be found from the foot and mouth crisis, the five extra pre-election weeks now at No 10's disposal may allow for more radical options to be finalised before the upper tier of cabinet, unchanged since 1997, is reshuffled.

The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, long the target of reformers for its poor track record, is likely to survive for the time being for precisely that reason: breaking it up or creating a department of rural affairs would divert and demoralise officials now struggling with foot and mouth.

Ministers are aware they can be accused of empire building if they resist plans being drawn up in think tanks, the Cabinet Office and the Downing Street performance and innovation unit.

So the main reason they advance for resisting "Balkanisation" is that it will serve only to increase the octopus-like power of the Treasury under the chancellor, Mr Brown.

Mr Blair is famously uninterested in tinkering with the machinery of government.

But key members of the Downing Street staff are disappointed with the results of four years spent trying to force Whitehall's "feudal baronies", as a key Blair adviser calls them, to co-operate more to push through policies that address problems such as poverty right across the board.

A Cabinet Office official, Sonia Phippard, has been drawing up options to present to the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson. But Geoff Mulgan in the performance and innovation unit and David Miliband, head of the No 10 policy unit, both political appointees, are considering their own blueprints.

They will have to square their plans with the personalities and portfolios Mr Blair must juggle. "David Blunkett wants the home office, but he doesn't want a ministry of justice taken out," said one minister. "Jack [Straw] won't get the foreign office - Tony doesn't want an anti-European there - but he won't want DETR broken up if he goes there."

Talk of taking transport out of the DETR again is now widely condemned as unwise. The regions and local government are far more likely to be shifted, either to the Cabinet Office, where their champion, Mr Prescott, is likely to become "the enforcer", or to the Department of Trade and Industry.

In a really radical shift, the English regions would be lumped in with the devolved regions of Scotland and Wales ("It is still too soon for Northern Ireland," said one official) in a department of the union, the constitution or even "the isles".

With his track record on constitutional reform, Robin Cook was once expected to take that portfolio. But Mr Blair is now lavish in his praise of the foreign secretary as a safe pair of hands at summits and elsewhere. Peter Mandelson's fall strengthens Mr Cook's claims as a pro-euro minister to stay put while the euro referendum issue is unresolved.

There are questions marks over other departments, including Chris Smith's Culture, Media and Sport, where the arts lobby has been campaigning to prevent culture and sport being sent back to the Department for Education and Employment and broadcasting broken up - with commercial policy going to the DTI, which over a decade has lost power and direction.

The Department of Social Security is also vulnerable. Its benefits agency (with 100,000 staff) is being merged with parts of the employment service to create a working age agency. Already regarded as a Treasury fiefdom, it will soon control only child support, pensions and some benefits policy.

Most of the radical options, notably a ministry of justice, will probably bite the dust as Mr Blair struggles to fit the right faces to departments.

The DETR was created for Mr Prescott's benefit, just as the Department for Culture, Media and Sport was moulded around David Mellor by John Major.

The Blair cabinet has lost seven of its original 21 members, but is unique in keeping all the top people in their jobs since 1997. Also unusual has been the dominance across domestic ministries of the Treasury. Most MPs agree that nothing will be done to cut its power unless one thing happens: Mr Brown succeeds Mr Blair at No 10. "Then it will happen immediately."

webTitle: Blair adviser lined up for key Downing Street role

fields.headline: Blair adviser lined up for key Downing Street role
fields.standfirst:
Full coverage of Election 2001
Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is to offer another of his closest advisers a top Downing Street job as part of a big reorganisation of No 10's political staff if Labour wins the next election.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is to offer another of his closest advisers a top Downing Street job as part of a big reorganisation of No 10's political staff if Labour wins the next election.

Phil Wilson, who has known Tony Blair since he was a young activist who helped him enter parliament for Sedgefield in 1983, is to be offered a role as deputy political secretary. He would work directly with Anji Hunter, who is in the centre of a row between the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson and Mr Blair, over plans to offer her a £120,000 job to be part-paid by the taxpayer.

Mr Wilson - now a lobbyist with Brunswick Public Relations - is credited with devising a new way of recruiting local Labour members at £1 a time and became one of Tony Blair's closest advisers at constituency level.

During the last election he was regarded as a key Millbank figure. Mr Blair plans to pay Ms Hunter £70,000 from taxpayer's funds, topping up a £50,000 a year salary from the Labour party. Mr Wilson may require a top-up of his salary to give him an equivalent sum to his present lobbyist job. He was unavailable for comment.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: At last Philip Beresford faces a serious challenge to his reliable "think of a number, any number, add six noughts and treble it" Sunday Times Rich List.
fields.body:
At last Philip Beresford faces a serious challenge to his reliable "think of a number, any number, add six noughts and treble it" Sunday Times Rich List.

It comes from Bizarre magazine, whose new edition contains a special "look after the pennies..." meanie list. In a clever stunt of the sort this column might have thought of first, were it not so smug and indolent, Bizarre wrote to the Sunday Times top 50 enclosing personal cheques. Mohamed Al Fayed (current worth £1,000,000,002) banked his for £2, while these presented cheques for 97p: passport purchasing Sri-chand Hinduja, merchant banker Bruno Schroder, FT publisher Viscount Cowdray and James Dyson, who knows that nature abhors a spendthrift even more than a vacuum.

We knew Alan Sugar was no miser from his libel case against the Mail, and he returned his cheque with a terse note. A shame in a way, since 97p would have bought three midfield players of the kind Spurs went in for when he was chairman, but hats off all the same, Sir Alan, and shame on the rest of you.

 Thank God, Keith Vaz lives. Yesterday we rang Alison Acton in his Leicester constituency office to rearrange an imaginary squash game between the troubled Europe minister and myself, expecting an outraged reference to his allegedly sick heart. Instead Alison promised to check an alternative date, and again she steers clear of any medical reference. "Keith's a little confused," she begins, "about the squash game. He doesn't know Matthew Norman, and doesn't really play squash. Are you sure it was Keith Vaz you're after?" Quite sure. Good day.

 Would any completely bald readers - or those with access to a latex bald wig - contact us regarding the new David Yelland Appreciation Society. We require people who are, or can appear to be, bereft of a single head-hair for various outings and stunts in east London. On being accepted into DYAS (and if the high street hardware chain Robert Dyas cares to launch a passing-off action, we'd be delighted), you will receive a membership tie featuring a jet black wig pincered between the doors of a New York subway train. Other benefits to be announced shortly.

 I am amused, meanwhile, by an item by David's TV critic Gary Bushell. Unusually, this concerns not a comedian friend still failing to get on telly after 15 years remorseless Bushell plugging, but a documentary maker who rightly cites as his favourite shop the majestic Nut Case in London's glamorous Uxbridge Road. "I asked if I should do Louis Theroux's show," writes Gary. "The response was huge. Three people said yes, four said no and 2,793 said: 'Who's Louis Theroux?'" I can see the confusion. Mr Theroux's shows tending to go out at peak time on terrestrial channels with multimillion ratings; rather than at 3am on obscure cable stations with audiences too small to be measured. So do the show, Gary, and learn the distinction.

 Readers who remember the Big Sheep in Bideford, Devon, from August's popular tourist attraction space filler will be intrigued to hear of a local newspaper tourist supplement announcing that "in the light of the current crisis" it has mutated into the Big Chicken. "Everything has been remodelled in time for Easter," it reveals, listing main features as Amazing Chicken Racing, Chicken Trials, and Egg Eating Contests. Inevitably, in the county of electrifying tourist attractions, this has caught on at once, and the fact that it was an April Fool does nothing to prevent local thrill-seekers besieging the site.

 A young woman calls from the Parker Romantic Novel of the Year to confirm that we will be sending someone to the Savoy lunch at which Alan Titchmarsh is speaking with Tania Bryer in attendance. How clever these PR professionals are at making you feel that the one thing in life they cannot live without is your column.

webTitle: Chancellor has to delay homes aid to poorest

fields.headline: Chancellor has to delay homes aid to poorest
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown has been forced to postpone a £100m measure to tackle inner city deprivation until after the expected June 7 general election because of a delay in compiling statistics.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown has been forced to postpone a £100m measure to tackle inner city deprivation until after the expected June 7 general election because of a delay in compiling statistics.

The chancellor had hoped to give a pre-election boost to Labour's heartlands by scrapping stamp duty on all property sales in the poorest areas. But the measure cannot be introduced until a map of poverty hotspots throughout the UK has been completed.

The delay emerged after the Northern Ireland assembly announced that it would not complete its map - a deprivation indicator - until mid June. All other regions have completed their maps.

The delay will come as a blow to the chancellor, who first announced the lifting of stamp duties in deprived areas in last November's pre-budget report.

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, later claimed that it would help to bring about an "urban renaissance" in these areas.

Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, last night seized on the delay. "Gordon Brown has spent the past four years in creasing taxes, like stamp duty," he said. "Now we learn that he is not even able to deliver a tiny relief from his own stealth tax, when he promised he would do so," Mr Portillo added

The Treasury last night played down the delay, saying that the chancellor had always said that the measure would be introduced only when the finance bill received royal assent.

The delay is expected to hold up property sales in deprived areas as buyers wait to benefit from the tax cut.

Stamp duty is paid on property deals worth more than £60,000. Buyers have to pay 1% of the value of their property on sales over £60,000 and under £250,000.

This rises to 3% on properties over £250,000 and under £500,000. On properties worth more than £500,000 buyers pay 4%.

Michael Osborne, the director of the East London estate agents Hamilton Fox, said: "Buyers for £250,000 plus properties will definitely be waiting until they hear the news on stamp duty. They would be crazy not to."

fields.headline: Carlton in Hollywood link-up
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Carlton has linked up with Hollywood star Nick Nolte's production company to make TV movies and drama series, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Carlton has linked up with Hollywood star Nick Nolte's production company to make TV movies and drama series.

Nolte, who has 48 feature film credits to his name including the Prince of Tides, 48 Hours and Cape Fear, may star in some of the TV movies that will be made through the Carlton deal.

Carlton America and Kingsgate, the Los Angeles-based TV and film production company set up by Nolte and producer Greg Shapiro, have signed an exclusive multi-year agreement to jointly develop and co-produce TV movies and drama series.

Carlton distribution arm Carlton International will sell projects made through the Kingsgate deal around the world.

"This new relationship with Kingsgate is a prime example of how we choose to ally ourselves with A-list producers to create strong domestic and international programming concepts," said Stephen Davis, chief executive of Carlton America.

Nolte's next feature film role will be in a Kingsgate production. He will star alongside Neve Campbell and Dermot Mulroney in Investigating Sex.

webTitle: Foot and mouth: 'the worst is over'

fields.headline: Foot and mouth: 'the worst is over'
fields.standfirst:
Despite 1,000 cases government scientists predict foot and mouth is over the worst

Election 2001: foot and mouth
Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The foot and mouth epidemic passed 1,000 cases yesterday but the government's chief scientist, Professor David King, told the prime minister that he believed the worst was over.
fields.byline: Paul Brown, John Vidal  and  Michael White
fields.body:
The foot and mouth epidemic passed 1,000 cases yesterday but the government's chief scientist, Professor David King, told the prime minister that he believed the worst was over.

In a upbeat assessment of the situation, he said that outbreaks were being contained at between 40 to 45 a day compared with 65 to 70 that could be expected if the epidemic was running out of control.

At the first scientific briefing to journalists for 10 days he said it was due to the accelerated slaughter policy begun on March 23 when the government first acknowledged foot and mouth was out of control.

The worst case scenario of the number of cases doubling every nine days to reach up to 400 cases a day by May 3 was not happening, Prof King said.

His briefing was in marked contrast to the views of the army officer in charge of operations in north-east England, around Newcastle, an area that Prof King acknowledged was a new "hot spot" for the disease.

Lt Colonel Gary Donaldson was quoted in the Northern Echo as saying he did not have enough vets or slaughter teams to cope and that the disease was out of control in the area. "I cannot wave a magic wand to produce another 150-200 vets," he said. "It is enough to make me weep."

But yesterday his commanding officer, Brigadier Andrew Farquhar, said: "It is not out of control but it is a very critical situation. We now have the logistics support in place."

Prof King revealed that he had briefed the prime minister about the progress of the disease before he made his decision to postpone the elections from May 3 to June 7. He told Mr Blair that by June 7 the epidemic would be fading fast and at worst there would be fewer than five new outbreaks a day.

Yesterday, according to the Ministry of Agriculture, the case total had reached 1,019 - with only 28 notified in the last 24 hours.

Armed with this advice, Mr Blair yesterday gave MPs a far more upbeat account. He spoke of foot and mouth cases now reaching a "plateau" and appealed for the urgent re-opening of most footpaths in time for the Easter break.

Mr Blair faced fresh accusations from William Hague that the slaughter and disposal programmes were still lagging, making the spread of disease worse. But Mr Blair insisted that, at 40,000 disposals a week, the rate is more than double what it was two weeks earlier. In some areas, slaughter within 24 hours was 100%, aides said later.

Neither the prime minister not his spokesman, Alastair Campbell, risked saying the outbreak is now "under control." Vaccination has currently been ruled out for ordinary farm animals because it is believed the epidemic can be defeated without it. However, last night, the EU vets gave permission for zoo animals and rare breeds to be vaccinated to protect them if they are within 15 miles of an outbreak.

Despite official optimism there were worrying new outbreaks yesterday in sensitive areas. Infection was found at a hill farm in the southern Lake District fells near Kendal. "It is what we have dreaded. It threatens to spread everywhere. It could be a disaster," said a national park spokesman.

fields.headline: Crime linked to absent fathers
fields.standfirst: Boy lacking dad more at risk of turning to crime
fields.trailText: Having a biological father who maintained a close relationship with his son, whether or not he lived in the family home, might be crucial in preventing susceptible boys becoming criminals, research presented yesterday suggested.
fields.body:
Having a biological father who maintained a close relationship with his son, whether or not he lived in the family home, might be crucial in preventing susceptible boys becoming criminals, research presented yesterday suggested.

But stepfathers appeared to do little to decrease the risk that a boy will turn to crime, the conference of the British Psychological Society's division of forensic psychology heard in Birmingham.

The study by the clinical psychologist Jenny Taylor looked at why a proportion of boys with all the "risk factors" associated with criminal behaviour resisted a life of crime.

Drawing on data from socially deprived areas of south London, she compared a group of "good boys", who had no criminal convictions and had caused teachers no trouble, with a group of "bad boys" at a secure unit for unmanageable adolescents, many of them persisitent offenders convicted of sexual assault, theft and stealing vehicles.

All 68 boys, aged between 12 and 16, were from working class backgrounds, had lower than average intellectual ability, had similar problems with their peers and with hyperactivity, had equally large families, and in both groups 40% suffered from dyslexia.

But there was one "very striking" difference between the two groups: 55% of the "good boys" lived with their biological fathers, compared with only 4% of the "bad boys".

Almost 80% of the "good boys" spoke of being close to their biological fathers. Among these were 24% of the group who said they had a biological father living away from home who was an influence in their lives.

Only 18% said there was no one they regarded as a father figure, while 3% said they had a stepfather.

Among the "bad boys", 45% said they had no one they considered a father figure, 30% said they had a stepfather, 22% a biological father not living at home and only 4% a father living at home.

Such findings would appear to back research suggesting that having a stepfather was an additional "risk factor", said Dr Taylor, who carried out the research while at the South London and Maudsley NHS trust.

It also suggested that a father who disapproved of crime and showed an interest in his son acted as a crucial social control, countering negative influences such as criminal peers.

Boys gained a sense of being loved and approved of, and the fear of jeopardising this proved enough to deter them from crime, she said.

"For children in this age group, formal controls - such as being told off by police - aren't enough."

Dr Taylor denied that her work suggested that "at risk" boys needed to live in a nuclear family.

"It's not necessarily about them living with their biological fathers but about having someone they think of as a father who shows an interest in them and what they're doing," she said.

The research, far from providing fodder for the rightwing family values lobby, could be seen as a boon for single mothers, she said. "This suggests we should move away from pathologising single mums and instead see that, if there are dangers, it's due to the absence of fathers."

 When offenders don a disguise, such as a balaclava, hood or mask, it makes them more violent and destructive to people and property, a forensic psychologist, Andrew Silke, of the University of Leicester, told the conference.

He believed this was less because they thought there would be no comeback than because, by becoming anonymous, they felt freed from the normal constraints.

The findings emerged from comparing police, victim and media reports in his study of 500 paramilitary punishment beatings in Northern Ireland, 205 of which (41%) involved offenders wearing disguises.

webTitle: Hugo Young: the Tories and foot and mouth

fields.headline: Going nowhere
fields.standfirst:
The Conservative leader's inability to profit from foot and mouth leaves Tories disconsolate

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: William Hague, they say, has had a good foot and mouth war. It would have been hard to have a bad one: all an opposition leader has to do is judge the tone in which he picks apart the mess.
fields.body:
William Hague, they say, has had a good foot and mouth war. It would have been hard to have a bad one. The chaos swirling between Maff, Ministry of Defence, Downing Street, Cabinet Office and numerous local authorities, shows how pitifully unequipped any British government is to handle a big emergency. All an opposition leader has to do is judge the tone in which he picks apart the mess. Mr Hague has done that nicely. He has been moderate and constructive. But he is none the better for it. His problems are far deeper. Investigating why he remains the big loser, one lights upon the extraordinary fact that he doesn't even understand what they are.

John Major took a decorous crack at him this week, coming to the aid of Ian Taylor, a rare Conservative MP who can plausibly be labelled left of centre. Mr Major once again proclaims the merits of that fabled place of worship and allegiance, the broad church. Every country needs at least two broad churches, with overlapping aisles, if it is to flourish as a democracy. Mr Major evidently fears that Hague has spent four years preaching, by a demonic instinct for self-destruction, to the narrowest sect of the undoubting faithful, with such effect that even the disaster that has overtaken the other side can't make the rest of us begin to listen to him.

This is a subject of amazement in the topmost reaches of the Labour party. Politicians whose own upward path began under the leadership of Michael Foot compare Hague unfavourably with that time. Michael, they say, at least knew which side he ought to be on. He fought the hard left, however ineffectively. The ambition of his leadership was to retrieve some of the ground from the zealots. Then Foot begat Neil Kinnock, the originating reformer, and the party was launched towards the condition of being electable.

William Hague has treated his zealots in the opposite way. He set out to do nothing except appease them. On every issue that inflames their guts, he has applied the torch. He declines to read them a single lesson in reality, refuses to discomfort them, fears to confront them with reasons for the party's plight, runs away from any search for the centre ground. Major, not Hague, was the Foot of this piece, struggling against the militant minority determined to capture his party. Hague, instead of learning Kinnock's lesson, turns himself to the vain pursuit of satisfying John Redwood and William Cash.

So Problem One is cowardice before zealotry. Problem Two is, despite this zeal, a gaping absence of strategic vision. Extremism in the visceral fields is not accompanied by consistency elsewhere. On public spending, Hague has time and again reversed the party line. On tax he once made a plausible promise - to cut it - but then let this dissipate into confusion. His various lines have been part of no ordered philosophical assessment of what modern conservatism means, or how to make it distinctive and relevant. Rhetorically Hague proposes a mistrust of the state. Actually he offers no coherent notion about how the state might be diminished. Psephologically, he proves month by month to be out of touch with the public he is hoping to impress.

He is not helped by the Tory press. The newspapers merely fire the zealots up. People say that Tony Blair is over- influenced by the Daily Mail. The charge is now out of date. But it was, in any case, nothing compared with the influence worked on the Conservative leader by the relentlessly Europe- hating, asylum-abominating propaganda from that quarter. The Mail and the Daily Telegraph are the heaviest crosses any Tory leader has to bear who might be searching for the centre ground. At least when Foot was being persecuted, and Kinnock having a difficult time, the progressive press, mainly the Mirror and the Guardian, were not working to savage them for every desertion of the faith. Quite the opposite. The Tory press, instead, takes pleasure in driving its party into the catacombs.

Can broad-church Conservatism be rebuilt, so as to make the party the gainers not the losers from some future national calamity? There's defiant talk on the Tory left. They will fight the election quietly, the better to position themselves for a confrontation with Hague as soon as it is over. This is where your hard-line Europhobia and your brutish inhumanity towards a variety of victims have got you, they hope to tell him after the heavy defeat they trust that Mr Blair is about to inflict. Romantics even speak of Chris Patten immediately resigning his place as a European commissioner and crossing the white cliffs to declare himself a candidate to lead his old party back from oblivion.

The trouble with this is that anything resembling a Patten constituency has shrunk close to single figures in the electorate that matters. Any parliamentary Conservative party, whether of 160 or 220, will be dominated by hard liners, legatees of this decade of growing sectarianism, which now makes it inadmissible for a pro- Europe Tory to be nominated for a winnable, or indeed any, seat. The great majority of newly nominated candidates now say not merely no but never to the euro: a transgression of the supposed party line that Hague does nothing to reprimand, still less forbid. Such is the measure of his leadership. With the exception of one departing MP, John Townend, there seems to be nothing that any Tory politician says from within the sect that Hague would judge inimical to the party's interests in the world beyond.

A measure of its distance from that world is to be found in the intense discussions of his likely successor. These now focus on Michael Portillo as the most credible applicant for what one might call the Patten vote. What a turn-around, what a plight! Mr Portillo is undoubtedly an able man, the most able of any in the field, who also understands the limitations of what has been happening in the past four years. But he is infected with the disease that largely defines the Tory predicament and excludes it from consideration as a party of government: the visceral anti- Europeanism that deforms so much of what else the party might have to say. That Portillo is becoming the candidate of the Tory left shows how truly straitened the gate to salvation has become.

The predicament, I think, will not end until the Europe question is resolved, one way or the other. Yet the new emerging battle in the party, waiting to greet any post-election leader, is over how long that resolution can possibly be postponed. If there is a euro referendum, the issue is no longer who fights on which side, but whether the result should be accepted. The ultras, among whom Portillo seems to be one, are preparing to declare the result invalid if it is yes, and to obstruct the single currency, by every possible means, up to the very moment of its birth here.

They say that foot and mouth poses no threat to humans. It must be something else eating away at Conservative brains.

On public spending, Hague has time and again reversed the party line. On tax he once made a plausible promise - to cut it - but then let this dissipate into confusion. His various lines have been part of no ordered philosophical assessment of what modern conservatism means, or how to make it distinctive and relevant. Rhetorically Hague proposes a mistrust of the state. Actually he offers no coherent notion about how the state might be diminished. Psephologically, he proves month by month to be out of touch with the public he is hoping to impress. He is not helped by the Tory press. The newspapers merely fire the zealots up. People say that Tony Blair is over- influenced by the Daily Mail. The charge is now out of date. But it was, in any case, nothing compared with the influence worked on the Conservative leader by the relentlessly Europe- hating, asylum-abominating propaganda from that quarter. The Mail and the Daily Telegraph are the heaviest crosses any Tory leader has to bear who might be searching for the centre ground. At least when Foot was being persecuted, and Kinnock having a difficult time, the progressive press, mainly the Mirror and the Guardian, were not working to savage them for every desertion of the faith. Quite the opposite. The Tory press, instead, takes pleasure in driving its party into the catacombs. Can broad-church Conservatism be rebuilt, so as to make the party the gainers not the losers from some future national calamity? There's defiant talk on the Tory left. They will fight the election quietly, the better to position themselves for a confrontation with Hague as soon as it is over. This is where your hard-line Europhobia and your brutish inhumanity towards a variety of victims have got you, they hope to tell him after the heavy defeat they trust that Mr Blair is about to inflict. Romantics even speak of Chris Patten immediately resigning his place as a European commissioner and crossing the white cliffs to declare himself a candidate to lead his old party back from oblivion. The trouble with this is that anything resembling a Patten constituency has shrunk close to single figures in the electorate that matters. Any parliamentary Conservative party, whether of 160 or 220, will be dominated by hard liners, legatees of this decade of growing sectarianism, which now makes it inadmissible for a pro- Europe Tory to be nominated for a winnable, or indeed any, seat. The great majority of newly nominated candidates now say not merely no but never to the euro: a transgression of the supposed party line that Hague does nothing to reprimand, still less forbid. Such is the measure of his leadership. With the exception of one departing MP, John Townend, there seems to be nothing that any Tory politician says from within the sect that Hague would judge inimical to the party's interests in the world beyond. A measure of its distance from that world is to be found in the intense discussions of his likely successor. These now focus on Michael Portillo as the most credible applicant for what one might call the Patten vote. What a turn-around, what a plight! Mr Portillo is undoubtedly an able man, the most able of any in the field, who also understands the limitations of what has been happening in the past four years. But he is infected with the disease that largely defines the Tory predicament and excludes it from consideration as a party of government: the visceral anti- Europeanism that deforms so much of what else the party might have to say. That Portillo is becoming the candidate of the Tory left shows how truly straitened the gate to salvation has become. The predicament, I think, will not end until the Europe question is resolved, one way or the other. Yet the new emerging battle in the party, waiting to greet any post-election leader, is over how long that resolution can possibly be postponed. If there is a euro referendum, the issue is no longer who fights on which side, but whether the result should be accepted. The ultras, among whom Portillo seems to be one, are preparing to declare the result invalid if it is yes, and to obstruct the single currency, by every possible means, up to the very moment of its birth here. They say that foot and mouth poses no threat to humans. It must be something else eating away at Conservative brains. hugoyoung@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Dear George
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Freedland has managed to get his hands on a private letter from Tony Blair to George Bush. Find out what words of wisdom the PM had to offer ...
fields.trailText: Jonathan Freedland has managed to get his hands on a private letter from Tony Blair to George Bush. Find out what words of wisdom the PM had to offer ...
fields.body:
Dear George,

I know things are getting a bit prickly for you over there just now - your first big crisis and all that. Don't worry about it, the first one's always the hardest. After that you get lots of grey hair, bags under your eyes and the pundits start calling you "seasoned" and "experienced". With me it was the formula one affair and Bernie Ecclestone; with you it's a spy plane and Jiang Zemin. Same thing, really.

Anyway, I'm writing to let you know that you've always got a friend in London (take a look at the map: it's right of America, across the blue bit and just after Ireland). You'll have noticed that us Brits have been the only government in the world to take sides in this spy-plane row between you and China. Japan, the Philippines and all the rest are either saying nothing or using diplomatic language to stay well out of it. Not us.

We've weighed right in behind you. Did you hear Robin Cook's remarks? No, I don't suppose you did. Anyway, he's our foreign secretary - kind of like your secretary of state. And he condemned Jiang's demand that you apologise for crashing into one of China's planes. He said it was "unrealistic". Cookie also agreed with your call for Beijing to send the 24 US servicemen home as soon as possible - and for China to give back your plane.

So, as you can see, we're doing the time-honoured British thing - staunchly serving as America's ultra-loyal ally, forever at your side. I don't care that, once again, I'll be on my own - just like I was when you and I bombed Iraq together in February. The Europeans will criticise me, calling me America's poodle, Uncle Sam's lapdog. But I don't care: being your number one ally is a prize worth all kinds of humiliation.

Just one thing. It would make life a tad easier for me, and for America's less faithful friends, if this whole alliance thing felt more like a two-way street. That means Washington standing with us, the way you want us to stand with Washington.

Kyoto is what I have in mind. Last week you said you'd tear up that global agreement on climate change. Now, I'm afraid that didn't go down too well here - in Britain or in Europe. People are in no mood to be your friend when you won't play ball with the rest of us.

We need a little so we can give a little. You bring America back into the fold on Kyoto, listen to us on Russia or national missile defence, and then we'll happily be your partner in facing down China. But you can't have it both ways. If you insist on America First, you'll end up being America Alone.

Anyway, I've banged on long enough. All the best, George. And remember: not too many late nights - unless you want to look as knackered as me!

Yours,

Tony

webTitle: Sophie faces new row over business role

fields.headline: Sophie faces new row over business role
fields.trailText: Sophie, Countess of Wessex, faces renewed questions about an apparent conflict of interest between her role as a royal and her business life as a PR executive. By Stephen Bates.
fields.body:
Sophie, Countess of Wessex, flew back to Britain from the Gulf last night to face renewed questions about an apparent conflict of interest between her role as a member of the royal family and her business life as a public relations executive.

Buckingham Palace was anxious to dismiss reports of a crisis over the future of the countess, but reports indicated that the Queen had held talks with her private secretary, Sir Robin Janvrin, after fears that the royal family could be dragged into disrepute by the business links of the countess and the Earl of Wessex, the Queen's youngest son.

Newspapers carried stories on Sunday about ill-advised remarks that the 36-year-old countess is alleged to have made to a News of the World reporter posing as a wealthy Arab sheikh, seeking to place work with her Belgravia public relations company R-JH.

She was said to have described the prime minister as "too presidential", Cherie Blair as "horrid, absolutely horrid, horrid, horrid" and William Hague as "deformed" and to have made disparaging remarks about the Queen and the Queen Mother.

There were suggestions last night that R-JH, set up by the countess, formerly Sophie Rhys-Jones, in 1997, two years before she married Prince Edward, may be in more difficulties; further tapes may indicate indiscretions by her business partner Murray Harkin, who also met the bogus sheikh and has since gone to ground. The Times claimed Mr Harkin was on the verge of resigning from R-JH as a result of additional remarks he made when the countess was not in the room.

Buckingham Palace last night dismissed reports that the Queen has held crisis meetings with her closest advisers about the future of the countess.

Stories in today's Times and Sun newspapers that the Queen had held discussions with Sir Robin were dismissed as "absolute nonsense".

In what is becoming a disastrous week for the royal family, it also appears to have fallen out with the Press Complaints Commission, whose chairman Lord Wakeham has insisted, contrary to palace assertions, that he did not advise on the strategy of trying to head off the revelations by granting an alternative interview to the News of the World, in which the countess asserted that her husband was not gay.

Compounding everything else have been reports that the count has used formal trips abroad to secure business for his private film-making company from the Sultan of Brunei among others.

The couple have returned to London under pressure with some palace insiders accusing the countess of naivity at best and stupidity in falling for the tabloid sting at worst. Commentators suggest she may have to give up her business.

fields.headline: Karadzic family 'arming Real IRA'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Northern Ireland
Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: Allies of Radovan Karadzic,the Bosnian Serb leader charged with war crimes by the Hague tribunal, are supplying arms to the Real IRA and other extremist groups across Europe from hideaways in the Serb part of Bosnia, according to a Spanish documentary team that has filmed the Bosnian Serb arms traffickers in action.
fields.body:
Allies of Radovan Karadzic,the Bosnian Serb leader charged with war crimes by the Hague tribunal, are supplying arms to the Real IRA and other extremist groups across Europe from hideaways in the Serb part of Bosnia, according to a Spanish documentary team that has filmed the Bosnian Serb arms traffickers in action.

Their film - broadcast last night on Spain's third channel, Antena 3 - alleges that a relation of Mr Karadzic, and others in the family's coterie are behind a trade that has turned the Bosnian Serb Republic into an international arms depot supplying groups that include the Real IRA and the Eta Basque bombers.

The weaponry is shipped through Kosovo, Croatia, and Germany to Ireland and other countries around the world, the Spanish film reports.

The illicit trade is carried on under the nose of the Nato-led S-For peace force in Bosnia.

Nato has been consistently criticised for failing to arrest Mr Karadzic. As leader of Bosnia's Serbs during the killings and ethnic cleansing of the early 90s, he is one of the men most wanted by the International War Crimes Tribunal in the Hague.

The arms for sale, mostly leftovers from the Bosnian Serb and Yugoslav armed forces and police, include Kalashnikov rifles, M-84 machine guns, M-50 grenades, pistols, explosives and detonators. Night sights and telescopic sights for snipers are also on offer.

A gang of arms traffickers, led by a Karadzic ally, Veljko Borovina, showed the Spaniards exploding bullets, banned by international treaties.

They said they could also get armoured cars and even helicopters, through contacts in the Yugoslav military and the Bosnian Serb army.

The traffickers said that Mr Karadzic's relation was a major arms smuggler who had sold weapons to the Real IRA through Germany. He is believed to be in hiding.

"[He] is totally trustworthy. During the war he trafficked in alcohol, tobacco and arms to finance the Serb army. He has the very best contacts and has sold to the IRA," explained Lario, one of the gang members who led the documentary team to the Bosnian Serb town of Sokolac.

The film makers from El Mundo TV, a production company owned by the Madrid daily El Mundo, posed as drug traffickers buying for paramilitary groups in Colombia.

They started their search for arms in Spain by contacting a well known Croatian gangster with property there. They were passed to a series of Balkan mafia contacts, whom they filmed secretly. The trail led to Budapest in Hungary and on to Bosnia - first Sarajevo, then Kiseljak and, finally, Sokolac.

There they were taken into a forest by Mr Borovina, who is wanted by police in connection with the murder of a former Bosnian Serb police chief Ljubisa Savic - a Karadzic opponent.

Mr Borovina invited his supposed buyers to try out a large range of weaponry.

"We've got Kalashnikovs, machine guns, pistols, grenades, whatever you want," he explained. "These bullets can penetrate a bullet-proof vest and rip it to pieces," he said, showing a hollow bullet banned by international treaties.

He also said he could supply bullets that carry chemicals, which are also banned under international law.

The traffickers explained that most of the weapons had once belonged to the Bosnian Serb army. So many weapons were now on the market, they added, that prices were half the original: a Kalashnikov at £320, an M-84 machine gun at £800. The traffickers agreed a price equalling £1.5m for 200 Kalashnikovs, 75 M-84s, 500 pistols, 50 sniper rifles with telescopic sights, half a tonne of TNT, 1,000 crates of ammunition and 5,000 grenades. Payment was to be made half in cash and half in cocaine.

In Britain, Ulster Unionist MPs recently claimed that Real IRA members were posing as charity workers to travel to the former Yugoslavia to buy arms.

The rocket-propelled grenade launcher used in last September's attack on the MI6 head quarters in London is believed to have been made by Yugoslav Defence Industries and sold by Serbs to the Real IRA. Ireland's Gardai police force discovered last year that the Real IRA had sophisticated Russian RPG18 launchers whose rockets can pierce tank armour.

Last July Croatian police discovered an arms haul destined for the Real IRA that included 10 RPG18s in the town of Dobranje, on the border with Bosnia. A similar shipment, also thought to be destined for Northern Ireland, was found in Slovenia.

webTitle: Leader: Tories should listen to their former leader

fields.headline: Message from Major
fields.standfirst:
Tories should listen to their former leader

Full coverage of Election 2001
Election 2001: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: One of the cruel rules of politics is that leaders derided in office tend to gain in stature afterwards.
fields.body:
One of the cruel rules of politics is that leaders derided in office tend to gain in stature afterwards. Jimmy Carter was a laughing stock in the White House, but has garnered plaudits as an international statesman ever since he left: more effective as an ex-president than he ever was as president. Might a similar fate await John Major, who has once again distinguished himself with a post-retirement intervention?

For the former prime minister has made a subtle, but unmistakable attack on the state of his party. Addressing a lunch for the pro-European Tory MP Ian Taylor, Mr Major lamented his host's exclusion from the current Conservative front bench. He hoped Mr Taylor would one day return, "since the Conservative party has always been a broad church". He added a coded attack on William Hague's recent speech warning that Britain risked becoming a "foreign land". Mr Major, by contrast, insisted that Tories had to "reach out to all in society".

Today's Conservative vanguard will doubtless whisper that Mr Major is out of touch, yesterday's man engaged in a burst of "backseat driving" - to name but a few of the available cliches. But they would do better to listen to what their former leader is saying. He knows better than most the price Conservatives pay when they seem intolerant, divided or extreme - and the exclusion of people like Ian Taylor is evidence of all three.

That is not just Mr Major's opinion. An NOP poll for ITN yesterday found that one in four voters describing the Tories as "extreme". That is far too high for what should be a mainstream party of opposition: when the word was applied to Labour it kept them out of office for 18 years. Mr Hague would go some way toward remedying the problem if he found room around his top table for those who articulate Toryism's One Nation tradition. Without them, he risks emulating his predecessor in one respect only - by losing an election.

webTitle: Mirror Group resents Sun's relationship with No 10

fields.headline: Mirror Group resents Sun's relationship with No 10
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The chief executive of the Mirror has attacked the close relationship between Downing Street and its rival the Sun, in a sign that No 10's decision to leak the election date to the Murdoch tabloid has raised hackles at Labour's traditional Fleet Street cheerleader.
fields.body:
The chief executive of the Mirror has attacked the close relationship between Downing Street and its rival the Sun, in a sign that No 10's decision to leak the election date to the Murdoch tabloid has raised hackles at Labour's traditional Fleet Street cheerleader.

In a highly unusual move, Philip Graf said it was extraordinary that Downing Street had bypassed the cabinet and parliament by effectively announcing a June general election through a newspaper and the BBC. "It does not seem a very satisfactory way to do business," he said.

Mr Graf's comments are a sign that the Mirror is increasingly concerned at the cosy relationship enjoyed by its principal rival, the Sun, with Downing Street. While Mr Graf said he had "a great professional admiration" for the top selling tabloid, his comments suggested that he felt that the Mirror did not have the same level of access.

It was claimed earlier this week that the Sun's political editor, Trevor Kavanagh, was briefed on the decision to delay the general election to June. The BBC's political editor, Andrew Marr, is thought to have been similarly briefed. News International, owner of the Sun, declined to comment on Mr Graf's remarks.

In the course of a wide-ranging speech about the relationship between the government and the press, delivered to the Worshipful Company of Stationers and Newspaper Makers in London, Mr Graf raised concerns about the relationships between newspapers and government. He suggested that Rupert Murdoch's takeover of the Times and the Sunday Times was helped by his support of the then government. He also pointed out that the Mirror had, at times, exerted its own influence.

But Mr Graf praised Tony Blair's press secretary, Alastair Campbell, for introducing more openness into the lobby system. Briefings are now conducted on the record, with comments attributed to Mr Campbell or to his stand-in, rather than "sources close to the prime minister". However, he attacked Labour's record on freedom of information, saying recent legislation was a "far cry" from the lofty ideals to smash government secrecy promised in the 1997 manifesto.

Mr Graf also warned that privacy cases brought by celebrities under the Human Rights Act threatened to undermine press freedom.

"There is already evidence to indicate that the Human Rights Act is being used by courts to restrict what can be reported in criminal proceedings and, at least initially, the courts have been more inclined to restrict press freedom rather than be robust in defence of it," he said.

In a highly unusual move, Philip Graf said it was extraordinary that Downing Street had bypassed the cabinet and parliament by effectively announcing a June general election through a newspaper and the BBC. "It does not seem a very satisfactory way to do business," he said.
