fields.trailText: A May 3 election would have been carefully timed to take place in the immediate aftermath of a wealth of handouts from the Treasury. Delaying the election, if only until June, leaves a lengthy list of potential pitfalls to be confronted in the next nine weeks. The Countryside Alliance may have proved an unlikely ally for Tony Blair, with the announcement that their postponed march on the capital will not be held before the foot and mouth crisis is over, but another tube strike is possible and the government faces other potential civil unrest. Before the election Labour has to negotiate these snakes and ladders:
fields.body:
A May 3 election would have been carefully timed to take place in the immediate aftermath of a wealth of handouts from the Treasury. Delaying the election, if only until June, leaves a lengthy list of potential pitfalls to be confronted in the next nine weeks. The Countryside Alliance may have proved an unlikely ally for Tony Blair, with the announcement that their postponed march on the capital will not be held before the foot and mouth crisis is over, but another tube strike is possible and the government faces other potential civil unrest. Before the election Labour has to negotiate these snakes and ladders:

 Today Potential pitfall or temporary boost as the Bank of England decides whether to lower interest rates.

 April 6 The children's tax credit is launched, giving an extra £10 a week to 5m families, and ensuring families with an income of up to £34,000 gain an extra £525 a year. The 10p starting rate of tax is also extended, giving all 25m taxpayers an extra 70p a week or £30 a year. But changes to national insurance will bring an extra £2.90 bill for middle income households.

 April 11 Unemployment figures are out and expected to be positive for a government which last month saw unemployment fall to below 1m for the first time in 25 years.

 April 19 Inflation figures should add to goodwill factor.

 Between April 9 and April 20 , the teaching unions will be holding their annual conferences, with trenchant criticism expected and unwelcome headlines for the government.

 April 21 Another pitfall with animal rights activists planning their biggest demonstration of the year to mark World Day for Laboratory Animals.

 May 1 Anti-capitalist protesters are planning to repeat the violence seen on May day 2000, when 150,000 people disrupted central London, pillaging shops and defacing monuments and statues.

 May 14 The trial of former Tory deputy chairman Jeffrey Archer for perjury and perverting the course of justice starts at the Old Bailey. Is listed to last for at least three weeks - the entire length of the campaign.

 May 15 An expected boost with inflation figures.

 May 16 Unemployment figures - and on May 17 retail sales figures - may boost the good news factor.

 May 21 Possible reminder of transpot chaos with the start of the summer rail timetables and deadline set by rail regulator Tom Winsor for Railtrack to complete its work programme.

 June 6 Eve of the election and the Bank of England offers a possible boost when it decides interest rates. England play Greece in Athens in a World Cup qualifier, and the result could prove crucial to the mood of the nation. Though he always denied it, Harold Wilson reputedly blamed his June 1970 election defeat on England's elimination by West Germany from the World Cup just four days earlier. Back in April he had asked cabinet colleagues if a football defeat just before polling day would mean the government suffered. Could it be that Mr Blair will ask the same?

fields.headline: Cheshire set beat targets
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Cheshire internet software firm Surfcontrol yesterday said it would hit sales targets of£25.4m for the year, writes Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
Surfcontrol, the Cheshire internet software firm which relocated across the Atlantic in Silicon Valley with its products that monitor workplace web surfing, yesterday said it would hit sales targets of $36.5m (£25.4m) for the year.

While more than 80% of American hi-tech companies have given profits warnings in the last few months, Surfcontrol was able to report better than expected third quarter results and said it had yet to be hit by the US economic slowdown.

Turnover for the third quarter rose 200% to $11.1m, but the group's losses also widened as a result of its continued expansion programme.

The firm made a pretax loss of $60m in the nine months to the end of February, up from $16m last year.

"Since the period end, trading has progressed well and we believe that we will have a successful outcome to the full year", said Steve Purdham, the chief executive.

Surfcontrol's shares, which dropped 112.5p on Tuesday, jumped 22.5p to 345p.

Analysts were upbeat about the results; one described the figures as a "cracking set of numbers" and said investors should take advantage of the company's present weak share price.

fields.headline: Snook attacks 3G gloom mongers
fields.trailText: Orange founder Hans Snook has defended the billions spent buying third generation mobile phone licences, writes John Cassy.
fields.body:
Orange founder Hans Snook yesterday defended the billions of pounds operators have spent buying third generation mobile phone licences, writes John Cassy in Miami.

Predictions that the expenditure would never be recouped were "not at all justified". He did admit that he could not see any "meaningful" 3G services arriving before the end of 2003 at the earliest.

"People think these licences are expensive because they don't understand where the revenues are going to come from and no one has grasped what the future will be like.

"It happens this way each time a new mobile technology is introduced, and each time the doubters have been proved wrong.

"The wireless internet will enable a whole host of different types of 'life services' that will change the way people interact and buy, and greatly increase network usage. There are also potentially trillions of micro-transactions that will be made using wireless devices, and I can foresee huge amounts of revenue from that."

The multimillionaire entrepreneur, now a special adviser to France Télécom, Orange's main shareholder, said the company would not risk damaging its brand by introducing new services before 3G networks were robust enough to cope with demand.

It would be the end of 2003 before Orange was ready to act on its vision for the next generation of mobile phones. Some other operators and handset manufacturers believe it might not happen until 2004 or 2005.

"We won't make the sort of mistake Virgin made when it put a very strong brand on a lousy railroad line," Mr Snook said after addressing the Accenture Global Communications Forum in Miami Beach.

"Branson should have improved the line before putting the brand on it because now everyone thinks Virgin is crap."

Mr Snook said that the prohibitive cost of buying licences in other parts of the world would lead Orange to consider becoming a "virtual network operator", leasing capacity from other firms and putting its own brand on top.

fields.headline: Elderly fume over bookie's 'joke' ad
fields.trailText: A betting firm has found that it went too far with a joke suggesting a bet on the chances of pensioners getting across a road without being run down. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
A betting firm has found that it went too far with a joke suggesting a bet on the chances of pensioners getting across a road without being run down.

Paddy Power, an internet bookie, advertised its services with a poster depicting two elderly women struggling across a zebra crossing as a lorry approaches.

Odds are placed next to each pensioner, along with the caption: Let's make things more interesting.

The Bristol Senior Citizens Forum, which has 300 members, said yesterday that it supported those who had defaced a poster in the city.

Chairwoman Anne Crabtree said: "It's a disgrace. Once again it is pensioners being treated with no respect.

"Is this what people think about pensioners? I shall be organising a petition, writing to my MP, and campaigning hard against it."

A spokeswoman for Help The Aged said: "Images like this fuel age discrimination and devalue older people. One wonders what Paddy Power's older punters would make of being viewed with such disrespect.

"We believe that the advertising standards agency should act on ageism, in the same way as it deals with complaints on grounds of sexism and racism."

The firm said its campaign had been misunderstood, and denied that the poster odds referred to which pedestrian would be hit first.

Paddy Power, the eponymous operations director, said: "That had never crossed our minds. The car in the background is merely incidental. The odds are about which granny will get across first.

"It is a bit of fun really. It is intended to encourage people to think there is a wide range of things you can bet on."

Mr Power said the campaign would continue with other images in a similar style.

fields.headline: Industry Standard Europe seeks buyer
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Internet and technology magazine the Industry Standard Europe is for sale, writes Amy Vickers.
Feb 22: Industry Standard lays off 69 staff
Feb 19: Industry Standard cuts more jobs
fields.body:
Internet and technology magazine the Industry Standard Europe is for sale.

It is in talks with potential suitors about a possible part or all-out sale of the business.

Just six months after the self-styled Silicon Valley bible launched in the UK, it is "actively pursuing strategic partnerships to accelerate the break-even point".

Pearson, which owns an estimated 5% stake in parent company Standard Media International, is said to be favourite to buy ISE outright.

Neil Thackray, chief executive officer of ISE, said he was talking to a number of parties.

"We're in a very different place from where we were six months ago," he said.

"While we're not under any pressure to do a deal - because of what has happened with the market downturn - it makes sense to sell equity to someone who can help us accelerate the point at which we break even."

Mr Thackray added it important to make the right tactical partnerships and to evolve so as to avoid being caught out by the market.

This week's issue of the weekly magazine carries a few minor tweaks. The most obvious is the tagline, which has changed from "The news magazine of the internet economy" to the more generic "Business intelligence".

Rumours of ISE being on the market began circulating last week when it was rumoured two deals were on the table.

One of these deals was said to involve Pearson, which paid £3m for a stake in Standard Media International last year.

Pearson, owner of the Financial Times, has recently scaled back its internet-related investments by more than 50%.

However, an extended equity deal with ISE may fit in with its strategy.

The FT and ISE are very similar in style and their depth of analysis and could complement each other.

ISE, which has 64 staff, is majority (around 50%) owned by US technology publisher IDG.

webTitle: Epidemic levelling out, says chief scientist

fields.headline: Epidemic levelling out, says chief scientist
fields.standfirst:
Vaccination option dropped as rate of killing infected animals speeds up

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Vaccination option dropped as rate of killing infected animals speeds up.
fields.body:
Two independent teams of scientists believe that the foot and mouth outbreak has reached a plateau and the daily tally of cases will begin to fall, the government's chief scientist, David King, said yesterday.

Key to containing the epidemic was slaughtering infected animals as quickly as possible, and this alone was beginning to turn the situation around, he said.

New outbreaks were running at 40 to 45 a day, compared with the 65 to 70 a day that would have been expected if the slaughter policy was not working.

Professor King said that as a result of the more optimistic forecasts the option of vaccinating 180,000 cattle in Cumbria and Devon had been dropped, at least for the time being. In a week it would possible to confirm whether the disease had peaked.

The rate at which infected animals were being killed was accelerating, even though there were still 380,000 animals awaiting slaughter. The vast majority of these were healthy animals on neighbouring farms which would have to killed as a "fire wall." The urgency was not so great in these cases, but it was hoped that all would be killed within 48 hours of their neighbours getting an outbreak.

On March 23, when foot and mouth was first acknowledged to be out of control and scientists believed the outbreaks might reach as many as 400 a day, it was taking 2.8 to 3 days to slaughter infected animals and up to a week to kill potential contacts.

This had been cut to 1.5 days or better for infected animals. This alone had brought down the number of outbreaks, and if the time was reduced even further the epidemic would tail off sharply.

Prof King said the teams of epidemiologists from Imperial College London and Cambridge had given the government clear advice on how to contain the outbreak.

"They have been working entirely independently and come up with remarkably similar results. This [has] given us a fantastic science base, and we can make policy decisions."

He said the scientists had been pessimistic because so far this spring the weather had favoured the virus. "If rain and cold continue, the virus can survive and spread more easily, but warm sunshine kills it."

The main problems for the government remained the "hot spots" of disease, where the spread continued. Cumbria and Dumfries and Galloway had always been the worst, followed by Devon, Mid Wales, Hereford, Gloucestershire and the area north of Birmingham.

In the past two weeks two new areas close to Newcastle upon Tyne had emerged. "We have established a new command and control centre in Newcastle to kill all infected animals as quickly as possible."

In Cumbria the government was continuing to slaughter animals to the south of the main outbreak to protect the fells. This would be a special fire wall.

The policy of killing everything within two miles of an outbreak had been abandoned elsewhere as too difficult; there were just too many animals involved. The work of the scientists showed that the most important action was to take out all the animals on neighbouring farms. This meant on average that for every one infected farm there were four to six neighbours.

Teams of scientist advisers were being sent all over the country in the next few days to explain to farmers what the government was trying to achieve, Prof King said. "If they understand the science and how it is working, then together we can defeat this thing. Their cooperation has been vital so far."

Ian Gardiner, deputy director of the National Farmers Union, said: "It does look on this evidence as if the epidemic has peaked. But it is too early to relax; we need to keep working at it, however painful it is."

fields.standfirst:
Train chaos After months of suffering, passengers face big fare rises


Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Rail fares are to rise by almost 10% on Virgin Trains and by more than the rate of inflation on several other services in a move which will infuriate passengers and reopen the debate on renationalisation of the railways.
fields.body:
Rail fares are to rise by almost 10% on Virgin Trains and by more than the rate of inflation on several other services in a move which will infuriate passengers and reopen the debate on renationalisation of the railways.

Chris Green, chief executive of Virgin Trains, blamed "rail cancer" following the Hatfield rail crash for the increase, due on May 21. He did not rule out a further increase later in the year.

Mr Green said the rail network had been badly hit "by its own foot and mouth disease in the shape of 500 emergency speed restrictions which wiped out four years of growth in just four weeks".

He added: "The fares increase is a last resort. We desperately tried to avoid it."

Virgin's fares will increase by up to 9.8% when the summer timetable is introduced. A standard open return fare from London to Manchester will increase from £150 to £164 (a 9.3% increase), Birmingham to London £80 to £87.50 (9.4%), Preston to London from £155 to £170 (9.7%) and Exeter to Birmingham £83 to £91 (9.6%).

Mr Green said the increase could only be avoided by either a further increase in its subsidy from the government or an agreement by Railtrack for extra compensation due to loss of business after Hatfield.

Virgin and at least four other train operating companies are threatening to take legal action against Railtrack. They want a further £200m.

Mr Green said big fare increases were unfair to all rail users. But Virgin had run out of options, short of slowing down investment, cutting trains, reducing staff or "handing back the keys".

This is the first admission by a senior rail figure from a large company that if matters do not improve, the government will have to start operating a substantial portion of the railway again.

Mr Green said Virgin and Stagecoach, which has a 49% stake in Sir Richard Branson's rail operation, have been un derwriting the income losses since Hatfield. This had culminated in Stagecoach issuing a profits warning for 2000-1.

Mr Green said Stagecoach-Virgin's shareholders had supported a fares freeze for the past year, but were set to lose more than £100m in income by the first anniversary of Hatfield at a time of peak investment for new trains.

He said Virgin had to watch while the government gave Railtrack £1.5bn of extra subsidy to tide it through Hatfield, a crisis of its own making. "We face months of judicial action to extract our rightful compensation."

The Association of Train Operating Companies, representing 25 train companies, including National Express and FirstGroup, confirmed that litigation would be initiated now that negotiations with Railtrack had broken down.

Railtrack agreed that legal action was possible, but said that all further claims would be resisted. It acknowledges that it has so far paid out more than £600m since Hatfield, but industry sources say the figure is almost £1bn.

Fares frozen by Great North Eastern Railway in January will increase by 3.3% in May, above the 2.7% headline rate of inflation. Fares at Midland MainLine, which operates the inter-city network between Sheffield and London will increase by between 2.6 and 5%, but the company says this will result in improvements for passengers.

GNER said the increase was delayed because of the impact of Hatfield. As the company most directly involved at Hatfield, GNER said that it was far from satisfied with Railtrack's compensation.

The decision to increase fares will profoundly dismay rail passenger groups, who are being officially told the news today.

A senior source said last night: "This is the biggest kick in the teeth the industry could administer to passengers. Their faith in rail has not even begun to be restored. It will have the effect of turning more people away."

Mr Green said Virgin's passenger numbers are 10% down on pre-Hatfield figures and there was a concern that a further 10% could follow with the fares rise.

He said: "The compensation from Railtrack has met less than half the cost of the post-Hatfield disruption and loss of income.

"We had no intention of raising fares by the extent proposed until it became clear that the huge cash hole could not be plugged."

webTitle: Russia's defiant TV crew becomes the news

fields.headline: Russia's defiant TV crew becomes the news
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Russia
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Journalists have barricaded themselves in at Russia's biggest independent television channel, NTV. By Ian Traynor.
fields.body:
His face caked with orange makeup, his shirt a pristine white for the bright TV studio lights, Andrei Norkin did yesterday what he has been doing on most days for the past four years: he read the news on Russia's biggest independent television channel, NTV.

Yesterday, however, the news he read was almost exclusively about himself and his 356 colleagues at NTV, barricaded inside their TV citadel at the centre of a political drama.

Mr Norkin and his colleagues have refused to leave the building for fear that they will not have jobs or studios to return to. They pumped out only news, in protest at Tuesday's sudden boardroom coup and takeover of the channel by the Kremlin-backed Gazprom corporation, Russia's biggest company.

There were no game shows, no soap operas, no movies, no police serials, just Mr Norkin and his fellow newscaster, Svetlana Sorokina, reading the news, interspersed with NTV's live coverage of its own sit in.

Roman Borkov, 25, an NTV news producer, sat in front of a bank of TV monitors feeding the videos into the whirring machines and directing the cameras.

"It's pretty weird. I've never done this before," he said. "We're only broadcasting what's going on within these corridors."

Mr Norkin and the rebellious NTV staff have suddenly been pitched into the biggest battle for freedom of the press that Russia has seen in the decade since communism collapsed.

The stand-off is the result of a year-long saga pitting Gazprom, seen as a Kremlin proxy, against Vladimir Gusinsky, the exiled mogul who founded the station eight years ago. During that time he put together what is arguably the most talented and most professional team of journalists working in Russia. It is also the only important TV channel in the country which does not dance to the Kremlin's tune.

On Tuesday Gazprom, which owns 46% of NTV, called a snap shareholders' meeting, and engineered a putsch of the board, from which they removed Mr Gusinsky and the NTV chief and top journalist, Yevgeny Kiselev. The agents of Gazprom installed a new management trio - with their own Alfred Kokh as chairman, Boris Jordan, a US banker, as NTV chief, and Vladimir Kulistikov, head of the state news agency RIA Novosti, as the channel's editor.

Still sitting in his director-general's office orchestrating the rebellion yesterday, Mr Kiselev said bluntly: "I'm not going to work with Kokh. I won't even shake his hand. He's just a toy in the hands of [President Vladimir] Putin."

It is this kind of unbridled criticism of Russia's powerful, and its exposure of corruption in high places, that have earned NTV the enmity of the Kremlin.

With his 1995 International Press Freedom award pinned to the wall behind him, Mr Kiselev vowed that the "civil disobedience" campaign he is leading would go on. Sweating heavily, eyes bloodshot, palpably exhausted, the normally dapper TV chief spat his contempt for the new managers.

"Kokh can come in and take over this office. But is he going to read the news, report from parliament, host talk shows? Because no one here is going to do that for him."

It's a view that is echoed in the corridors outside his office, as tired camera crews, technicians, secretaries, and journalists chainsmoked through the afternoon in adrenaline-driven, coffee-fuelled solidarity. They expect a police raid at any time to evict them.

"Kokh and Jordan have broken the law as far as we're concerned," Grigory Krichevsky, director of news programmes, said. "They can come here, but all they're going to find is empty rooms and empty boxes. No one will pay them any attention and no one will work with them."

These tactics are to be applied with military rigour.

"This is not about money, it's about convictions and freedom of thought, about ideas," Mr Borkov said.

"And it's got nothing to do with Gusinsky, it's about our TV company," said Ms Sorokina, whose famously demure screen presence has melted away to reveal a forceful personality.

As TV professionals, they have a keen talent for the theatrical and the dramatic, precious weapons being deployed in the national hearts-and-minds campaign to save the station.

The men in suits from Gazprom might have the big money and political backers, but they are losing the propaganda battle.

Liberal politicians paraded through the studios yesterday, providing more soundbites which were instantly fed into the live broadcasts. The last Soviet president, Mikhail Gorbachev, pronounced the hostile takeover a disgrace and "a challenge to all of society".

He said he wanted to discuss the matter with President Putin, suggesting that, as ever in Russia, the Tsar was being misled by his courtiers. Mr Kiselev, however insists that the whole crisis has been engineered "on the orders of the Tsar".

What will happen next in this drama is less than clear. Gazprom has called another emergency NTV board meeting for tomorrow.

Mr Norkin, meanwhile, will light another cigarette, fix a stray hair or two and face the cameras to read the latest news about Russia's real-life television drama.

Ted Turner steps in

The tug-of-war to decide NTV's future could hinge on the US mogul and CNN founder, Ted Turner, who claimed last night to have been offered most of Vladimir Gusinsky's media holding company for $225m (£157m), writes Ian Traynor .

The company includes newspapers and magazines, a Moscow radio station, and 49% of NTV. But the deal is far from done.

A western consortium of investors, led by Mr Turner, and including the US financier George Soros and a Swedish media magnate, has been in negotiations for months.

Sources close to Mr Gusinsky said yesterday that only a memorandum of understanding had been agreed. The deal's approval appeared to depend on talks scheduled for next week.

CNN said yesterday that Mr Turner would only proceed if he could hire and fire the TV channel's board and management.

He said that the US banker, Boris Jordan, just appointed NTV chief by Gazprom, would have to go, CNN reported.

fields.headline: Desmond in crunch talks with Hollinger over Westferry plant
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Express owner Richard Desmond is meeting Hollinger International today as the dispute over the Westferry printing plant reaches boiling point. By Dan Milmo

Click here for latest Express stories
fields.body:
Express owner Richard Desmond is holding a crunch meeting with Telegraph owner Hollinger International today, as the multimillion pound dispute over the Westferry printing plant reaches boiling point.

Mr Desmond's Northern & Shell company, which co-owns the plant with Hollinger, is set to ignore today's deadline of paying an outstanding £8m printing bill.

Sources close to the Westferry board, which is dominated by Hollinger executives, said a writ will be slapped on Northern & Shell if it refused to pay up.

"We hope the talks will produce a payment of the bill, but if they do not legal action will be taken," said one source.

Mr Desmond is refusing to settle the bill until he is paid the £11m dividend he believes Northern & Shell is owed as a shareholder in the company.

However, Hollinger is refusing to authorise this payment until Northern & Shell supplies a budget for its contribution to the plant.

According to the Westferry source, the stalemate could threaten the long-term future of the plant, which prints the southern editions of the Daily Telegraph, the Financial Times, the Express newspapers and the Guardian.

"If the dispute goes on long enough, Westferry will run out of cash. You cannot run a business if a major source of revenue is being withheld," the source added.

Sources close to Northern & Shell dismissed the legal threat, saying the squabble should be settled outside the courts.

"They will sort it out. I would be very surprised if a writ was issued," the source said.

The dividend row is overshadowing a long-standing dispute between Northern & Shell and Hollinger, in which the Telegraph owner is trying to buy Mr Desmond's 50% stake in the business.

Mr Desmond inherited the holding when he paid Lord Hollick's United Business Media £125m for the Express newspapers in November last year.

Both parties are poles apart in valuation, with Northern & Shell demanding £80m and Hollinger offering just £30m.

The price will now be settled by an independent arbitrator, who will be appointed over the next few weeks.

Jeremy Deedes, managing director of the Telegraph Group, said it will make a decision on the stake as soon as the arbitrator comes up with a price.

"The process of appointing an arbitrator is still going on, and this will lead to a price being fixed. Then the Telegraph group will consider whether or not to buy the stake," said Mr Deedes.

fields.headline: GQ Active closed down
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Conde Nast has axed GQ Active almost two years after the magazine changed to quarterly format, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Conde Nast has axed GQ Active, almost two years after the magazine changed from monthly to quarterly format.

The supplement, which was launched in 1997, grew out of the success of Men's Health, the first glossy men's magazine devoted to health and fitness.

"It has been very successful in its quarterly format, but we have decided not to carry on with it," said a spokesman.

She said it was not yet known whether jobs would be found within the company for the three staff working on the magazine.

It is believed editor Brian Schofield will continue to freelance for parent magazine GQ.

The closure of GQ Active follows the closure last year of Emap's Zest for Men or ZM magazine.

The market leader, Men's Health, had a circulation of 235,851 at the last ABCs.

But some observers believe the market cannot support the additional titles.

Peter Baker, co-ordinator of the Men's Health Forum, said: "There's no doubt that there's a market for magazines about men's health.

"But Men's Health seems to have cornered the market."

He added he thought there may have been a backlash amongst magazine readers against "the relentless promotion of the sixpack" and cosmetic issues, as opposed to more general stories about health and fitness.

webTitle: Fund managers pull Sunday Times ads

fields.headline: Fund managers pull Sunday Times adverts
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The paper has lost five lucrative advertisers following a series of negative articles, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Sunday Times has lost lucrative advertising contracts from five of the UK's biggest fund management companies after it ran a series of negative articles about the industry.

Schroders, Threadneedle, Perpetual, Invesco and Aberdeen have all said they will not advertise in the newspaper, according to a report published today in the trade paper Money Marketing.

The decision follows a row between the Sunday Times and the Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds.

The industry body complained to the Press Complaints Commission about a Sunday Times story that claimed the investment fund industry was "cheating small investors" with hidden charges.

The PCC rejected the complaint, claiming that the quotes from the Financial Services Authority within the Sunday Times story backed up the writer's arguments.

But fund managers claim the negative coverage has affected their advertising response rates.

"One has to ask whether the editorial policy, which appears to be anti-fund management, is responsible for the decline in advertising responses," said Robin Stoakley, director of Schroders.

Richard Caseby, managing editor of the Sunday Times, defended the paper's record saying its Money section acted as a champion for the consumer.

fields.headline: Thomson pledges honesty in holiday pricing
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The UK's biggest travel brand is abolishing discounting for the rest of this summer, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Thomson, the UK's biggest travel brand, is trying to bring an element of sanity back to the marketing of holidays by abolishing discounting for the rest of this summer.

The travel industry has been attacked by consumer watchdogs for artificially inflating prices then offering heavy discounts to hoodwink consumers into thinking they are getting a good deal.

Discounts in January, the peak booking season for this summer's holidays, reached the highest ever level of 50%.

Thomson said it will offer "bottom line" pricing on the remaining 1m holidays it expects to sell this summer.

The new pricing structure appears in its fourth edition brochure launched today and will be communicated via a marketing and advertising campaign.

"We're getting to the point where there's 12-month discounting in the industry and discounts could reach 70% by next year" said Shaun Powell, managing director of Thomson Holidays.

"We're just saying let's get sensible. Thomson is the market leader so we hope that the rest of the industry will follow our lead."

Thomson believes the success of the initiative depends on whether independent travel agents are honest with their customers.

Pressure groups such as the Consumers Association have criticised the holiday industry for deliberately confusing the consumer.

The association has suggested the Office of Fair Trading should take action against "dishonest" pricing techniques.

fields.headline: Second sight
fields.standfirst: Abundent bandwidth could be the next big thing, writes Neil McIntosh
fields.trailText: Abundent bandwidth could be the next big thing, writes Neil McIntosh
fields.body:
This week Britain managed second from bottom place in a worldwide survey of broadband internet access. According to Netvalue, an IT research house, the UK lags far behind South Korea, the US, Hong Kong and the leading European economies, with only China faring worse out of the 11 countries profiled.

It is news that should embarrass the government, which says it wants the UK to have the "most competitive and extensive broadband market" of the G7 countries by 2005. But the survey simply confirms what those of us who have attempted to sign up to broadband internet access have known for some time. The situation is desperate, and shows no sign of improving fast.

My quest for broadband began one spring afternoon last year. It was a day of hope, almost a year ago now. It seems much longer.

That morning I swallowed my scepticism and, through BT's website, "registered my interest" in ADSL, the technology which takes an ordinary phone line and turbo charges it for internet access.

I, and thousands like me, hoped to wave bye bye to the dull old world wide wait, an au revoir to jerky streaming video and tinny sound. Even if we had to rely on lumbering old BT to deliver it.

Right on cue, an evangelistic book by technology vision ary George Gilder came out, giving us an even clearer idea of why broadband would really matter. In Telecosm - How Infinite Bandwidth will Revolutionise our World, Gilder looked beyond the go-faster stripes of broadband and saw a world transformed by a surplus of bandwidth - that invisible commodity that allows computers to talk to each other.

To paraphrase Gilder (badly), abundant bandwidth - through the air, over wires, or from the heavens - is the Next Big Thing.

It is not just something that makes the internet go faster. It makes the internet go so much faster it changes the online world's very nature: it is the electronic penicillin, capable of curing all manner of ills in commerce, bringing new knowledge to millions and changing the way we entertain ourselves.

This is not to say Gilder has bought into the broadband we are being urged to aspire to in Britain today. In fact, despite the advertising millions being devoted to the various "broadband" offerings of BT, NTL and Telewest, what's on offer would not meet Gilder's definition of the word.

The 0.5Mbps (megabits per second) links of ADSL or cable modems might run at around 10 times the speed of the best dial-up modems, but they are just the forerunners of what Gilder reckons is needed for the Telecosm to come about. In Gilder's broadband world we will have bandwidth to squander, in bringing about the great changes he foresees.

If Gilder's previous predictions are anything to go by, his technological dream becomes reality far more quickly than you might expect. A decade ago he described the Microcosm, where many components of the physical world would be transferred to a digital state, and much of what he predicted has since happened, right on cue.

The problem is, while Silicon Valley could deliver the Microcosm to the world, the Telecosm relies on local players like BT and NTL. And that is where things begin to go wrong.

Here at Online, we hear tales every week of readers being frustrated in their attempts to get ADSL or a cable modem. My experiences are no different: all BT has done with my details since that optimistic day last year is lose them to hackers, thanks to a website security glitch.

By the end of last year, my mind was beginning to turn to my local cable company, NTL. It took a few days to find someone at their call centres who knew what a cable modem was but, eventually, they were persuaded to start the installation process just before Christmas.

There were all the fruitless waits in endless call queues, and countless broken promises to call back, visit - do anything at all, in fact. But, to its slight credit, it did finally get round to installing a cable modem three weeks ago. Soon I even hope to get the new kit working. Are there many £300m+ a year consumer services blighted by such appaling service?

Worse, the government - with its ambitious plans for a "broadband Britain" by 2005 - seems blissfully unaware of the calamity befalling its vision. Writing in the Finan cial Times in March, e-minister Patricia Hewitt claimed "puzzlement" over the debate about the broadband roll-out in the UK, and claimed that things were on the right track.

Yet, at a House of Commons culture, media and sport committee hearing only a month earlier, Hewitt floundered when asked to define broadband, before saying that "current generation broadband" was actually 2Mbps - four times faster than what was on offer to consumers today. What we have now - 0.5Mbps - is only "higher bandwidth." By that definition broadband is not on offer to consumers in the UK.

Thus a yawning reality gap opens up. The government sees ADSL as the key to broadband Britain, yet what is on offer now does not qualify as broadband.

Ministers claim the UK is at an advanced stage in introducing broadband, yet in South Korea first time net users are getting fast connections installed as standard while the UK's masses dabble with dial-up.

Competition is supposed to speed up the arrival of broadband to our homes, yet in those cabled areas where there is competition, no company has proved itself capable of delivering satisfactorily to the mass market.

Meanwhile the biggest European telecoms companies are saddled with vast debts after buying mobile phone licences. They, and the struggling UK cable companies, are not going to be able to invest their way out of this mess. They will likely want to cherry-pick lucrative business users rather than dabble with low margin consumers.

Those who have endured the Kafkaesque trials of obtaining higher speed net access know things are in a bad way. At the start of March, BT had only connected 20,000 users to its ADSL services, and even by BT's figures more than one in five of that paltry number were not satisfied with the service they were being given.

Such figures are not available for the cable companies, but my experiences - and those of others - suggest their reputation for inept service follows them into the broadband internet era.

If they can't even answer their phones, or chase up sales leads off their website, how can they hope to even match what is happening in Asia, Europe and the US now - let alone deliver that bold vision of the broadband future, the Telecosm?

fields.headline: Slaughterman shot in cull accident
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: A slaughterman is believed to have been accidentally shot with a stun gun during the mass cull of livestock in Cumbria, it was revealed last night.
fields.body:
A slaughterman is believed to have been accidentally shot with a stun gun during the mass cull of livestock in Cumbria, it was revealed last night.

The 27-year-old man from Hastings, East Sussex, suffered life-threatening head injuries in the incident at Great Orton, near Carlisle. It is not known if the stun gun accidentally went off or if it was faulty.

Another man, in his late thirties and from Warwickshire, was treated for shock after the accident which happened at 4pm yesterday.

Cumbria police confirmed that both men were involved in the cull at the huge burial site on the former airfield when the incident occurred. A police spokesman said that the matter, which has been referred to the health and safety executive, was being treated as an industrial accident.

Paramedics were called to Great Orton to treat the slaughterman. He was taken to Cumberland general infirmary and later transferred to a hospital in Newcastle, where he underwent emergency surgery. His condition was "critical".

The other man involved was treated for shock but later discharged.

Details of what happened remained sketchy last night but a police source said: "The man was hit in the head with a stun gun and it is believed the other man may have been holding the gun. I don't know whether it was accidentally fired or there was a fault."

The gun which it is believed the men were using was probably a captive bolt stunner, a heavy instrument weighing some 4lb which propels a 4in bolt of metal into an animal's skull, stunning it but not killing it. It is designed to cause a severe concussion in a cow or sheep.

If fired into a human skull, which is much thinner, it would inevitably cause great devastation.

Accidents are relatively rare because for the bolt to have any impact it must be fired from extremely close range. It can kick back strongly if it is not used properly. Slaughtermen have travelled from around the country to help cull animals at the former airfield site, which is being overseen by the Ministry of Agriculture and the army, and at farms around the stricken county. Many have said it would probably be the last work they would have for some time.

Great Orton has been used for the past fortnight to bury sheep and cattle. Last week it started taking live animals for slaughter on site, before burial. Civilians have worked alongside army slaughtermen.

The RSPCA has been told that it can enter the site at any time without prior warning to check that the animals are being killed humanely.

Last week the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, visited the site.

fields.headline: The smell of rotting, burning flesh had gone. Now the stench was from their own dead animals
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Sixty pairs of wet eyes stared from a pile of fresh carcasses. Blood ran in a straight line from the sheeps' nostrils into the road. The village smelt of raw mutton. It was Britain's 1,000th foot and mouth case and cars slowed down beside the field to let their occupants have a look.
fields.body:
Sixty pairs of wet eyes stared from a pile of fresh carcasses. Blood ran in a straight line from the sheeps' nostrils into the road. The village smelt of raw mutton. It was Britain's 1,000th foot and mouth case and cars slowed down beside the field to let their occupants have a look.

Foot and mouth case number 1,000 was confirmed yesterday in the heart of an area known as Cumbria's "carcass production line".

Gordon and Alice Moffat's dairy farm was one mile from the army's foot and mouth slaughter and burial pit. The nearest infected farm was 500 yards away and pyres burned all around.

Cumbria accounts for nearly half the total cases in Britain. The fields in the north of the county are empty. Despite the government's efforts, the Moffats said they knew it would get them. "We were surrounded," they said.

On their farm the wind could blow three ways bringing differing smells: rotting flesh, burning fleece, or now the meaty stench of their own dead animals. It was the smell, villagers said, of "all your Sunday dinners at once".

Yesterday disinfectant turned the air acid. A neighbour was in tears at her front door. A young driver eased past in a Mercedes and retched.

The Moffats had a 150 acre farm with 260 sheep and 125 cattle. Foot and mouth was confirmed yesterday morning. By the afternoon the neighbouring fields were so silent vets could be heard snapping plastic gloves off their hands at the gates.

Then stun guns sounded across fields, in corrugated sheds. A cow was heard screaming behind a wall and sheep in the fields fled to one end and grouped there. They did not know they would be next.

Julie Moffat, who works with her parents on the farm, said: "Three weeks ago we had a suspected case but we were cleared. The animals haven't been well. There has been something not right about them. They have been salivating at the mouth and they have gone off their cake. Their milk dropped and their teats were sore."

"Things are moving fast," Ms Moffat said, while the cull was carried out. "The slaughterers were here by the afternoon. The vets have been very good."

It was a familiar site out side the farm. Two vets pulled up in their saloon cars. They each took a deep draw on a cigarette at the gate, before pulling on a white paper suit then galloshes, gloves and head protection.

First they went to a field full of sheep, shot them one by one in the head and hauled them into piles. Half an hour later one vet doused the carcasses in disinfectant, wading up to his knees in dead flanks.

Then he picked up a bucket of brown disinfectant and emptied it on himself, waddling, dripping, back to the farm to slaughter the remaining cattle.

Next the army liaison officer pulled up in a camouflage Land Rover with a pile of maps. Then the rumble of lorries would begin to transport the dead for burial.

Alice Moffat said the sadness was acute because it was a family farm with animals bred over generations. "Being the 1,000th confirmed case isn't something anyone would want to claim," she said. "It is terrible that it has reached this scale and unfortunately there will be many more to come.

"It is ridiculous for the government to even suggest that this thing is under control. There were lots of cases confirmed overnight and in Cumbria at least it doesn't appear to be getting any better."

The family was helping the slaughtermen work as fast as possible, although it was a grim task. "It has been a very upsetting day for us. It will be horrible to see the animals killed. This is a very bad day for this family.

"The fields around Cumbria are very sparse at the moment. It's strange to see so many empty.

"The stress of waiting for the disease to strike has been awful as the farms nearby go down one after the other. In a sense it will be worse when all that is over because then there will be nothing to do."

Next door, Dorothy Reay stood on her doorstep in tears.

She said: "It is a terrible milestone. It is heartbreaking to live here and see it all happening. It is tragic. It shouldn't have happened. It shouldn't have got this far."

She said all the villagers were angry with the government response to the outbreak.

"People in the cities have no idea. People in the cities think this is about milk, meat and money. It isn't. It is heartbreaking. You can't describe how people feel."

webTitle: Cumbria pub chain fears a stay-away Easter

fields.headline: Cumbria pub chain fears a stay-away Easter
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: A Cumbrian pub chain said yesterday that its sales were flat due to the impact of foot and mouth on the number of visitors to rural areas.
fields.body:
A Cumbrian pub chain said yesterday that its sales were flat due to the impact of foot and mouth on the number of visitors to rural areas.

Jennings Brothers, based in Cockermouth in Cumbria, said that half its 175 pubs were in areas heavily affected by government restrictions.

Some of the pubs could not be reached due to the restrictions; others had suffered due to the decline in visitors.

The firm's finance director, John Houghton, said the epidemic had not had a "material effect" on trading in the financial year to March 3.

But he thought the chain could suffer in the coming months, particularly over the Easter and August Bank Holiday weekends - its busiest periods.

He said he hoped people would listen to the government's message urging tourists back to parts of the countryside unaffected by the crisis. "There is lots to do here without going walking in the hills. Research shows that walking is only the third most popular countryside activity - the first is visiting towns and interesting places.

"When you come to the Lake District you say you will go walking, but most people tend to spend their time in the pub."

Jennings Brothers' share price fell 7%, or 10p, to 130p after the statement.

webTitle: Gurkhas given role as shepherds in Wales

fields.headline: Gurkhas given role as shepherds in Wales
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Gurkhas with experience of herding are being deployed as shepherds in the Black Mountains in Wales to help collect and cull sheep, defence sources said yesterday.
fields.body:
Gurkhas with experience of herding are being deployed as shepherds in the Black Mountains in Wales to help collect and cull sheep, defence sources said yesterday.

Soldiers from the Signals Regiment are helping Ministry of Agriculture officials map infected areas in the region.

Sources said the Royal Logistic Corps was training 180 soldiers as slaughterers to help kill cattle and sheep.

They are among 1,545 troops, commanded by what the ministry of defence calls a "chain of brigadiers", helping to combat foot and mouth throughout the country.

Defence sources, who say the disease will continue into July before it is eradicated, insisted it was not the army's job to take charge of the fight against foot and mouth. Its role, they said, was to "deliver logistics" by providing a coherent command and control system, based on the advice of Ministry of Agriculture scientists and vets.

They described it as a "multi-agency" approach, adding: "The great enemy is time."

Some training exercises have been disrupted as a result of the deployments. Army patrols in south Armagh, Northern Ireland, have also been affected and would not enter rural areas unless there was a serious terrorist incident, sources said.

webTitle: National parks brace for deadly blow

fields.headline: National parks brace for deadly blow
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The government and NFU leaders are holding their breath that the foot and mouth epidemic has peaked in Britain.
fields.body:
The government and NFU leaders are holding their breath that the foot and mouth epidemic has peaked in Britain - but it may just be starting in the two most visited national parks and some of the most remote but treasured upland areas.

Yesterday, as the army admitted there was a possibility that the disease had reached the high fell flocks, there was a confirmed outbreak at a hill farm at Selside in the heart of the southern Lake District near Windermere, and a suspected case in the Peak District national park.

"This what we have been dreading," said Bob Cartwright, head of management with the Lake District national park authority. "We fear that that we may now lose a whole farming system and a cultural landscape."

There have so far been two other outbreaks in the park in the Duddon Valley, and several right on the northern and western edges. None are believed to have infected upland sheep.

But yesterday's outbreak was at Forest Farm, near Kendal, which has grazing rights over thousands of acres of open moorlands and has "rough fell" sheep, a distinct but endangered breed.

Lieutenant Colonel Gary Donaldson, who is in charge of the army's response in the north-east, said: "Our intelligence tells us foot and mouth is on the fells and we have lost them."

The Moorland Association, which represents the owners of 750,000 acres of English upland areas, yesterday joined leading British conservationists and ecologists and the Peak and Lake national park authorities in calling for urgent vaccination.

Yesterday the National Trust, which has also called for vaccination, said that up to 7,000 of its "hefted" flocks (sheep which live permanently on the moor) had so far been culled.

The Lowther estate, one of the largest landowners in Cumbria, said that the Selside outbreak meant that its 4,500 acre Abbey Farm, which has 2,500 hefted sheep and takes in much of Shap Fell, may now have to be culled. It is estimated that up to to a third of the hefted flocks in Cumbria have already been killed or condemned.

The Rare Breeds Survival Trust said it was planning to take emergency measures to protect six breeds of sheep which were under threat from the cull.

The suspected case of foot and mouth in the Peak District national park, which has been so far free of the disease, could devastate the park, according to the farmer whose premises are being inspected again.

Spray House Farm in Little Hayfield has 2,000 sheep, which roam on around 2,600 acres of hill with the potential to wander on a further 20,000 acres.

A spokesman for the Peak District national park authority said it was still planned to reopen trails within the park. A final decision will be made today by Derbyshire county council.

webTitle: Mbeki's Aids experts split over link to HIV

fields.headline: Mbeki's Aids experts split over link to HIV
fields.standfirst:
Report spares South African president from embarrassment

Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: A panel of international scientists convened by the South African president, Thabo Mbeki, to resolve the issue of whether HIV causes Aids has failed to reach agreement after nearly a year of debate.
fields.body:
A panel of international scientists convened by the South African president, Thabo Mbeki, to resolve the issue of whether HIV causes Aids has failed to reach agreement after nearly a year of debate.

An interim report made public yesterday produced conflicting sets of recommendations because of divisions between themainstream scientists, who believe HIV is the cause of Aids, and the "dissident" faction that claims the disease is the result of social factors such as drug use and poverty.

Instead, the panel could agree only on the need for further research and discussion.

Among the recommendations proposed by the dissidents was one to end the "hysteria" around Aids by suspending "the dissemination of the psychologically destructive and false message that HIV infection is invariably fatal".

The South African government will not be disappointed by the lack of consensus. The report neither embarrasses Mr Mbeki by concluding he was wrong to question the cause of Aids, nor does it say he was right when his government quietly reversed its original policy. The health ministry is moving towards the distribution of some of the very anti-Aids drugs the president once condemned as too toxic and ineffective.

The panellists were most sharply divided over the use of anti-retroviral drugs. Those who deny HIV causes Aids say such medicines do no good while producing severe side effects. Others argue that anti-retrovirals are beneficial in a number of ways, including preventing mother to child transmission.

Among those Mr Mbeki appointed to the 33-member panel were the controversial American scientists Peter Duesberg and David Rasnick who are at the forefront of the Aids dissident movement. They had a profound impact on Mr Mbeki's view of the disease after he discovered their writings on the internet.

But another panel member, the French co-discoverer of the HIV virus, Luc Montagnier, has urged the South African government to be pragmatic about treating Aids rather than engaging in academic arguments about its cause.

A year ago, Mr Mbeki wrote to Bill Clinton, then US president, comparing critics of the Aids dissidents to the tyranny of the Spanish Inquisition and apartheid.

But some scientists were so outraged by Mr Mbeki's stance that 5,000 of them signed a declaration before last year's international Aids conference in Durban stating categorically that Aids was the direct result of HIV.

South Africa's trade union confederation, Cosatu, a key ally of the ruling African National Congress, also strongly criticised the president by implying he was sacrificing the lives of more than 4m South Africans - one in 10 of the population - who have HIV. Since then Mr Mbeki has largely retreated from public debate on the issue.

After a cabinet meeting yesterday at which the Aids panel report was discussed, the health minister, Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, said the government would stick to its belief that HIV caused Aids, a view it was unwilling to espouse a year ago.

The South African government now argues that there is no ideological obstacle to the distribution of drugs, only financial constraints.

Dr Tshabalala-Msimang said that while the division among panellists on the cause of Aids was fundamental, there was more agreement than before on the importance of factors such as poverty, literacy and sexism in the spread of HIV and Aids.

The report was released as the world's largest drugs firms made public an affidavit to the Pretoria high court in their battle with the South African government over the importation of generic drugs. It alleges that the health ministry rejected cheaper anti-Aids medicines when the pharmaceutical companies offered them.

The affidavit will form part of the case presented by 39 drug firms when the hearing resumes in a fortnight.

Dr Tshabalala-Msimang said that while the division among panellists on the cause of Aids was fundamental, there was more agreement than before on the importance of factors such as poverty, literacy and sexism in the spread of HIV and Aids. The report was released as the world's largest drugs firms made public an affidavit to the Pretoria high court in their battle with the South African government over the importation of generic drugs. It alleges that the health ministry rejected cheaper anti-Aids medicines when the pharmaceutical companies offered them. The affidavit will form part of the case presented by 39 drug firms when the hearing resumes in a fortnight.

fields.headline: Winds of change
fields.standfirst:
Since George Bush's shock departure, Europe has been struggling to promote a cohesive front on Kyoto. Britain, at least, is doing its bit

Special report on renewable energy
fields.trailText: Since Tony Blair and George Bush met at Camp David more than a month ago to discover they shared so much in common - Colgate - they have not spoken again. Both men are undoubtedly busy. Mr Bush has had his spy plane shot down in China and Mr Blair has had his election plans shot down in the killing fields of northern Cumbria.
fields.body:
Since Tony Blair and George Bush met at Camp David more than a month ago to discover they shared so much in common - Colgate - they have not spoken again. Both men are undoubtedly busy. Mr Bush has had his spy plane shot down in China and Mr Blair has had his election plans shot down in the killing fields of northern Cumbria.

It speaks volumes for the new transatlantic froideur that the two leaders have not been in contact. Nevertheless, the view in Whitehall is that George W is no dupe. Downing Street may privately sniff at some of his public performances, but in private, the word is that he is well briefed, intelligent and formidable. Comparisons with the cue-card reading Ronald Reagan do not wash. They believe they are facing a genuine rightwing ideologue. All the more reason to take seriously the president's decision to tear up the Kyoto agreement on climate change.

The announcement is causing shock waves not just in the environmental movement, but throughout the capitals of Europe.

But as one cabinet minister frankly admits: "The Republican administration may trust us, but in terms of leverage - whether it is Star Wars or Kyoto - the plain fact is that the United States are going to do whatever they want to do."

The rejection of the Kyoto Protocol by Washington has left Europe struggling to adopt a coherent response. At best the Europeans can only hope to hold the line and hope no one else peels off. At Prime Minister's Questions, Tony Blair stood by the Kyoto agreement and predicted there will be intensive talks in the run-up to the next round of talks in July. Mr Blair, in the second of his two recent speeches on the environment, described Kyoto as a "monument to enlightened global diplomacy."

In the short term, the aim must be to go on showing that good environmentalism and good economics need not be in conflict.

An announcement today by the Department of Trade and Industry will start to show that Mr Blair is serious about meeting its ambitious target of ensuring that by 2010, at least 10% of future energy needs will be met from renewables.

Mr Blair went on to offer an extra £100m to support renewables technology, in addition to the cash already provided. At present 2.8% of electricity comes from renewables.

A lords select committee published a report in July 1999 warning that it was "inconceivable that UK targets for electricity from renewables can be met without much fuller development on onshore and particularly offshore wind energy".

To meet the 10% target, the lords said that wind power "in each year of the next decade needs to grow at about five times the best annual rate achieved in recent years'.'

Yet the development of offshore wind has been ridiculously slow and bedevilled by planning permission problems. Developers need to make up to seven different approaches to gain consent. The law of the sea is opaque and despite the willingness of the Crown Estates, and Prince Charles, to cooperate, the process has been frustrating and slow.

Consent has been needed under the Electricity Act 1989, the Food and Environment Protection Act 1985, the Coast and Protection Act 1949, the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, the Electricity Act 1989, the Water Resources Act 1991 and Transport and Works Act 1992. In addition, a lease is required from the Crown Estates commissioners for any project inside British territorial waters.

Faced by this unsurpassed example of un-joined up government, it is not altogether surprising that the first offshore wind farm at Blyth harbour, in Northumberland, took nearly six years from conception to opening in December 2000. It has precisely two turbines.

Following much inter- departmental wrangling, the new energy minister, Peter Hain, finally announced plans for a one-stop shop based in the DTI. Permission, as a consequence, may take as little as a year.

Today progress will move to an altogether different dimension. Mr Hain, in conjunction with the Crown Estates, will announce 18 coastal sites for which planning permission can now be sought. Each site will have as many as 30 turbines, generating 90mw - or, together, the equivalent of 1% of total electricity supply. It is expected that more than 1m households will be able to receive their full energy needs from these wind farms.

Greenpeace, not known for fawning, is preparing to welcome the announcement as a "huge, huge improvement". The British Wind Energy Association reckons it is a huge step for just one announcement. Britain will move from bottom of the league in wind power generation to near the top, or close to a par with Denmark.

The sites to be leased include the Bristol Channel, the Solway Firth, Teesside, Humberside, Skegness, and the Kentish Flats.

The projects will attract government funding, as generating costs are higher than for nuclear or fossil fuels. But Mr Hain believes Britain, with its engineering skills generated from the North Sea oil industry, is uniquely well-placed. The industry will also benefit from the £100m aid for renewable energy announced by Tony Blair last year.

Although coastal sites will clearly not attract the same level of planning opposition, as on shore sites, they may yet be controversial. Nimbyism does not stop at new housing estates, or animal burial sites. Blyth, for instance, is a couple of miles offshore and visible from the coastline on a clear day. Many of these sites will be near coastal resorts.

If this all comes off, it might even make oil men like George Bush sit up and take notice.

Patrick Wintour is the Guardian's chief political correspondent.

fields.headline: Frog decline 'due to global warming'
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Climate change fed by fossil fuel pollution could be the underlying cause of the worldwide deaths of frogs, toads and salamanders, according to US scientists today.
fields.body:
Climate change fed by fossil fuel pollution could be the underlying cause of the worldwide deaths of frogs, toads and salamanders, according to US scientists today.

Amphibians have been declining at alarming rates since the 1970s.

Environmental campaigners have blamed industrial pollution, agricultural pesticides, invading predators, forest and wetland destruction and even the pet trade.

But Joseph Kiesecker of Penn State University, and colleagues from Oregon State, point the finger today at global warming.

They report in Nature that global warming causes changes in rainfall patterns. Amphibians are sensitive to changes in moisture, so they become stressed. While under stress, they more easily fall victim to infectious diseases.

There are six amphibians native to the UK. All are in decline.

In Australia, 14 native species are in sharp decline, and four have become extinct in the last 30 years.

webTitle: Move to lift prison voting ban fails

fields.headline: Move to lift prison voting ban fails
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Human Rights Act
fields.trailText: A ban on 52,000 convicted prisoners having the right to vote was yesterday upheld by the high court, but campaigners vowed to fight on.
fields.body:
A ban on 52,000 convicted prisoners having the right to vote was yesterday upheld by the high court, but campaigners vowed to fight on.

Lawyers representing three inmates had brought a test case, arguing that the ban which dates back to Victorian times was in conflict with the European convention on human rights, as set out in the 1998 Human Rights Act.

But Lord Justice Kennedy, sitting with Mr Justice Garland, rejected the challenge. The judges said it was not for their court to change the law, and a decision should be taken by parliament.

Lord Justice Kennedy said lawyers for the applicants had taken "far too simplistic an approach" and added: "As the home secretary said, parliament has taken the view that for the period during which they are in custody convicted prisoners have forfeited their right to have a say in the way the country is governed."

The prisoners who launched the application for judicial review were Anthony Pearson, serving 10 years for importing drugs; Richard Martinez, serving life on a charge of arson with intent to endanger life; and John Hirst, serving life for manslaughter.

Lawyers for the prisoners intend to appeal. The reform has the backing of Martin Narey, director general of the prison service.

Meanwhile, in a separate blow for prisoners' rights, a convicted murderer yesterday lost his appeal court battle to artificially inseminate his wife while he is still in prison.

Gavin Mellor, 29, asked three judges to rule that the home secretary had acted unlawfully and breached the European convention on human rights by preventing him donating sperm so that his wife could become pregnant by artificial insemination.

Lord Phillips, master of the rolls, said that the refusal to provide IVF treatment was "neither unlawful nor irrational". Mellor was refused leave to appeal to the House of Lords, but his lawyers could still petition the law lords directly for permission.

Mellor, now at Nottingham prison, met his wife Tracey, 25, while she was working as an administration officer at Gartree prison, Leicestershire, in January 1997. The couple married in prison in July that year.

Mellor was jailed for life in February 1995 for killing George Sims, 71, in Crewe, Cheshire.

Mrs Mellor would be 31 when her husband's tariff (minimum sentence) expires in February 2006, although he might be granted temporary release as early as 2004.

Lord Phillips said that what the prisoner needed to demonstrate was that, if artificial insemination was denied, founding a family might be not just delayed but prevented altogether.

fields.headline: Kursk 'carried nuclear weapons'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: The Russian submarine Kursk had nuclear missiles aboard when it sank in Arctic waters last year, a Norwegian television station claimed last night.
fields.body:
The Russian submarine Kursk had nuclear missiles aboard when it sank in Arctic waters last year, a Norwegian television station claimed last night.

Grigorij Tjomtsjin, a member of a Russian commission investigating the accident aboard the atomic-powered vessel, told the station "yes, there were" when asked if it had nuclear weapons on board.

"They are no danger," he added, according to a translation of his remarks from Russian.

The Kursk sank after an unexplained accident during a military exercise in the Barents sea last August with the loss of all 118 crew. Twelve of the dead have since been recovered from the wreck. Tests in the water around the submarine have shown no unusual traces of radioactivity.

The Russian authorities have repeatedly denied there were nuclear weapons aboard.

Last night the Norwegian nuclear watchdog Bellona, which first highlighted the scale of the dumping of nuclear waste around Russian submarine bases near Murmansk, also distanced itself from the television report.

It pointed out that there may be a commercial interest in raising the possibility of nuclear weapons on board, when a complicated salvage operation was involved.

Harald Ramfjord of Global Tool Management, a company working on plans to raise the Kursk, also claimed to have seen evidence of atomic missiles aboard.

"One of the documents I had access to indicated that there were two atomic missiles aboard the vessel," he told TV2, adding that the Russian documents were stamped "secret".

A Norwegian foreign ministry spokesman, Karsten Klepsvik, said the ministry had asked its embassy in Moscow to investigate the report.

fields.headline: Being made to look ridiculous
fields.standfirst:
Is it inevitable that the peer to peer music copyright pirates will be beaten? Matt Ford investigates
More net news
fields.trailText: Is it inevitable that the peer to peer music copyright pirates will be beaten? Matt Ford investigates
fields.body:
Are you paranoid? The internet is a breeding ground for conspiracies, and the fear of corporate surveillance is one topic that has rattled around for years. This week however, rumours became reality as it emerged that spy software is the latest weapon in the entertainment industry's war against copyright pirates. But as file trading peer to peer networks like Napster and its successors become increasingly popular, can corporations force millions of people to obey laws they don't believe in?

News site 7amnews.com has exposed a piece of software called Media Tracker, which it alleges the entertainment industry is using to spy on individuals using P2P networks. Media Tracker can tell exactly what pirated music, video or software files you are trading. It can trace your identity back through the network of servers and internet service providers (ISPs) you use when you access the web, and it can root out your computer's unique IP number. Lawyers can then use this to trace your identity, and send out a cautionary letter to your ISP insisting that you stop sharing copyrighted material, or potentially face prosecution.

Industry lawyers have contacted ISPs over a hundred times in the past few weeks asking them to exclude individuals involved in file trading. By tracking over one million Roy Orbison songs being traded on Napster, lawyers were able to deduce the offenders' ISPs, demand from them names of the 60,000 individuals involved, and then force Napster to block their access. Similar legal action by the thrash metal band Metallica also led to users being barred from Napster.

But these are small victo ries given the many millions of users in dozens of countries all disobeying copyright through P2P networks every day. Effectively engaged in a mass act of uncoordinated civil disobedience, people power looks set to overwhelm legal muscle and technical espionage.

Unable to prosecute every user, the entertainment industry's options are already looking limited. Perhaps by making examples of a few high profile users they might intimidate others into stopping, but attacking your own customers is hardly good business. When Metallica took legal action against Napster - and effectively its own fans - they turned themselves into a joke, destroyed their rebellious image overnight and alienated the very people buying their albums. "It was a disaster," said an EMI new media spokesman. "The same teenagers who had Metallica posters on their walls were parodying the band on websites all over the internet, and re-doubling their efforts to copy and circulate the group's music".

In addition, the long-term success of any surveillance campaign would depend on the co-operation of ISPs, which are unlikely to want take on the time-consuming, and incredibly unpopular burden of becoming a global internet police force.

If ISPs start accepting responsibility for what is held on subscribers' hard drives, it will not only dramatically increase their responsibilities, but also severely compromise the privacy of their customers, who will simply leave and join another less discriminating ISP. Any attempt to force ISPs to comply would pit the entertainment industry in a legal battle against very wealthy and powerful companies.

Even if the entertainment industry lawyers overcome these obstacles, and manage to find a practical way of using the technology, it may already be out of date and unable to cope with the most recent P2P innovations. New file trading networks such as Freenet http://freenet.sourceforge.net are totally decentralised and spread files across all the computers involved. There is no central hub or index, and no way for individual users to tell what is being stored on their computers. No one keeps track of users, and this makes it nearly impossible for even sophisticated programs to track who is sharing what with whom. Even if other networks become unsafe, pirates could escape the prying eyes of entertainment industry lawyers by moving on to Freenet.

Unless internet users decide to stop voluntarily, there seems very little the entertainment industry can do to force them. In a bizarre millennial twist on people power, popular greed has succeeded where socialism failed and capitalism is about to take a knock from the largest display of selfish solidarity the world has ever seen.
