fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: John Prescott is rightly furious about George Bush's decision for the US to abandon its commitment to the Kyoto treaty. It looks as if Bush is doing the bidding of the oil, energy and other big businesses that backed his election.
fields.body:
 John Prescott is rightly furious about George Bush's decision for the US to abandon its commitment to the Kyoto treaty. It looks as if Bush is doing the bidding of the oil, energy and other big businesses that backed his election. Thank goodness our government isn't in the pocket of similar multinationals. Two months ago Prescott made a stand against global warming by launching the Carbon Trust. According to the DETR, the trust is "a major element of the UK's climate change programme", which will spend £130m of climate change levy receipts to "help business invest in energy efficient technologies and practices". What better person to head the Carbon Trust than Ian McAllister, chairman and managing director of Ford Motor Company in the UK? Prescott said he was "delighted" to appoint McAllister. Ford is delighted with the success of its profitable and highly polluting sport utility vehicles. According to one motoring reviewer, Ford's latest SUV, the three-ton Excursion, "descending a gentle slope, might just squeak past 15 miles per gallon".

 Opera singer Otto Ackermann, 41, has been evicted from his flat in Wurzburg, Germany, because his three-times-a-day practising routine hurt business in a brothel downstairs. The vice girls said his voice shook the walls and frightened clients away.

 The first of what could (but probably won't) be a series: Guardian readers who are dead ringers for captains of industry*. Ray O'Grady of Chester writes, enclosing a photograph of himself that reveals a remarkable likeness to Hans Snook, former boss of the Orange mobile phone company. "You may possibly wish to write an article about how much we both resemble each other," writes Ray, "or maybe not." Ray wants to be put in touch with Hans, and we'll do our best. * Do you resemble a captain of industry? Send a photograph of yourself to the City Diary at the usual address. Please state which captain of industry you most closely resemble.

 Britain's railway franchises are a byword in good management. So it comes as a surprise that it was black bin bags at dawn last Monday for Brian Birdsall, the managing director of Midland Mainline, sacked by its parent company, National Express. The reasons behind binning one of Mainline's most experienced rail managers are unclear: Birdsall's resistance to merging the management of National Express's franchises (which include Gatwick Express, Silverlink and ScotRail) is one possibility, or that he was carrying the can for cramped new carriages that provoked so many complaints that the fleet is being replaced. Meanwhile, Phil White, chief executive of National Express, picks up a £1m bonus. Hmm.

 Entries have been figuratively flooding in (and I mean that literally) for our competition to help analysts at Merrill Lynch find a better way of saying "sell". The bank has been running seminars titled "Managing investment downgrades", and our readers have been quick to help. Leslie Young of Preston suggests: "It's time to let other investors share in this success." If you can do better, send 'em in.

 Time again for Dog of the Day, where City analysts manage investment downgrades with the timing of a busted metronome. Today's prize poodle is David Nisbet at Deutsche Bank, who cut Prudential from a "buy" yesterday morning. The Pru's share price ended up nearly 50p. Woof woof!

webTitle: Maurice Greenberg, head of AIG, bids for American General

fields.headline: You don't mess with Hank
fields.trailText: Asked yesterday whether the Prudential would continue its fight for US insurer American General, one Wall Street analyst was incredulous: "What, and take on Hank?"
fields.body:
Asked yesterday whether the Prudential would continue its fight for US insurer American General, one Wall Street analyst was incredulous: "What, and take on Hank?"

The reputation of Maurice Greenberg - nicknamed Hank after a 1930s baseball star - is so great that his name is often used as an alternative for the firm he leads, American International Group. Mr Greenberg, 75, has been described as the most powerful man in the global insurance business.

As head of the business since 1967, he is credited with making AIG into the most highly valued insurer in the world through expansion and tight cost controls.

His shareholders are unlikely to question his desire to buy AG in the same way those in the Pru did. For a start, AIG shareholders have received a compound return of 20% a year, compared with 9% for the S&P index. Second, AIG tends to be asked fewer questions than any other US company and offers the bare minimum of financial information.

Colin Devine, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said: "The Street really tends to take everything he does as a leap of faith. But if they can't justify the valuation, they just say: 'It's Hank'."

Much of Mr Greenberg's reputation is based on an ability to consistently outperform Wall Street expectations. Maitland Lammert, an analyst at Edward Jones, said: "He has built AIG into a global business and is considered a genius."

A large part of his reputation is also related to his fiercesome ego, and an inability to suffer fools lightly. "Crotchety", "charismatic" and "a monster" are all words used about a man who fired his two sons after designating them as his heirs.

One analyst said: "If you write something he doesn't like, you will get a personal phone call from him and he will rip your face off."

His reputation goes some way towards explaining the deferential tone of the analysts' questions during yesterday's meeting to discuss the AG bid. Most congratulated him before asking about the cost savings to be gained from the deal - at least $200m and more than the Prudential.

When one reporter asked the question that has long been whispered on Wall Street, Mr Greenberg showed his temper. "This call is about the acquisition and not about the succession," he snapped.

Although he runs the company like a family firm in many ways, he controls just over 20% of the votes with a 3% stake. He is only the second chief executive in AIG's 72-year history, having taken over from Cornelius Starr - who had no heir - in 1967. Mr Starr, a former ice cream parlour owner, established the business in Shanghai by selling life insurance policies to the Chinese.

Mr Greenberg, the son of a New York dairy farmer who was honoured for his role in the first world war, had joined the firm seven years earlier to enhance its international operations. AIG now does business in 130 countries around the world and earned $5.6bn from its operations last year.

Buying AG would enhance AIG's domestic life insurance business and make it rival Citigroup as America's largest financial services firm, with a combined market value of about $206bn. About half its revenues would come from life insurance, theremainder from car insurance, mortgage guaranty, annuities and aircraft leasing.

The deal would be the AIG's second huge acquisition since 1998, when it bought SunAmerica for $18bn.

Despite his age, few analysts believe the planned AG deal will be Mr Greenberg's last. Mr Devine at Salomon said: "He'll go out of there when he's dead."

Mr Greenberg, who has five children and lives in New York, earned a base salary of $6m last year.

webTitle: Japan threatens to halt £1bn for drugs

fields.headline: Japan threatens to halt £1bn for drugs
fields.standfirst: Animal activists could 'prevent major investment'
fields.trailText: Animal activists could 'prevent major investment'.
fields.body:
Violent animal rights extremists could jeopardise more than £1bn of investment in Britain by Japanese drugs firms, the director general of the Association of the British Pharmaceuticals Industry, Trevor Jones, warned yesterday.

He claimed fear of violence could deter the firms from pressing ahead with plans for three discovery laboratories and seven development centres in Britain over the next five years.

Professor Jones recently visited Japan with the science minister, Lord Sainsbury. During the trip, Prof Jones said: "We were questioned very heavily as to whether the environment was suitable. They said that unless some action was taken, they would have to think again."

The ABPI says it welcomes debate about the ethics of animal testing but abhors attacks on drugs companies' staff, families and homes. It claims violence is on the increase in Britain, encouraged by the apparent success of activists in crippling the controversial animal testing firm, Huntingdon Life Sciences.

Prof Jones claimed that in addition to doubts expressed by Japanese firms, research directors of five international drugs groups already operating in Britain had written to the home secretary pleading for a crackdown on protestors. "They've expressed doubts about whether their current arrangements are secure, and whether their current expansion plans can come to fruition unless things change," he said.

His warning was dismissed as "scaremongering" by campaigners. Greg Avery, of Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty (Shac), said: "They're creating more hysteria in an attempt to bully the government to do what they want."

Shac condemns violence but has upset the industry by protesting outside the homes of investors in HLS.

Mr Avery said: "If these foreign companies are coming to this country in order to torture animals, we don't want them here. It's a good thing if they think again."

The government has proposed an amendment to the Companies Act giving drugs companies the right to restrict access to information relating to the addresses of directors. The ABPI wants the police to get further powers to tackle animal rights "terrorists", and Prof Jones called for more "preventative action" to be taken. He said: "Looking at other types of violence, the police have taken very positive action to prevent attacks. In Faslane, they don't wait for people to attack nuclear submarines - they're pushed back before they get there."

In its annual review, the ABPI said exports of medicines from Britain surged 20% to £7.1bn last year, outstripping imports by £2.3bn. It painted a healthy picture of the country's drugs companies, despite a squeeze in the amount the NHS pays for medicines. It identified opposition to animal testing as one of the biggest challenges facing its members.

The industry points out that it is required by law to test all drugs on animals. It maintains that this will help prevent the launch of medicines such as Thalidomide, which later turn out to be harmful. Critics, however, say that the development of advanced computer models means that animal testing should no longer be necessary.

Prof Jones said he thought the violent fringe of animal rights activists consisted of "a core of about 20 people", with loose links to "seven or eight cells operating independently as free-ranging strike, or attack forces".

In January, five letter bombs were sent by activists to targets in the north of England, including a retired doctor and a charity shop. Past victims have included Professor Colin Blakemore of Oxford University, who supports vivisection.

Prof Jones said: "I wish these people would take their balaclavas off and appear, as we do, to explain their point of view."

webTitle: Dealers predict profit warning from Cookson

fields.headline: Cookson downgraded
fields.standfirst: Dealers predict a profit warning from Cookson
fields.trailText: It is hardly surprising that dealers think a profits warning is on the way from Cookson, the electronics and precious metals group.
fields.body:
It is hardly surprising that dealers think a profits warning is on the way from Cookson, the electronics and precious metals group. Yesterday, Lehman Brothers became the second broker in a week to cut its earnings forecasts.

Citing feedback from Cookson's electronics customers, mainly printed circuit board makers, Lehman reduced its pretax profits forecast for the current fiscal year by 10%. A month ago Lehman reduced its earnings estimates by 15% following an update with the company.

Lehman reckons sales at Cookson's electronic equipment division (20% of group sales) are down 35-40%, implying a £15m-£20m drop in profits.

Lehman still rates the stock as a buy on the grounds that it is trading below fair value and the sector average.

Cookson shares, which were changing hands for 167p at the start of March, closed 2p lower at 136p.

webTitle: NAB ready to bid for Alliance & Leicester

fields.headline: NAB lays foundation for bid
fields.standfirst: Market forces NAB ready to bid for Alliance & Leicester or Royal Bank of Scotland
fields.trailText: Talk of a takeover in the banking sector grows louder by the day, but it is not the lapsed bid for Abbey National that traders are gossiping about.
fields.body:
Talk of a takeover in the banking sector grows louder by the day, but it is not the lapsed bid for Abbey National that traders are gossiping about.

National Australia Bank is understood to be in talks with the stock exchange and the financial services authority about a complicated dual-listing as a prelude to a bid for, perhaps, Alliance & Leicester , up 26.5p to 771.5p, or Bank of Scotland , 14p higher at 676.5p.

NAB, which owns the Yorkshire and Clydesdale banks, is not expected to make its move until the competition authorities complete their investigation into the Lloyds-Abbey deal. This expected in July. NAB refused to comment.

A dual listed company structure - NAB shares are already traded in Sydney - would allow the £15bn bank to expand in Britain. It would give NAB a currency attractive to British institutions, which are usually reluctant to hold foreign paper.

Analysts were not surprised to hear NAB was preparing the foundations for a takeover in Britain, noting comments it made after selling its US operation, Michigan National, to ABN Amro for $2.75bn (£1.95bn), this week.

Apparently, NAB ruled out repatriating the proceeds until the opportunities to accelerate growth in Britain became clearer. NAB is under pressure to expand abroad because of regulatory constraints in Australia.

In the wider market, it was another nail biting session for traders who watched the FTSE 100 go on yet another roller-coaster trip. After recovering from an early 108 point deficit, the blue chip index swung in and out of positive territory for much of the session before moving sharply higher in the final hour.

As usual it was events on the other side of the Atlantic that called the tune. With Wall Street recovering its poise after a shaky start, buyers emerged for bombed-out telecom stocks and this helped to push the FTSE higher.

The final scores showed the FTSE 100 ahead 72.6 points at 5,535.7, with the likes of Vodafone , up 10.5p to 196p, Marconi , 36p higher at 336p, and BT , 35p better at 514p, providing most of the impetus.

Overall the picture was mixed. The FTSE Techmark 100 slipped 6.58 points to 1,764.44, and Colt Telecom was worst blue chip performer, tumbling 46p to 628p, on whispers that 47% shareholder and founder, Fidelity, was dumping shares again.

That said, there was some cheer for Prudential shareholders as the stock rose 51.5p to 795.5p in response to news that its unpopular merger with American General had been blown out of the water by an offer from American International Group, the world's largest insurer. Dealers attributed most of the gains to hedge funds closing short positions they established when the deal was announced last month.

Elsewhere, the great Marks & Spencer debate rumbled on with Schroder Salomon Smith Barney cutting its rating to "underperform" from "neutral" and setting a downside target price of 220p.

At 29 times forward earnings, SSSB reckons the potential for a significant profits recovery at M&S is already in the price. The shares fell 7.25p to 257.75p.

ICI's dismal run continued, its shares losing a further 12p to 393p after CSFB advised clients to be cautious because of US litigation over the use of lead in paints. The chemicals group countered, saying it expected to deal successfully with any litigation.

Lower down the market, the FTSE Small Cap index ended 34.9 points lower at 2,794.9, rocked by poor corporate news. Fund management group Savoy Asset Management was among the worst performers, shedding 87.5p to 160p after revealing that full year profits would miss market expectations because of the slump in global stock markets.

On Aim, internet consultancy, Internet Business Group , dropped 7.5p to 3.5p following a profits warning.

fields.headline: At this price?  Man
fields.standfirst: Sugar broker, Man, shares double since company transformed into a hedge fund manager
fields.trailText: Shares in Man, formerly a lowly rated sugar broker, have doubled since the company metamorphosed into a hedge fund manager
fields.body:
Shares in Man, formerly a lowly rated sugar broker, have doubled since the company metamorphosed into a hedge fund manager. Yesterday it produced another rabbit out of the hat by issuing a reverse profit warning - telling analysts that their profits forecasts had been too low. The announcement had the effect of putting the company within spitting distance of the FTSE 100.

Man, previously ED&F Man, said performance fees earned during the year ending March 31 would be "substantially ahead of market expectations".

The share price hit new highs at 900p, up 46.5p.

The company has £4.5bn under management after a period of rapid growth. It spent £85m buying up the remaining 40% stake in US hedge fund Glenwood and Australian hedge fund Ord Minnett Strategic Investments, and replenished its coffers with a £75m rights issue in January.

Analysts had been expecting Man to announce performance fees of £35m for the past 12 months. But a more likely figure is nearly double that.The company is benefiting from turbulence in the equity markets which is driving investors to look at alternatives.

Chief executive Stanley Fink said the company is seeing an earnings increase of up to 30% from some of its managers such as AHL, the largest in the Man stable.

He believes this level of gain cannot be sustained in the longer term but that there is no reason to suppose it cannot keep growth at an average of 18%.

Man uses computers to track back data as much as 50 years to find trends that can be exploited to make short term gains.

It got rid of its ED&F Man name last year when it sold its commodities business to a management buy-out.

The shares are recommended by Schroder Salomon Smith Barney as an "outperform", which says entry into the FTSE 100 would bring in the tracking funds.

It spent £85m buying up the remaining 40% stake in US hedge fund Glenwood and Australian hedge fund Ord Minnett Strategic Investments, and replenished its coffers with a £75m rights issue in January. Analysts had been expecting Man to announce performance fees of £35m for the past 12 months. But a more likely figure is nearly double that.The company is benefiting from turbulence in the equity markets which is driving investors to look at alternatives. Chief executive Stanley Fink said the company is seeing an earnings increase of up to 30% from some of its managers such as AHL, the largest in the Man stable. Man uses computers to track back data as much as 50 years to find trends that can be exploited to make short term gains. It got rid of its ED&F Man name last year when it sold its commodities business to a management buy-out. The shares are recommended by Schroder Salomon Smith Barney as an "outperform", which says entry into the FTSE 100 would bring in the tracking funds.

webTitle: Father of minimalism, Frank Stella, on Moby Dick

fields.headline: The prince of whales
fields.standfirst: Why has the father of minimalism devoted 15 years of his life to Moby Dick? Frank Stella explains all to  Jonathan Jones
fields.trailText: Why has the father of minimalism devoted 15 years of his life to Moby Dick? Frank Stella explains all to Jonathan Jones.
fields.body:
Frank Stella decides he wants to be interviewed behind the huge desk of his London dealer. "I'm head of the corporation," he jokes. He's wearing a fleece with Team Stella emblazoned on it. A few minutes later a former director of the Tate Gallery pops in to say hello. Whatever Stella does now, even if he goes senile and starts exhibiting doodles, he will be remembered as a great American artist. He has known this since he was in his early 20s.

Stella was born in 1936, grew up in a suburb of Boston, and was just out of Princeton when he produced his so-called Black Paintings. With such grimly evocative titles as Die Fahne Hoch! (The Banner High), named after a Nazi marching song, and The Marriage of Reason and Squalor, Stella's first paintings are shocking. Each consists of a layering of black rectangular stripes, fanning out like the citadels of some lost Assyrian city, taking their shape from the canvas itself. They have been interpreted as both an attack on the high modernist art of the abstract expressionist artists who came before him - Pollock, Rothko and Newman - and the continuation of their achievement. He has been acclaimed as both the founder of minimalism and the last artist to stand against it.

Either way, Stella's debut was a sensation. His Black Paintings were shown at the Museum of Modern Art in New York in 1960 in an exhibition that also showcased Jasper Johns and Robert Rauschenberg. But the 24-year old Stella stood out. The paintings were bought by the museum, and are now displayed alongside such masterpieces as Johns's Flag, Pollock's One and Matisse's Piano Lesson.

Stella was a prodigy, a figure of exceptional glamour, the champ, characterised as a genius while still at Princeton. Genius is a big word, but before he left university, Stella was accustomed to people applying it to him and the praise in the 1960s only got more elevated.

But what does a genius do next?

Frank Stella is in London to promote a book, Frank Stella's Moby Dick by Robert K Wallace. It chronicles and analyses the series that Stella himself sees as central to his later career - artworks made during the 1980s and 1990s, including lithographs, sculptures and installations, each of which takes its title from one of the 135 chapters of Herman Melville's great American novel. "Why couldn't there be a British Melville?" wonders Stella. "They had great explorers, but, I don't know, a quest for God or chasing the white whale is different from a quest for empire, right? The British want to really own it somehow; the Americans just want to be able to grasp it. Maybe they're slightly less materialistic - it's hard to believe."

Indeed it is. But American art such as Stella's is less materialistic, pushing for abstraction while British art remains defiantly earthbound. Stella's spiritual apprehension of the visual world may be linked to his origins in puritan Boston (not that far from Nantucket from where the Pequod sets sail in Moby Dick).

It occurs to you, seeing him behind that big desk and listening to his dryly humorous voice telling his tale, that Stella himself would make a character in a great American novel. He's a modern Queequeg - the supremely talented harpoonist in Moby Dick, who, when asked for his credentials, throws his harpoon at a tiny blob of tar on a roof, hitting the target dead centre. If that was a whale's eye, he says, the whale would be dead now. Stella once told his friend Michael Fried, the critic and art historian, that his own idea of genius was the baseball player Ted Williams, because he could see the ball perfectly and then hit it right out of the park.

Stella became a revered American artist when he was in his early 20s, but he didn't rest on his laurels and he didn't make more and more brutal paintings. Instead he tried to stage that elusive second act. He began to make his paintings more complex in structure, colour and shape, and then brought them off the wall, welding, shaping, doing what a sculptor does, but still - in fact more recognisably than with the Black Paintings - seeing as a painter.

Critics have been, to say the least, divided about what happened to the art of Frank Stella. Right now, art is in a swing back to the minimalist objective art of the 1960s; artists are acclaimed for their starkness, and Stella's early work looks modern in a way that his later work does not. Young artists are transfixed and influenced by Die Fahne Hoch! or Six Mile Bottom (1960), with its silvery authority, in a way they are not by 138 attractive but inessential works responding to Moby Dick. But then, as Stella says, when he started out, some critic described his stripe paintings as "boring". "People say I jump around a lot, but it seems to me like I spend plenty of time on everything I work on. I can't say I left many stones unturned. But things do wear out for me."

If Stella's career were a great American novel, the most important supporting character would be Fried. It's not just that they went to Princeton together and both became towering figures in the nation's cultural establishment (Fried has become one of America's most lauded academics) but that Fried's and Stella's ideas are intertwined. At one point, Stella criticises the art of his contemporary, the minimalist Donald Judd, as "literalist". It's one of Fried's favourite words.

Fried loathed the minimalists - Donald Judd, Robert Morris, Carl Andre - artists who emerged in New York in the 1960s, wanting to do something different from the generation of Pollock and Rothko, and who simply presented "objects" to the viewer, brutally shorn of traditional aesthetic values. In a famous 1967 article in the New York magazine Artforum, Fried denounced minimalism as "theatrical" - claiming that it made cheap claims on people's attention - and "literal" - ie misunderstanding the nature of art as illusion. Modern art, he argued, was the opposite of this - a repudiation of theatre, false values, and the merely objective; ultimately, a spiritually uplifting art. It's a debate that still matters because minimalism is the underpinning of art today. All those vitrines and casts, the shark and the house.

But what did Fried have to say about his friend Stella? For many, Stella's early paintings were the founding statements of minimalism. Fried argued, however, that as Stella developed, he was making it more and more plain that he was a painterly painter, who believed in art, and that his works, with their increasing richness, were deliberate corrections of the minimalist mistake. Yet, in his youth, Stella said some tough and undeniably minimalist things about art. He said that in his paintings, "What you see is what you see". He said, "I tried to keep the paint as good as it was in the can."

Today he says that he never wanted to destroy anyone's idea of a well-made painting. The Black Paintings are, "quite painterly - although they're one colour, they seem to me to be closer to Rothko than just about anything else. The idea that these were such a rejection of abstract expressionism I don't think is accurate." Stella describes his Moby Dick series as a kind of tribute to those Captain Ahabs, the abstract expressionists. "They're still the generation I admire. This is paying my debt, or not so much paying my debt as expressing my admiration for the abstract expressionist generation that I grew up with and that I admired the most, and that I still admire."

Moby Dick, Ahab's doomed pursuit of the mystical image of the great white whale, was a touchstone for the abstract expressionist painters. Jackson Pollock named at least one painting after the novel and intended to give its name to his classic early work Pasiphae, then switched to something from Greek myth because his patron Peggy Guggenheim didn't like the Melville reference. Pollock's sense of space is absolutely suggested by Melville, and the rolling, wild wave forms of Stella's Moby Dick - inspired by observing beluga whales swimming in the New York aquarium - are very Pollock.

In the Moby Dick series, Stella sees himself challenging the deepest assumptions of modern art with a new understanding of what abstraction can do: "Abstraction in the 20th century is dependent on cubism, which is arranging planes in space, but the planes are arranged in a kind of stiff and geometric kind of way. Once the planes begin to bend and curve and deform then you get into what happens in Moby Dick - it's a way of opening things up for abstraction."

Stella certainly has more in common with the American painters of Pollock's generation than he does with the ironising, theatrical minimalists who thought he was on their side. But he has ended up cast adrift in an open boat, an American individualist making his own eccentric way, as the watchers from the shore try and fail to categorise him - a minimalist, a modernist, a postmodernist. This makes the novel in which he is a character, the champ, the American genius, a troubling read. Frank Stella has never done anything that lived up to his early work. But who has?

 Frank Stella's Moby Dick by Robert K Wallace is published by Michigan University Press, price £42.50.

webTitle: Arts' fixations: pop's fascination with cars

fields.headline: Driven to distraction
fields.standfirst: From the Beach Boys and their T-Bird to Billy Bragg's Vauxhall Velox, pop has always been fascinated by cars.  Adam Sweeting continues our occasional series on the arts' fixations
fields.trailText: From the Beach Boys and their T-Bird to Billy Bragg's Vauxhall Velox, pop has always been fascinated by cars. Adam Sweeting continues our occasional series on the arts' fixations.
fields.body:
Where would pop music be without cars? Since the dawn of rock'n'roll in the 1950s, the automobile has been vying for supremacy with girls as the genre's most obsessed-over and fetishised topic. Chuck Berry could find bliss merely by "ridin' along in my automobile" with "my baby beside me at the wheel". In their iconic encapsulations of the burnished nirvana of southern California, the Beach Boys were dazzled by visions of girls driving around in T-birds having "fun fun fun". Elvis Presley didn't sing about cars much, but he adopted the Cadillac as his personal gold standard, buying them when he felt an urge for some conspicuous consumption, giving them away as presents and even sending them out on tour when he couldn't be bothered to go himself.

Professors of demographics and economic historians could doubtless offer numerous convincing reasons that the car should have become such a pillar of pop's internal dialogue, though for a simpler explanation you could just watch George Lucas' movie American Graffiti, in which small-town teenagers experience the scintillating blossoming of rock'n'roll while driving around in cars. The car represented freedom and mobility for the suddenly affluent postwar teen - the American postwar teen, at any rate. Before the invention of the pubescent dotcom billionaire, teenagers didn't own their own homes, so the car was the perfect parent-free venue for such necessary pastimes as "necking" or even "going all the way". Cars meant glamour and independence, and there was no better symbol of American optimism and infinite economic potential.

As in so many things, the British version was slightly different, a trifle desperate and frequently curled up at the edges. Although British politicians insisted we'd "never had it so good" and informed us we were living through the "white heat" of a "technological revolution", the evidence wasn't easy to spot, especially if you were 16 years old. Where American youth might find itself tooling around in gas-guzzling Thunderbirds and Mustangs, its impoverished UK counterparts were probably trapped on British Rail's clattering rust-buckets or, at best, braving the elements on the back of a sputtering Lambretta scooter. Getting a ride in the family Hillman was scarcely the raw material of teen mythology. And while America was already crisscrossed by freeways and interstate highways, the British were still marvelling at a strange new construction known as the M1.

Although Jeremy Clarkson has done his best to persuade we Brits that we really do belong to a car culture, soundtracking his TV exploits with The Eagles' Take It Easy or the breast-beating testosterone road anthems of Bob Seger, it's never going to be the same. You could write a thesis on love and death in the American automobile, so intricately is the car entwined with the American psyche and America's economic growth, but we British have never quite managed to see it the same way. James Dean sealed his own legend by getting decapitated in a silver Porsche Spyder on a California highway, but by bathetic contrast Marc Bolan was killed when his badly maintained purple Mini drove into a tree on Barnes common. Jan & Dean's cars-and-death classic Dead Man's Curve, complete with blasting horns and crash noises, gave the car a love-in-death aura Wagner himself would have admired, but it's a thoroughly un-British approach. We'd rather see Madness charging around in a Morris 1000 in their video for Driving in My Car.

Indeed, the yawning cultural chasm dividing the transatlantic cousins is expressed with uncanny clarity in their respective treatment of cars in pop songs. America was where Prince would sing about a Little Red Corvette, but in Blighty we had to put up with Tom Robinson telling us about his Ford Cortina. Bruce Springsteen's Born To Run used hurtling imagery of engines, wheel-rims and fuel-injection to concoct a kind of West Side Story with jacked-up suspension and go-faster stripes, whereas our own Gary Numan took the word "cars" and turned it into a suicidal dirge.

Berry Gordy's Motown label was named after the throbbing hub of the American motor industry, and its streamlined approach in some ways echoed the industrial practices of the big car-makers. Meanwhile, in Essex, Billy Bragg detected the contrast between Dagenham and Detroit, heard Bob Dylan's song From a Buick Six, and wrote From a Vauxhall Velox as an ironic retort. As for Bragg's A13 (Trunk Road to the Sea), it's like rock myth seen through the wrong end of a telescope, a scruffy suburban anticlimax full of roadworks and fly-tipping to set alongside such chrome-plated Americana as Route 66.

As pop has grown longer in the tooth and become more self-conscious, some of its practitioners have felt that its most basic preoccupations had come to seem frivolous or embarrassing. Radiohead wrote a song called Airbag, but ingeniously spun it into an extended essay on dread and insecurity. "Some things hurt more, much more, than cars and girls," argued Prefab Sprout in Cars and Girls in 1988, apparently as a mocking rebuke to Springsteen, whose songs sometimes appeared to be about little else. Still, Bruce has managed to introduce some variations within the genre. After all, he brought us the existential isolation of Stolen Car, as well as the cinematic melodrama of Thunder Road. For every rocked-up stomper like Cadillac Ranch, Springsteen had a Racing in the Street or a Wreck on the Highway to add some fatalistic yang to his supercharged yin.

And whereas you need the skills of a Bletchley code-breaker to winkle out the oblique subtleties of chief Sprout Paddy McAloon's songwriting, Bruce gives you the story in a nutshell: "Waving to the girls, feeling outta sight, spending all my money on a Saturday night," he explained in Pink Cadillac. "Honey, I just wonder what you do there in the back of your pink Cadillac." Springsteen hands you the myth in a few terse syllables and leaves it to others to worry about toxic emissions and congestion charges.

Yet it would be wrong to assume that a focus on such ostensibly facile concerns as sex and driving must necessarily drive out nuance or subtlety from a songwriter's work. If the art of the pop song isn't about using minute detail to shed a broader light, I'd be fascinated to hear what the alternatives are. For example, Don Henley's elegiac hit The Boys of Summer managed to nail the doubts of a generation with its line "I saw a Dead Head sticker on a Cadillac", a brilliant shorthand depiction of how the hippies gave up flower-power and went into advertising. When Neil Young wrote Long May You Run, it wasn't just a nostalgic ode to a favourite car, it was a coded depiction of the journey from innocence to experience, or perhaps from youth to manhood - "we've been through some things together, with trunks of memories still to come. We missed that shift on the long decline, long may you run."

But we must consider now whether, in this ominous new era of car-phobia and eco-politics, the car song is doomed. Will car-hating London mayor Ken Livingstone outlaw songs about automobiles from the pubs and clubs of the capital, even as he throttles the city to death with tolls, speed-bumps and cycle lanes? Certainly it's impossible to imagine anybody today writing such an unabashed hymn to the environmentally unsound joys of high-speed driving as Chuck Berry did in My Mustang Ford. "I got a 1966 cherry-red Mustang Ford, it's got a three-eighty-five horsepower overload," Chuck revealed. "You know it's way too fast to be crawlin' on these interstate roads."

Goodonya! Personally, before petrol reaches 10 quid a litre, I'd take a tip from the Counting Crows - and "just get into my car and drive".

For example, Don Henley's elegiac hit The Boys of Summer managed to nail the doubts of a generation with its line "I saw a Dead Head sticker on a Cadillac", a brilliant shorthand depiction of how the hippies gave up flower-power and went into advertising. When Neil Young wrote Long May You Run, it wasn't just a nostalgic ode to a favourite car, it was a coded depiction of the journey from innocence to experience, or perhaps from youth to manhood - "we've been through some things together, with trunks of memories still to come. We missed that shift on the long decline, long may you run." But we must consider now whether, in this ominous new era of car-phobia and eco-politics, the car song is doomed. Will car-hating London mayor Ken Livingstone outlaw songs about automobiles from the pubs and clubs of the capital, even as he throttles the city to death with tolls, speed-bumps and cycle lanes? Certainly it's impossible to imagine anybody today writing such an unabashed hymn to the environmentally unsound joys of high-speed driving as Chuck Berry did in My Mustang Ford. "I got a 1966 cherry-red Mustang Ford, it's got a three-eighty-five horsepower overload," Chuck revealed. "You know it's way too fast to be crawlin' on these interstate roads." Goodonya! Personally, before petrol reaches 10 quid a litre, I'd take a tip from the Counting Crows - and "just get into my car and drive".

fields.headline: Arthur Smith
fields.trailText: In the 1970s and 1980s, anyone associated with comedy could get a free lunch from a TV producer just by hinting that they had an idea for a new That Was The Week That Was.
fields.body:
In the 1970s and 1980s, anyone associated with comedy could get a free lunch from a TV producer just by hinting that they had an idea for a new That Was The Week That Was. Just as every politician's ultimate ambition is to be on telly, every TV executive's dream is to make a programme that generates a question in the House of Commons.

TV people, by and large, are as unoriginal as the next man, so if they see a successful programme, their first instinct is to copy it before anyone else does. Thus, the 1980s and 1990s were clogged up with presenters trying to be David Letterman, and in the last five years there has been a holy grail to create the British Larry Sanders Show. This was the best sitcom ever. One day a show may scale its heights but I wouldn't cancel your holiday.

Bob Martin was disappointing: Michael Barrymore was so determined not to overact that his TV presenter character hardly existed. The show didn't seem real or the characters interesting.

Larry Sanders is on Play UK every night and, apart from football and The Simpsons, is the only reason to get non-terrestrial TV. Oh, the pleasure of again seeing the vain, venal chat-show duo of Larry and Hank, produced by Rip Torn's Artie, who swears more beautifully than any other character on screen.

Critics and comedy writers have the notion that it is not the lines that should be funny, but the characters. But this is rare: Friends is full of crisp one-liners but from the mouths of a bunch of vapid pretty people. Hank has never said anything funny in his life but is an utterly hilarious figure. In Larry Sanders, jokes are written on cardboard for Artie to sneer at or Hank to misunderstand. There is a dark realism to the plots that makes the best episodes into miniature Chekhov plays with laughs.

Now I've gone too far. I've killed it with praise. It's just American pap distracting us from the revolution, a tiny titter in the universe. I shall never watch the Larry Sanders Show again. Or The Sopranos.

fields.headline: Second official accuses Chirac
fields.trailText: Another former senior Paris official has directly implicated the French president, Jacques Chirac, in an alleged £60m kickback scheme at city hall while he was mayor of the capital in the 1980s and early 1990s.
fields.body:
Another former senior Paris official has directly implicated the French president, Jacques Chirac, in an alleged £60m kickback scheme at city hall while he was mayor of the capital in the 1980s and early 1990s.

According to testimony published yesterday by Le Monde, the former deputy-director of the city's public works department François Ciolina told investigators: "Certain businessmen told me openly that, in order to win contracts, it was necessary to deposit cash at the office of the mayor."

Mr Ciolina said that Mr Chirac was the inspiration for the scam - alleged to have skimmed money off public building and maintenance contracts - and that the coffers of his Gaullist RPR party were the main beneficiary.

His revelations came on the day that Mr Chirac was supposed to be questioned by the investigating magistrate, Eric Halphen.

The president, who has immunity from prosecution as long as he is in office, refused last week to obey the summons, arguing that to do so would be "contrary to the principle of the separation of powers and to the demands of the continuity of the state".

Mr Ciolina, who is himself under investigation for influence peddling in the ever-widening scandal, confirmed many of the accusations levelled against Mr Chirac by Jean-Claude Méry, a former property developer and senior RPR fundraiser who died in 1999.

In a confession recorded in 1996 but released late last year, Mr Méry said the covert fundraising system was run "exclusively on Mr Chirac's orders", and brought the RPR some £10m a year.

According to Le Monde, Mr Ciolina confirmed that this sum was a "credible" amount.

webTitle: Women sing the praises of inclusion

fields.headline: Women sing the praises of inclusion
fields.trailText: The opera singer Montserrat Caballé yesterday stormed one of the last bastions of Spanish cultural misogyny after being accepted into the exclusive, and previously all-male, Cercle del Liceu club at Barcelona's opera house.
fields.body:
The opera singer Montserrat Caballé yesterday stormed one of the last bastions of Spanish cultural misogyny after being accepted into the exclusive, and previously all-male, Cercle del Liceu club at Barcelona's opera house.

A heated meeting of club members yesterday finally overturned last month's decision to blackball the famous soprano and nine other women who had applied to join. That decision provoked outrage across Spain and in the international opera world.

But yesterday's was a pyrrhic victory for the club's president, Joan Anton Maragall, and the rest of his board; they had to resign when their macho opponents took revenge by proposing a successful motion of no confidence.

Mr Maragall's wife, Magda Ferrer, was one of those admitted to the club by yesterday's special assembly.

The meeting also decided to end a application system, using black and white balls, whereby only a third of votes was needed to block candidates.

An emergency committee has taken over the running of the 1,200-member club, which holds private recitals and hosts debates on opera, music and the arts.

The news was greeted with delight by some of the women who were given approval for membership. "At least I will not now have to ask my husband's permission every time I want to go in. This is a great victory for women," businesswoman Adela Subirana said.

Ms Subirana, one of the wealthiest people in Barcelona, would previously have needed written permission from a male member before entering the rooms, decorated with modernist Catalan art, that the club occupies within the recently rebuilt opera house on the tree-lined Ramblas boulevard.

"This is one of the last outposts of die-hard conservatism," one outgoing board member said.

The opponents of the reform accepted, if somewhat ungraciously, that women had now become Cercle members.

"I don't think that anyone will insult them when they get here," said Alberto Roca, an opposition leader who has joined the emergency committee.

A new board is to be elected later this year.

Women, in theory, will be allowed to stand.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Sudan crash kills generals
fields.body:
Sudan crash kills generals

Sudan's deputy defence minister and 13 senior officers were killed when their plane crashed on takeoff as they were leaving southern Sudan after atour of the civil war zone yesterday, state radio said.

The dead included the deputy minister, Ibrahim Shamsul-Din, nine lieutenant-generals and three brigadier-generals.
AP, Khartoum

Jackal suspect jumps bail

Christa-Margot Frohlich, a suspected accomplice of the jailed terrorist known as Carlos the Jackal, has fled France for Germany in violation of her bail terms, French judicial sources said yesterday. Germans are not extradited to France.

The former schoolteacher is accused of playing a key role in an April 1982 car bomb that killed a pregnant passer-by in Paris. She is also suspected of planting the explosives that blew up a Paris-Toulouse train the month before, killing five people
Jon Henley, Paris

Rise in torture by Burundi

Amnesty International has reported a "noticeable escalation" of torture by Burundian security forces in recent weeks, since rebels invaded parts of the capital Bujumbura. Screaming was often heard by people near the worst detention centre, it said.
Reuters, London

fields.headline: Estrada charged with corruption
fields.trailText: A day after being stripped of his immunity from prosecution, the deposed Philippines president, Joseph Estrada, was charged yesterday with eight counts of corruption during his presidency involving more than 4bn pesos (£56m).
fields.body:
A day after being stripped of his immunity from prosecution, the deposed Philippines president, Joseph Estrada, was charged yesterday with eight counts of corruption during his presidency involving more than 4bn pesos (£56m).

A special anti-graft court will now decide whether to proceed with the case, which encompasses accusations of embezzlement, perjury, bribe-taking, using state institutions to manipulate the stock market, and economic plunder, which carries the death penalty.

A trial is expected within two to three months.

Mr Estrada, 63, who was ousted in a political revolt coupled with massive street protests in January after his trial for impeachment collapsed, said the charges were cooked up by his successor, Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo.

Mr Estrada's wife, Luisa Ejercito, one of his sons, Jinggoy, and several cronies were also charged with various corruption offences yesterday.

Charges against Mr Estrada include skimming off millions of pesos from illegal gaming syndicates, and, along with his wife and son, allegedly pocketing 130m pesos of funds intended for tobacco farmers.

Mr Estrada called the charges a product of mob rule and scheming by Mrs Arroyo.

"I will exhaust all legal remedies. I will face all the charges filed against me, most of which are fabricated," Mr Estrada said, adding that he does not expect a fair trial.

webTitle: Peres tables peace plan with Palestinians in Athens

fields.headline: Peres tables peace plan with Palestinians in Athens
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israeli government yesterday put proposals for ending violence to a Palestinian delegation in the highest-level meeting between the two sides since Ariel Sharon became prime minister two months ago.
fields.body:
The Israeli government yesterday put proposals for ending violence to a Palestinian delegation in the highest-level meeting between the two sides since Ariel Sharon became prime minister two months ago.

The Israeli foreign minister, Shimon Peres, is believed to have tabled a four-point plan during talks in Athens with his Palestinian counterpart, Nabil Sha'ath, and the chief Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erekat.

As well as the Athens meeting, the Jordanian government hoped that a plan it was putting forward jointly with Egypt may prove successful, while three doveish Israeli MPs travelled to Ramallah on the West Bank to discuss options for reducing violence with the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat.

An Israeli foreign ministry spokesman said there were reports that Mr Arafat was considering flying to Athens for talks with Mr Peres but he had no firm information about his intentions.

Mr Peres, speaking after more than two hours of talks at an economic conference, said he hoped security officers from both sides would meet within 24 hours to discuss how to end the violence.

US representatives are to be included in the security talks at the border between Israel and the Gaza Strip.

Mr Peres said: "This is the first sign that there is truly an intention to stop the terror and begin to talk." He added: "We shall continue to talk. Better talking than shooting."

But Mr Erekat warned against raising expectations. "We have different points of views in the way we see things on the ground."

Behind the scenes, there was near-total pessimism on both sides about the prospects of finding a peace formula.

Israeli officials stressed that there was no contradiction between Mr Sharon's refusal to negotiate until the violence has ended and Mr Peres's meeting in Athens. "This was an exchange of views, not negotiation," a spokesman for Mr Peres said.

Mr Peres's four-point plan involves: a Palestinian pledge that violence will cease; in return, the Israelis will ease the hardship caused by its economic blockade of the West Bank and Gaza; a promise by the Palestinians to halt incitement to violence and to adopt the vocabulary of peace and reconciliation; and a return to talks without preconditions.

The Athens talks were held under the auspices of the EU security chief, Javier Solana, who is trying to fill the gap left by Washington.

webTitle: Lion of Panjsher drums up Europe's help in struggle against Taliban

fields.headline: Lion of Panjsher drums up Europe's help in struggle against Taliban
fields.standfirst: Pakistan must stop supporting Kabul regime, Masood says
fields.trailText: Ahmad Shah Masood, the veteran soldier leading the armed struggle against Afghanistan's Taliban, made his first visit to the west yesterday to urge the international community to put more pressure on Pakistan to halt its support of the ruling hardline Islamic regime.
fields.byline: Jon Henley in Paris and Rory McCarthy in Islamabad
fields.body:
Ahmad Shah Masood, the veteran soldier leading the armed struggle against Afghanistan's Taliban, made his first visit to the west yesterday to urge the international community to put more pressure on Pakistan to halt its support of the ruling hardline Islamic regime.

Commander Masood, Afghanistan's most celebrated military tactician, met the French foreign minister, Hubert Védrine, and the leaders of both houses of parliament before leaving for Strasbourg to address members of the European parliament today.

Appearing to loud cheers and applause at a Paris news conference, he declined to say how yesterday's talks had gone, saying simply that he had "explained what needed to be done" for the fighting in Afghanistan to end, and that it was now up to foreign leaders to take action.

"The path that will give access to peace is for the international community to put strong pressure on Pakistan," he said. "Pakistani interference in Afghanistan in terms of training, soldiers, funding and logistics is evident. What happens now depends on leaders and European presidents. Do they want to defend the just cause of the Afghan people, or will they content themselves with mere declarations?"

Cmdr Masood said he was confident that the Taliban's recent destruction of two ancient statues of Buddha in central Afghanistan - an act met with worldwide condemnation - would successfully mobilise revolt against the extremist regime both inside the country and abroad.

"The real nature and the true face of the Taliban are now clear by all our people," he said. "To understand the Taliban and their way of thinking, you have only to look at this destruction. People also see how much Pakistan is contributing to the Taliban. In the near future, I have no doubt that you will witness a mass popular movement against the Taliban."

Cmdr Masood, 47, a wiry, grey-haired man in a woollen hat, was a leading figure in Afghanistan's war of resistance against the Soviet occupation in the 1980s. He never once lost control of his native Panjsher Valley, 50 miles north of the capital Kabul, despite repeated offensives from the Soviet army.

After the Soviet Union pulled out of Afghanistan, rival mojahedin factions fought for control of Kabul and the "Lion of the Panjsher", as Cmdr Masood is known to his soldiers, won the city in 1992 and became defence minister.

But four years later he fled in the face of the rapid Taliban advance, and has since been pushed back into a small area of north-western Afghanistan. There he effectively runs the opposition Northern Alliance controlling around 5% of the country.

Despite military and financial support from Russia, Iran, India and Tajikistan, Cmdr Masood's forces have struggled to regain large areas of land, including their political headquarters at Taloqan, lost to the Taliban last summer.

He has since agreed fragile military alliances with rival commanders, many of whom have betrayed him in past battles, and promised to mount a new offensive in the coming weeks as the winter snows melt.

Cmdr Masood said he was willing to accept European aid in any form, whether political, military or humanitarian. "We face major human problems in health, education and with refugees," he said. "I have to signal with regret that the aid provided in the past has been minimal and insignificant. Due to the lack of food in the north, lives have been lost."

A French foreign ministry spokesman said Mr Védrine had promised a package of humanitarian aid measures for the Afghan people suffering from a drought that has brought famine to several areas of the country.

webTitle: Pokemon feels force of religious fatwa

fields.headline: Pokemon feels force of religious fatwa
fields.standfirst: Pokemon creatures accused of promoting Zionism, freemasonry, Christianity, Darwinism and Shintoism
fields.trailText: Pikachu, Charmander and Butterfree are fighting for their lives. The Pokemon creatures loved by millions of children around the world stand accused of promoting Zionism, freemasonry, Christianity, Darwinism and Shintoism - not to mention gambling.
fields.body:
Pikachu, Charmander and Butterfree are fighting for their lives. The Pokemon creatures loved by millions of children around the world stand accused of promoting Zionism, freemasonry, Christianity, Darwinism and Shintoism - not to mention gambling.

Religious authorities in Saudi Arabia and Qatar have already issued fatwas (religious rulings) banning them and a verdict from the United Arab Emirates is expected on Saturday.

"We will issue a decision within the next few days," Sheikh Ahmed al-Haddad of the Research and Fatwa Administration in Dubai said.

Pokemon (short for pocket monsters) began as a Nintendo video game in Japan five years ago and has turned into a multibillion-pound business with spin-offs in cards, books, comics, toys and clothing.

Most controversy centres on Pokemon cards, with symbols indicating the characters' imaginary powers. Critics claim they are emblems of Zionism, free-masonry, Christianity and Jap-anese Shintoism. An evolving creature card is accused of confirming the theories of Charles Darwin, which are rejected by orthodox Islam. And trading cards is seen by some as encouraging gambling.

fields.headline: Time to mourn
fields.standfirst: Kenya buries bus crash victims and schoolboys killed in a fire
fields.trailText: Angry Kenyans mourned the victims from recent bus and fire tragedies yesterday, and demanded better safety in schools and on roads.
fields.body:
Angry Kenyans mourned the victims from recent bus and fire tragedies yesterday, and demanded better safety in schools and on roads.

Sixty-nine boys burned to death when fire ripped through the Kyanguli secondary school dormitory near Machakos, 30 miles from Nairobi, on March 26. Days later, two buses collided on a bridge and plunged into a river, killing at least 33 people.

Fifty-eight of the fire victims were buried in six mass graves at their school yesterday. At the same time, hundreds of miles to the south-east, many of the bus crash victims were buried in on the banks of the River Sabaki, where the twisted wreckage was pulled from the floodwaters. Relatives blamed late rescuers, poor roads and unroadworthy buses for the tragedy.

Kenya's newspapers said the tragedies had a common thread - a lack of respect for safety at all levels of the state. The Daily Nation said that the toll of major disasters reads like a telephone number".

Police are investigating claims that an arsonist may have started the blaze at Kyanguli secondary school. But the tragedy was magnified by overcrowding, barred windows and blocked escape routes.

President Daniel arap Moi acknowledged that school safety procedures had not been respected.
Reuters, Machakos

fields.headline: Tennis star's stalker guilty
fields.trailText: An Australian naval architect who claimed he was in love with Martina Hingis was yesterday convicted of stalking her. A jury in Miami had heard that since 1999 he had followed tennis's top ranking woman player from tournament to tournament, waited outside her house and made her so fearful for her safety that she hired a bodyguard.
fields.body:
An Australian naval architect who claimed he was in love with Martina Hingis was yesterday convicted of stalking her. A jury in Miami had heard that since 1999 he had followed tennis's top ranking woman player from tournament to tournament, waited outside her house and made her so fearful for her safety that she hired a bodyguard.

A Miami-Dade county court jury found Croatian-born Dubravko Rajcevic, 46, guilty on one count of stalking and three counts of trespassing. He will by sentenced by Judge Kevin Emas later this week and faces up to four years in jail. He had been examined by psychologists and deemed mentally fit to stand trial, although suffering from delusions about Hingis.

Rajcevic, an Australian citizen, was arrested during last year's Ericsson Open tournament at Key Biscayne, near Miami and has been in jail since then, unable to post the $2m (£1.4m) bail.

His attorney, Frank Abrams, said Rajcevic was not a threat to the 20-year-old Swiss star but suffered from a case of unrequited love. Rajcevic had asked while giving evidence: "Is there something wrong if I want to marry Martina Hingis. Is that wrong?" He said he became interested in her after parting from his wife. "Plenty of people get divorced [and] look for someone else. I tried with Martina Hingis."

Hingis told the court she had always made it clear that she was not interested in a relationship, and had been worried that his obsession might turn to "hate and aggression".

She had told Rajcevic to stop bothering her when he phoned her in Paris in 1999. She had also personally confronted him outside her home in Zurich, where he had stationed himself and made frequent requests to see her. "I told him to get out of my life."

So concerned was she for her safety that she moved to a hotel in Zurich and hired a full-time bodyguard. Rajcevic had bombarded her with flowers and faxes and refused to desist, the court heard.

The most serious case of obsession to affect the tennis world led to the stabblng of the then number one player, Monica Seles, by a German fan of Steffi Graf in 1993. Seles's form was badly affected by the attack and she never regained her pre-eminence in the game.

fields.headline: Jenny Colgan
fields.standfirst: Lounging by the pool with 24 minutes of my first, fabulous script in the bag. So who needs a self-help manual?
fields.trailText: Lounging by the pool with 24 minutes of my first, fabulous script in the bag. So who needs a self-help manual?
fields.body:
Dinner with the hot-shot Hollywood producer was OK. Some people clam up when they are a bit nervous. I am not really one of those people. Some people do not have heavy Scottish accents. Hmm. And some people don't forget to take their change of contact lenses so that, rather than staying in the guest bedroom as invited, the very high-up producer has to drive the incomprehensible gabbling girl 30 miles home in the middle of the night. Plus I couldn't stop staring at his wife as she was so insanely beautiful that I kept checking her out to see if I could catch any flaws. Apart from that I think it was fine.

I went to the big bookstore on Third Street promenade to buy a book about, you know, writing a script, as opposed to putting one word after another for nine months until you've got lots of them, which is how I write books. Screenwriting, I have found, doesn't like words one after another; it likes them on different lines in different fonts and not too many of them.

The section on screenwriting is 400 miles along. It is stuffed to the gills with Become a Rich and Famous Writer in Three Days by Me, Someone You Have Never Heard Of, and Teach Yourself Comedy! and Show the World You Don't Know What You're Doing By Buying This Book, You Sad Loser. Do You Honestly Think Charlie Kaufmann Bought One of These?.

Uneasily, I eye the other people flipping pseudo-casually through the racks. The man beside me has a hungry look in his eye. He look like he really wants to believe that Write Your Way to Weight Loss! is going to change his life. And the girl in six layers of hippie clothes and the henna tattoo. She's going to use her screenplay book to write something that will really get back at her parents. In short, I don't want to be among these people. I don't want people to think: God, look at her - if she has to buy a book about writing a screenplay, she's in trouble before she even starts. This is what I am currently thinking about all the other people there.

So I buy If On A Winter's Night A Traveller (partly to mess with my head and partly to regain my bookshop self-esteem) and I've started the script my way - just one word after another (but with kicky italic fonts and the screenwriter's secret weapon - centreing).

Finally, though, I got to sit, by the pool, actually doing some work. I'm there! I've done it! And also I now have a lovely A4 white-skin shape on my thighs. I think it shows I mean business. I have written 24 minutes and not one of the characters goes outside once. The last movie I can remember that happening in was Die Hard. Perhaps my delicate comedy love-triangle could get invaded by terrorists who hold them hostage. In a florist's.

The Americans have just started showing their adaptation of This Life, called First Years. It is an aberration. The character playing Miles has a big mullet. Yeah, I know. And they talk about "issues" all the time. Hey, like they know how to have fun - but they have integrity, goddammit. You know how Milly's race was never referred to? Well, in the very first episode here, the Milly character went to her parent's house and had a long, long conversation about growing up mixed-race, with lots of meaningful stares into the middle distance and close hugging. Can't wait to see how they deal with Ferdy when he starts shagging plumbers in the bathroom.

The meeting of friends of friends is still going well. I'm meeting someone new on Monday. "How will I recognise you?" I asked.

"Oh, I'm an actress and I've got blonde hair and blue eyes."

Her and everyone else in Hollywood. Maybe I should get her to wear a carnation.

fields.headline: No 1854
fields.standfirst: Ovaltine
fields.trailText: Ovaltine
fields.body:
Yuck! What is that stuff anyway? Malt extract, barley, milk powder, cocoa, vitamins and minerals - a bedtime favourite drink since 1909.

Aah, that symbol of Britain! Not any more. Production in England is set to stop next year. It'll be made in Switzerland instead.

You mean they'll use mountain milk, rather than good British cows? Bet that was nothing to do with it. The official reason is to improve competitiveness. We all know that Switzerland is a cheap place to do business.

But future generations won't know what they're missing! Poor little blighters.

So how will we get our kids to fall asleep? Don't worry, supplies will be imported from the Swiss factory. Anyway, it's now being marketed as energy-giving rather than yawn-inducing.

Get away! 25,000 cups were served to athletes in the 1948 Olympics actually. And Sir Edmund Hillary used it on his successful ascent of Everest in 1953.

Has anyone touched the stuff since then? More than 10m jars are apparently sold in the UK each year. Some people must be guzzling it.

Enough to sing about? Ad campaigns have been memorable. The "We're the Ovaltineys" jingle made the top 20 in 1980.

Who was that by? The Ovaltineys, a bunch of child stars who promoted its nutritional benefits. They even had their own show on Radio Luxembourg.

Is it really good for you? Novartis, who make it, reckon you can virtually live off its nutrients. After all, Great Britain was brought up on it, so it must work.

All that history lost. Jobs as well? The plant in Kings Langley, Hertfordshire, will close, with the loss of 245 jobs.

Most likely to say: "Because we all drink Ovaltine, we're happy boys and girls."

Not to be confused with: Horlicks.

webTitle: Catherine Bennet: Those missing Sophie letters

fields.headline: Those missing Sophie letters
fields.trailText: Mr Major | Your Royal Highness | Mr Hague | Charles and Camilla
fields.body:
Dear Mr Major,

You warned me to be wary of the press, but I never anticipated anything on this scale. On top of being persecuted for the crime of looking uncannily like Diana, I now find myself accused of saying things that are completely untrue. As if I would have said that I could "get you to a function" any time. Only last week you said you were too busy to jump out of a cake. Besides, what I actually said was "I can get John Major to function anytime" - on days, for instance, when you might be feeling exhausted by your wonderful high profile public speaking career.

Do tell me you're not offended, and when you have a second, an RSVP about the Horseit.com do would be appreciated. Would you mind being the back legs? With the royal connection, I need to keep a bit of dignity!

With best wishes,

yours ever,

Sophie.

 Your Royal Highness,

I ought to tell you that a distasteful rumour is circulating to the effect that I have talked disrespectfully about your royal highness. Apparently some people are saying that I referred to you as "the old dear". I need hardly say that this is utterly untrue. As you know, I'm terrifically keen to help ease the burden on the family, so when I was contacted by a man who said he was an Arab sheikh of unsurpassable wealth, it seemed a fantastic opportunity to increase my role and, to be honest, try and escape from the shadow of Diana. Perhaps if I did something quite different, such as striking a hugely important middle-eastern PR deal for RJH, people might let me down from her plinth. For a few days, at least.

After making my salaams and offering the sheikh a box of Turkish delight, I attempted to follow your example, and put him at his ease with a little talk about common interests. Would he care to appear, for example, in a new Ardent production, working title, "The Chase: Sport of Kings, Sultans and occasionally, Sheikhs". We talked of stalking. I explained that in this country we only shoot the old stags which would die anyway if nobody killed them. "Not the young deer," I said, putting it as simply as I could, "the old deer". At the same time I mentioned your highness's wonderful marksmanship during these acts of mercy. A hookah which I had rented for the occasion was bubbling loudly. "Queen - the old deer", I repeated clearly.

I'm sure I can count on your support, now you know the circumstances, but I'd still be grateful if you'd tell the Queen Mother that I did not call her "the old lady" (we were discussing the whereabouts of the royal yacht Britannia). And in case of any further upsetting rumours, I should perhaps add that I never described Prince Philip as a caveman, Princess Ann as a psychotic speed-freak, and the whole family as a walking PR disaster. I must admit, I should have known better than to call Cherie Blair "Horrid, horrid, horrid". But then she is, isn't she?

Now that's sorted, could we have a quick word about the Norfrost 2000? Would you agree with me that it's the world's most efficient chest freezer? Or do you need more time? It's just that they want the sample back.

All love,

Sophie.

 Dear Mr Hague,

You know me well enough to know that I would never describe you as "deformed". Think about it. It's just not the sort of thing Sophie says, is it? Just ask Boodle & Dunthorne, DFS, Hoover, or any other of RJH's blue-chip clients. To quote just one recent testimonial, from Miele, the German manufacturer of domestic appliances whose quality and longevity have become a legend: "Congratulations to the RJH team. You really put the record straight". So let me do the same for you. "Reformed", was the word I used when invited to describe you by Mr Mazher Mahmood. I was simply pointing out that you were no longer a 14-pint man. "He's a reformed character," I said. So whatever rubbish you may read over the next few days, please don't be upset. You and I know the truth, even if others don't. Oh, how I'd love to be able to sing it from the rooftops, "It's NOT TRUE, he's NOT DEFORMED."

After years of being compared to Princess Diana, take it from me, I know how hateful these endless personal comments can be. I mean, I can see there is an incredibly strong resemblance - some mornings I've already shouted "Hi! Diana" before I do a double take, and realise it's just my own reflection in the mirror. But give me a break! Not all of us have time to spend all day at the gym.

Gosh, far from disliking your appearance, I have seriously debated asking if you would consider becoming the Face of JCB - Europe's premier manufacturer of construction equipment. I might add that the full conjugal relations enjoyed by myself and Prince Edward, which you may soon read about in the News of the World, should be proof, if any were needed, that I find receding, or non-existent hair, no obstacle to passion.

On a more serious note, it occurs to me that the postponement of the General Election will leave you with some unexpected free time. Had you considered a luxury weekend break in one of Britain's most gracious and historic hotels? If so, look no further than the Lanesborough, London's foremost home for discriminating travellers. A complimentary bottle of champagne awaits you in your Executive Junior Suite. Rates available on application.

Yours very truly,

Sophie.

 Dear Charles and Camilla,

I'm so very, very sorry. I should never have mentioned your wedding plans. The only thing that has helped me through this nightmare, Charles, is the memory of your own interview with Jonathan Dimbleby. Haven't I always said you're ahead of your time? Every time I began to agonise about the News of the World, I think how much worse your own admission of adultery on national television must have been for you. Especially coming on top of the awful Tampax tape. You must still be smarting. I think the best thing I can do is follow your example: dismiss the whole experience as a particularly steep section of my royal learning curve, and move on to the next goal.

Speaking of which, any more thoughts about a wedding list? Thomas Goode offers a discreet but thorough service, and as Camilla says, the old stuff's looking a bit chipped. Why not try this old established purveyor of premier quality glass and chinaware since 1827? Just one thing, when you're in there, could you mention my name, including the countess bit? It's little details like that that make RJH the obvious PR choice for specialists in traditional luxury goods.

Love,

Sophie.

Buried in the back pages

The Daily Telegraph's report about the death of Lord Hartwell, the paper's former proprietor, featured an intriguing detail about his last moments: "His family said it was fitting that he died while reading the Daily Telegraph". Frustratingly, it was not specified which article Hartwell was reading at the time. Was it likely to have aroused admiration or apoplexy in a man of his temper? Considering the circumstances that led to his separation from the family paper, it seems quite possible that, far from expiring contentedly in the company of, say, Peter Simple, his departure was associated with one of the paper's more with-it elements: a tribute to Elizabeth Hurley, perhaps, or one of Sion Simon's regular bids for a safe New Labour seat. Either way, with its ageing readership, it is brave, if a little foolhardy of the Telegraph to have advertised itself as a deathbed accessory. While Hartwell's death will undoubtedly strike many Telegraph readers as the ideal way to go, still more others will, I suspect, in future prefer to study their paper in the safety of the local A&E department, or anywhere else a well-staffed resuscitation unit is known to be on hand.

Either way, with its ageing readership, it is brave, if a little foolhardy of the Telegraph to have advertised itself as a deathbed accessory. While Hartwell's death will undoubtedly strike many Telegraph readers as the ideal way to go, still more others will, I suspect, in future prefer to study their paper in the safety of the local A&E department, or anywhere else a well-staffed resuscitation unit is known to be on hand.

fields.headline: Swanning around
fields.standfirst: Loch Ness
fields.trailText: Loch Ness
fields.body: Our destination was the shore of Loch Ness to photograph the creamy butterbur, which is one of the earliest plants to flower here - its first buds showed this year on March 11. However, we had only driven as far as our local hostelry, aptly named The Grouse And Trout, when a bird of prey flew over. My first guess was a harrier because of the very buoyant flight, but binoculars proved it to be a red kite, and when it turned we could easily see the forked tail. Despite being fairly common in some parts of the Highlands, this was only the third one we had seen in our strath. The next sighting of note was at Loch Ceo Glais. In the shallows, three whooper swans were upending in their search for food, perhaps stocking up for their long trip north to their breeding grounds in Iceland. We passed a small, common-gull colony where a few birds were loafing around, and noted new grain feeders on the edge of a wood and a number of cock pheasants. Then we drove down the steep hillside to Dores where we found that the butterbur was about eight inches tall, although, as usual, there were no leaves, as they come much later. This striking-looking plant was introduced from Europe for a flush of early spring colour in woodland, and in some parts it is common, while the native common butterbur is much rarer this far north. Both plants have huge rhubarb-like leaves which were used, in the old days, for wrapping butter, hence the plant's name. Our round trip took us through Inverness, and just outside the city were large numbers of greylag geese. We wondered where they had flown from on their way north and what they could be carrying with them!

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Radio: De Valois Evening | Race Myths | Seven More Days That Rocked The World
fields.body:
Christopher Cook is given the best part of three hours for a De Valois Evening (7.30pm, Radio 3) in which he and his guests recall the steely personality and remarkable achievements of the queen of British ballet. Since Dame Ninette was 102 when she died last month, there is a vast list of dancers and choreographers who worked with her. Among those paying tribute are Anthony Dowell, now director of the Royal Ballet, and her biographer Katherine Sorley.

Professor Steve Jones launches a series about the development of Race Myths (8.0pm, Radio 4). Decoding the human genome established that there can be far greater differences between two black or two white individuals than exist between either group as a whole. It seems odd, therefore, that racism became such a major factor as far back in history as ancient Greece. This opening segment examines the emergence of colour as a cultural discriminator.

Stuart Maconie recalls another famous death in Seven More Days That Rocked The World (10.0pm, Radio 2), that of Buddy Holly in 1959. For millions around the world the crash of his chartered light aircraft was the day the music died. Though only 22 at the time, Holly's compositions and style of performance had a huge influence. Some of his unreleased recordings only reached the public 20 years after he was killed, and became runaway best-sellers.
