webTitle: Satellite, cable, digital pick of the day

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Invasion Of The Body Snatchers | Hope And Glory | Run Lola Run | The Right Stuff | Let Him Have It | Live Speedway
fields.body:
Films

Invasion Of The Body Snatchers (Don Siegel, 1956) 10.40am, 6.40pm, Sky Cinema Hysteria grips a small California town: people fear their loved ones are turning into complete strangers. Doc Kevin McCarthy, aided by the woman of his dreams, Dana Wynter, soon discovers the awful truth. Alien pods are replicating the townsfolk, and there is no way out. Fears of the red menace underpin Siegel's tense, fast-paced sci-fi tale which, despite excellent remakes by Kaufman and Ferrara, remains the scariest.

Hope And Glory (John Boorman, 1987) 8.15pm, FilmFour Affectionate view of the war as experienced by little Bill Rowen (Sebastian Rice-Edwards). In this great adventure, captured in telling detail, the Blitz lights up the night sky rather than dealing death, and a barrage balloon bumps comically over London roofs.

Run Lola Run (Tom Tykwer, 1998) 8pm, Sky Premier A little drama as bright as its heroine's red hair. Franka Potente's Lola gets a phone call from her panicky boyfriend (Moritz Bleibtreu) saying that he's got 20 minutes to come up with a stack of cash for the mob, or he's dead. Lola sets off on foot, fast, to save him, and Tykwer gives us three versions of what happens next, the outcome swaying from tragic to happy-ever-after. Hugely charming and entertaining.

The Right Stuff (Philip Kaufman, 1983) 9pm, TCM Kaufman's film does full justice to Tom Wolfe's gritty, fascinating book about the US space programme. In its examination of the men with the right stuff - what it takes to be an astronaut - Sam Shepard's test pilot Chuck Yeager is tops, the Han Solo of the fraternity, but he was turned down because he had no university qualifications. An exciting, touching and funny tribute to some of the heroes of our time, and the appalling risks they took. With Scott Glenn as Alan Shepard, Ed Harris as John Glenn and Barbara Hershey as Yeager's wife, Glennis.

Let Him Have It (Peter Medak, 1991) 10.10pm, FilmFour A powerful and angry account of the gross miscarriage of justice that was the Craig/Bentley murder case. Christopher Eccleston plays Derek Bentley, the 19-year-old epileptic with the mental age of 11 who was hanged, in 1952, for the shooting of a policeman. His 16-year-old friend, Chris Craig (Paul Reynolds) had fired the gun, but was too young to be executed. The court decided that when Bentley, already under arrest, shouted: "Let him have it, Chris" he meant "shoot", not "hand over the gun". The conviction was finally quashed by a court of appeal in 1998.
Paul Howlett

Sports

Live Speedway 7.30pm, Sky Sports 1 Sky may have five sports channels, not to mention Eurosport and all the other channels who dip their toes into the sporting pool, but they don't always get it right. You could spend tonight watching great football on BBC1, or Masters golf on BBC2, but it is my duty to recommend this battle between the Sheffield Tigers and Workington Comets.
Simon Burnton

webTitle: TV review: Through The Eyes Of The Old

fields.headline: Don't look back in anger
fields.trailText: TV review: Through The Eyes Of The Old
fields.body:
Old people in prime time? Old people in prime time that aren't being jolly grandparents or attacked in their own homes or sometimes - in Casualty mainly - both? Old people in prime time that aren't David Jason, John Thaw or Thora Hird? Shurely shome mishtake, as old Sean Connery (70) might say. Yet there they were, all wrinkles, recollections and rheumy eyes in Through The Eyes Of The Old (BBC1). And blimey, what absorbing, moving viewing they made.

That shouldn't come as a surprise. Why wouldn't a collection of older people reflecting upon the past and ruminating on the present be engrossing television? Isn't it obvious that those with the most life experience have an awful lot to say about life? There is a reason for that phrase "older and wiser", isn't there? And even if there wasn't, they are - like teenagers, say - people with stories to tell.

But unlike other people's, old folks' stories get lost. Not in an accidental, down-the-back-of-the-sofa kind of way. More in a sack-of-kittens-in-the-canal kind of way. For if we're honest, most of us young 'uns don't like old people. Even the phrase "old people" sounds like an insult. The scorn that taints those words has meant the evolution of supposedly nicer sounding alternatives like "senior citizens", "pensioners" and "the elderly", but these still sound opprobrious because any description of those in the autumn of their lives is unavoidably contaminated with contempt. We could describe everyone over 70 as "wonderful human beings" and it would still sound like a slur. Any stories these wonderful human beings have to tell, goes the logic, aren't really worth listening to.

(The logic, naturally, is flawed but we follow it nonetheless. Just as when a grandparent dies - or worse, goes loopy and forgets pretty much everything about everything - and you yearn to have the time back so you could ask them all about their lives, so Through The Eyes Of The Old was riven with sadness. You want to be able to fill in the gaps between the fragments of stories they told you as you were growing up, stories you weren't really listening to because you were too preoccupied with how to get them to buy you candy floss or American Cream Soda. This you learn as you get older. And when it's too late.)

Of course, this loathing is nothing personal - towards them, at least. We may detest their Rainmates, their tartan shopping trolleys, their dithering in M& S and their doddering down the street, but we do so generically and instinctively. We don't care whether they are a veteran of the suffragette movement (Margaret, 94), a Parkinson's sufferer and campaigner for pensioners' rights (Zelda, 77), or a pet bereavement counsellor and Mrs Pepperpot lookalike (Rita, 88-and-a-half).

We reduce these people down to a collection of cliches - rheumy eyes and Rainmates, for example - until they are just old. And then we hate them for it. We do this for the same reason we don't like fat people or people with disabilities: because they remind us of our own frailty, the inevitability of our own mortality. There, but for the grace of God, we go. Unfortunately for them, old people are the unwelcome reminder that one day, God will stop being quite so graceful.

When, in one of Through The Eyes Of The Old's many poignant moments, Margaret explained how suddenly old age creeps up on you - "It's like waking up, looking in the mirror and a different face being there. It's not you any more" - she articulated one of our greatest fears. When Zelda confessed how she hates not being in control of her body, she expressed another. Strokes, arthritis, cataracts, incontinence: it's all in store for all of us.

But not all of us. Maurice Chevalier said he preferred old age to the alternative, but there are those who would disagree, however subconsciously.

If you can live fast, die young and leave a beautiful corpse, who'd be old and wrinkled and despised by society? Worse, who'd be erased from a youth-obsessed society like a vanished commissar? You have to stop being a kidult sometime. Old age, as Bette Davis rightly observed, isn't for sissies.

Through The Eyes Of The Old may have been overlong but it was an admirable, brave and engaging documentary. Aside from the unnecessary stunt of using little cameras to show the world from the viewpoint of some of its contributors - CodgerCam, I suppose - it was mature and worthwhile. That it should have been made in the first place, however, is a damning indictment of how we treat our elders.

fields.headline: Eyes wide apart
fields.standfirst: Stare into Michelle Pfeiffer's eyes, and other faces will suffer by comparison, according to  Michael Morgan
fields.trailText: Stare into Michelle Pfeiffer's eyes, and other faces will suffer by comparison, according to Michael Morgan
fields.body:
What would happen to your nervous system if you stared intently into the eyes of Michelle Pfeiffer for two minutes? One of several possible answers can be inferred from a paper recently published in Nature Neuroscience. The eyes of Ms Pfeiffer, as you may have observed, are unusually far apart. On the continuum leading from rabbits to foxes, she is definitely the hunted rather than the hunter.

The authors of the Nature Neuroscience paper have discovered that staring at an unusual face for a while makes other faces seem distorted in the opposite direction. Staring at Ms Pfeiffer would probably cause you to see the eyes of ordinary faces as unusually close together, like those of tennis player Bjorn Borg.

People in the trade call this kind of distortion "sensory adaptation". We often stare for hours on end at images in an attempt to alter our brain, though seldom do we see such interesting images as that of Michelle Pfeiffer. In fact, most adaptation experiments are so mind-numbingly boring that the method could only have been invented by the Germans, according to William James.

A classical example of sensory adaptation is the waterfall effect. In 1834 the physicist R Addams visited the Fall of Foyers, near Loch Ness. In his own words: "Having steadfastly looked for a few seconds at a particular part of the cascade, admiring the confluence and decussation of the currents forming the liquid drapery of waters, and then suddenly directed my eyes to the left, to observe the vertical face of the sombre age-worn rocks immediately contiguous to the waterfall, I saw the rocky surface as if in motion upwards".

The effect had previously been observed in the Austro-Hungarian Empire after inspecting columns of marching troops. With typical technical ingenuity, psychologists have managed to bring the waterfall effect into the laboratory and prove that it really exists. Over 1,000 scientific papers have been published on the phenomenon. Marlowe (the private eye, not the playwright) said that chess was the most elaborate waste of human effort to be found outside of an advertising agency. He was mistaken.

The waterfall effect is usually explained by fatigue in sensory nerve cells. We know that many nerve cells in the visual pathway respond vigorously to movement on the retina, and that each cell has it own preferred direction of motion. Since a particular moving object, and even a stationary one, stimulates all these cells to some extent, but some more than others, the perceived direction of movement must depend upon a delicate balance in the population of cells as a whole. In effect, perception is decided by a vote in which every cell has a voice. If one kind of cell is repeatedly stimulated by movement in its preferred direction, it becomes fatigued and its voice is diminished. When the movement stops, the overall vote goes in the opposite direction. The same is seen with colour. Adapting to a bright red swatch makes a yellow swatch look green. This is how we know that the perception of yellow depends upon a hung vote between the reds and the greens.

In the face adaptation experiment, people were shown computer-processed images of faces which could be distorted to exaggerate features such as the distance between the eyes. They learned to distinguish between "Adam" and "Anti-Adam", who were distorted in opposite directions. They then adapted for several minutes to Adam. Finally, they were shown a face midway between Adam and Anti-Adam; adaptation to Adam made them more likely to classify the intermediate face as Anti-Adam. The logic of adaptation experiments leads us to infer that face perception depends on an electoral contest between cells specialised to detect certain facial features, like the distance between the eyes. After adaptation to Michelle Pfeiffer, the ayes narrowly have it.

A final twist has been provided by Peter Thompson, a psychologist at the University of York, who asked people to estimate the distance between their own eyes, in centimetres or inches. You might like to try this yourself before reading what Thompson found. Think how your eyes look in the mirror. How far are they apart? Three inches? Most people over-estimate their inter-pupillary distance. Why they do so is as big a mystery as why the experiment was done in the first place. The Committee Internationale des Mesures Inutiles has defined the milli-Helen as the amount of pulchritude required to launch one ship. If the Pfeiffer be adapted as the unit of inter-ocular distance. I calculate the average overestimation by people of their own interocular distance as about 50 milli-Pfeiffers.

 Professor Michael Morgan is at the applied vision research centre of the City University

When the movement stops, the overall vote goes in the opposite direction. The same is seen with colour. Adapting to a bright red swatch makes a yellow swatch look green. This is how we know that the perception of yellow depends upon a hung vote between the reds and the greens. In the face adaptation experiment, people were shown computer-processed images of faces which could be distorted to exaggerate features such as the distance between the eyes. They learned to distinguish between "Adam" and "Anti-Adam", who were distorted in opposite directions. They then adapted for several minutes to Adam. Finally, they were shown a face midway between Adam and Anti-Adam; adaptation to Adam made them more likely to classify the intermediate face as Anti-Adam. The logic of adaptation experiments leads us to infer that face perception depends on an electoral contest between cells specialised to detect certain facial features, like the distance between the eyes. After adaptation to Michelle Pfeiffer, the ayes narrowly have it. A final twist has been provided by Peter Thompson, a psychologist at the University of York, who asked people to estimate the distance between their own eyes, in centimetres or inches. You might like to try this yourself before reading what Thompson found. Think how your eyes look in the mirror. How far are they apart? Three inches? Most people over-estimate their inter-pupillary distance. Why they do so is as big a mystery as why the experiment was done in the first place. The Committee Internationale des Mesures Inutiles has defined the milli-Helen as the amount of pulchritude required to launch one ship. If the Pfeiffer be adapted as the unit of inter-ocular distance. I calculate the average overestimation by people of their own interocular distance as about 50 milli-Pfeiffers.  Professor Michael Morgan is at the applied vision research centre of the City University

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: Shrewishly into that good night
fields.body:
Shrewishly into that good night
South Australia could gain a reputation for carelessness. Like the rest of Australia it has lost the pig-footed bandicoot, toolache wallaby and hare wallaby. Now the brush-tailed bettong and the bilby have left the territory and the next to go could be the Antipodean equivalent of the tree shrew, the phascogale. The state is earning the reputation of mammalian extinction capital of the world. The problem, according to Peter Hornsby of Adelaide University, is the loss of cover in the Adelaide Hills. He has been fixing nestboxes at sites that might suit the phascogale, if any survive in the state. "Paradoxically, if there were not phascogales in the zoos," he said, "we wouldn't even know what they looked like."

Press the flesh and heal a burn
A team at the University of Buffalo and the Shriner Burns hospital in Boston say they have engineered skin that heals. The artificial tissue releases keratinocyte growth factor(KGF) that could help people with severe injuries or burns. It has, they claim "the natural composition and topography of skin". It can prevent dehydration and shield against pathogens. And by spurring the growth of new skin cells, it would spur faster healing, they report in the Journal of the Federation of American Societies of Experimental Biology. Next step is to test it on animals.

Not such a nice cup of tea
Regina Watschinger of Austria told the European Society of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious Diseases meeting in Istanbul this week that she had found why antibiotic resistant and potentially dangerous Acinetobacter baumannii appeared on hospital gastric tubes in Linz. It arrived with the tea. The cup that cheers was mass produced and stored in thermos flasks -and used to rinse the gastric tubes. She looked at the flasks and found the bug. "Then we looked at 56 other tea flasks from nine departments in three different hospitals. Nearly half - 26 to be precise -were contaminated in the same way."

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
There to serve
There has been so much in the press recently regarding Napster and the whole P2P (peer2peer) issue, and of possible alternatives if Napster is fully shut down. What I don't understand is why no-one has mentioned Napigator? This is surely the Napster users' saviour.

It is a while since I downloaded my version, but a search on Google would no doubt turn up the relevant website. Once downloaded, Napigator will list all Napster servers, including unofficial non-Napster run servers. These servers run openNap, MyNap or similar, and do exactly the same job as real official Napster servers, providing login facilities for the Napster client and a database of all other logged in users and their shared files. Napigator will show around 160 servers, 60 odd of which will be Napster servers. The rest are run by those wishing to help out the global online music sharing community. Clicking on a listed server will start the Napster client and connect it to that server. Thus even if all Napster servers are completely shut down, there is absolutely no reason why the Napster users community can't continue sharing their files exactly as before. The server software is also freely available.
Richard Hill
Ricky@mangamail.net

Primary link
Pat Kane (Second sight, March 29) shares my affection for Finland. The first time I visited, nearly 30 years ago, I felt at home there, despite the alien language. I have read that the Finnish education system has a strong emphasis on music, with all children at primary level participating in choral singing and many in instrumental playing. This has demonstrably resulted in a very high level of musical creativity in that country. Given the close association between music and mathematics, could this have anything to do with the burgeoning creativity we see in the IT world there? Perhaps David Blunkett, Chris Smith and Patricia Hewitt should get together. Tim Pearce
commonweal@co-op-party.org.uk

Put in order
Harry Beck did not revolutionise the map of the London Underground by "fudging the actual locations of the stations" (Online, March 29). He realised that the key question was not "where is station X?", but "how does one get to station X?" Thus he was able to replace unwieldy topographical maps by a diagram which preserved information about the order and connectedness of the stations on the network. He changed the criteria of representation to what was appropriate for the needs of most passengers.

Bernard Hrusa-Marlow
bernard@hrumar.freeserve.co.uk

History rewrite
Thanks for the edited version of my Mac OS history (OS X odyssey, Online, March 29), but something has gone a little wrong.

The operating system project abandoned in May 1996 (1994-1996 section) was Copland, not Rhapsody. Rhapsody was the code name for the earliest version of what became OS X.

In addition, the second and third screenshots have been printed the wrong way round. The second from the top shows Copland and the one at the bottom shows NexTStep.
Cameron Paterson
cameronp@lineone.net

Free icons
In the article X marks the spot, about the new Macintosh operating system, Craig McGill mentions that he would like new icons to improve the default set that comes with Mac OS X. There is a large collection of free new icons for Mac OS X at http://xicons.macnn.com
Tony Swash
tonyswash@blueyonder.co.uk

OS overdose
Regarding your piece on the launch of OS X, I wish you'd sent somebody with half a clue to meet the fanatics. I've been using protected memory and quashing badly behaved applications under Windows NT for years, and now do the same under Windows 2000. Your screen shot of the force quit dialogue looks similar to that found when you press Ctl-Alt-Del in Windows 95. "The first operating systems written from the ground up"?

Excuse me, isn't this NextStep's take on Unix we're talking about? Not to mention the fact that Mac aficionados have been claiming for years that their machines never crash.

Don't get me wrong, I have an extensive vocabulary of swearwords for when my Intel/Microsoft machine decides to mess me around. I just get irritated when the latest Mac is touted as a panacea to cure all computing ills.
Steve Jeffery
Steve.Jeffery@catalyst-uk.com

No internet
With reference to last week's article about the release of Apple OS X, I am currently experiencing Mac mania of the opposite kind. OS X contains great promise, but as delivered, it is basically dysfunctional, since, as hundreds of messages from disgruntled customers on Apple's own website testify, it is impossible to establish a reliable internet connection with it. I am seeking my money back.

Strictly speaking, only unopened software can be returned and refunded, but how is one to know the software doesn't work without opening it?

Is that because Apple knew something we didn't?!
Alan Waters
A.Waterts@lancaster.ac.uk

Mouse trap
According to Ashley Norris, this year's CeBIT show included "the first cordless mouse from Logitech". I wonder what one would call this rodent-like thing, devoid of wires and made by Logitech, that I've been using for two years now? Roger Whitehead
rgw@office-futures.com

In search
Veggie Links: http://uk.search.yahoo.com/search/ukie?p= veggie&y=y (March 29) Wow! If I go to a search engine, and enter a term, it might actually provide me with a list of web pages that mention it? What will they think of next? Owen McShane
owen@dub.org.uk

fields.headline: Reanimator
fields.standfirst: Dave Rowntree is drummer with the band Blur. He founded the computer animation company Nanomation
fields.trailText: Dave Rowntree is drummer with the band Blur. He founded the computer animation company Nanomation
fields.body:
What was your earliest experience with computers? My dad was a systems analyst at the BBC way back when the term had just been coined. He took me to a computer exhibition where Commodore had just released its PET computer, which I fell in love with. My school had one in what was laughingly called "the computer room"! None of the teachers knew how to work it so I ended up with the room virtually to myself.

How did you become involved with computer animation? I'd always been interested in visual trickery - 3D holographic and Viewmaster stuff. I came across a program called Povray, written as shareware. It was very basic, there was no user interface and you had to write a text file describing in mathematical terms where things were in the scene, but it blew me away! All you could really do was put a couple of spheres above a mirrored surface -no one had the patience to write anything else!

What kind of technology are you employing at Nanomation? We have Intergraph TDZ-2000 machines for the high-end animation as we use Soft- Image XSI and the programs are fussy about what hardware they run on. The days when you needed amazing Silicon Graphics machines to run animation software are gone now. Whether you love or loath Windows NT, or the Intel system architecture, it has brought that kind of thing into the mainstream. I also use a Dell Inspiron laptop round the world for email etc as it is the only one I can run SoftImage on.

Does the net's infrastructure need an overhaul? The new technology could be in place tomorrow if we were starting from scratch but there's so much money invested in old-style IP and TCP networks. The exciting new thing, call it Internet.2, would be where links were updated and moved depending on where people click. That would give you the kind of content screening that you don't get at the moment.

How do you feel about file-sharing software such as Napster? I'm blisteringly in favour. I challenge record companies to show me evidence of a single penny they've lost due to Napster. However, I think Napster are cowards now for selling out to the major labels. You can't stop people exchanging any digitisable media over the internet because whatever scheme you use to prevent it, people will circumvent it!

Any favourite websites? I have been known to use Tesco.com but my favourite site is Zombo, which is a clunky animation with a voice-over telling you how great it is. I think that paraphrases the net. Promises you the earth but delivers a bit of animation with a scratchy soundtrack!

Visit: www.nanomation.co.uk

fields.headline: Humanoid helpers
fields.standfirst: The latest Japanese robots can hold a conversation and sing Happy Birthday. It is hoped they will be able to look after the country's ageing population, says  Michael Fitzpatrick
fields.trailText: The latest Japanese robots can hold a conversation and sing Happy Birthday. It is hoped they will be able to look after the country's ageing population, says Michael Fitzpatrick
fields.body:
A family of souped-up answering machines, mechanical tomcats and servants wired to do our bidding is competing for a place in our homes.

In Japan, some of these robots are even threatening to rival flesh-and-blood family and pets as the country's rapidly greying society looks to technology for a helping hand and companionship.

At the forefront of robot technology since the 1970s, when manufacturers rushed to automate factory floors, Japan has no problems with machines taking over the living rooms. Technologists brought up on a fare of cute and helpful robots in the media are striking up robo friendships as more practical robots such as Aibo make it into the nation's, and the world's, homes.

Electronic pets are all very well, say the scientists, but we should develop more humanoid robots to help around the house.

Better mobility is just one reason. Even more important, say researchers at America's leading robotics laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, it is easier to interact with and control something human-like.

The robot would also find it easier to learn from us if we interacted with it on a normal level, says Professor Rodney Brooks of MIT's artificial intelligence laboratory.

"An important aspect of being human is interaction with other humans. For a human-level intelligent robot to gain experience in interacting with humans it needs a large number of interactions. If the robot has humanoid form then it will be both easy and natural for humans to interact with it in a human-like way."

Human-shaped androids have also proven in psychological tests in Japan that people are more likely to co-operate with a machine if they were, in a way, acquainted with it. We are more likely to warm to a human shape than other shapes.

Cue the winsome little droid PaPeRo - short for "partner-type personal robot". With a robot that can recognise you, switch on the TV and engage in small talk, its maker, NEC, seems to have made the electronic Jeeves a reality. The doll-like appearance has the cute, friendly demure look that the Japanese favour.

PaPeRo comes with a vocabulary of 3,000 phrases, recognises another 650, will respond when you call him, and can remember up to 10 different faces. Programmed to move around looking for human company, the little robot can also communicate expressively through its "eyes" - which also serve as cameras - and its mouth, which is made up of LEDs.

NEC sees the robot as providing home help for the dramatically increasing number of elderly, in particular. Not yet fully commercialised, PaPeRo should be a common feature in Japanese homes within two years, says NEC.

Meanwhile, if you can't wait for a fully mobile electronic companion, toy maker Tomy has just the thing: a £120 robot toy that can remember what you did last week and chat about it.

This particular robot, however, stays put. Tomy, the company behind Pokémon toys, has produced a mini cyber being with a vocabulary of the average Pokémon fan.

According to the company, Memoni is capable of memorising some 20,000 words, and is therefore theoretically able to form two billion sentences. What's more, it is able to respond to statements such as "I'm going for dinner tomorrow with so-and-so," with retorts such as: "Really, you took her to the same restaurant last time."

And as the robot remembers words from past events, it is also able to continue the conversation with remarks such as, "You were late for your last date with her, weren't you, so watch yourself," and so forth, Tomy said.

Memoni, who weighs in at 600 grams and stands 18 cm tall, "uses artificial intelligence to pick up relevant words within a conversation and can answer accordingly," says a Tomy spokesman. It homes in on two words in the conversation such as "date" and someone's name and makes an informed guess at what might be an appropriate retort. However, for the time being, Memoni can only converse in Japanese.

Initial training of the drone takes one week and it can also be used as a kind of secretary, as it keeps a diary and can remembers users' schedules.

Programmed to remember birthdays and meetings, Memoni is capable of greeting its user with a rendition of Happy Birthday on the appropriate morning and ask how yesterday's meeting went.

About to go on sale this summer in Japan, Memoni joins a growing band of intelligent electronic companions, including its English-speaking stablemate Dog.com -the latest Aibo rival - to be launched in the UK this May by Tomy.

Derided by scientists in the past as idle imagining, androids (or humanoids, to use the preferred robotics term) are now springing to life in labs across the world. From fiction to reality, the circle of the android/ humanoid tale, it seems, is nearing completion.

fields.headline: Psion looks to next generation
fields.standfirst: Two handheld prototypes unveiled at the Cannes Expo prepare for the new era of communication says  Ashley Norris
fields.trailText: Two handheld prototypes unveiled at the Cannes Expo prepare for the new era of communication says Ashley Norris
fields.body:
If there is one company that desperately needs some good PR it is Psion, the British handheld PC maker. In February it suffered the double whammy of poor financial results and the cancellation of a key new product. And March didn't bring much cheer with the news that sales of PDAs (personal digital assistants) are slowing down in the world's largest market - the USA.

While Psion bosses dream of a brighter future, its design staff have been busy conceptualising the products that can turn these into reality.

At the Mobile Expo conference in Cannes recently Psion gave industry executives a preview of what to expect.

The two new Psion models are billed by the company as prototypes, rather than real- world models. They have been designed to illustrate what Psion products will look like in the third generation mobile phone era scheduled to begin in 2002-03.

According to Psion, the one that is more likely to end up as a real-world product is the Ace multi-screen communicator.

Targeted at executives on the move, and about the half the size of a PDA, the Ace flips open to reveal as many as three LCD screens.

The user could make a video conferencing call on one screen while keeping the agenda and a database displayed on the other. Alternatively the screens could be used for a four-way video conference call.

Perhaps its most useful application will be in enabling the next generation Psion user to watch three football matches simultaneously. Other features include Bluetooth compatibility which keeps the unit wirelessly connected to the earpiece and a slot for a Secure Digital (SD) card for storing image and video files.

Psion's second prototype, the Halo, offers the full range of functionality associated with 3G technology; namely a camera, video facilities, a web browser and PDA functions. But due to its size it has no screen; instead an integrated projector beams the information on to any available surface.

In February it suffered the double whammy of poor financial results and the cancellation of a key new product. And March didn't bring much cheer with the news that sales of PDAs (personal digital assistants) are slowing down in the world's largest market - the USA. While Psion bosses dream of a brighter future, its design staff have been busy conceptualising the products that can turn these into reality. At the Mobile Expo conference in Cannes recently Psion gave industry executives a preview of what to expect. The two new Psion models are billed by the company as prototypes, rather than real- world models. They have been designed to illustrate what Psion products will look like in the third generation mobile phone era scheduled to begin in 2002-03. According to Psion, the one that is more likely to end up as a real-world product is the Ace multi-screen communicator. Targeted at executives on the move, and about the half the size of a PDA, the Ace flips open to reveal as many as three LCD screens. The user could make a video conferencing call on one screen while keeping the agenda and a database displayed on the other. Alternatively the screens could be used for a four-way video conference call. fields.headline: Games reviews
fields.trailText: Rugrats in Paris: The Movie | Pokemon Gold and Silver | Black and White
fields.byline: Jack Schofield, Greg Howson and Mike Anderiesz
fields.body:
Rugrats in Paris: The Movie
Sony PlayStation £19.99 THQ **
This is the game of the film, which will be released tomorrow. Apparently the 3D world of RIP is based on the movie, and like the movie, the gamefeatures a new character: Kimi.

Basically what you get is a series of mini-games such as golf, bumper cars and whack-a-ninja, loosely tied into an adventure. The games are fairly straightforward, as you would expect for a title aimed at children aged 5-12. But anything from 10 up is pushing it a bit. I doubt that the average 10 year old finds this kind of thing stimulating. It has neither the depth nor the pace of, say, a Spyro the Dragon game.

The graphics are the best part of RIP on the PlayStation. You get a real 3D world to toddle round, and it is well drawn. You also get real Rugrats voices, though, as usual, the comments quickly become repetitive.

Unfortunately the 3D world that is Reptarland is strangely deserted; Disneyland Paris was never that bad.

So what remains is a bunch of animated Rugrats. If you want to play at being Tommy, Angelica or whoever, this might be fun for while. If not, not. (JS)

Pokémon Gold and Silver
Game Boy £24.99 Nintendo ****
Ignore the appalling TV-show and films and throw out the bags, pencil cases and other merchandise. Pokémon is back where it belongs - on the Game Boy.

Following on from last year's opportunistic Yellow version, which offered only cosmetic changes, Gold and Silver are the true sequels to the multi-million selling Red and Blue games. Rather than casually exploiting its cash cow (in 2000 nearly 70% of its software sales in the UK were Pokémon related) Nintendo has crammed numerous improvements into the two new cartridges.

Some 150 new creatures have been added (bringing the total to 251) but perhaps the biggest innovation is an internal clock that you set at the start of the game. From then on, game time corre sponds to real-time so, if you play at 10pm, it will be night in the game.

Grabbing a quick go over your cornflakes? Yep, it is morning. And, because some Pokémon are nocturnal, you will be burning the midnight oil to collect the full set. There are also certain events that correspond to certain days so, for example, you can only cross a river on a Wednesday. The other big change is the introduction of gender, allowing you to breed new species.

Many of the other improvements are more mundane. The menu system has been spruced up, with information more readily accessible, while the use of in-game cellphones throws up interesting plot elements.

There is even a tip-giving radio station, although the BBC needn't worry yet. Of course the problems that hindered the original are still present. The controls are fiddly, the Pokémon storage system is a hassle, and, despite the graphics basic. But there is enough innovation in Pokémon Gold and Silver to keep the fans happy this Easter. (GH)

Black and White
PC £34.99 Lionhead/EA *****
As far as national treasures go, Peter Molyneux should be right up there with the Queen Mum and quilted toilet paper. Very few Brits can go toe to toe with Nintendo and iD for classic game designs but Molyneux has been pulling them out of hats for a decade now. Black and White is his biggest by far, and while it is not perfect, what deity is?

Alas, 400 words barely scratches the surface of this game. Drawing on his previous hits Populus and Dungeon Keeper, B&W is all about playing god. You start with a small community of villagers and a disembodied hand. With the hand you cast spells, move around a gorgeous 3D world, and encourage or bully your people into loving you more. An early reward for their piety is an avatar - a hybrid beast that evolves into a towering behe moth by following your commands. If you choose to be an angry god, your avatar will be equally sadistic in appearance and habit.

All this makes the first part of the game a slow and somewhat repetitive process. Once you run into other deities, however, things start to hot up, with new villages to win over and rival avatars to fight. Combat is part role playing game and part beat-em-up, with battles turning on one successful combo as frightened villages scamper for cover.

So far, so good - and for biblical sunsets and epic pyrotechnics B&W takes some beating. However, the interface remains too clever for its own good. Drawing patterns on the screen with the mouse is a poor substitute for the familiar point-and-click controls. It is a bit like designing a car and replacing the pedals with buttons, even after hours of play you may find yourself struggling just to move around efficiently.

Still, once you get used to the controls, this is a land mark title in so many ways. Artificial intelligence is a much over-used term in videogames, but B&W takes AI to new extremes. Villagers respond directly and dynamically to your actions, they even get bored if you try to impress them with the same miracles. In one swirl of his mouse, Molyneux has moved the goalposts yet again. Black and White may not be his most instinctive game, but it will still influence many genres for years to come. (MA)

fields.headline: Dora Scarlett
fields.standfirst: Drawn to India by her love of a simple rural existence, she created a clinic which grew to serve hundreds of thousands
fields.trailText: Drawn to India by her love of a simple rural existence, she created a clinic which grew to serve hundreds of thousands.
fields.body:
Dora Scarlett, who has died aged 95, was a writer, broadcaster, communist activist, and above all the founder and driving force of an organisation providing medical care to the poor in India.

But, throughout her life, her real love was gardening and living a simple rural existence. Her last 40 years were spent in India, where she started a rural clinic giving free treatment to poor villagers. From very simple beginnings it grew to encompass three health and development organisations working with hundreds of thousands of poor and marginalised people. Dora was made an MBE in 1994.

The daughter of a schoolteacher, Dora grew up modestly in Liverpool, with strong memories of the strange plants in the Sefton Park glasshouse. She shone at school, but refused the expected move to university, because she was more interested in horticulture. She worked first on a chicken farm in Oxfordshire and later farmed her own smallholding in Devon. There, long before the idea became fashionable in the 1970s, self-sufficiency and simple living appealed to her.

She became involved with the Communist party, and after the war went at the party's instruction to Hungary to work as a broadcaster for Radio Budapest. She was supposed to beam stories of a communist paradise to British audiences, but found herself increasingly disillusioned with communism - and equally taken with the peasant life of eastern Europe. When the Soviet invasion came in 1956, Dora left in a hurry, with the help of the British embassy. Back in London, she left the party and wrote a book about her experiences, Window Onto Hungary. She then spent several less than happy years in London, and in 1959, without telling a soul, she left. Six weeks later she was in Madras, after travelling by cargo ship.

Having found the simple rural life, Dora was soon working in a village clinic outside Madras. She formed a friendship with a local farmer and his wife, and together they went deep into south India, finally settling some way west of the ancient temple city of Madurai, in the foothills of the Western Ghats, which run down the spine of India. Here was a place remote from the modern world, with empty land and little in the way of medical facilities.

Dora sometimes recalled those early days, which must have been the high spot of her life: finding the land, divining water, digging an open well, the first crops on hitherto unused soil. She told of trudging from village to village with a bag of basic medicines, learning how people lived. And she had special memories of the first western volunteers - American Peace Corps members at the time of Vietnam - and how they toiled all day in the heat, digging pits to plant the coconut trees that now ring the place she called Seva Nilayam, or Home of Service.

Everything was to be modest - the buildings of mud and tile in the local style, traditional farming methods and an absence of vehicles. Certainly antibiotics were to be used where needed, but simple homespun medicine would serve where they were not. Seva Nilayam soon had a reputation for caring as well as effective treatment, and for being welcoming to the poorest and least regarded.

Seva Nilayam attracted volunteers from around the world, and funding from Switzerland, Denmark, Australia, the US and Britain. The centre took "in-patients", but not conventionally on rows of beds in wards. Rather, these were patients who needed rest and good food as much as treatment, or who lived too far away to attend daily. The in-patients were part of the community, some staying a few days or weeks, others much longer. They helped out in the farm, garden, kitchen or clinic, in an environment not much different from that of their village.

In the 1970s, a new challenge arose. Western development agencies were moving to more progressive policies - preferring preventative to curative medical work. Dora's philosophy was that westerners had no right to impose their views on what Indian society might or might not need. Undeterred by the loss of funding from agencies, she became her own fundraiser. Sitting on a wooden stool in a mud-walled building, bashing at a 1920s typewriter, she composed a letter that started: "I am writing to you from a remote corner of India . . ." and mailed copies to all the people she could think of.

She believed that if you simply stated your need, people would respond. And they did. Soon Dora was writing a bi-monthly newsletter; not appealing for money but describing the life she saw around her in clinic, village or further afield in India, and adding her insights. Over the years these letters - each one a wonderful read - came to comprise a very individual statement about Dora Scarlett and her life and work in India.

Many compared her beliefs to those of Gandhi - whom she had met in the 1930s when he visited London. She recalled taking early morning walks with him in the East End and being deeply impressed by his presence. But she always insisted her ideas were her own. Dora Scarlett's collected letters and information about her work are available from a UK registered charity that supports Seva Nilayam: Village Service Trust, Shoreditch Town Hall, 380 Old Street, London EC1V 9LT, telephone and fax 020-7739 9630, email: villageservicetrust@lineone.net

As disabilities of sight and hearing grew in old age, Dora stepped back and the Seva Nilayam board appointed a director to manage the organisation. She remained at Seva Nilayam, taking an interest in the clinic and garden, and in turn being cared for. In her later years she returned to the Catholicism of her upbringing.

But Seva Nilayam had always embraced all faiths, indeed it was predominantly Hindu in its customs. So naturally her funeral followed local custom. Hundreds of local people attended the simple burial service in the beautiful garden she had created at Seva Nilayam.

fields.headline: Nicholas Hammond
fields.standfirst: A distinguished classical scholar, he was parachuted into wartime Greece to play a leading role in organising resistance groups
fields.trailText: A distinguished classical scholar, he was parachuted into wartime Greece to play a leading role in organising resistance groups.
fields.body:
Nicholas Hammond, who has died aged 93, was a classical scholar of great distinction and prodigious output. Like that of a number of his classicist and archaeologist contemporaries, his knowledge of Greece, its modern language and topography were put to good service by the Special Operations Executive (SOE) in occupied Greece during the second world war.

He won scholarships to Fettes College and Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge. After an outstanding performance in the classical tripos, he was elected a fellow of Clare College, Cambridge, at the age of 22. Summer vacations in the 1930s were spent in feats of walking that led to the unrivalled knowledge of the topography of northern Greece and southern Albania that was to stand him in such good stead during the war. His first-hand knowledge of Greece and its modern language (he also spoke Albanian) made him an obvious recruit for SOE.

When SOE first tried to send him into Greece in the summer of 1940, in the hope that he would be able to foment resistance in Italian-occupied Albania, he was denied entry by the suspicious Greek authorities. Once Greece had entered the war, their attitude changed, and he was allowed into the country in March 1941. On behalf of SOE, he taught sabotage techniques to Greeks, many of them communists, who were intended to act as the nucleus of post-occupation resistance groups. When the Germans invaded Greece in April 1941, he himself destroyed stockpiles of material of use to the enemy. In 1962 he was appointed professor of Greek at Bristol University, a post which he held until his retirement in 1973. He subsequently held a number of appointments as visiting professor at American and Australian universities. He served both as president of the Society for the Promotion of Hellenic Studies and as chairman of the British School at Athens, and was elected a member of the British Academy in 1968.

As don, as schoolmaster and in retirement, he published at a rapid rate, focusing in particular on the history of ancient Macedonia and Epirus, his research being informed by his intimate knowledge of the topography of these regions. In 1993, he published a further volume on the Allied military mission and the resistance in Western Macedonia.

When the Yugoslav republic of Macedonia emerged as an independent state in 1991, Hammond became a popular figure in Greece when he backed Greek protests that the Macedonians had plundered a name, Macedonia, and a symbol, the 16-pointed Star of Vergina, to which Greece claimed exclusive title. His suggestion, however, that the new state be given the ancient name of Paeonia was never very realistic. He retained his interest in Greek affairs until the very end.

Three weeks before his death, he and three Cambridge colleagues drew attention in a letter to the press to the threat to the site of the battle of Marathon posed by Greek plans for the 2004 Olympics.

He is survived by his wife Margaret and their two sons and two daughters. Another daughter predeceased him.

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: Tisa, Countess von der Schulenburg's life story (obituary March 8) makes most epic film plots look like Noddy tales.
fields.body:
Arnold Hadwin writes: Tisa, Countess von der Schulenburg's life story (obituary March 8) makes most epic film plots look like Noddy tales. As a child, I first met her in the mid-30s in Spennymoor, Co Durham, where she was teaching unemployed miners to carve in wood. She became known there - and later in the Ruhr - as "the Pitman's Countess". While she was staying with us in Bradford (where I edited the Telegraph & Argus), before attending her exhibition at the Bede Gallery, Jarrow, in 1975, we took her to the Cow and Calf rock on Ilkley Moor. There was a covering of snow and it was freezing, but she insisted on us leaving her to paint, asking to be picked up after two hours. When we returned she looked her age, but after a large Campari and a wash, she descended the stairs in the hotel like the strikingly beautiful, dignified, aristocratic countess that she was.

At all times she had a little bag, containing a crust of bread, on a string around her neck. She would never starve. We never washed the window sill bearing the traces of paint from her early morning sketches of the Pennines.

Tisa once told me that an artist had to live with the working class to be anything more than a dilettante. Long ago, I recorded her words: "I remember standing in front of 30 men in caps and muf flers, faces thin and emaciated. I was struck dumb. But I stayed on to teach them how to carve. It was in Spennymoor that the door into England slowly opened. I had found a community I could serve; a cause that inspired me. The men in their poverty were carefree and easy-going. I heard them laugh more than grumble. An indomitable love of freedom, irresistible and sometimes unaccountable gentleness (yes, even shyness) - these were for me the typical qualities I had been looking for, for so long."

In Hamburg after the war, when she was interpreting for displaced female refugees, the occupying forces provided hundreds of pairs of wooden clogs, crude and ugly. She scrounged tins of red, yellow and green paint so that the women could have something colourful on their feet. "That gave them some dignity."

Michael N Clutten writes: For many years I enjoyed the reports from Jerusalem of that outstanding broadcaster Michael Elkins (obituary March 13). His voice and use of the English language were unforgettable, and his ability to paint pictures with his words have never been surpassed. One of his finest pieces of broadcasting was A Jew At Christmas from, I think, 1979. It was poignant, yet unsentimental - BBC radio at its best.

webTitle: How female voters are key to winning next election

fields.headline: A woman's right to choose
fields.standfirst: Female voters are shifting from the Tories to Labour, according to a new survey.  Lucy Ward  on how wooing and winning women is the key to the general election
fields.trailText: Female voters are shifting from the Tories to Labour, according to a new survey.  Lucy Ward  on how wooing and winning women is the key to the general election.
fields.body:
Anyone would think an election was in the offing. Suddenly, the political spotlight is back on women's votes, and poor Worcester Woman is once more being dragged from her people carrier to account for her voting preferences. As the party war rooms gear up for the probable June 7 election, a survey out today finds that women are sceptical that any political party really has their interests at heart.

The poll, which was conducted for Good Housekeeping magazine, found that 29% felt Labour best served women's interests, while just 13% thought the Conservatives put their concerns first and a mere 9% chose the Lib Dems.

Within the Labour and Conservative parties, meanwhile, women are fighting to convince strategists that an appeal to the female vote is vital. Women's ministers Baroness Jay and Tessa Jowell and the employment minister Margaret Hodge are warning Downing Street that it cannot continue to sideline issues such as new rights to flexible working if it hopes to maintain Labour's 1997 record in winning over women.

In Conservative central office, meanwhile, there are suggestions to compel the frequently reactionary local selection boards to include women on their future lists of potential Westminster candidates, as the party finds it has once again failed to select more than a handful of women in winnable seats.

Amid such last-minute scrambling to woo the women's vote, new research to be published next week suggests the pattern of female voting in Britain may be undergoing a sea-change which will require the Conservatives, in particular, to try far harder to win women's support.

An analysis by Rosie Campbell, a researcher at Birkbeck College, of the 1997 British election study - a major survey of more than 3,500 voters examining voting preferences and a wide array of other data - suggests that women's traditional voting patterns are moving from right to left.

Where once women were generally more Conservative than men, except for the youngest age group, women are now staying leftwing longer. In 1979, only women in the under-25 age group were more likely to vote Labour than their male counterparts; by 1992, that trend had extended to the under-35s, and in 1997, women up to 45. "The age at which women are more likely than men to vote Labour is creeping up," says Campbell, who will be presenting her findings at a Political Studies Association conference in Manchester. "What we are seeing is a new trend in women's voting."

The shift could mean that Britain may be starting to follow the example of the US, where women are more leftwing than men in all age groups. The gender voting gap in the recent Bush-Gore US presidential race is estimated at some 20 points, with women strongly favouring the Democrat candidate.

It certainly seems true that young women are more left-leaning than young men - a trend that, according to recent research by the Harvard academic Pippa Norris, is found generally across western post-industrial countries.

The reasons may be various but, Campbell suggests, a link is likely with the changing lives of women, who are now more likely to go to work and return after having children than their grandmothers, and to base their vote on the public as well as the domestic sphere.

The findings undoubtedly make bleak reading for William Hague, whose party is stuck at around 34% in the polls with little expectation of a miraculous reversal on polling day. The image of the loyal legions of sturdy matrons waving their union flags at Tory conference was already looking outdated: the Campbell study appears to confirm that the death knell is sounding for the blue-rinse brigade who for so long formed the backbone of the party.

Tessa Keswick, director of the centre for policy studies and a fierce Tory campaigner for reforms to win more female MPs and voters to the party, readily acknowledges women voters' drift towards Labour. "Women have very different interests from men and face absolutely different essential life choices," she says. "I think the Conservatives have been left behind in addressing those concerns. Even among older women now Labour is winning support - it has done a lot for the pensioners, so even among the older vote there has been a strong move against the Tories."

While Labour developed a strategy to win women in the late 80s and 90s, the Conservatives did not, Keswick points out. This time, there will be real post-election changes to try to secure more female Westminster candidates, she says: "At a senior level, some steps have been taken, but it has not really translated into anything very obvious to the public."

But the Conservatives' battle to bring back women voters will have to be much bigger than a drive to select more candidates. Mary-Ann Stephenson, director of the women's campaign group the Fawcett Society, suggests the shift to the left among women could be linked to fundamental changes in the Labour party. The party's strong union links and "blokeish" image used to put women off, so the loosening of those connections and "women-friendly" changes in the unions have attracted female voters.

"At the same time," Stephenson says, "more women have begun to work outside the home, and they do not see the Conservative party offering a role for women. These voting changes suggest the gender gap is not a given - that women are somehow genetically conservative - but it is related to what is going on in women's lives, and what is going on within the parties."

But while the Campbell research appears to be good news for Labour, Tony Blair should avoid getting too smug. Labour still has to deal with the enemy of all parties - apathy. "There is a shift for women to be more leftwing than men in the younger age ranges, but what the Labour party has to do is mobilise that into votes," Campbell says. "If women are turned off by the [electoral] process, they may sympathise with traditionally Labour issues, but not turn out on polling day."

The Good Housekeeping poll suggests that, while women were more likely than men to vote in the last general election, an enormous 42% of women in the 18-24 age group and a quarter of the 25-34 age group are not planning to vote in the forthcoming election. And, for all that they appear to be left-leaning, women are also the most volatile voters - the survey finds only 17% putting party loyalty first when deciding how to vote, while 56% vote on the basis of policies.

It is also possible that, after four years of new Labour, the optimism reflected in the 1997 survey data and Labour's election landslide could have faded. Fawcett research published in February highlighted a "dissatisfaction gap", with only 31% of women compared with 40% of men saying they were satisfied with the government.

Polling expert Deborah Mattinson, who has conducted focus group research among women voters for the Labour party, is sceptical even of the suggestion that women are staying leftwing longer. "The gender gap has had a lot to do with the parties and how, historically, they have been perceived. In the 70s, the Tories had a very positive image among women which has gradually faded. I don't particularly see evidence that women are changing their views - they remain the most volatile part of the electorate and it could be that when Tony Blair's gloss fades off and the Tories have a new leader who women like, the vote will swing back."

Harriet Harman, former social security secretary and a consistent campaigner for greater Labour moves to woo women voters during this parliament, is urging her party not to let its new attractiveness to women fade. "We need to entrench women's support for Labour, and that means not only policies such as flexible working rights but also women sharing power in the party. That is why there is such a worry that our record number of women MPs could go down."

A shift of views among younger women may be less a rush from the arms of Labour to the Tories but something subtler, according to the feminist writer Beatrix Campbell. "It is not so much that Labour is changing the minds of women voters - neither Labour or the Conservatives dare engage with women on anything that matters, and both will scurry into the arms of the Institute of Directors rather than consult women. It may be that women are more confidently in the progressive portion of society, but that may bear no relationship to the party system - hence this suggestion that so few will vote.

"And if young women don't vote, that is very worrying for new Labour, and very, very worrying for society."

Poll positions

Good Housekeeping surveyed 1,000 women - here's what they said:

How will the floaters vote?

 56% of women said policies were their priority.

 Loyalty to a party scored just 17%

 Two million more women than men voted in the last election

 42% of 18 to 24-year-olds and 25% of 25 to 34-year-old women will not vote at all

 Only 2% of women are swayed by how partners vote

Which party best serves women?

 29% said New Labour

 13% chose Conservative and only 9% went for the Liberal Democrats

What women really want

 Health is top priority for 60%

 Education scores second at 17%

 Environment comes first for 10%

 Just 4% put taxation first

Women's favourites

 More than 25% of women vote Tony Blair the most attractive politician

 William Hague, beaten by Charles Kennedy and Michael Portillo, polled just 4% but he fared better than Mandelson, Brown and Cook

 Blair is the most admired politician (26%) although a quarter of women didn't admire any of those listed

 William Hague and Ann Widdecombe won just 10% each of the most-admired politician vote

Should we bring back Thatcher?

 More than 40% of women would welcome Lady Thatcher back as leader

 But another 37% think she didn't actually do the country any good at all

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.trailText: Anna Nicole Smith | Hugh Grant | Baby Spice Emma Bunton | Vincenza Tomassetti
fields.body:
"It was disgusting. I hated it and it scared me. You were only supposed to be topless on stage, but sometimes the guys watching would offer you money to sit with them. I did it, and I'm not proud of that. But I look back and wonder if there was any choice. I had a son to bring up on my own, I had rent to pay and my car had just been repossessed. I could have sunk lower - the choice was there to make more money by becoming a prostitute. But Howard was my saviour ... He took me out of a bad place and I love him for that. All I know is that he made me laugh for the first time in years. And he showed me respect. No man had ever done that before." Anna Nicole Smith on the elderly tycoon J Howard Marshall, the Mirror

"I totally understand the Bridget attraction. I like a bit of meat with my gravy. I have her down as a hangover conquest. When you have a hangover you sort of fancy everything. Particularly the slightly grubby girl in the office leaning over the photocopier, maybe slightly overweight, with a little bit of coffee spilled down her skirt. I think that's very sexy all that stuff. Maybe I'm a perve." Hugh Grant on the title character of his new film, Bridget Jones's Diary, the Sun

"It really upsets me. It's so scary that people can't be themselves anymore. I never worry. If I'm doing a video I'll go down to the gym a week before filming, and I'll think it's going to change me in a week! It doesn't of course, but I feel better. I hate seeing what this does to young children. I had a packet of crisps the other day and asked my cousin if she wanted one and she said, 'Oh no, I can't eat them.' I was like, 'Oh my god, you're seven years old!'" Baby Spice Emma Bunton about the stick-like women she's been surrounded by in LA, B magazine

"I was already booked in for liposuction on my stomach. I was going to be put to sleep so I thought they might as well make my chest bigger at the same time ... My breasts have never been small, but they were beginning to sag. It got to the point where I hated the way I looked ... There's always the next younger model out there. My husband's successful, he works in Manhattan and he's exposed to a lot of beautiful women. I used to be more trusting but it's harder as you get older. I always have a say in who is hired. I'd never let him take on a young girl. Why put something under somebody's nose? He's not dead." Vincenza Tomassetti, wife of a construction multi-millionaire, the Mirror

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: British hostages set free
fields.body:
British hostages set free

Two British UN workers taken hostage by Somali militiamen were freed yesterday after clan elders reportedly intervened to secure their release. Bill Condie, 61, and Roger Carter, 41, were kidnapped last week. A UN spokeswoman said they were in good health and were being flown to Nairobi in Kenya last night.

Ulster honours Clinton

Former US president Bill Clinton is returning to Belfast on May 24 to receive an honorary degree from Queen's University for his services to peace, it was announced today. Mr Clinton was the first serving US president to visit Northern Ireland.

Honey boosts endurance

A spoonful of honey could work just as well as expensive energy supplements for sportsmen. Research by Richard Kreider of the exercise and sport nutrition laboratory at the University of Memphis has found that honey significantly improves performance and power.

Polynesian club on Welsh shore

A South Pacific war club has been washed up on the beach at the Mumbles, Swansea. Scientists are trying to work out how the artifact travelled 16,000 miles from French Polynesia.

Teacher wins race payout

A Muslim teacher, Memtaz Khan, 32, who quit her job at a school in Slough, after being severely criticised for taking a day off to celebrate Eid, Islam's biggest festival, yesterday won £4,000 in an out-of-court settlement for racial discrimination.

webTitle: Matron's rule returns in NHS quality drive

fields.headline: Matron's rule returns in NHS quality drive
fields.trailText: Matrons are to be brought back by the NHS in an effort to raise the quality of nursing.
fields.body:
Matrons are to be brought back by the NHS in an effort to raise the quality of nursing.

The modern matrons will each have charge of patient care across five or six wards, and will also have power to withhold payment to cleaning or catering contractors providing unsatisfactory service.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, announced that around 500 matrons, earning up to £31,000 a year, will be in post by April next year, rising to 2,000 by 2004. Traditionally, matrons had managerial and clinical responsibility for nursing across a whole hospital. The rank became obsolete 30 years ago when hospitals gave managerial authority to chief nurses and directors of nursing.

Ministers have concluded that matrons were forceful advocates for standards of cleanliness and behaviour. They think the subsequent generation of nursing managers tended to cede clinical responsibility to ward sisters and charge nurses who lacked clout to fight for their patients' interests.

Every hospital will have matrons to run groups of five or six wards, with clear authority to prevent or remedy any shortcomings in patient care.

They will be "strong clinical leaders given the power to make things better for patients and families". Their visibility will be emphasised by distinctive uniforms.

They will be responsible for controlling hospital-acquired infections. They will have "influence over" cleaning and catering budgets averaging £2m per hospital trust, and "power to withhold" payments for below standard service. Other responsibilities include ensuring frail and vulnerable elderly patients are treated with respect - such as calling them Mr or Mrs if they prefer it, rather than their forenames.

A Department of Health spokeswoman said that although the full complement of matrons would not be in post until 2004, each hospital would have at least one within a year.

Mr Milburn said: "Patients want to know who to turn to. They need to know who's in charge. Matrons on the wards will have the authority to put things right for patients."

Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, said: "Patients have been crying out for someone they know to be in charge on hospital wards. The idea of modern matrons recognises that strong nursing leadership leads to better patient care and that, when things do go wrong, there is someone with authority to put them right."

Geraldine Cunningham, co-director of the college's leadership programme, said the scheme built on successful experiments at hospital trusts, including Luton and Dunstable in Bedfordshire, where senior nurses were given real power to remedy defects in hygiene and care.

Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS Confederation, representing hospital managers, said: "It is good to see more involvement of clinicians in management being positively encouraged. The challenge is to ensure that we do not create a cadre of disconnected middle managers rather than front line leaders."

Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, said: "I sometimes wonder if an original thought has ever passed through Alan Milburn's head. We have been calling for the return of real matrons for a considerable time ... What he proposes is completely inadequate."

fields.headline: Patients denied new arthritis drug
fields.trailText: Arthritis sufferers are being denied access to ground-breaking new drugs developed in Britain because they can cost up to £8,000 a year, doctors said yesterday.
fields.body:
Arthritis sufferers are being denied access to ground-breaking new drugs developed in Britain because they can cost up to £8,000 a year, doctors said yesterday.

Consultants said the treatments, delivered by injection, were a step on the way to curing the excruciating pain of rheumatoid arthritis, but were up to 200 times more expensive than traditional pills used to slow the disease.

Around 15,000 new patients a year in England and Wales who fail to respond to these drugs, or who suffer side effects, would benefit, doctors said. The health minister, Lord Hunt, has said clinical evidence for the new drugs was "convincing", but doctors said some health authorities were refusing to fund treatment until they were told to do so by the national institute for clinical excellence (Nice), the NHS advisory body on clinical effectiveness and value for money.

The drugs, which act as blockers to a substance that leads white blood cells to attack people's joints, are among the latest to get caught in the bottleneck between being licensed for use and formal endorsement. Doctors said this meant only a small proportion of potential patients who would benefit were doing so, and that it depended on which health authority they lived in.

Clinical trials have indicated that arthritis can go into remission and reduce with the new drugs.

The treatments were developed by the Kennedy Institute at Charing Cross hospital, London, but are more widely available in the United States, Holland and Germany.

Lord Hunt insisted that Nice had been established to ensure "a more consistent introduction and use of such drugs".

Andrew Banji, chairman of the clinical affairs committee of the British Society for Rheumatology, said: "The present situation is unfair, divisive and possibly in contravention of the European human rights directive."

fields.headline: Auction of Kerouac manuscript 'blasphemy'
fields.standfirst: Sale of On the Road scroll likely to raise $1.5m but causes anger
fields.trailText: Sale of On the Road scroll likely to raise $1.5m but causes anger.
fields.body:
The former wife of Neal Cassady, one of the two central figures in Jack Kerouac's novel On the Road, yesterday denounced as "blasphemy" an auction at which the original manuscript of the story is expected to sell for up to $1.5m.

Carolyn Cassady, who appears as a character in the novel, now lives at Bracknell, Berkshire. She is the most eminent and intimate survivor from the personalities of the early Beat generation. She called the sale a tragedy.

The manuscript was expected to be acquired for display at New York public library, which held it for some years. But its owner, Tony Sampas, who inherited it through the family of Kerouac's third wife, explained the decision to offer it to private collectors by telling the New York Times: "We have a financial imperative. I have an estate to settle and some bills."

Christie's, which is holding the auction in New York on May 22, said the first version of one of the 20th century's most influential literary bestsellers should reach the same price league as a manuscript by Kafka, Joyce or Proust. On the Road still sells 110,000-130,000 copies a year.

For sale is the 120ft long scroll of tracing paper on which Kerouac wrote his account of the "irresponsible wanderlust of the soul" in a three-week burst.

April 22 will be the 50th anniversary of the day he finished writing it in 1951.

He wrote soon afterwards to his closest friend, Neal Cassady, who is called Dean Moriarty in the novel: "Story deals with you and me on the road... marks complete departure from previous American Lit[erature]."

His original title for the novel, heavily revised before it was published in 1957, was Visions of Neal. Carolyn Cassady, 78, said: "He typed a lot of it on my college typewriter in my attic - he liked it because it was my sister's. She was educated in Europe, so it had European punctuation, which he preferred.

"I will always remember how concentrated he was on writing, how rapidly he typed and that I had to furnish him with a lot of coffee."

Cassady died in 1968, Kerouac in 1969. Carolyn, mother of Neal's three children, had a long affair with Kerouac at her husband's suggestion. She divorced Cassady in 1967 after 17 years of marriage, but they remained close. In On the Road she is called Camille.

Now a great-grandmother, she has lived in Britain for 18 years. In 1996 Penguin Books published Off the Road, her memoir of marriage, friendship and child-rearing.

She said of the auction: "It is a blasphemy, a terrible thing. The scroll was always meant to be preserved in a library under temperature control, where the public could see it.

"It should be kept as we do the letters of Browning and Dickens in the British Library. Jack loved public libraries. He went to them all the time himself. If they auction it, anybody rich could buy it and keep it out of sight.

"It's tragic because Kerouac changed the history of literature. The book was responsible for altering the way people wrote and thought about society."

David Sandison, a London author who has written biographies of Kerouac and Ernest Hemingway and is working with Mrs Cassady on the first modern biography of Neal Cassady, said: "It's a great shame if the scroll is going to pass into monied hands and be owned by somebody who just wants another notch on their bedpost."

'All that road going ...'

How the novel ends: "... So in America when the sun goes down and I sit on the old, broken-down river pier watching the long, long skies over New Jersey and sense all that raw land that rolls in one unbelievable huge bulge over to the West Coast, and all that road going, all the people dreaming in the immensity of it ... just before the coming of complete night that blesses the earth, darkens all rivers, cups the peaks and folds the final shore in, and nobody, nobody knows what's going to happen to anybody besides the forlorn rags of growing old, I think of Dean Moriarty ... I think of Dean Moriarty."

fields.headline: In Blackpool's sights
fields.standfirst: Offshore wind farms announced
fields.trailText: Tourists in Blackpool could find, if they squint hard enough out to sea late next year, that they can see several tiny wheels spinning on the horizon. It will not be a mirage or the local tipple, but the first sign that Britain is getting serious about green electricity.
fields.body:
Tourists in Blackpool could find, if they squint hard enough out to sea late next year, that they can see several tiny wheels spinning on the horizon. It will not be a mirage or the local tipple, but the first sign that Britain is getting serious about green electricity.

The site of the first 18 offshore windfarms will be announced today by the crown estate, which owns the seabed on which their foundations will be dug. Each farm will be about 5km (three miles) off the coast - at that distance the structures, despite being 50 metres high, will look just a few millimetres tall. They will appear off areas including Blackpool, Skegness, Redcar, Clacton-on-Sea, the Humber estuary, the Solway Firth and the Thames estuary.

All the farms are expected to be given local planning permission and government consent and few objections are expected from the anti-onshore windpower lobby, which has fought against turbines on land. The prototype for the farms, off Blyth in Northumberland, has won wide approval from the local community.

The farms could generate enough electricity for 1m homes. They will save the equivalent of 4.5m tons a year of greenhouse warming gases and make Britain a world leader in offshore wind power, Friends of the Earth said yesterday.

The £1.6bn investments are expected to come from major energy companies.

webTitle: Harsh regime in call centres exposed

fields.headline: Harsh regime in call centres exposed
fields.trailText: Workers at call centres endure oppressive conditions imposed by supervisors who deny them breaks and monitor their toilet visits, according to a TUC report yesterday.
fields.body:
Workers at call centres endure oppressive conditions imposed by supervisors who deny them breaks and monitor their toilet visits, according to a TUC report yesterday.

Calls to a TUC hotline showed the two main complaints to be stringent rules about spending any time in the loo, and a lack of adequate rest breaks during long shifts.

A breakdown of 733 calls received since February 12 found one in four call handlers was unhappy about the extreme levels of supervision.

Workers frequently had to ask permission to go the lavatory and some had been required to explain why they went so often, the TUC said.

In one case, it was alleged, a manager produced disposable nappies and threatened that whoever made the most visits would be made to wear one.

The report is part of a campaign to improve conditions in the call centre industry, which employs 400,000 in the UK.

Long term damage to health was another prominent complaint; more than one in 10 callers mentioning symptoms ranging from hearing problems to work-related stress.

One worker admitted dreading night shifts because there was no policy for dealing with abusive callers though staff were banned from hanging up. She said: "We have an adult channel, and take late night calls from people wanting to subscribe. There have been a few times when I've taken orders from men and I can tell they are masturbating while on the phone to me."

TUC general secretary John Monks said yesterday: "Although most call centres offer decent terms and conditions, our hotline shows a significant minority offer poor terms and some are operating under sweatshop conditions."

Several centres were named and shamed by a Channel 4 News investigation last night. In one a woman said she had to enter a personal computer code every time she left her desk for water or to go to the toilet.
