fields.headline: Patent sense on drugs
fields.trailText: Sarah Boseley's article (Blair sides with drug giants, March 31) and the related leader missed the point of our approach to improving access to medicines for developing countries.
fields.body:
Sarah Boseley's article (Blair sides with drug giants, March 31) and the related leader missed the point of our approach to improving access to medicines for developing countries.

You are right to say that the pharmaceutical industry competitiveness task force concluded that intellectual property rights are not a barrier to access to medicines. But the fact is that 95% of the medicines on the World Health Organisation's essential drugs list are out of patent and so intellectual property is not an issue.

This does not mean that access to even these medicines is satisfactory. Price remains a critical issue and we are considering how differential pricing might work so developing countries pay considerably less for medicines.

Funding remains a challenge. In February, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and International Development Secretary Clare Short called for further support for a fund to increase availability and affordability of medicines for HIV/Aids, TB and malaria. We are also working with developing countries on trade-related aspects of intellectual property rights. The challenge is to deliver effective international cooperation and to do it quickly. Success will require partnership with other states, international agencies, civil society and with the pharmaceutical industry. The UK is not out of touch with international thinking, we and our international partners are leading it.
Philip Hunt
Minister of health, House of Lords

fields.headline: Heart consultants' learning difficulties
fields.trailText: Your report suggested that decisions of doctors at the Royal Brompton and Harefield hospitals were made, not on medical grounds, but on the basis of unevidenced assumptions about quality of life, potential longevity and future costs of care.
fields.body:
Your report (Down's children 'denied heart ops by biased doctors', April 2) suggested that decisions of doctors at the Royal Brompton and Harefield hospitals were made, not on medical grounds, but on the basis of unevidenced assumptions about quality of life, potential longevity and future costs of care. Last week's white paper Valuing People (a strategy for people with learning disabilities) indicated there are now, in the UK, 75,000 people aged between 40 and 59 and 20,000 aged between 60 and 74 who have serious learning disabilities. Many of these have Down's syndrome. People with Down's now live to an average age of 60 - countering myths about short life expectancy.

Last September, the secretary of state for health made the welcome decision that in future all babies born with Down's would be screened for the heart defects that affect one-third of their number. However, this measure will prove ineffectual if screening cannot be followed up by surgery because of the prejudices of consultants.

The white paper promises that NHS complaints procedures, as they affect people with learning disabilities, will be revised later this year. I suggest that any consultant refusing to operate on a person with Down's syndrome should have to set out their grounds for refusal in writing. There should always be medical grounds, over and above the presence of a learning disability, to substantiate a refusal of surgery.
Dr Gaye Johnston
St Martin's College, Lancaster
g.johnston@ucsm.ac.uk

 The recommendation of the inquiry, that parents of seriously sick children should be given tapes of key consultations with doctors (Parents 'should get tapes of talks with doctors', April 3), strikes a resonance with our approach to cancer patients. Research reveals that, on average, patients retain about 10% of information given during any consultation. As part of the government funded Cancer Services Collaborative, a project aimed at redesigning and streamlining the pathway of care for cancer patients, we have demonstrated that providing patients with tapes of key clinical consultations greatly improves the quality of information giving and provides the patients with some certainty at a difficult time.
Prof David Kerr
University of Birmingham

fields.headline: Lost cause
fields.trailText: Does anything, even DNA proof of guilt, faze the James Hanratty campaign (Hanratty may still be innocent, OK, April 4)?
fields.body:
Does anything, even DNA proof of guilt, faze the James Hanratty campaign (Hanratty may still be innocent, OK, April 4)? As a young reporter on the Observer, I was in court when Hanratty was convicted. Just before sentence was passed, Hanratty was asked if he had anything to say. He stuttered: "Only that I did it. I mean, I didn't do it." Thirty years later, I interviewed John Needham, a former RAF police corporal who was duty NCO at RAF Halton in late 1961 when Hanratty was brought in to attend an identity parade. Mr Needham told me that during a casual chat, Hanratty, who seemed to the corporal to be "openly cocky about it", said to him: "They know I did it. I know I did it, but I don't think they can prove it. It's not up to me to help them."

Paul Foot's tenacity is entirely admirable, but even he should know when to stop flogging a lost cause.
Peter Dunn
Hexham, Northumberland
PandEDunn@aol.com

fields.headline: Trading in human rights
fields.trailText: It is not only Keith Vaz who has been "vague" with regards to the government's handling of the Ilisu Dam project (Vaz caught up in fresh row over conduct, April 4).
fields.body:
It is not only Keith Vaz who has been "vague" with regards to the government's handling of the Ilisu Dam project (Vaz caught up in fresh row over conduct, April 4).

Richard Caborn, the minister responsible for deciding on export credit cover for the dam, told the international development committee last year that "nobody... has come back and raised the human rights questions in terms of this dam and the awarding of ECGD cover". Yet in January he told the committee chair that the Foreign Office "had, in all its dealings with ECGD on this issue, stressed the importance of environmental, social and regional issues, including human rights implications for the local population".

These shambolic attempts to debate human rights and the Ilisu dam - which will affect 78,000 Kurds - betray how seriously ministers take Robin Cook's announcement that "the Labour government will put human rights at the heart of our foreign policy".
Kate Geary
Ilisu Dam Campaign ilisu@gn.apc.org

 This case is a pitiful example of government spin and corporate toadying. DTI minister Richard Caborn told the international development committee that the Foreign Office had raised no human rights concerns. Now, it turns out that Keith Vaz had raised some - though not all - of the issues. Why did Caborn fail to inform the committee? And how can a decision now be made without all the relevant information?

The condemnation of Vaz came about because ministers in the DTI put the interests of big business before human rights. Instead of considering the welfare of those affected by this ill-conceived dam, Caborn and the DTI have shown more interest in backing the construction company Balfour Beatty.

How many more scandals have to be exposed before the government realises it must refuse support for this dam?
Duncan McLaren
Friends of the Earth

 Robin Cook pats himself and the Labour party on the back for Britain's role in delivering an international criminal court and for indirectly securing the arrest of Milosevic (Tyrants beware, April 3).

And yesterday you covered Israeli helicopter gunships hunting down and rocketing an Islamic Jihad commander in the Gaza Strip (Israeli helicopter gunships kill Islamic militant in Gaza, April 3).

Could someone tell me the difference between Milosevic assassinating his political opponents, and Ariel Sharon and Ehud Barak doing the same? One is indicted for war crimes, the others (having committed exactly the same crimes) are not even mentioned by Robin Cook.
Brigid Keenan
London

 You report that a Council of Europe report states that our record on racism against refugees is among the worst in Europe with the race hate rhetoric rivalling that in Austria (UK 'most racist' in Europe on refugees, April 3).

It is not enough to blame the media or the Tory party. The government is responsible for creating a climate of opinion in which extreme hostility to refugees has been encouraged. Despite disavowals, government has talked of "bogus" asylum seekers and has trumpeted refusal figures. The refusal figures have gone up because people who are very vulnerable and do not speak English are refused for failure to return a complicated form within 14 days of arrival in the country.

Now the government has started refusing people it knows cannot be returned. Since last October it has refused everyone from Iraq, including all those Kurdish people in the name of whose safety we periodically bomb that country.
Louise Christian
London info@christianf.co.uk

webTitle: Letters: We're still on track in East Anglia

fields.headline: We're still on track in East Anglia
fields.trailText: You refer to the strategic rail authority having allegedly rescued Anglia Railways with a £1m grant for additional services and previous grants worth £3m. This is incorrect.
fields.body:
You refer to the strategic rail authority having allegedly rescued Anglia Railways with a £1m grant for additional services and previous grants worth £3m. This is incorrect. Those grants, which are from the SRA's passenger partnership scheme, are for innovative new train services with regional, social and community benefit, which we have proactively developed (including the pioneering London Crosslink service). In the aftermath of the Hatfield accident our parent company, GB Railways Group, has separately negotiated with the SRA over the timing of existing agreed grant payments and access to their performance bond.

Anglia Railways has one of the best records in the rail industry, delivering 60% more mainline services, a fleet of new trains, extra local services and high standards of customer service - all ahead of schedule. We have invested (some in partnership) over £50m into rail services in East Anglia, while receiving a grant cut by over 50% between 1997-98 and 2000-01.
Tim Clarke
Managing director, Anglia Railways

 Re your report that "Connex now has zero tolerance policy towards its passengers" (Jobs and Money, March 31): our policy helps to prevent honest customers from subsidising the dishonest minority who attempt to travel without a valid ticket. Last year we prosecuted 5,000 people for fare evasion and last week's initiative enabled us to recover an additional £250,000 worth of revenue.
Rosemary Drummond
Connex

 Your letters (April 4) ignore the appointment (thanks to John Prescott) of a Railtrack "public interest director". This sets a far-reaching precedent for all private firms servicing a public interest. Even the Bullock report on industrial democracy (much more sophisticated than anything offered by the EU) failed to provide for consumer representation. There is a need for more research to pave the way for possible amendments to company law.
Richard Benjamin
London

webTitle: Overhaul for adoption services in Scotland

fields.headline: Overhaul for adoption services in Scotland
fields.trailText: Scottish education minister Jack McConnell has announced a wide-ranging review of adoption services in Scotland in a bid to break down the barriers to adoption.
fields.body:
Scottish education minister Jack McConnell has announced a wide-ranging review of adoption services in Scotland in a bid to break down the barriers to adoption.

The number of approved adoption applications in Scotland has halved over the past 10 years from 900 to 450.

An adoption policy review group, including adoptive parents and young people who have gone through the adoption process, will review adoption law and practice in Scotland, producing its first report within six months.

The first phase will concentrate on services, focusing mainly on children and young people in the care system, with a second phase to be launched later to examine the legal aspects of adoption.

Mr McConnell signalled his intention to close the loopholes governing intercountry adoption by taking up legislation that is going through Westminster. While the Scottish parliament could put forward its own legislation, this could take more than a year to be passed.

"It seems to me absolutely right that we should be part of a UK system of sanctions and controls so that intercountry adoption procedures are consistently structured across the UK. We must stop the trade in children," he said.

The adoption review will focus on:  The place of adoption services in the range of services for children and young people;  The quality of recruitment, selection and assessment for prospective adopters;  The extent and quality of post-adoption support;  The case for Scotland joining the proposed UK national adoption register.

"For too long, the obstacles to adoption have grown and the numbers of children being adopted has fallen. We have to reverse that trend," said Mr McConnell.

"I am determined that more people should be able to consider providing a stable home for some of our young people. Modernising the current system and cutting through red tape can help us achieve that."

Changes in Scottish adoption law were last introduced with the Children (Scotland) Act 1995, when the lifelong interests of the child were placed at the heart of the adoption process. But many agencies feel the time is now right to review the legislation.

Marjorie Morrison, child placement consultant for British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering (BAAF) in Scotland said: "The whole nature of adoption has changed tremendously and the reasons why children are placed for adoption are much more varied. Although there were some changes in 1995, they were fairly minor, and the main act has been the Adoption (Scotland) Act 1978.

"We have got to make sure that in breaking down barriers we don't create risks for children, there are proper safeguards and people are properly prepared for the task. It must be properly resourced, and there should be the right framework to enable proper planning for children in child-centred timeframes. That is where the complexities lie."

Douglas Hamilton, policy officer for Children in Scotland, said it was important that the review looked at the impact of the changes introduced by the Children (Scotland) Act over the past six years in order to take forward a coherent strategy for adoption services.

"The Scottish executive is placing adoption within the context of vulnerable children generally - children in foster care and those looked after by local authorities. This is a very encouraging starting point and a very positive way of taking this forward," he said.

webTitle: A hot night and an icy morning

fields.headline: A hot night and an icy morning
fields.standfirst: Pauline Hope, a social worker since the 1970s, reflects on some of the most memorable events of the trek so far and gets involved in local negotiations
fields.trailText: Our group was the first of the season to arrive at the Waterfall Resort hotel and things were still at the preparation stage. The lucky few had a flushing toilet and a cold tap that worked.
fields.body:
Our group was the first of the season to arrive at the Waterfall Resort hotel and things were still at the preparation stage. The lucky few had a flushing toilet and a cold tap that worked.

In years to come, it will be last night and this morning that I will remember from the trek. During an evening impromtu firework display, the last and loudest caught fire on the dry foliage on the hillside above us and spread quickly. A combined force of guests and staff soon put it out.

In the morning there was ice on the ground and no showers for any of us. However a cheerful breakfast of burgers (eggs and spam) and porridge greeted us. As coffee came readymade with milk and sugar, I just had hot water as my morning beverage.

Today's trek was entirely on a tarmac road through the Yunmang Shan national park. The rock formations, peaks and deep, deep valleys were amazing and we walked under clear blue skies in T-shirt temperatures.

The trek gave me plenty of time for reflection. I have been an individual member of the British Agencies for Fostering and Adoption (BAAF) for many years and have a longstanding love affair with the Far East. I had walked on the Great Wall before, so when BAAF's Great Walk of China flyer arrived through my letterbox it took only a short time to decide to join. All of the money we have raised has come from sponsorship, with BAAF in the UK and Care for Children in China as the beneficiaries.

I have been a social worker since the 1970s and have specialised in adoption and fostering since 1977. I had spent all of my working life in councils until the past three years when I joined Father Hudson's Society, a voluntary agency based in the Midlands.

My work now is mainly with adults, who either want to adopt or who have been adopted. We place children on behalf of authorities and in the past year we have placed 20 children for adoption including family groups of five, four and three children. We also have a small fostering project, so the fostering work of Care for Children is of special interest to me. I am glad its work is spreading beyond its starting base in Shanghai, though to do so it inevitably will have a constant need for funds.

To return to the trek - after four hours our coach collected our tired and blistered group and took us to our hotel in Huarimo, a large and bustling town about an hour's drive from Beijing. The hot baths and showers were particularly welcome after our icy start to the day.

There was time before the evening meal to visit the local shops. Our curiosity value to the local inhabitants once again proved amusing. As two of our members were celebrating birthdays, three of us stopped off at a local cake shop and emerged half an hour later with a birthday cake, decorated with a dragon amid a pattern of clouds and roses. All of the negotiations were conducted with paper and pencil, as language proved a distinct barrier. Photos of the cake artist and his wife were taken for posterity.

Another memorable and exhausting day, rounded off with a warm bed and the prospect of our final day on the Great Wall at Mutianyu.

webTitle: Uefa Cup preview: Barclona v Liverpool

fields.headline: Liverpool look for Owen to bruise brilliant Barca
fields.trailText: Mutual respect ruled among the players but Gerard Houllier was talking tough yesterday and he believes that with both teams capable of winning the competition, a 0-0 draw is out of the question.
fields.body:
As Liverpool emerge into the Nou Camp this evening, the last thing on their supporters' minds will be ping-pong. "But it'll be a bit like a table tennis game," insisted Gérard Houllier yesterday. "Barca like to attack and so do we. I'd be surprised if it ended 0-0."

With good reason. Liverpool have scored 96 goals in all competitions this season; Barcelona, red-faced at their early exit from the Champions League and a hopeless 10 points adrift of Real Madrid in La Liga, have failed to score at the Nou Camp only twice this season.

"We don't fear anybody," said Houllier, who is attempting to emulate the Liverpool side of 1976 that triumphed in Barcelona on their way to Uefa Cup victory. "We are getting stronger as the season progresses. I think my team can compete with any side in Europe."

The home coach Lorenzo Serra Ferrer, likely to be replaced by Valencia's Hector Cuper in the summer, described this as the biggest game of Barca's season in a desperate plea for supporters to attend. The turnout may still reflect Catalan displeasure at their side's stuttering progress.

"Barcelona can be brilliant," he said. "Offensively, not many teams can compete with them. Rivaldo, Overmars, Kluivert, Luis Enrique - that's got to be the best in Europe. But because they attack so much they leave themselves open.

"Rivaldo's a great player because he can repeat and reproduce individual brilliance which changes the face of games. But we've got Michael Owen."

Houllier has been keen to tie the England striker to a new contract, conscious that his current deal expires in 2003. "I think Michael would be making a mistake to leave us," he said, "but I can't criticise players who might want to move abroad because I am a Frenchman who moved to England".

fields.headline: Wimbledon wake up to play-off promise as Wolves left howling
fields.trailText: One down, eight to go for Wimbledon, who according to their manager Terry Burton need to win nine of their last 10 games to make the play-offs.
fields.body:
One down, eight to go for Wimbledon, who according to their manager Terry Burton need to win nine of their last 10 games to make the play-offs.

Stranger things have happened, and given the increasing fallibility of those above them Burton's 79-point target may be unnecessarily high, no doubt deliberately so. With games in hand and seven of their last nine at home, his young team are playing with a force, momentum and style that suggest they may yet be involved in the shake-up.

Wimbledon certainly began like a team with more than pride at stake, and should have been ahead early. A dozy back pass by Joleon Lescott gave David Nielsen, making his first start since signing from FC Copenhagen, the chance to lob the Wolves keeper Michael Oakes from a tight angle. But the effort lacked power and Ludo Pollet cleared off the line.

Wimbledon were looking ominously full of running and invention. At the heart of much of their best work was Kevin Cooper, another recent Burton signing and well known to the Wolves manager Dave Jones, who once signed him for Stockport County. Cutting in from the left the midfielder put one drive just over before arriving late to head a Neil Ardley cross wide

With Ardley repeatedly switching wings the Wolves defence was constantly being pulled out of position. On one instance Pollet and Lescott were left pointing at each other after Jason Euell was allowed to advance unchallenged from the halfway line before shooting wide.

The Londoners' eagerness - they were out for the second half fully five minutes before the home team - was almost rewarded when Cooper's cross found Trond Andersen un marked on the penalty spot, but Oakes's save from the Norwegian's header was of the highest quality.

The inevitable goal arrived soon afterwards, and equally inevitably it was made by Cooper, who threaded a neat short ball into the area for Ardley to advance and beat Oakes off his near post. At last Wolves were stirred: Carl Robinson's volley forced Kelvin Davis to make his first save and George Ndah poked a shot inches wide after a Kenny Cunningham error, though generally Wimbledon remained in control.

"We played as well as we have all season in the first half," said Burton. "The quality of our football has changed this season and we were outstanding tonight." It was a fair comment.

fields.headline: Mjallby leaves Celts one win away from title
fields.trailText: Celtic are now one victory away from securing the championship and the second leg of a domestic treble.
fields.body:
The last time Dundee visited Glasgow to play one half of the Old Firm they left with a 2-0 victory in their back pocket. Last night, however, their opponents were not Rangers but the champions elect, Celtic. It would have been no great injustice had Dundee won, and their performance received post-match compliments from both managers.

A goal scored five minutes from time by a defender pushed forward following a late reshuffle means that a win against St Mirren on Saturday would be enough to wrap up the championship for Celtic.

Johan Mjallby's 85th-minute goal, precipitated partly by a last-man challenge by Barry Smith - which led to a red card for the Dundee defender - proved again the depths of Celtic's will and sense of destiny.

Mjallby's bundled shot had O'Neill thanking his lucky stars a risk had paid off. But with anxiety beginning to replace jubilation in the stadium, the risk of being short-handed at the back was deemed worthwhile. "We have the chance on Saturday and we will put absolutely everything into it," said O'Neill. "I'll do all the worrying for the fans."

As well as netting just minutes before the end, Celtic did so minutes from the start, Tommy Johnson running across Steven Tweed to convert a low cross from Henrik Larsson.

At that point Celtic's speed of thought threatened to tear the visitors to shreds, but Claudio Caniggia - supposedly interesting both sides of the Old Firm - dragged his team-mates into the game with a display of individual skill that steadily became catching.

Celtic's safety-first policy in defence stood in marked contrast with a gambling instinct up front, though Johnson seemed strangely unable to convert his goal into a confident touch, one clear shooting opportunity with the interval looming needlessly snatched at.

A slight knock robbed the game of Caniggia's genius at the interval, yet Dundee replaced him with his much admired fellow countryman Fabian Caballero and actually gained from the loss. Suddenly, it was Celtic's turn to be on the back foot. Despite Didier Agathe's thrilling runs, the balance of play was shifting, one well-constructed move allowing Alberto Garrido to make Robert Douglas look uncomfortable with a long-range shot.

This has been familiar territory for Celtic. But the reason they find themselves at the top is because they can hold their nerve when the initiative drifts from them. This time they were tested more than on most occasions but beaten only once, when Georgi Nemsadze's delicious cross into the heart of the Celtic defence was met by Sara's equally delicate volley to equalise.

fields.headline: Souness slights Blades after Ndlovu blunts Blackburn
fields.trailText: Peter Ndlovu kept United's play-off ambitions alive while Rovers returned to second place.
fields.body:
Peter Ndlovu's late volley salvaged a point for Sheffield United against promotion-chasing Blackburn here last night, a deserved reward for a stirring second-half fightback by Neil Warnock's side that kept their play-off ambitions alive - and prompted the Rovers manager Graeme Souness to dismiss United as "a modern-day Wimbledon".

The striker's equaliser, a fine chest trap and volley following Henning Berg's half-clearance, could not stop Rovers from returning to the automatic promotion places but certainly slowed the momentum the home side had built with Saturday's 5-0 romp over Burnley.

"They are in your face and they are good at it," Souness said. "It's a simple style of football and not my way of playing the game, but it's effective. Wimbledon proved that by doing well in the top division year after year.

"It wasn't a great night for us but we are second at the end of it. The ball is still in our court."

Warnock countered: "I'd also be disappointed if I had Graeme's millions and didn't come away with a result. I don't know about calling us the new Wimbledon - we played some good football out there tonight.

"Still, I suppose I'd be a bit bitter if a club with a wage bill one sixth of my team's ended up getting a result. It would have been a crime if we had been beaten."

Souness had stressed the need to compete first and play later against Warnock's feisty team and Berg gave Rovers the lead inside four minutes. The defender, a title winner with Blackburn six years ago, rose above Shaun Murphy to head Alan Mahon's free-kick past Simon Tracey for his first goal since returning to Ewood Park from Manchester United in September.

But unlike Burnley, United were stung into action by the early goal. Robert Kozluk almost levelled on 25 minutes with a viciously struck effort from 25 yards that Brad Friedel did well to tip over.

With United giving notice of regaining a foothold in the match as the second half got under way, Souness opted to dispense with the attacking skills of Eyal Berkovic in favour of a full-back, Stig Inge Bjornebye. Even so Matt Jansen soon went close when he cut inside the penalty area before seeing his left-foot shot hit the post.

But United continued to press forward with the pacy strike partnership of Carl Asaba and Ndlovu. The marauding Ndlovu had terrible problems with Blackburn's offside trap but eventually broke through to make his point.

fields.headline: Hendrie's late strike helps run the Foxes to ground
fields.trailText: Lee Hendrie's winner left Leicester's chances of qulifying for Europe more remote than ever.
fields.body:
Aston Villa finally ended Leicester City's hold over them with an overdue victory that adds impetus to their finishing-straight sprint for European qualification.

Until last night Villa had failed to win any of the 14 League and Cup encounters with their Midlands neighbours since the Premiership was formed.

And in ending their own unenviable record Villa also extended an equally unacceptable sequence for Leicester, one that is posing a very real threat to their chances of qualifying for the Uefa Cup for the second successive season.

City have now lost nine Premiership away games in a row, a sequence that goes back to November and one that has been interrupted just once, curiously at Villa Park in the FA Cup. City had Callum Davidson sent off in that 2-1 victory and the Scottish international defender went some way towards atoning by putting his side in front in the 27th minute.

It was a goal scored, however, more by luck than judgment. Villa's keeper David James appeared to have Davidson's low effort from distance covered before he was wrong-footed when the ball took a diversion past him via Alpay Ozalan's leg.

Judgment and luck were also involved in Villa's equaliser two minutes later when Dion Dublin headed a cross from Lee Hendrie into Simon Royce's hands.

According to the linesman the ball had crossed the line before the City keeper grounded it in front of the line.

The official had no hesitation in signalling a goal, a decision that was greeted with scepticism by both managers. "You can tell by looking at a video of the incident there is no possible way anyone can be sure that was a goal," City's manager Peter Taylor said.

"To be fair I can't believe he gave it," said Gregory, "and I'm sure Peter Taylor isn't very happy. I certainly wouldn't be."

Despite that considerable portion of good fortune, Villa were good value for their victory over opponents handicapped by the absence of experienced midfielders Robbie Savage and Muzzy Izzet.

As hard as they tried Lee Marshall, Junior Lewis and Stefan Oakes were dominated by Villa's new-look midfield quartet as, once again, Gregory opted for a 4-4-2 formation. That included Hendrie playing on the left of the four for the second game in a row and once again to good effect.

He scored Villa's final goal in the 3-1 win at Manchester City on Saturday and was responsible for an even more important one last night when he fired home the winner 17 minutes from time.

The midfielder served notice in the ninth minute with a fierce cross-shot that evaded the diving Royce but also his left-hand post. He should have done better in the 69th minute, however, when Villa executed a manoeuvre that would have delighted all devo tees of route one football. James kicked long, Dublin headed on only for Hendrie to shoot wide when one on one with Royce.

He redeemed himself when, having taken a short free-kick to Gareth Southgate, he accepted the reply and shot past Royce to settle matters.

fields.headline: Parlour leads Arsenal fightback
fields.standfirst:
Henry 58, Parlour 60 | Ayala 41
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Two goals in two minutes by Thierry Henry and Ray Parlour gave Arsenal hope for the second round after Valencia had scored a vital away goal.
fields.body:
After Arsène Wenger's call for a show of English power, it was fitting that Ray Parlour thunderously handed Arsenal a narrow advantage to take to Spain in 12 days' time. The job of reaching the semi-finals may be far from done but it looks a lot easier than it did at half-time.

Trailing to Roberto Ayala's away goal and with Valencia in control, Arsenal seemed in trouble. How foolish, though, to doubt the Highbury spirit. Twice in two minutes, through Thierry Henry and Parlour, Wenger's side breached a defence that had conceded only six goals in 12 Champions League matches. The tie is excitingly poised.

If Wenger could take pleasure from the fightback and the way his gamble of throwing on Sylvain Wiltord as a third forward at the interval had paid off, he felt regret as well as he prepared to visit the Mestalla stadium, where Valencia are unbeaten in this competition in 16 matches.

On top of the disappointment at his players' apparent lack of belief and determination in the first half was sorrow at the wasted chances, not least Henry's failure to snaffle a third when one on one with Santiago Canizares.

"We scored two goals but I still have regrets because I felt from the bench that a third and fourth goal was possible," the Frenchman said before dismissing suggestions that his team are now favourites to beat last season's runners-up.

"The tie is very open," he said. "Valencia have a huge advantage because they scored an away goal but the positive outcome is that we know exactly what we have to do now: we have to go there and be positive. We know we cannot play for a 0-0 against such a good attacking side. We have to try to score."

In a bright, energetic opening 20 minutes it seemed Arsenal would do just that. Patrick Vieira somehow hit the bar from two yards and Wenger seemed to have sensed a defensive weakness in the 35-year-old right-back Jocelyn Angloma as Arsenal poured down the left flank.

Yet as Valencia settled, they began to grab the upper hand. And the counter-attacking quality of Hector Cuper's team was soon evident. Not long after Juan Sanchez had hit the side-netting from close range, David Seaman and then the post denied John Carew.

When Valencia took the lead just before the interval it was little surprise. Ayala, who later picked up a booking that will rule him out of the return in what looked a case of mistaken identity, volleyed in after Sanchez had headed back a Gaizka Mendieta cross.

"At 1-0 down at half-time the players realised we could lose a game like this without reacting," Wenger said. "We felt we could put them under pressure much more and we had a fantastic reaction."

Not least from Patrick Vieira, who offered such an impressive driving force from midfield that Wenger described his second-half performance as "phenomenal" and Cuper bemoaned his players' failure to subdue the Frenchman.

By introducing Wiltord for Ljungberg, Wenger knew he might over-commit and hand the initiative to Valencia, but the substitution paid off. Immediately the Spanish side were on the back foot and just before the hour Arsenal had an equaliser that was down to a mixture of skill and luck.

Wiltord's cross from the right was miscontrolled by Nwankwo Kanu on the edge of the area but fell to Robert Pires, whose backheel was emphatically finished by Henry for his 21st goal of the season.

Buoyed by that, Parlour added the second shortly after. His hat-trick at Werder Bremen in the Uefa Cup last March showed his penchant for scoring in European quarter-finals, and this effort will take some surpassing. Picking up possession in midfield he drove towards the Valencia area before unleashing an unstoppable shot from 25 yards.

"Parlour's goal was the symbol of the difference between our first- and second-half performance," Wenger said. "We had that determination we didn't show in the first half."

Henry, released by Vieira, should have made the victory even more emphatic but failed to beat Canizares. "He had too much time," Wenger said. After seeing Arsenal withstand late Valencia pressure, he will hope that miss does not prove costly.

Arsenal (4-4-2): Seaman; Dixon, Keown, Adams, Cole; Pires, Parlour, Vieira, Ljungberg (Wiltord, h-t); Kanu (Lauren, 84min), Henry.

Valencia (4-4-2): Canizares; Angloma, Ayala, Pellegrino, Carboni; Mendieta (Vicente, 89), Baraja, Aimar (Angulo, 68), Kily Gonzalez; Carew, Sanchez.

Referee : D Jol (Holland)

On top of the disappointment at his players' apparent lack of belief and determination in the first half was sorrow at the wasted chances, not least Henry's failure to snaffle a third when one on one with Santiago Canizares. "We scored two goals but I still have regrets because I felt from the bench that a third and fourth goal was possible," the Frenchman said before dismissing suggestions that his team are now favourites to beat last season's runners-up. "The tie is very open," he said. "Valencia have a huge advantage because they scored an away goal but the positive outcome is that we know exactly what we have to do now: we have to go there and be positive. We know we cannot play for a 0-0 against such a good attacking side. We have to try to score." In a bright, energetic opening 20 minutes it seemed Arsenal would do just that. Patrick Vieira somehow hit the bar from two yards and Wenger seemed to have sensed a defensive weakness in the 35-year-old right-back Jocelyn Angloma as Arsenal poured down the left flank. Yet as Valencia settled, they began to grab the upper hand. And the counter-attacking quality of Hector Cuper's team was soon evident. Not long after Juan Sanchez had hit the side-netting from close range, David Seaman and then the post denied John Carew. When Valencia took the lead just before the interval it was little surprise. Ayala, who later picked up a booking that will rule him out of the return in what looked a case of mistaken identity, volleyed in after Sanchez had headed back a Gaizka Mendieta cross. "At 1-0 down at half-time the players realised we could lose a game like this without reacting," Wenger said. "We felt we could put them under pressure much more and we had a fantastic reaction." Not least from Patrick Vieira, who offered such an impressive driving force from midfield that Wenger described his second-half performance as "phenomenal" and Cuper bemoaned his players' failure to subdue the Frenchman. By introducing Wiltord for Ljungberg, Wenger knew he might over-commit and hand the initiative to Valencia, but the substitution paid off. Immediately the Spanish side were on the back foot and just before the hour Arsenal had an equaliser that was down to a mixture of skill and luck. Wiltord's cross from the right was miscontrolled by Nwankwo Kanu on the edge of the area but fell to Robert Pires, whose backheel was emphatically finished by Henry for his 21st goal of the season. Buoyed by that, Parlour added the second shortly after. His hat-trick at Werder Bremen in the Uefa Cup last March showed his penchant for scoring in European quarter-finals, and this effort will take some surpassing. Picking up possession in midfield he drove towards the Valencia area before unleashing an unstoppable shot from 25 yards. "Parlour's goal was the symbol of the difference between our first- and second-half performance," Wenger said. "We had that determination we didn't show in the first half." Henry, released by Vieira, should have made the victory even more emphatic but failed to beat Canizares. "He had too much time," Wenger said. After seeing Arsenal withstand late Valencia pressure, he will hope that miss does not prove costly. Arsenal (4-4-2): Seaman; Dixon, Keown, Adams, Cole; Pires, Parlour, Vieira, Ljungberg (Wiltord, h-t); Kanu (Lauren, 84min), Henry. Valencia (4-4-2): Canizares; Angloma, Ayala, Pellegrino, Carboni; Mendieta (Vicente, 89), Baraja, Aimar (Angulo, 68), Kily Gonzalez; Carew, Sanchez. webTitle: Time for English teams to choose substance over style

fields.headline: Time for English teams to choose substance over style
fields.standfirst: Sean Ingle offers Manchester United some advice in the wake of Leeds and Arsenal's European success
fields.trailText: Sean Ingle offers Manchester United some advice in the wake of Leeds and Arsenal's European success.
fields.body:
For the past decade, continental football's virtues have stamped on English football's supposed vices. We drool over outrageous flicks and tricks - and rightly so - but for too long we've underplayed the ugly-but-effective old-fashioned British attributes: of drive and determination; of hassling and harrying; of high-tempo football.

Last night Arsenal and Leeds offered a reappraisal.

Of course, it's going to far too suggest - as several papers did this morning with their England 2 Spain 0 headlines - that English football is now the Daddy of the European game. It isn't. But what last night showed is how English teams - who despite what Richard Keys might tell you won't be matching the platinum-plated skills of La Liga - can still beat the best, by fusing foreign talent with a bit of good old Bully.

Examples abound. Every time Arsenal used the in-swinging corner - Steve Bould anyone? - Santiago Canizares flapped like a penguin in an Artic winter. Then, after Valencia began to dominate, the Gunners chucked on another forward and ratcheted up the tempo. Suddenly Valencia's iron-gated defence looked fragile, and within minutes Arsenal were ahead.

It was the same at Leeds, where Deportivo's prima-donnas strolled into town talking of an easy victory - and left their inflated egos hanging between their legs. The key was that Leeds never allowed their opponents to settle. They pressed from the start, showed Depor no respect and got what they deserved, with two of their goals coming from set pieces - an Ian Harte howitzer and a Rio Ferdinand header - and another from an old-fashioned cross.

Maybe there's a lesson here for Manchester United. As Roy Keane admitted after the Bayern Munich defeat, United's relentless drive - the drive that brought them from back from the brink twice against Juventus in 1999 - was strangely absent. Where were the men piling into the box that brought them a late equaliser in their first leg against Juve and their greatest comeback ever against Bayern in the Nou Camp? Where was the determination that saw them erase a 2-0 deficit against the Bianconeri in the Stadio Delle Alpi? And where - crucially - was the fifth-gear tempo that usually lets them cut through their opponents, no matter how well organised they are?

Of course Liverpool's cautious, almost continental, approach in the Uefa Cup shows that there are other ways for English clubs to win in Europe. But if Manchester United need some pointers about how to tackle Bayern in next week's return they could do worse than take a look at the examples set by Leeds and Arsenal. The English style may not be the most aesthetically pleasing. But it can still bring European success.
